Visited this place for lunch around 3pm on a Saturday. Although the sign showed that their was a 45 min wait for the pizza, ours arrived in 25 min which was nice.

We ordered house salad which was totally average. Only ordered it to get some nutrients. We shared a personal pan pizza (which is the smallest size) given we had a heavy breakfast. Our toppings included onions, garlic, mushrooms and black olives. Overall the pizza was good and very filling. But thought it wasn't the best pizza we had in Chicago.

Overall worth trying if the waiting time is less than 45 min.

pics.caption: Tossed House Salad (ate some of it)
Personal Extra topping personal pan Pizza

review.des: This was my first place I've ever had Chicago style deep dish pizza and it was amazing. I would recommend everyone to come and try this place. It's custom made so you can add whatever you want but just know it does take about atleast 45min for any style of pizza. The service here was great everyone was very friendly. Definitely will be back when I'm in town.

The wait was about an hour on Sunday when we arrived at 6pm for a party of 4.  They give you a pager to page you when your table is ready.  Except they didn't page us and gave our table away by accident. We checked up on them and they gave us the next table.

We started with a house salad which was a complete joke for $5.  It was super tiny and just loaded with croutons.

We got a large pan crust with pepperoni, sausage, jalapeños and garlic.  45 mins later, it was ready. The crust was crispy but still doughy on the inside; really thick crust, truly deep dish.  What was really good was the crust had melted cheese that became crispy. I managed two slices but mostly everyone else only ate one slice.

Our server was not very tentative and we had to flag her down multiple times to get the soda refilled, get utensils, or and cancel the beer she forgot to get us while we were already half way through our meal.

The restaurant is in need of maintenance as their ac couldn't not keep up with the occupancy.  The intake vent was very dusty and some of the ac was dripping. I'm not even sure what their kitchen looks like.

Only thing about this place  is that it's different from the rest of the pizza places in town. I don't think it's worth it. I'm also not a deep dish guy.

I came here during lunch time in the middle of the week and  the restaurant had a decent amount of people inside. Our server was quick to take drink orders and make ask if we had any questions about the menu. I ended up getting the lunch special which is a personal cheese pizza and a drink for 5 bucks. This is an amazing deal for quality pizza. They said it could take 45 minutes for the pizza to cook but it only ended up being like 25-30 minutes. The pizza itself has nice and crispy crust with a good sauce and plenty of cheese. I had heard a lot about Pequod's and I wasn't disappointed. Next time I'm back in town I would definitely come back and try some of their other pizzas.

I called in and order the deep dish for delivery. You're gonna laugh at this. I was here and there and saw that pizza finally came after talking to my roommate on the day that I moved into my new apartment. It was dreaded day and cold just like the people. After I was an a ominous mess I dreaded the fact that I saw a burnt crust and really gooey insides of the pizza. I called back and found out that's how they serve it. Burnt and sticky. I didn't know that deep dish had that. Later found out that it's a technique that they used for caramelized pizza.

Since moving to the Windy City I been looking for the deep dish of all deep dishes. We got here and had giordarnos pizza. It was alright but nothing to write home about. Next we tried Lou Malnati's deep dish pizza. That hit the spot but I felt like it there was something else out there for me to try. After searching high and low, I saw other yelp reviews that Pequod's was the spot to go. After exploring downtown we decided to dabble in this pizza. Boy oh boy I'm so glad we did! The pizza was fire! But the crust stole the show! That crispy burnt cheese was it for me! We ordered the sausage and pepperoni pizza with garlic. Parking sucks around the area and there will be a wait, especially after a Cubs game. I won't dock them a star for that. Too bad I live far as hell to eat this pizza because if I lived close, I would eat this every day! I will be back if I'm in the area!

Personally, the best pizza in Chicago. Not, perhaps a "real" deep dish... but in a pan, with caramelized, delicious crusts, nice layer of cheese (if you're expecting a lot of cheese like on other deep dish pizzas filled half with tomato sauce and half with cheese, you should ask for an extra topping of cheese) and filled with fresh, yummy ingredients.

While searching for deep dish, I've been to the famed Lou Malnati's  and Giordanos but was never wowed. I thought it was just that I don't really like deep dish. It is too big, too soggy, too salty and too tomatoyee. Well, wether Pequod's is real deep dish or its fixed version, this is one pizza I like! It's definitely not NY style thin or Costco pizza (which I like, btw, but I wouldn't say they are better than Pequod's as some reviewer mentioned... at least personally, this here is definitely worth it), and also crusty and filled with yummy ingredients. I like that the tomato sauce is not overpowering. On this last visit, I thought they had skimped out on cheese though. The last several times I've been, the cheese was oozing out while the server was serving up the pizza, but this time, it definitely stayed in place, and I could taste it less. I hope it was just a temporary hiccup rather than a permanent cost saving tactic.

Their $4.95 lunch specials come with a personal size pizza and a drink. Some years ago, it was with a beer but that's changed to a fountain drink. I really like this personal size... Feels like more caramelized deliciousness.

We ordered a large pizza with pepperoni, mushrooms, onions and garlic, and they definitely loaded it up. We also shared the app combo. Glad we did, since we were hungry and the pizza takes 40 minutes to cook. Yes, either order ahead (I'm not sure you can, actually, but I should next time I go), or be ready to wait. The appetizer combo came with 4 pieces of each item so the 4 of us in our party didn't have to fight over anything.

So sorry Lou, sorry Giordano... Pequod's is where I go!

pics.caption: sorry for this blue lighting... but this is the app combo - mushrooms, mozzarella, jalapeño, zucchini
the gooey cheese isn't there this time...
Being served that pizza we waited 40 minutes for!

review.des:
The reviews don't lie. The pizza is fantastic. The crust is crispy, charred in some places, thick and substantial. Toppings are generous and large size - meaning when we ordered green peppers, they were thick slices. When we ordered Italian sausage, it was big flavorful pieces.

Wait time is what it is. Pequod's is simply too popular to keep the crowds away. Call in your order ahead of time and when you arrive and are seated, then the original 40 minute cooking time will be reduced to 20 minutes.

Appetizers are small in my opinion. We had the zucchini slices and it was barely enough for 4 people.

Everyone has a favorite pizza joint. This is mine. And I've come from out of town twice to eat here because it's THAT good. If you're a major cheese lover, Pequod's won't be for you because their specialty is the crust. They don't drown their pizzas in cheese.

Love their deep dish here! Also love their personal sized pizza lunch special. I've tried one other deep dish pizza in Chicago, and I must say I love Pequod's much more.

The pizza will take a little while to bake, but the crunchy crust and crisp cheese edge is worth it! Also not too bready and packed with flavor.

pics.caption: Personal size pizza witg sausage and mushroom

review.des:
Best deep dish pizza in Chicago, on par with Giordano's in my opinion.  The front of the building is small, and upon stepping inside I thought the space was tiny.  But there is a second floor and it telescopes back, plenty of room, but show up earlier than later to have a shorter wait time.

The pan pizza will take ~45 min to cook, so start with some drinks and appetizers.  The garlic bread and marinara sauce was large, but not especially flavorful, get it if you want but also try other things on the menu.  The pizza itself is why everyone comes to Pequod's and it meets the hype.  The crust on the pan pizza is caramelized in a way that Lou's tries, but Pequod's expertly accomplishes.  The crust adds an extra dimension to the pizza that Lou's or Giordano's cannot match.  The crust is thicker at Pequod's than other places, but the topping to crust ratio is appropriate. The ingredients on the pizza are also top notch, the sausage was flavorful and the basil aromatic after cooking.  The waiters do serve the pizza for you, and do so aggressively so I didn't get a photo of the whole pizza.

pics.caption: Large pan pizza, sausage tomato basil
Garlic Bread with marinara, skip and get pizza
Blue moon with an orange slice

review.des:
People have strong, opposing opinions on deep dish and this just didn't do the trick for me. Pequod's intentionally is very crust heavy, which to me loses all the flavor from the sausage and cheese. It was just too much bread.
Other than the pizza - the service was good. We went on a Friday night and only had a 35 min wait and were able to wait in their sister bar.
My personal preference is for Lou Malnati's, so I don't think I'll be choosing to go back here

pics.caption: Half peppers and onions and half garlic/ basil. You can see much of it is bread

review.des:
It's quite a common thing for a business to, in one fashion or another, claim to be the best. Best in the city, best in the world, best in show; the claim has all but lost its meaning- with one exception: the customers.

You can read reviews, take into consideration the opinions of critics, etc. But when you get down what really counts and matters, it's the opinion of the paying customer that matters. And when you hear "best" being used to describe a place over and over by multiple customers, it's best to pay attention.

For weeks before visiting Chicago, we had been told by ex-pats and friends alike, that the place to get the best pan pizza in all of Chicago, was Pequad's.

And you know what? It really is.

Without exaggeration or embellishment, Pequod's is the gold standard of deep dish pizza in all of Chicago (maybe the whole world, for that matter). The crust is thick, crisp, and not doughy or undercooked. The cheese edge is perfectly caramelized, without being burnt. The toppings are thick and  plenty, no matter how many or few you choose. On average, one person can usually eat one, or two slices. So come as a group, or plan on bringing home leftovers (re-heat in a pan or iron skillet, if you do).

Now, there are a couple of downsides, that everyone should be aware of, before going in. For starters, on busy days/nights (especially in game nights), and seating is first come-first served, with a long waiting time (don't worry- it's worth it). So, if you can, request a table at least twenty four hours in advance.

The other thing to keep in mind, is when it's slammed, your order may be a bit heavy on the sauce. So, when ordering, be sure to ask to go easy on the marinara.

Make no mistake about it, Pequad's stands alone. They're incomparable to any other place. They are well worth going out of your way for. I can not recommend them enough. What they serve does not just feed the body, but the soul. But don't take my word for it, try them yourself. You can thank me later.

Went here on a Friday night with a reservation for four people. Had to wait about 15 Mins to get a table. Not bad at all. I'm a White Sox fan so all the Cubs stuff was great to see (haha).

Restaurant has an upstairs that I didn't notice was so big. We requested the table right in front by the entrance but to no avail. Host did what she could (I think!?)

I knew I wanted some of this caramelized crust I kept hearing about. Also knew the pizza would take 45 Mins so we ended up ordering two appetizer combos and some wings (wings suck). The fried platter was LIT. Zucchini and BOOMERS were en fuego. The table ordered some beers and a margarita.

But let's get to the pizza...pepperoni and sausage pan. Both awesome. Crust was the boss. Better than Lou Malnatis and Due/Uno. I love places that have a large following and there aren't a ton of locations.

Parking was easy to find too. Our server was good but VERY upset about a table next to us that told her they felt "pressured". As Kramer says, POISE COUNTS!

If I want deep dish or pan pizza, I'd go back. If I want stuffed in the city I have to find my way to ART OF PIZZA!

We came to Pequod's after I ran the Wisconsin marathon, and it was probably the best decision we could've made. We got a medium pizza with sausage and pepperoni-- the sausage chunks were huge and they loaded the pizza with pepperoni slices. I ate half and my boyfriend ate the other half, and we were stuffed. Everything about this pizza was perfect!

I also loved the atmosphere of this restaurant. It seemed like the perfect college town pizza place. Tons of seating also, we were expecting to have to wait when we first entered but we very quickly got seated on the second floor. Good selection of beer on draft, small selection of wine; we asked about a cocktail menu but they only have the basic liquors and no menu. Not a problem to me, beer goes perfectly with beer!

Super dive bar-y style pizza joint. With both an upstairs and a downstairs, it was much larger than I anticipated, and insanely crowded.

I appreciated that they did an amazing job helping us to party plan. Everything from taking our 20 person reservation to discussing bill breakdown to pre-ordering was above and beyond. Our service was attentive throughout and everything came out quickly and promptly (trust me when I say order ahead, or you'll be hangry waiting 60 minutes for your pizza!).

Personal pizza preference for me is the thinner the crust, the better, and their thin crust did not disappoint! Don't fret if you're not a fan of deep dish because this is a great option. Their pan style pizza crust was also delicious; "burnt" and crispy, which is just my style.

So happy I finally got to experience this Chicago classic! :)

pics.caption: Check out the size of that slice!!

review.des: I love Pequods. It's good. But when it's delivered, the crust gets soggy, and really there's nothing you can do about it. Or can you?? Keep it simple with the deep dish. Sausage & mushroom is my go to for toppings. Also, don't forget to order some onion rings while you wait.

Pequod's!!! WTF have I been doing as a Chicagoan that it took me this long to try you?! I'm not going to lie, I've always been a Lou's loyalist when it comes to Chi Pizza - but y'all are giving them a serious run for their money.

First things first, I get this isn't deep dish in our traditional sense, but it dang sure ain't thin crust. It is its own style 'Pan Pizza' as they call it, with a lot of crust and less cheese to it.

I think I always overlooked Pequod's since it's a bit more humble in it's building (a two story spot in Lincoln Park with another location in Morton Grove) and also not having a million locations like some of the other pizza chains. Let me advise everyone else, don't follow in my footsteps! Do ~not~ sleep on Pequod's!

I tried the Sausage Pizza last night and as mentioned, it has a crispy crust thicker than you're used to while still a bit airy, less cheese, less sauce and a decent amount of sausage on top. It was everything I dreamed it could be - tasty from the first bite to the last. I am a weak sauce and could only shovel one piece down the hatch (and I even struggled with the one piece) but others in my group had 2, even 3 pieces so YMMV.

If you go to their actual location, you'll get the pie piping hot & fresh from the oven! But don't front, you may just want to take it to go to eat in shame alone while Netflixing and there's nothing wrong with that. Just be sure to dig in as soon as you can to get all the warm goodness you deserve.

I saw online they do a 'Chicago Lunch Special' - $4.95 for a 7" pan cheese pizza with a drink, Monday-Friday 11am-3pm for dine in orders. Yep, I'll be back for that.

I'm not quite sure I understand the hype of this place... everyone seems to rave and I didn't think it was that good.

On a Monday evening 3 of us snagged a seat at the bar with no wait. For a table it would have been 30-45 min.

We ordered a medium pepperoni pizza. They told us it would come out in about 45 min so we decided to get some apps in the meantime.

We got the app sampler. It was standard fried food fare. Nothing special about any of the items.

We also got an order of wings. Let me tell you, I am a tough critic on wings. These were really high up there for me! They were fantastic and a redeeming quality for this place. They were not breaded (a must) had been fried until crispy, were not soggy and were still super saucy. The sauce was thick and coated the wings well. My only negative I can say is we only got one drumstick. I guess some other order must have had a ton!

The pepperoni pizza didn't actually take 45 min to come out. While the dough was thick and I liked the crispy edges, I think the general crust was too dry. Almost like I was eating focaccia bread instead of a pizza.  Regarding the rest of the flavors, nothing to write home about. Just pepperoni, which could have been a bit crispier in my opinion, standard sauce that I didn't even notice, and some cheese. Overall given all the hype, the pizza was nothing special.

I would likely not come back here, but at least I can say I tried it once!

pics.caption: The wings were amazing - get the wings!!!

review.des:
My first time here: 2 large pizzas was just perfect for 8 of us (I was a bit stuffed though). We were lucky to be able to grab a reservation since there was a large group of us.

Pizza was good, they didn't skimp on toppings at all. Service was good as well. Ended up being $16pp which is very reasonable since everyone had a drink. Only complaint is that it's pretty crampy (one could say cozy) and loud, and I wasn't a fan of the restrooms.
Great pizza!  Courteous staff.  Very long wait times.  Otherwise 5 stars if you know what I mean ;).

Came here at 4pm on a Sunday and was seated right away. By the time we left around 5:30 however the place was slammed with people waiting outside. We ordered our pizza right as we sat down because we knew it would take a while. The 40min wait time for the pizza to cook was fairly accurate. We ordered the Pequod's salad and that came out right away. Nothing special but enough to split between 2-3 people. Of course we ordered the pan pizza as that's what they're know for! We got sausage, Canadian bacon and peppers on top (pictured). While we enjoyed our pizza I definitely think it's a bit overhyped. I personally prefer Gino's pizza/crust over Pequods.

And a side note while the place is divey (I didn't mind) the bathrooms were pretty dirty and that's never cool.

Real Chicagoans know: this is the best Chicago pie there is. They've been using the same pans for like 100 years, so every pizza tells the story of pizzas past. The way the cheese caramelizes around the edges is just perfection, I don't know how else to describe it.

I took your advice.  I took all of your advice on my first trip to Chicago, and I'm so glad I did.  I only had the time (and the desire, tbh) for one deep dish pizza while in the city, and I went with Pequod's.  And it was absolutely phenomenal.  The personal pizza with pepperoni added is the way to go, do not second guess yourself.  And the staff was so friendly!  I took a Lyft straight from the airport here, and they didn't make me feel silly at all when I rolled my suitcase through the door like the goofy tourist I was.  Best pizza, best pizza joint.

Pequods pizza does deep dish well. They have this 4.95 deal on the weekdays for the regular cheese pizza. You can add toppings at the price of 80cents each. Totally worth it to try it on the weekdays.

I heard that on the weekend the wait can go over 3 hrs. So be prepared to wait.

We got seated right away during lunch and pizza takes around 40 minutes to make. So do get some appetizers and their CHILI. Omg so gooooood.

Deep dish pizza is doughy... and I can't really finish it but I can say I tried it! From LA to Chicago.

Best deep dish in Chicago.
Also the veggie pizza have jalapenos that aren't pickled - can get super hot.

Best Chicago deep dish pizza I've had, I think I see where some of the criticisms come into play, particularly involving the sauce/dough ratio, but there's something just good about having that doughyness. The best part is definitely the charred cheesy crust, its really to die for. If you come at the right time the wait could actually be zero, aka a Thursday afternoon. Overall loved my experience there

I love Pequod's! Some of the best deep dish pizza in the city. I think the crust is perfect. I like the deep dish with mushrooms and spinach. I also have had the pesto pasta and the pequods salad which is so good. It is totally worth the wait! But if you do not want to wait then I would recommend going at an off time. Definitely a great place to take out of town guests or people that really love pizza!!!

The pizza we ordered was good. It tasted fresh. I wish there was more cheese, but it was good nonetheless. I'm an out-of-towner and visited this restaurant based on a recommendation from a friend.

The food was good and so was the service, but I would not go back if in Chicago again. I've had better pizza.

We went in around noon on a Saturday. Surprisingly it was not too busy, and we got seated right away on the upstairs (it was 2 of us). But by the time we were done with our meal, we saw people waiting outside the door.

We ordered small (10 in) size pan pizza, which is their deep dish. There were many topping options- we went with pepperoni, fresh basil, and garlic. It took about 20 mins to get the pizza. I think it was not bad, but it had too much bread (and the bread was too dry for me). The cheese on the outside was definitely unique thing that Giordano's or Lou's don't do- so I thought that was a plus.

Overall, I think it is worth trying it once if you haven't, but I honestly don't see myself coming back for deep dish. Maybe I will give it a try for thin pizza next time if I'm around the neighborhood.

Not big fan. Pizza sauce has a more acidy taste to it. Didn't really like the crust much either. I know that people have about this place but I have had better in Chicago. Then again that's the beauty of Chicago. You get so many different variations of Chicago style pizza that there's definitely a pizza for everyone. I enjoy Chicago's Pizza, Giordano's, Loumanatis. So you know where I'm coming from.

Husband went here while visiting a friend. This was a pretty solid pizza experience. The problem with eating pizza in Chicago is there are too many options that have great reviews. Fortunately, a friend recommended this place and it was a good choice.

He had pan crust pepperoni, sausage, and meatballs.

The restaurant looked like your typical Chicago pizza bar and customer service met expectations.

Just coming back from new york and getting the best pizza there, I had to try out the pizza in chicago. I was expecting about the same or better because pizzas from these two cities are suppose to rival one another.

GARLIC BREAD
The bread wasn't very crispy and was very oily. I didn't taste much garlic and overall there was nothing special about it in flavor or texture. I could've bought a frozen garlic bread and made it better.

JALAPENO POPPERS
The poppers were very disappointing because there was no spice or heat to them at all. They were cheesy, but bland. I definitely will not be eating these again.

PAN PIZZA- sausage, spinach, green pepper, tomato, fresh garlic, bacon, fresh basil, and italian beef
For a pan pizza, the pizza was thick and not even crispy. It was pretty soggy and soft. It would've been forgivable if the flavors were there, but sadly, not even. I did like the flavors of the meat and veggie ingredients, but the texture and flavor of the pizza itself just killed the whole meal.

The pizza here definitely is not on par as the one in new york nor the ones I've tried in other cities. I won't be getting pizza here or anything else.

We waited for 2+ hours to eat Chicago deep dish. TWO HOURS. Yet, we destroyed our half cheese, half mushroom-jalapeño pizza in about 10 minutes. We accomplished this fest not because we were ravenous, but because the pizza really was that great. Compared to the big deep dish names in the city, this local pizza joint boasts flavors that ensnare the senses.

The tomato sauce is more than just sugar and tomatoes, but a blend of Italian herbs that flood the mouth with a full, umami experience. There is a healthy amount of fresh mozzarella cheese layered on the pizza, the kind that pulls away in long beautiful strands with each bite. I loved that each bite was a burst of cheese and sauce, with a fluffy bed of crust to cradle it all from beneath.

There was no grease at all on the bottom of this crust, and the ends are definitely not going to be skipped: additional cheese is toasted to a crisp on the edges and is a special surprise at the end of each slice.

Deep dish looks overwhelming and can certainly be excessive. However, this place managed to strike the perfect balance of flavors and breadth. We left stuffed and happy, not gross, and I couldn't have asked for a better first deep dish experience in this city.

I've lived in Chicago (suburbs) most of my life, and prior to this I lived in Connecticut... I know the pizza game. First and foremost you HAVE to understand deep dish and ny-style are fundamentally different foods. Think of it like comparing vodka to beer... Sure they're both alcohol but everybody has a PREFERENCE.

That said, wherever you sit on the Lou's/Gio's debate, I feel comfortable and confident saying this place is the best in all of Chicago. The carmelized crust brings this pizza to the next level. If you're from out of town and want to do things "the Chicago way" I reccomend getting your pizza with green peppers, mushrooms and sausage. In terms of portion sizes, normal eaters can usually eat 1-1.5 slices of the 12", and big eaters maybe 2-3, absolutely no more.

The place is pretty big (upstairs / downstairs) but I'd reccomend budgeting about 2.5 hours all said-and-done if you come on a Friday night or Saturday night. Wait times can  exceed an hour, then it takes about 45-60 minutes to get your pizza after getting seated. I went once on a Saturday afternoon and we were seated right away. I believe you can also phone in advance to get "priority seating" (not a reservation) which is probably worthwhile if you're going at a peak time.

I reccomend ordering as soon as you sit down. While you wait, you can order drinks (they're pretty inexpensive) or apps. The apps are very average- avoid the bread but the mozz sticks were solid. The service definitely isn't stellar here, but the pizza MORE than makes up for it, as do the very low prices, realative to the big dd chains. You could easily come out with a tab under $50 for 4 people.

This is unequivocally the best dd spot in all of Chicago and I always have (and will continue) to bring all of my nyc / west coast friends here when they visit.

I have spent a lot A LOT of time in Chicago. I took a recommendation from people who live locally and Pequod's is BY FAR the best Chicago deep dish. Anyone who tells you different hasn't branched our or they are a tourist. The pizza came out at a great pace and we started off with beers and some side salads. The service was prompt and attentive. Love it. I'll keep coming here for sure and I highly recommend you check it out. The pizza is very filling. The picture is of a small. For two people we had half left and were very full.

Pro tip: coming in during off hours so you don't have to wait. The wait can be incredibly long during dinner hours!

The service at Pequod's is absolutely pathetic.  The pizza is amazing, and I've gone back half a dozen times despite the service because of the pizza, but our experience last night was the last straw.  There's too many good pizza places in Chicago to warrant sitting through this kind of chaos.

My husband and I went on a Tuesday night at 6 pm and ordered 1 medium, thin crust pizza and a garlic bread.  The sign did say it was 40 minute cook time for pizza, which we were prepared for, and the restaurant wasn't overly busy at the time.  After waiting for an hour, we had NO garlic bread, NO pizza, meanwhile two other tables large tables (one with 3 deep dish, and one with one) were served before us.  We told the waitress we had a 7:10 movie across the street, and she said our pizza was 5 minutes away.  15 minutes later and we still had no food, while others were getting their appetizers and pizza.  We decided to walk out.  It was absolutely abysmal service.  Had it been the first time, we would have given it a pass, but this was at least the 5th or 6th time that Pequod's took insanely long to serve us.  Don't waste your time - there's better pizza places in Chicago.

Still the reigning champ. Came back here and got a small, half cheese / half pepperoni, which was perfect for two people. (Two slices each, which left me full, but not disgusting.)

Absolutely the best deep dish I've ever had, and a staple of my Chicago trips.
I've had 4 different types of pizza in Chicago within my 5 day visit. And let me tell you, this one is the real deal! Such a yummy pizza and the staff was super nice. Highly recommend!

Now on to the Pizza BEST eats spots.  We tried three spots on our trip.

Pequod's takes the pie, hahaha!  Pizza is so so delicious, you never want to stop eating.

Awesome place, with upstairs seating in addition to the main seating, always busy.  Both visits we were able to grab seats at the bar and avoid the wait lines.

Ordered the small pizza on the first visit, plenty for two, and the personal on day 2, a second lunch...we were crazy, but that is how good this place.

Go and judge for yourself!

Pequod's isn't exactly the deep dish one would expect, but it definitely has a following that's greater than any traditional deep-dish spot.
A deep doughy pizza with baked cheese on the outside, making the crust look burnt. However, the crunch really sets it apart from many competitors. Pure Perfection!

GOAT deep dish pizza. I honestly don't even like deep dish but this stuff is amazing. Gooey, caramelized crust, unreal toppings and fantastic red sauce. What more can you say? It's Pequods! A must visit when in Chicago.

In any other city, Pequod's would likely be standout 'pan' (i.e. deep dish) pizza.. But in Chicago, it unfortunately falls to the middle of the pack:

1) Lou Malnati's
2) Pizzeria Uno
3) PEQUOD's
4) Gino's East
5) Giordano's

The toppings were plentiful and the sauce was well balanced - nothing ruins a good slice of deep dish like drowning it in tomato sauce. The caramelized crust is an especially nice touch.

The one major downfall of Pequod's is their crust-to-cheese ratio.. Although the crust is light and airy - and significantly better tasting than most crust-heavy options - each slice is mostly dough with a thin layer of cheese and toppings. Double the cheese, half the crust.. & you have a winning combination.

Pequod's is worth the visit, but be prepared to wait.. Getting a table at peak times can take an hour or more, and ordering a pan will set you back another 45 min. Get there early.. Take your time. Enjoy a slice.. Or simply order ahead for instant gratification.

pics.caption: Love the caramelized crust, but the crust-to-cheese ratio could be more balanced

review.des:
I've had pizza all over the country and have really honed in on Chicago since I live here. I must say that deep dish tends to be hit or miss and very subjective. I have tried both deep dish and "thin" crust from Pequods. Nothing great, nothing terrible. They overload the pepperoni as a topping. Very saucy pizza. Expect to wait an hour plus for the pizza (which is pretty standard.)

If you are not from the area, be prepared to wait a while for a table. Not much room to wait inside. You'll frequently see tons of people waiting outside the front.

Ok I'm sorry, im probably going to get murdered for saying this but....it just isn't that good.
I'm a big fan of chewy doughy pizza and this just isn't it. I don't know if that's how deep dish is supposed to be, but I was expecting something entirely different than what I experienced here.
The pizza is just very "bread-y," as if someone just put some cheese and tomato sauce on top of bread. The bottom of the pizza is hard like biscuit hard, and the crust wasn't too flavorful either.
I was very hyped about this place after hearing so many good reviews but for some reason it just really disappointed me
My favorite pizza in Chicago! Pan pizza with the caramelized cheese on the crust... muah!

I had the thin crust cheese with green peppers and mushrooms. The sauce was good and toppings  were tasty. The crust wasn't bad either it had a foldable texture but wasn't to soft . Overall good pizza just nothing that stood out. I don't eat pork and I feel that a lot of pizza joints in Chicago shine with there tasty sausage. So I am getting a more bland pizza than sausage eaters.

All in all good pizza. The place is dim and a has chill environment. The staff was nice and helpful. I would try the deep dish next time , I haven't tried theirs yet.

Pequod's is one of my husband's favorite places for pizza. Unfortunately, its a little further away from our house so its a special trip every time we go here. The pizza is no doubt really good whether it'd be deep dish or pan pizza. I am not personally a fan of their pasta but I do like their pan pizza. We've been here for dinner with our friends and on birthdays and certainly turned out to be great. I would recommend this place to anyone whether a visitor (we've done this plenty of times) or chicagoan (if they haven't already been here).

I have been here twice now and both times it has been great! Go and put your name in and then go a few doors down to the bar and get a drink while you wait (your buzzer reaches the bar so you won't miss your spot at Pequods!) Really great pricing for a yummy pizza. The crust is almost caramelized and is my favorite part. We got the sampler app and the stuffed jalepenos were delicious

Pequod's is a small pizzeria and has 2 floors. Be ready to order once you're seated since the pizzas are all made to order. With that said, be prepared to wait, the pizzas will take about 45-50 minutes to be made once your order is placed. The staff will tell you this but it's good to know beforehand as well. The pizza itself is worth the wait!

Zucchini Slices
One of the stars of our meal. The Zucchini was well breaded, very crispy on the outside. Molten veggie on the inside. Delicious. Can pair with ranch but great on its own.

Cheesy Garlic Bread
Not very tasty. Didn't seem like it was cooked correctly and the flavors were off. Most likely will never get again.

Pizza
Got a Medium thin crust pizza for 4 ppl. Well sized and we ended taking 1/3 of it to-go. The pepperoni used were super cute small slices but so high quality delicious. Get extra toppings of this if you can! The crust was a fantastic balance of crisp crust and fluffy bread insides.

My experience was.... lacking. We came on a hot summer day, mistake numero uno. The AC was on but not effective at all, so the atmosphere was incredibly humid. Iced waters all around were more than necessary. Drinks took a minute to come due to the busy nature of the establishment. I felt bad, bc it was the old structural integrity of the building that mostly ruined the experience. However, staff themselves were helpful. If anything, would probably order out from here, instead of dining-in.

pics.caption: Pepperoni pizza. Thin crust, normal amount of topping.

review.des:
Pequod's is my hand's down choice for best pizza in Chicago. I have nothing new to say that 2000 other reviewers haven't. This is the type of place that causes traffic jams from all the people trying to dine in and take-out and blocking the lane next to the traffic light.

Pequods is deceptively large, with two expansive floors and hundreds of tables, yet the wait is never less than 30 minutes. It's that good.

Anyone who tells you they didn't love Pequods, ask them if they had it at the restaurant or as take out. The take out is good, but this pizza was MEANT to be eaten fresh out of the oven and it is world's better when eaten as dine-in. The crunchy chewy bite of the burnt cheese crust adds such a depth of flavor to each slice. Save Lou Malnattis, Gino's, Giordannos for the tourists, eat like a local and get Pequods.

Pro-tip: Grab a beer at their sister bar next door while you wait, and check out the fried zucchini flowers appetizer.

I've lived in Chicago for about 4 years now and never been a huge fan of Chicago style deep dish pizza. But my experience at Pequod's makes me now think that I'm just not a fan of Giordano's and Malnati's, not Chicago pizza as a whole, because Pequod's was and is THE PIZZA OF MY LIFE. It's also a huge plus they're open late!

Best deep dish in town. I tried Lou Malnati's last time I was in Chicago and was underwhelmed. This time I tried Giordanos and Pequods. While both were better, I have to give Pequod's the edge for having a better balance of sauce to cheese.

I love my trips to Chicago mostly for the pizza.  A colleague insisted we go to Pequod's as it was supposed to be better than Lou's.  Perhaps "better" is dependent on individual taste.    

I ordered a caesar with anchovies and was not disappointment except for the small portion of dressing.    

We split a small pizza with sausage, bell peppers and mushrooms.   The crust, cheese and sauce were as good as advertised but the sausage and bell peppers were overpowering and left me slightly disappointed.   I enjoyed the sausage by itself, as most of it falls off anyway.  And maybe I'm just not a fresh bell pepper lover.  

If you go to Chicago, it is worth a stop but you might start with something like just cheese and pepperoni.

Honestly this is a place you either love or think is ok... and because its pizza there is no bad.  Ordered for delivery based on the hype and left much to be desired.  Too doughy for our tastes on the deepdish.  But give it a shot you may love it

This off the beaten path deep dish pizza place came highly recommended. I was told to stay away from the chain deep dish and try this one. It is a little place near Lincoln Park. It is known for long waits and great pizza. We arrived early At about 4:30 PM expecting a long wait and we were seated immediately. We got their house special salad and put in our order for a large deep dish with pepperoni, sausage, and onion. The salad was very good and when the pizza came I was amazed. It was not too greasy but it did have a lot of sauce. I thought it was some of the best deep dish I had ever tried and was very glad I did not go to one of the chains. The place does not have a lot of personality but it is all business when it comes to their pizza.  Service was good and prices were very reasonable it was 1875 for large pie and three dollars for each additional item.

This review could be a little biased since I haven't had Chicago pizza up until this point. I moved from Cleveland this week and picked the place with the highest number of reviews above 3 1/2 stars. Let me tell you, this pizza is a different experience.

Sorry in advance for this next comment Chicago, but this is my outside view of what I thought your pizza would be like.... I thought Chicago pizza would be a giant bread bowl with tomato soup. Haha  It's DEFINITELY not! This was a first time pizza experience and it was unlike anything I've had before. The crust is what makes it so good. It looks burnt, but it's not it's caramelized stick to your ribs crust. If you're looking for the ultimate comfort food look no further.

My friend and I came at a really great time. A little bit after they opened when the crowd isn't there yet.

We ordered their famous deep dish pizza. You get to choose the toppings. Each topping is $1.85 so don't go too crazy because that is how you get an expensive pizza.

They have a sign for you telling you that it will take about 40 minutes for your pizza to be ready if you order it.

My friend and I have small stomachs so after a slice we were pretty full.

After hearing a lot of great reviews and recommendations from friends, me and one other person decided that we'd look forward to having some traditional deep dish pizza from Pequods as the pinnacle of our trip to Chicago.

Unfortunately, by the time Saturday rolled around, we both were ill and didn't want to risk leaving the hotel. Instead, we ordered a deep dish pizza for delivery. The Pequod's hostess gave us an estimated time of 2-hours for delivery after taking our order and jotting down our phone number. We expected the wait to be that long so we ordered the pizza at 5pm and just had a small snack until it arrived.

At about 7:45, we were concerned that something may have happened and called Pequod's back. After listening in on some back-and-forth arguing in the background, they had informed us that they made the delivery and called us to come down to get the pizza. We had never received a call so we asked what number was used to call us. The number they read back to me was off by 1 digit. A simple mistake but handled very poorly.

After telling them that they used the wrong number, they tried to tell me that I told them the wrong number. I think I know my own phone number. The more likely scenario would be that the hostess punched the number in wrong and it was a simple typo ( they had a 9 instead of an 8 ).

I said, okay fine, so how long will it take to redeliver it? They said ANOTHER HOUR. Pequods is 15min a way from downtown. We begrudgingly inform them that instead of waiting another hour, we'll drive the 30min round trip to pick it up.

So we began the journey, sick and hardly able to move, to Pequods on a Friday night, downtown at 8pm. The drive took longer than expected. Because there is no parking, I get dropped off at the front and immediately go to the pick up area inside. Upon receiving the pizza, I was told that it was "taken care of". At the time I wasn't sure if they were trying to apologize and pay for the pizza or if they just used my card that I had put down when I ordered it for delivery hours before. We certainly didn't get an apology.

We get back to the hotel around 8:45. By this time, it had almost been 4 hours since we ordered the pizza and it had certainly been sitting out for about 3 hours.

Needless to say, it was cold, hard and not enjoyable. The amount of effort that Pequods made to ensure satisfaction was dismal at best. If they would've apologized, remade the pizza, and would've been more clear on "it's already taken care", I think I would happily give this place another shot when I come back. Due to the poor handling, I gave this 1 star only because I later found out through my bank statement that they did, indeed, charge me for the pizza.

Sweetened semi-solid tomato sauce charred in a pan that they call pizza.  YOU can dupe this @Home.  Peel off cheese in a tasteless and useless deep dish dough is the only FUN thing you will experience.

It's a good thing I know the ingredients of a HAWAIIAN PIZZA as the female server didn't.  "The personal pan is add your own ingredients."  Lame deflection.  Then, she disappeared.

GOUGING... the PREMIUM TOPPING of Italian Beef on a personal pan pizza is one layer, 2-slices of Italian Beef.  You just paid extra for tomato sauce and useless dough!  80% of this order went to trash.

Decent crunchy ITALIAN BEEF.  My first grilled sweet pepper, then sliced.  Less beef than Others.

Ask your own SERVICE is an embarrassment to Chicago dining.  ASK for water.  ASK for a table, host gives you a bar.  You ASK for a table again as it's empty, I still got a bar.  However, a Dude entered and got a table for 1.

NO outlets near tables.  NO Wi-Fi either?  Don't forget it's a dive pretending to be IT.

pics.caption: Pequod’s Tomato Sauce Pizza disguised as Hawaiian 7” Personal Pan Pizza

review.des: The best pizza ever in a relaxed atmosphere...functional wait service...relaxed ambiance

Finally, I've been here a second time. And I don't know what it is, but I'm not head over heels about this place like some people are.

Don't get me wrong, I've got a lot of respect for the caramelized crust, which is a nice little take on deep dish (which, to be honest, can only be modified so much). But I still like Lou Malnati's crust more.

Obviously this place has a better, divey vibe, which I like.

Pequods is probably my least favorite deep dish in all of Chicago and I was raised eating deep dish pizza.

I live out of state now, so every time I visit, I need to satisfy my deep dish craving. Gino's East is usually my go-to, but I wanted to try something new. Pequods was rated so highly on yelp, I figured I had to go.

We came in at just the right time and only had a ten minute wait for a table. Notice the sign upon entering that says the current wait time for pizza. Ours was 45 minutes.

The lunch special seemed like a great deal for a personal pan pizza and soda for $4.95. I added spinach to mine and my boyfriend added spinach and meatball. My dad chose plain cheese.

While we waited, we each ate a side salad. The house made Italian dressing was very oily and lacked seasoning.

The pizzas arrived around the 45 minute mark, so keep that in mind if you're starving.

None of our pizzas were hot and seemed to be sitting out for awhile before they were brought to us. The waitress said the kitchen was probably backed up. Humph. The sauce was unimpressive and I had to add oregano, parmesan, and red pepper flakes to make it more enjoyable. Then there was the cheese, or lacktherof. It was a very thin layer. Excuse me, I like my deep dish to be heavy on the cheese and sauce with crispy, thick crust. Pequods pizza tasted more like a lot of fluffy white bread with a small layer of cheese and sauce. My boyfriend agreed and was disappointed with his "premium" meatball topping.

When we were leaving the restaurant, there were at least 20 people waiting for a table. Maybe we all just had a bad batch, because I can't figure out why this place is so popular.

In the end, $4.95 for a personal pizza and soda is a great value, but don't expect flavor to be included.

pics.caption: Personal pan pizza with spinach and meatball $4.95 lunch special

review.des: I used to come here way back in the day. It's typical Chicago style deep dish and it's delicious. I'm a big Lou Malnatis fan but this comes pretty close.

I love stopping here whenever I'm in Chicago. My first visit was sometime at the end of May in 2017, and I loved it. I don't travel that often, and I thought I would never get to eat here again. But then I found myself in Chicago on September 2, and made a point to stop here.

When I arrived, there were people waiting outside for tables. I realized that things were probably not going to work out for me with regard to getting a table. When I stepped inside there was barely any room to move, because so many people were waiting either to get to the host stand, or to order food to go or to pick up their to go orders.

I got to the host stand and I was told that there was an hour and a half wait. I asked if I could place an order to go, and the host indicated that I could but that was a separate line. I got in that line and when I got to the front the woman with whom I was speaking indicated that there was a place at the bar and that I could sit there if I would like. So I did.

When I sat at the bar, the bartender/waitress indicated that there was an hour and a half wait. I've already been told this by the host I had already accepted it. I placed my order and then sat and waited. About an hour and 15 minutes later my food came to me. It was hot and delicious. Deep dish pizza with pepperoni, green olives, and pineapple. Suck it if you don't like it. I love pineapple on pizza.

When I was about finished eating, a woman who had come in about 30 minutes after I did, and who was also sitting at the bar, said to the bartender "I'm a food blogger, and I was hoping to give you a good rating but having to wait an hour and 15 minutes for a personal size pizza is bullsh*t." The bartender apologized. And then a few minutes later gave the woman an update and told her that her food was coming out soon. As I was already in the process of paying, I wrote on the back of my receipt "I am NOT a food blogger, and I'm sorry that you have to put up with that. So I am giving you a larger tip than I normally would have because of that woman." So I tipped her $9 on a $25 ticket. I showed her my note, and she got a good laugh. She packaged up the rest of my food to go, and I left. The end.

My favorite of the deep dish genre in Chicago. As a newbie to the city, I have always been on a quest to find the perfect deep dish. I have traveled to 4 locations and Pequod's is by far my favorite.

The crust is thick, the sauce is flavorful, and the toppings are fresh. Definitely worth it!

Horrible service!!! Crawling slow... Come here only if you have hours to burn or nothing better to do than watch paint dry...

As per website instructions I called and order my dine in order (at 12:13) which means "we will put your pizza in 15 mins before your arrival"

When I came in the hostess was confused when I informed her my order was "dine-in" like she never seen their website before. Thankfully, a server stepped in, helped her and confirmed my order was received and said she got the kitchen to put it in and that it will take 25mins from when we were seated. We were seated (1:04pm). When we were seated I told our server about our dine-in order he said he saw it and the order was in (I literally saw it on his tablet!!!)

One eternity later... At 2:08pm the manager came to inform us that the kitchen has some how "threw" away our order and forgot it?!? Our server came to tell us that he "did everything right" and it was the kitchen's fault. Way to go for team work! The least you can do is accept responsibility for it instead of blaming your team mates. You could have followed up with them anytime at the 25, 35, 45, 55 min mark when you noticed we did not have any pizza on our tables but you didn't!!! You chose to check in with the kitchen after 1h and 4 mins later? And had the cheeks to say "you did everything right".

I too accept responsibility for trusting that you know how to do your job like an adult and not following up with you sooner.

Only the long wait for a table keeps a fifth star from appearing in this review.  We were in town for a wedding and wanted to sample what Chicago calls pizza.  We were directed fortunately to Pequod's and were not disappointed.  To cut our wait time we ate at the bar.  Our bar tender was very helpful as we discussed our ordering options.  It's a fun environment and the pizza was delicious.

The pizza here is amazing!!

The dough is thick, and nice and crusty on the bottom. The edges are just covered in baked cheese, so every bite has great flavor. The toppings are a bit pricey, $3 each, but they PILE them on, so I would recommend just choosing a few.

The pizza takes a while to cook, which they tell you up front, so just get an appetizer to munch on and relax. Or, come outside of peak lunch/dinner hours. The appetizers are pretty standard fried fare, don't expect much.

The pizza slices are very filling, so a large pizza stuffed four hungry people.

Definitely recommend visiting!

Everyone and their mother has told me to check out Pequod's, and it really is the epitome of deep dish. I've tried many other deep dish places but this one definitely stands out in the ratio of crust to cheese to toppings.

Eating in the actually restaurant, my cousins called for preferred seating which is not a reservation but to be able to be seated quicker. They told us the wait for them to make pizzas is about 40 minutes, but we didn't mind with our large group while we drank. The second pizza we ordered came with the wrong toppings and they were kind enough to make a new one and give us a discount for the wait.

There's not a single bad thing I can say. I'm from NYC, where everyone knows a NY Slice is one of the best things anyone can have. And as the pizza lover that I am, trying Deep Dish or Pan Pizza in Chicago (whatever you'd love to call it), has been on my bucket list my entire life and these guys did not disappoint.

Started off with Mozzarella Sticks to hold off the long wait, and it was one of the best I've had. Not even going to lie. Super crispy, full of cheese, good for a beautiful cheese pull. And then came the pizza. And my goodness was it tasty. We got extra sauce, pepperoni, half pineapple (for my lady) and half sausage (for my half). Every single bite had a tremendous flavor, not excessive in dough and the iconic crispy/burnt crust was soooo good. Its one of the things they are known for! So happy we chose Pequod's! Our waiter was super attentive and checked in throughout. Can't wait to return when we are back in town! Thank you!

Everything was just... okay here. I had definitely done my homework about the wait times at Pequod's and filled out their priority seating form online. I'm not sure that this actually did much. They say that this is not a reservation, but you should get seated in about half the time if you were just to walk in. When we arrived, we were told that we would be seated in about 15-20 min. We ended up waiting about 45 min (after having to go to the hostess time 2 times to check on where we were)

One of my big issues with this place is the service. When our table was finally ready, the hostess pointed to a table in the corner and told us that that would be our table and that it just needed to be cleaned off. The entry way area is very tiny and cramped, so rather than crowd the hostess stand we just went and stood by the table that the hostess said was ours. Another waitress/hostess came over to clean the table off and asked if we were her 6-top. There were only four of us, but we replied that the hostess told us this would be our table. She was very rude and dismissive and said "Well, there's been a change you need to go back to the hostess stand" Keep in mind, we've already been waiting almost an hour and each time to get to the hostess there's a line. We finally get seated after another 5 min trying to get back up to the hostess and it takes almost 10 minutes for our waitress to even come over to our table.

As other reviews have said, the pizza's take quite awhile to make. They are very up front with this fact so it was not a surprise. Previous reviews have said they were able to place an order while they were waiting or call in an order. We were not allowed to do that (I'm not sure if this was a recent change or what)

If the pizza had knocked my socks off I could dismiss the service/time issues... but really it was just ok. I think it was an experience to do this as a tourist, but I would probably not come back.

I got a small (10 inch) meatball, onions, spinach and garlic and I could only finish 3 of 4 slices and I'm a big guy who was pretty hungry.

I didn't really like the burnt crust gimmick they have but the cheese and ingredients were quality and overall it definitely filled my expectations for a Chicago style pizza I had to try as a tourist. Definitely better than Giordano's, but maybe I gotta try Lou Malnati's or whatever it's called and compare it to that.

My bartender Jennifer was pretty attentive and kept the refills coming.

This is my experience after a few trips to Pequod's. There is always a wait...always. You just have to accept that fact and plan accordingly. Have been hear with small groups at 5 a d at 7, and no matter what, you'll have a 45-60 minute wait.

However, the pizza is pretty darn good, the crust with caramelized cheese however, is AMAZING!! I legit could eat 5 lbs of the crust, I'd be sick, but happily so. The toppings are always plentiful and service doesn't take too long, about 40 minutes usually.

Service is okay, considering how busy a d over worked the staff always seems. Prices are decent a d I have heard they have an amazing lunch special that is really a bargain.

Personally, I think this is better than Lou's and the rest of the Chicago staples for pan/deep dish, and if you are patient, will be happy you waited every time.

Pequod's is hands down my favorite deep dish pizza. I would not recommend the thin crust. I love the burnt cheese on the edges. I get extra cheese because I'm a cheese lover and they don't use as much as I'm accustomed to on a deep dish pizza.

Always delicious, I am a frequent customer. I wish I would have know about this place years ago, I wouldn't have wasted time with Lous and Unos.
Top notch grub.

Chicago pizza... the real deal! This place is zero frills but some of the best damn pizza I have ever had! Coming to Pequod's on my last day in Chicago was like the cherry on top of my birthday weekend sundae! Looking forward to making a stop at this place a Chicago trip tradition. The $5 personal pizza lunch special seemed too good to be true... but it wasn't!

Yum, yum, yum. And I don't even like things like the "burnt" caramelized crust. But here, delish! Always hopping. Especially on a nice summer night. Lots of families even though it was later in the evening since the kids don't have school. I got lucky and snagged a bar seat to eat at right away so I didn't have to wait for a table. That's a nice thing they've got going on there. See a seat open at the bar and you can grab it and order your meal there. The bar tender was awesome. He made sure my Arnold Palmer was always filled before I hit bottom and did it perfectly. Super friendly and nice. Speaking of nice, the hostesses are always pleasant as you walk in. Let you know wait time, etc.

The pie was nice and gooey. Eat your pizza there. It's repeatable but absolutely best eaten hot and fresh. I like to get the combo of pepperoni and sausage on this pie. Nice amount of sauce.

These people appreciate your business and always treat their customers well. It's a fun, loud atmosphere with a unique take on deliciousChicago deep dish. I'd much rather come here than some other pizza joints that ignore you and are lackluster in both food and people.

Can't wait for the next time I'm nearby and stop in.

After hearing about the long lines at Pequods, my husband and I decided to go at around 3:00 on a Wednesday. We were seated right away, but there weren't many open tables. The service was quick and friendly, and perfectly attentive. We ordered buffalo wings and a pizza 1/2 sausage and 1/2 meatball. The wings were really good. The pizza was delicious. The crust was crispy with cheese, the sausage, meatballs, and tomato sauce were super flavorful. We liked the sausage a bit more than the meatball. The downfalls: the meat was unevenly placed so there were many bites with just cheese. Also, by the time we got to the second piece, the bottom crust had gotten a bit soft. Regardless I would definitely go back and recommend it to others.

Hands down amazing pizza and worth the wait! There are hour long waits for very good and delicious reasons! If you don't mind sitting at the bar as opposed to waiting 1+ hours for a table, then it's first come first serve!

We were expecting to wait 1.5 hrs, but luckily bar space opened up so we snatched up those seats right away. Sitting at the bar also has its perks, because you can order and receive your drinks right away. We ordered the Fried Mushrooms, Half Order of French Fries, and the Small Pan Pizza with Mushrooms, Sausage, and Spinach!

The Fried Mushrooms were perfectly Fried. The inside wasn't complete mush or still raw. The Half Order of Fries were also seasoned well and not overly salty. The given wait time for the pizzas are 1 hour, which makes sense since something this good takes time. The appetizers helped to satiate the hunger as we waited.

The pizza was phenomenal! The crust was just so perfectly buttery and crispy at all the right places. The crust was not damp and soft from the cheese, sauce, or toppings like how some other deep dish places get. The toppings were very generous! The sausage piece were the size of meatballs!

I've never been a big fan of Chicago deep dish pizza, the first time I had it (at another restaurant) I wasn't impressed so I was hesitant to have it again.  I heard so much and read so much about this place that I decided to give Chicago pizza another try.  This is more unique than other places, they have the cheese on the side that burns, I love that!  The sauce really made the pizza really delicious.  I couldn't stop raving about the sauce!  All the ingredients are fresh and delicious.  Keep in mind, it takes about 40 minutes for the pizza.  The wait wasn't that bad, and the service was great.  I highly recommend if you're in the Chicago area!

Pequod's is a divisive food. I'm from New York and grew up with a pizzaiolo grandfather with Calabrian roots. This pizza would make him spin in his grave.

I work near Pequod's and have eaten it a half dozen times or so, a few times in person, a few times delivered. We order it at work pretty often, because a bunch of people in my office love it. I'm not one of them. Do I really have to acknowledge that this place is popular? It's very popular, and my opinion is the minority opinion. It's not like I don't know this.

One time after moving from Brooklyn to Chicago, I went with my wife to Pequod's and ate in person. We ordered a medium mushroom pizza. I strongly suspect the mushrooms came from a can. I could only describe the mushrooms as having the texture of snot and the taste of dirt. I have never in my life been made to feel so crestfallen by my food.

Look. This is not pizza. This is focaccia. Unfortunately, this isn't even good focaccia: it's mediocre focaccia masquerading as pizza. This is food that lies to your face. It's almost entirely bread, with a rumor of sauce and a whisper of cheese, and everything is mysteriously sweet. Are they actually adding sugar to the sauce? What is even happening here? To continue to insist that this is pizza when it so clearly is not pizza is a form of gaslighting.

And the "caramelized crust"? Please. That's not culinary ingenuity, it's a parlor trick. It's just burnt cheese. Big whoop.

It took me forever to believe my friend's assertion that Pequod's was really THAT DAMN GOOD...but now that I've been here, it really is THAT DAMN GOOD.

There are so many things about Pequod's deep dish pizza that make it superior to any other pizza I've had in Chicago. Their trademark crust made of caramelized mozzarella cheese instead of extra dough. The sweet and tangy tomato sauce that balances out the crust. The fact that they use a ton of mozzarella cheese, but it never gets too stringy at any point. The plentiful amount of toppings they throw into their pizza unlike other places in Chicago (yeah, I'm looking at you Giordano's). The super high quality meat they use in their pizza. Bottom line, if there is such thing as deep dish pizza perfection, Pequod's has achieved it!

If you're trying to wonder how much is the right amount, a large pizza is RIDICULOUSLY huge and should be more than enough for four people. And the wait for the pizza to cook is about 30-40 minutes, about what I expected.

Service was pretty friendly, I have zero complaints on this end.

Sometimes you gotta call it how you see it immedaitely, and I'm calling it right here: Pequod's has the best deep dish pizza in Chicago!

We had heard that Pequod's had the best deep dish in Chicago so we were pumped to go especially since we really enjoyed giordano's and Lou malnati's. When we arrived, we were disappointed to see that the wait time for the pizza to come out was an hour. And that's on top of the 20 minute wait time to get in in the first place. But nevertheless we persisted and ordered mozzarella sticks, hot wings, and house salad to get started. The appetizers were very mediocre - I like frozen mozzarella sticks better and the hot wings were too tangy. We gave it a pass since pizza is the main attraction.

We ordered two pizzas - one large with the toppings of the lou and one small with pepperoni, jalapeño, and garlic. The large pizza disappointed our entire party of 6.  The sauce needed more salt and seasoning, pizza seemed a little waterlogged, and didn't live up to the hype or wait time. The burnt cheese crust at the end was good though. The small pizza was a bit better because the pepperoni added the much needed salt but we left and went to Lou Malnati's after haha. Also there was this drunk weirdo hanging right outside our open window and we were concerned for our safety. We will pass on Pequod's in the future but are glad we got to try the different deep dish pizza places Chicago has to offer.

Pequod's is in my top 5 of Chicago pizza places.
Very tasty pizza. But what I really like is the fact
that they obviously use super high quality meats.
Delicious! And if you don't eat meat still go. Really
good stuff.

This is a must try for Chicago deep dish. The carmelized cheese on the crusts is awesome and different from other spots in the city. I'd recommend getting more than just cheese if you go here, or getting extra cheese if you want a plain pizza, otherwise it can be a bit breadier than some like it.

ALL BREAD. ALL HYPE.

Born and raised Chicagoan: Logan Square/Avondale.

I enjoy pizza and I'm not the type to state that real chicagoans don't eat deep dishes; I love deepdish. contrary to what most people think, most born and raised chicagoans love deepdish too. It's not something you eat on a Tuesday. A quick slice, quick bite, deepdish is none of that. It's a meal. A good meal. It's a midwestern special occasion...Chicago has the best Best pizza in the country. I recall going to the famous Pequod's years back(2 years) and visiting a friends place down clybourn I figured we'd order from them.  I wonder why I haven't gone in awhile? Today's order reminded me why...2 hour wait to get Focaccia bread with thin layer of sauce and pepperoni  placed in the most messy fashion... do your self a favor, and I swear I'm not the only Chicagoan to agree, go to Lou Malnati's...

Please don't believe people that state chicagoans don't eat deepdish. We do, but this place ain't it.

The wings were pretty good though.

My Chicago friend recommended this place. Upon entering, we saw the sign that said it will take 40 mins to make the pizza and we were already starving.

We ordered the chicken fingers which was regular and came with bbq sauce in a to go container. The chicken fingers were crispy just the way I like it.

I thought the deep dish was ok. Don't get me wrong, it was delicious but nothing spectacular. I felt like I had something similar. It had the right amount of meat vs cheese and dough, wasn't overwhelming!

A small deep pan for 2 is more than enough for us.

They had the lunch special, a personal cheese deep  pan and drink for $4.95 I believe, such a great deal if you don't mind just a cheese pizza.

Super busy location after being seen on the travel channels food show.

We ordered the pepperoni and sausage deep dish.

It's a traditional tavern, bar & grill type establishment.  It was seen on Food Network or the Travel network and so it was extremely busy when we walked in the only tables are available for two chairs at the bar. Which I prefer.

We received our food within 20 minutes and the bartenders were extremely nice.

The restaurant was clean and I can highly recommend this restaurant.

This was a fantastic deep dish pizza. It's the best I've ever had. I don't think there's much that can be improved upon. Do not go anywhere else. Do not mess with your one chance at an excellent Chicago style deep dish. Come with an empty stomach, with your sleeves rolled up and you won't be disappointed.

Definitely get the caramelized deep dish. There is no other way to go. A small feeds two people. Medium can work for two very hungry people. The pizzas are dense and they do not skimp out on the toppings. I don't think I have ever had better Italian sausage than what they serve.

I won't even ding them for this but the pizza came out a bit luke warm. It wasn't pipping hot, burn your tongue and the roof of you mouth. So that's good. But then again the pizza cooled off rapidly. I am not really sure what I am getting at by saying bus because I both appreciate how it wasn't too hot but then again it became a bit unappealing when it cooled off. Maybe I'm hard to please.

The service was great. Just attentive enough to not be annoying and get what we needed. The place is your standard brick walled pizza shop. Our wait on a Friday was about 30 min at peak dinner hours. Not bad!

I highly recommend this place. This is just about as perfect as it gets.

Coming to Chicago I had to try some deep dish pizza and after extensive research, I settled on Pequod's. Everyone was raving about their "caramelized" aka burnt-looking but not really burnt crust.

What I wasn't looking forward to was the hour plus long wait that everybody mentioned. Fortunately, it only took our pizzas about 30 minutes to come out. This was likely because we ordered personal-sized pizzas.

The pizza was delicious as was the crust. The personal size ended up being more than enough. It looks deceptively small until you remember that it's deep dish, so I actually had some leftover.

We got some apps beforehand because we expected the pizza to take longer to come out (cheesy garlic bread and fries), and I'd recommend the cheesy garlic bread.

We waited over an hour in line. Then, we ordered a med pizza once sat. We watched everyone around us, who was sat after us, eat their pizza. So, we asked the waitress if there was a problem. She let her manager handle it so she could continue taking other orders. My date was upset. Manager tried to console us by offering a free pizza but my date wasn't having any of it. Now, Im back in Los Angeles and still bummed I traveled all the way to Chicago with no pizza to tell about. :(

We were sat next to the waiter server station. A member of the wait staff passed us by at least 60 times. :( :( :(
This ranks in my top 3 list for thin crust Pizza.  Great crust, sauce, sausage, pepperoni, mushroom & onion absolutely fantastic!

Thin crust pizza taste like the dough was frozen. The classic pizza was much better. But it has a lot of dough. Service was not that great. Had to ask for every thing and people were asking the bar for plates and other items.

pics.caption: Thin crust with mushroom and pepperoni

review.des:
Came to Chicago for a friends New Year's Eve wedding so we didn't have much time in the city. My boyfriend suggested we hit up this place, Pequod's.

Super cold 2 degree afternoon, snagged a table by the door( that sucked) but the service and people were great. We immediately ordered a medium pepperoni and mushroom deep dish and buffalo wings. The wings came out lightning quick and we devoured every last one. That sauce was amazing!

As we waited 45 min, my impression of this place fell a bit. Since we were by the table by the door, the 5pm traffic flow came thru and people were crowding around us at all sides. My chair was getting smacked by people walking behind me, getting their coats snagged on my chair. By the time our food arrived people were hovering over our deep dish pan, faux fur from people's coat hoods literally above the pan. My boyfriend had his back to the main entrance(which was worse than my seat) and people were literally talking loudly in his ear and hovering over our table while we attempted to eat dinner. We asked to switch to a booth and the waitress was unable to make the switch happen.

Not a huge fan of deep dish to begin with but if I were in town again there's a chance I would swing by.

A pizza poem!

You can eat here but you do u know em?

Located in Lincoln and pick ur toppings,

With garlic, peppers, sausage--there's no stopping!

The classics are the best here I can't deny,

The top deep dish in Chicago I won't lie!

There's room at the bar to dig in your teeth,

A pro tip to remember when there's not a seat.

The first time you go skip the apps and not the pizza,

Always order extra sauce and extra cheese--duh!

So if u live here or aren't local give it a try,

Guarantee you'll enjoy this pizza pie!

I live this place. Be prepared to wait unless you go at an off time. There are a few bars I'm nearby, so you can stop in for a drink waiting for your table. Nothing else to comment about besides the deep dish. All of the other food is average, exactly what you would expect, (salads, apps, etc). The pizza is off the charts, my favorite deep dish in the city. Carmel crust is the nail in the coffin. So delicious, I typically get the sausage since it's not your typical store bought Italian sausage. It's fresh crumbles that make for an unbelievable pizza. Go here if you want the best Chicago deep dish experience in the city

When I tell you this place is that place? It's THAT place. Had this a while back, but just now getting to the review.

Piquods is a weird little restaurant (maybe bar??) that we found out in Chicago. It's mainly famous for having a whale with panties on it's head or something like that...  while the inside joke of that or why it's a whale goes completeeeeely over my head, let me tell you, it's the best Chicago pizza I've had thus far! That crust is to LIVE for and it's sooooo thick. The cheese was just dripping off fresh out the oven and I enjoyed every last bite!

If you're ever in Chicago, please check out this place because I know whenever I go back, I'm gonna get this again along with a few other spots I didn't get a chance to go to.

Trust and believe you won't be disappointed.

I don't often give 1 star reviews, but when I do, it's for terrible pizza. We ordered 2 pan pizzas, and both were bland.  

There were 7 of us in our party, and all 7 said "Meh."  Go to Lou Malnodi's or Aurello's or Giordanos or literally anywhere else. The pizzas at Costco are better.

The staff was very nice. The upstairs was 20 degrees hotter than the rest of the restaurant.  But the fact that their famous pizza was bland and...bad...just made me weep.

Queequeg and Ishmael deserve better than this!

HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE "PIZZA"

I am a native Chicagoan and was raised on extraordinarily great pizzas, and over the last three years, I have sadly watched all the best Chicago pizzas, except for one, slide down into the pizza abyss, where lousy pizza goes to die. Pequod's is not the lone survivor, that place starts with a "G." Pequod's is just another hack "pizza." I'll explain in greater detail for those of you wondering how this could be. Last Friday, late, my wife and I had a craving for pizza. Since our old favorites, which I won't indict here now, have become terrible, I decided to order my first Pequod's "pizza." I was so excited after all the buzz I had heard over the years. I even told the order taker how excited I was to order from them for the first time. Well, after the bready thing arrived, and we inspected it, I realized I had been taken for a ride. The "pizza" was not pizza at all, but rather three quarters of an inch of extremely sugary bread, topped with an imperceptibly thin film of cheese. The toppings we ordered, garlic and spinach, were nonexistent. I did spot what looked like a tiny spinach leaf, but I cannot be sure it was indeed spinach. Neither my wife nor I were able to taste any garlic, and we are both lovers of garlic. Atop the barely noticeable cheese and nonexistent toppings was a fine layer of what tasted like sugar-laden canned spaghetti sauce. I cannot believe anyone would eat this stuff, it's awful. I paid 20 bucks for a half a loaf of lousy bread and a slice of cheese with some smeared on spaghetti sauce. If this alleged "pizza" was good at one time, that's in the past, and I can assure you, it is not worth trying. We also ordered salads and soup, which was fair at best, and certainly the highlight of the order. I will never order from Pequod's again, once was more than enough. I wish I could give a negative rating, or a zero, because that would be an accurate score, so I will do it here: minus 3 rating for Pequod's. Absolutely terrible. Perhaps they will read my review and hastily make the appropriate upgrades to their bready thing that they mistakenly call a "pizza."

pics.caption: Pequod's Three Quarters of an Inch of Bread with Barely Any Cheese, Toppings or Sauce; Not Real "Pizza."

review.des: I've been here several times and have been disappointed every time. Yesterday was the last time I'll get pizza from here. The pizza was so much bread--about an inch of bread--it was ridiculous. It was an over-cooked loaf of bread essentially, very disappointing pizza for the wait time. For the price of the pizza you're better off trying to make a pizza yourself.

A must visit if you are in Chicago, most if not all locals suggested this was their favourite deep dish pizza in Chicago. Personally I preferred Lou Malnati's but the rest of the party said Pequods was their favourite by far. Great atmosphere, excellent drinks and they tell you the wait time for deep dish pizza as you walk in.

We were told a 90 minute wait and we discussed and were happy to wait.  After 2 hrs and 15 min, we were treated poorly, ignored and we left. No pizza is worth that with two small children. Art of Pizza is your answer, good pizza is the question.
We left and had wonderful pizza with people not over promising and under delivering.  A huge amount of time we will never get back.  Angry and never going back.

This review has been a long time comin! As a Chicagoan let me break down the significance of Pequod's to you. Gene and Jude's is to the native Chicago hot dog as Pequod's is to native Chicago pizza. Both of these places are highly over looked by tourists but deeply loved by us natives. If you're newly introduced to either, well, better late than never- just get wit da program!

Until my most recent visit I strictly ordered the deep dish (i never say pan. sorry not sorry.) because that's what they're known for! This will probably be the crispiest deep dish crust you'll ever have and instead of a nice handled crust to hold onto it's sloppy & a little burnt. Perfectly imperfect achieving even more crunch when you've reached the top! Thin crust is equally good but that shouldn't surprise you because even the littlest mom & pop pizza place cranks out the best thin crust. Chicago pizza is unbeatable. Chicken tenders and no cheese garlic bread are a must for appetizers. Just don't forget to leave room for the pie. (Pizza pie, duh. not dessert. lol)

Dinning during prime time weekends you're looking at an hour+ wait and impossible parking. Can vouch that this is a great place for large groups.
