They accommodated our group of 20 allowing us to make resos and place our order in advance. 7 Pizzas and 1 Italian Beef. Only one pizza order was incorrect and for the most part, service was good. They will not seat your party unless everyone is in attendance. Thankfully, that was no problem for this group of Elites!

Special Shout Out: To our honorary guests-Yelp Team Leaders wishing them a farewell, to Christopher V for suggesting Pequods, to Ahmad A for all he did for us that night (We still owe you, Friend), to everyone who was in attendance & on time (blown away by your punctuality!!), & to Selena C + Liang H for planning!

You will just have to trust me when I say..don't be scared of the 60-90 min wait time to sit down and the additional 45 min to have your pizza cooked.

IT IS ALL WORTH IT! I promise.

That is why I have constantly endeavored the gruesome act of my stomach battling me inside. So if you do decide to come on a weekend night for dinner, don't come hungry. Come when you think "yeah I'll be hungry in about an hour or two." There is also a bar connected to the restaurant called Whale Tale, where you can wait to grab an app and drink.
Now, be prepared for the best deep dish in the city. No BS, it'll end any Jordan/Lebron argument.
15/10

Came here after reading all the hype on yelp about the caramelized crust. This pizza is very heavy on the breading part of deep dish, and caramelized means a little burnt, sweet, and soft. It wasn't my favorite. Toppings are ok, I think the best one was the Italian sausage. Pretty good value for deep dish, go with a group and split it and dinner came out to like $6 a person.

You know what's amazing going to a place that doesn't change a damn thing and is still a hit. From living in Chicago 22 years then moving to the burbs to start a family I just had to bring them here. Granted we brought our 10 month old (he's loud but not bitchy) here last night great idea because there was seating up stairs which is the best spot. Nice relaxing still has TVs. Pizza is amazing the sauce is the best in the city the crust and dough is complex yet fluffy. If you crave pizza with a layer of toppings stop by grab a pitcher and relax.

WoW oh WoW
Im not a big pizza fan first off I may have it 3x a year tops and have never really liked deep dish but this completely changes the game for me. I fell in love. My mother and I both had the lunch special ( a personal pizza with soda for $5 wow!) Only downside is the pizza takes a while to cook so I have learned to call ahead so the wait is not as long. the personal size is enough even if your big hungry, tho you will be wanting left overs later. I am already craving going back!

Came on a Sunday evening around 6:30PM and the restaurant was fully, completely packed with throngs of people waiting to get seated outside.  I overheard that the wait is at least 1.5 hours.  At this time the restaurant was in a state of controlled chaos as customers who are waiting, customers who are seated and staff members shuffle around the small space and yelling to be heard.  

I had called ahead 1.5 hours to place a carry out order at 7PM and was surprised to find that I had to wait another 20 minutes before the pizza was ready.  Not sure if the pizza was already made and waiting for a staff to bring it out or they actually just started making the pizza when I arrived and paid.  Either way really defeats the purpose of calling ahead.

While I liked the Italian sausage on the pizza.  I didn't like the dough, which was too soggy (I know should have had the pizza at the restaurant but can't afford the wait time).  And the dough was too thick, accounts for at least 75% of the thickness of the pizza.  I want a better dough to sauce/veggies/protein ratio.  Glad I tried it because the hype is high but I don't think Pequod's is worth the wait.

The best deep dish in Chicago, and I've had them all. As a stuck up former New Yorker, I take my pizza seriously. Pequod's delivers with that unique carmelized crust, and a lightness to their pies that others lack. Cool vibe, but be prepared to wait.

My love for deep dish pizza started with Lou Malnati's during my first visit to Chicago and it only exponentially increased when I had dinner at Pequod's Pizzeria. The wait for a table and for pizza can be long, but I really appreciate that Pequod's is blunt and straight forward about the wait.

My friend and I came to the restaurant on a Sunday evening around 6pm and waited about 45 minutes for a table. While we waited, we headed a couple doors down to a bar also owned by Pizano's. When we finally got a table at Pizano's, we ordered wings and fries to munch on while our pizza baked. We ordered a small deep dish pizza with sausage. The crust is absolutely delicious with melty cheese baked in a cast iron skillet. Pizano's is also very generous with their toppings.

Between the two of us, we finished the wings and fries, but we were only able to eat a slice of pizza each. I gladly asked for a box and enjoyed the leftover pizza as a midnight and breakfast the next morning. Only downside was that Pequod's a bit of a trek from our hotel.

You have no idea how much I wanted to love this place. I did my research on Chicago pizza and decided to try Pequods. I really don't get the hype around this place. There was a 2 hr wait to be seated but we got lucky and scored seats at the bar after like 20 min. Throughout my meal I kept feeling sorry for ppl who came before us and were still waiting to be seated. They were bout to realize they wasted 3 hrs of their life waiting on unmemorable pizza. Burnt cheese is so over hyped and for most parts it's like you are eating a thick crust with some cheese and sauce with no flavor

Maybe deep dish isn't for me but then I remember  Patxi in San Francisco and hope one day Chicago will live up to its name and surprise me with a great deep dish. Until then I say if you want deep dish go to Patxi!

Look, we Chicagoans know we have some of the best pizza in the world, right here in our city. But those darned tourists always go to the places advertised in airplane magazines or thise crap places found in search engines. You can be an idiot,  or have the best pizza in Chicago.  Piquads is and should be thought of as top 5! This order as you like it place is all about fresh real ingredients. So your pizza is authentic great tasting food. Their sausage cannot be rivaled. The crust is authentic Italian and has a flavor that enhances the sauces.  There is no best ingredients to their pizzas. I thing veggie pizza is usually a waste but their spices and veggies rule.

While visiting Chicago, I knew we had to have some deep dish pizza.  It came down to choosing between Pequod's and Lou Malnati's.  After reviewing both places, I chose Pequod's because of it's unique crust.  

The atmosphere is wonderful, homey, cozy and everyone was friendly.  Even though it was pre-dinner (around 4:30), the place was packed.  We sat, had a pitcher of beer while we waited for our pizza.

I have to admit I was pretty disappointed.  While I'm not a deep dish connoisseur, I have had it on plenty of occasions.  I felt the pizza here was a little flat and thin - it didn't have the unctuousness of a deep dish pizza.  The crust was basically just blackened/burned cheese.  It was interesting and chewy for the 1st bite, but the novelty wore off after that, and I began to crave the traditional flaky crust that I associate with deep dish.

While I do take responsibility for choosing Pequod's, and I appreciate the traditional twist on the crust, I wouldn't go back.

This place is a bit of a jaunt to get to if you're using public transportation, but it's worth it. We were seated right away, upstairs. The temperature of the restaurant was a bit uncomfortable, too hot. The restaurant is a bit dingy, but hey, we're here for the food. We ordered a pan pizza with sausage. It was delicious! Really large, flavorful hunks of sausage. They caramelize the edges of the crust, so it ends up being a slightly burnt mix of cheese and crust. In comparison to other deep dish places, I'd say the crust here is thinner and there's less cheese. It's also quite a bit cheaper than other deep dish places.

My friends and I went out to eat tonight and it was my first time coming here and I was impressed.

We were told the wait was gonna be 30 minutes but it was shorter than that which was great. Also, we were told the pizza would take about 40-45 minutes to make, but it came out sooner which was also great.

Our server Kelly was really polite and kept coming to check on us every so often.

Will definitely be coming back

Looking for Chicago style pizza? Then you need to check out Pequod's!! It's usually very very busy, so try to make a reservation ahead of time. We came here as a group of six and ordered a few appetizers and two medium pizzas to share, which was more than enough! For apps, we got the cheesy garlic bread, bruschetta and breaded shrooms. I highly recommend the cheesy garlic bread, which comes with a marinara sauce on the side, as well as the breaded shrooms. I mean c'mon, fried mushrooms!! The bruschetta was underwhelmingly flavorless.

For the pizzas, they weren't kidding about the caramelized crust! This is hands down the best part about the pizza. I'm typically more of a thin crust pizza kinda gal but Pequod's makes me wanna change my mind!

Came in for a late night grub. Holy pizza.

We ordered half pepperoni half veggie, extra crispy, and extra red sauce on the side.

Always have enjoyed deep dish pizza. Pequod cheese pan pizza small size and a personal of sausage, onion, and mushroom was ordered. The personal was a bit on the soggy end to my liking. I think partially due to the toppings. The cheese was perfect. Crunchy, a little doughy, but enough sauce and cheese for each bite. The burnt crust was also tasty and not overly charred. Overall had a good experience and with good company

Dang. I wanted to love this place but I'm just not there yet. EVERYONE says that this place is truly the best deep dish place in Chicago. The one that locals, and not tourists go to. While I can vouch that it seemed pretty void of the tourist disasters that are Giordano's and Lou Malnati's, it still didn't blow my mind. I felt that the cheese and sauce on the deep dish were lacking flavor - the only thing that impressed me was the flavor and consistency of the crust. We ordered a "thin" crust too, and it was super thick - and not that good. Service was great though and I liked the low key atmosphere. Overall I would give it another shot. And would still come here over any of the other deep dish places in the city.

During my first visit to Chicago, I tried deep dish pizza from Pizzeria Uno and Giordano's. True Chicagoans smiled politely when they heard about my Chicago style pizza experience, and told me I needed to try Lou's or Pequod's.

Fast forward four years later, and my husband received multiple recommendations from his co-workers recommending Pequod's for the best pan pizza. My sister, her husband, my husband, and I ended up at Pequod's after spending the day at the Shedd Aquarium.

It was packed. The entry space is small; there is no indoor waiting area, so people have to stand around. Standing combined with heavy winter gear and bags was no fun. However, I thought the host was quick and kind. He acknowledged everyone, and after waiting for about 25 minutes, we were ushered upstairs to our booth.

We ordered the appetizer sampler and it was fair. The appetizer sampler and the garlic bread are nothing to get excited about--standard mozzarella sticks, mushrooms, fried zucchini, and jalapeno poppers.

We ordered two small pan pizzas to split between the four of us. My sister and I had pepperoni and black olives on our choice, and my husband and brother-in-law added fresh garlic, pepperoni, sausage, and jalapeños to their choice.

The wait was pretty standard, so be prepared to wait anywhere between 30-50 minutes for your pizza.

When the pizzas arrived, I was most excited about the crust. However, I was pretty disappointed! The crust on the pizza my husband and brother-in-law ordered was soggy. The pepperonis weren't crispy like I liked them. The sausage on my husband's pizza was very chunky; I didn't like it. The jalapeños were tossed on like an afterthought, and they weren't even cooked--just warm, pickled jalapeños. The pizza my sister and I ordered was a little better, but not by much.

Am I missing something??? Is Pequod's not supposed to be Chicago style and just a pan pizza? Is there a difference?! And if it is just a "pan" pizza, this can't be the best Chicago has to offer. I need answers.

All in all, I wasn't excited about my pizza experience at Pequod's, and as of right now...omg. I can't type this. Should I type this? Okay. Okay. My favorite Chicago style pizza is at a place in California called Patxi's pizza. I like the cornmeal crust and the thinly sliced sausage. Patxi's has crisp pepperonis and to die for red sauce. Okay. I'll show myself out.

By Yelp's standards, 3 Stars = "A-OK" which is exactly what Pequod's is.

I'm ready to get slammed in my comment section, but that's all I have to offer, nothing more, nothing less.

The pizza was not-memorable, other than it was not better or worse than one of it's major competitors (to remain nameless)... literally, I could not tell the difference between the crust at Pequod's and that of it's major competitor who also offers a butter/caramelized crust.

Pequod's is hyped as the best Deep Dish in the city, and I disagree. It was A-OK. The prices are very affordable. The sauce is very mild in flavor and could use some more seasonings to make it more robust.

You'll wait about 45 minutes for a table for 2, then the same amount of time for the pizza. Service is nice enough and the menu does not expand much beyond basic italian fare.

Pequod's is a unique offering in a city of amazing pizza. Unfortunately, their product (while good) didn't quite match the hype.

First off, this is objectively not "Chicago Deep Dish" pizza. It's pan pizza. I'm only pointing this out to tourists who might confuse the two.

*Deep Dish: thin, crumbly crust with little to no rise and a side wall of crust (like a pie). Pizza usually served with cheese/toppings on the bottom and sauce on top.

*Pan: thick, risen crust topped with sauce, cheese, toppings (in that order).

Pequod's menu has two styles of pizza listed: 'thin' and 'pan.'

Now that that confusion is out of the way, here's my review:

Pequod's is a small pizzeria that is very popular and you should expect to wait at peak hours. The pizzas take about 45-50 minutes to bake once your order is placed, so be prepared to sit down for a while. What you are looking to get here is the pizza.

Food
*We started with a 1/2 cesar salad to pick at while we waited for our pizza. We ended up sending the salad back because most of the lettuce was turning brown around the edges. It may have been okay, but I'm surprised something so unappealing looking could make it out of the kitchen.

*We ordered a small pepperoni pan pizza. Perfect for two light eaters who wanted no leftovers. The pizza was tasty. The toppings were all in good quantities and had great flavor and aesthetics. The crust was disappointing. Somehow, they have a pan crust (risen, airy) but the bottom is still sort of crumbly in texture (imagine crumbly fried biscuit on the bottom and airy pan crust in the middle). While the bottom and sides was nicely browned/charred, the middle tasted doughy/yeasty, like a dough that was cooked on the bottom but a little raw in the center.

*The very best aspect of the pizza is the crispy edges formed by caramelized cheese welded to the crunchy exterior crust. I could eat this crust all. day. long.

*It's sort of a weird pizza. I feel like you have to eat 75% of an okay pizza to get to the 25% of the best darn thing you'll put in your face all day.

Service:
*It's not great. Everyone was friendly and prompt when we first arrived, but then our server just sort of left us alone in a bad way. As I mentioned earlier, we had to send back our appetizer salad, but we sent it back with the cook that brought our pizza. The server never came back after our salad arrived to check on us. We never received an offer for refills on our waters. The place wasn't extremely busy, we just sort of felt ignored.

Value:
Our small pizza was $15 and I think that's fair if not a deal! Obviously, our salad was comped, but I really liked the fact that we ate our fill and were out for under $20. Of course if you get a lot more toppings on your pizza that can go up quickly, but I was highly satisfied with the value of our order.

Overall:
Pequod's was on my Chicago pizza bucket list, but it's far from my favorite in the city. I'd recommend this place to anyone looking for something a bit off-beat and memorable. The outside edge of the pizza crust is so good, it's worth your attention and any pizza-lover should have it before they die.

pics.caption: This crust is the reason you should check out Pequod's.

review.des:
I don't even know where to start...

When we planned our trip to Chicago, we had made a list of restaurants to try based on recommendations from friends and colleagues. Pequod's never made the list. What a sad mistake it would have been to have missed this place.

Fast forward, we are in Chicago, dining at one of our favorite restaurants in the country, when we strike up a conversation with our server. We give him the list, for his take, and he immediately questions why we have omitted Pequod's? We all look at each other and shrug; never heard of it... He went on to tell us that it's the best pizza in Chicago. Well then, on the list it goes.

So, on our last day in town, before heading to the airport, we made it in. The hope was it would live up to the recommendation as this would be our last meal in town. And boy did it! The great experience started with the fist call. I asked if they could store our bags (party of four, each with a suitcase) and reply was "we don't have a spot, but head on down, we'll figure it out" - love that!

We get there and the place is packed! That said, they found a spot for our bags and we were seated within ten minutes. The appetizers were great, especially the fried zucchini and fried mushrooms. The beer selection was great. And finally, the deep dish (extra cheese and mushrooms) was to die for. We hit Lou Malnoti's and Giordani's on the same trip, but Pequod's blew them out of the water.

Do not leave Chicago without giving them a try!

My boyfriend saw this place on Food Network. He couldn't wait to try. So we came right from airport.
Got brought upstairs which caught us off guard. Old school dark brick vibe. A little too dark for me honestly. Our table smelled like a dirty wet rag when we sat down. That's very off putting. We each ordered personal pan pizzas with toppings. I'm Italian from New York and a pizza snob. So I'm a little bias. The sauce is tasty but more of a sweeter marinara than I like. This place is famous for the way the cheese bubbles and burns on the edge. People go crazy for that. I didn't like it.
The dough is dry not moist. So I felt like I was hearing a hearty bread with sauce and cheese. I asked for fresh garlic and black olives as sides. I
Smelled garlic lightly but did not see or taste any. The black olives were good. Not bad just not my cup of tea. The smelly table set the tone maybe.  If your coming to Chicago it's one of those places you should try.

pics.caption: Personal Pan with fresh garlic and black olives

review.des:
The carmelized crust was delicious but there was a lot of bread compared to Giordano's. We ordered the Pequods salad and it was very impressive.

I'm a huge Giordano's fan and was told by some locals this is better - but Giordano's it's still the winner for us.

I have been to Pequod's many times for a "dining in" experience and have always had a great pizza.

This time I decided to get a pizza to carry out because the place was already very crowded.

Unfortunately, it was only a "meh" pizza.

The carmelized edge was a treat, but the crust and sauce were bland.  The sausage was very sparse.

For a place of this caliber, the pizza was extremely disappointing.

Had to give Pequods a second trial after so many people raved about them. Second time around, pequods stole our heart. We ordered sausage, pepperoni, and onions; it was delightful. The crust is so fulfilling (my favorite part is the burnt cheese). Definitely a must try. There is usually a long wait but the buzzers they give you as place holders connection reaches to the bar next to Pequod's- go get some dranks while you wait! P.s. fried mushrooms hit the spot as an appetizer
Walked from our hotel for a city tour walk to eat at Pequod's.  We had to have the traditional pan pizza.  It is a great family neighborhood restaurant that you will love.

I've tried Pequod's and Lou Malnati's, but I still think that New York has the best pizza. Guess I'm not a big fan of the deep dish. The flour/crust has the consistency similar to corn bread.

Got the appetizer samplers which included mozzarella sticks, the jalapeño poppers, mushrooms and zucchinis. I thought the jalapeños were the best of the four. I also ordered two personal pizzas, and the half-spaghetti for the three of us. There was more than enough food. And I'd recommend sticking to their specialty, pizza.

So by recommendation of a local Chicago resident, we decided to partake in Pequod's for a real legit Chicago Deep dish pizza.  This is a small joint with old school charm but for all the right reasons.  After a short wait, we got to sit upstairs which we didn't even know existed.  We started with the appetizer platter of fried cheese, zucchini, mushrooms and hot poppers.  I love fried cheese however the hot popper was the winner as it pleasantly had a cheddar cheese/pimento mix instead of what the normal cream cheese that I'm accustomed to and it was delicious.  But that's not where this journey ends, as recommended by the waitress we had the Supreme deep dish pizza.  The pizza takes 40 minutes to cook so I had time to have a house salad, which was good but I should have not wasted stomach room as the main event was coming!  The pizza arrived.  Giant cast iron pan filled with mushrooms, peppers, onions, and sausage - homemade sausage made in house.  I'm not usually a fan of sausage on pizza but this place is the  exception, soo good.  Sound good?  I haven't gotten to the best parts!  The crust was crunchy on the bottom but perfectly cooked  which made the best vessel for all of these toppings and then we get to the sauce!  Oh my!  I don't think I need a pizza to eat this sauce but it sure went well with it.  This is my first real Chicago deep
Dish pizza and was possibly the best pizza I've eaten thus far.  I truly want this pizza at home and it makes me mad knowing I cant( no offense to my pizza owner friends) but I have a totally new respect for deep dish and what we have is not deep dish, for true!
Amazing pizza! Best I've ever had! Thanks to my uber driver David for the recommendation!

Best deep dish I've ever had! This spot came highly recommended, and I was not disappointed. We were expecting a small wait for lunch, but were quickly seated when the host realized he had a free high top near the bar. A personal big component in eating near a bar is the amount of distraction (hubbub, TV, etc), and it was perfect- plenty of sports options, but not so overwhelming that you couldn't focus on your conversation.
We started with the garlic cheesy bread, which was sooooooo good! It came with a little cup of marinara, which could have been bigger (I mean come on, marinara), and was steaming and fresh. Totally worth burning my taste buds.
And then the pizza. God, the pizza. I was interested in the caramelized crust when I saw it on the menu, and it was AMAZING. Normally I have to get really motivated to eat an entire pizza by myself, even a personal size, but this pizza was the motivation. I honestly questioned whether it's still really that unacceptable to lick a plate.
Best place to start my time in the city, and I'm craving it now that I'm gone!

Fantastic deep dish pizza.  Far superior to Giordanos and the other tourist places, this comes from a guy who was born in Chicago.  

Only downside to the place is the long wait and parking can be tough in the area.  That being said it is definately worth the visit.

Deep dish pizza is a Chicago thing and Pequod's sure executes it well enough! I've been to almost all the deep dish place you can name in Chicago but still like Pequod's better. And yes their pizza does have more bread and it's charred at the bottom (which is the best part). Other appetizers are not bad too for your regular bar food.
Just be aware that this place is overcrowded over the weekend for peak dining time, and would be a long wait if come with a big group. To what level? Well, there was one time a group of my friends came here, put our name down, went across the street to watch a movie, and then came back to get our table. if you come a bit early or only a few people, the wait isn't too bad.

"Real Chicagoans don't eat deep dish!" I'm a real Chicagoan, and I'm telling you, that statement is WRONG. Especially when it comes to Pequod's.

Don't get me wrong, there is a time and place for deep dish, but if you're making that time and place for it, Pequod's can't be beat. The crust is absolute perfection. Great portions of both meat and veggies. And just has that "pizza place feel".

There's not much else to say. Pequod's has the best deep dish in the city.

I love pizza in all its forms: NY style, New Haven style, and Chicago-style. This was certainly worth the wait. I ended up going online a few days ahead and getting on the priority list, which made getting a table on a Friday night only 15 mins.

It is very crowded so don't expect much for elbow space. Our waitress was awesome and quickly got our orders in (because Chicago-style is 45 mins of cooking).  We ended up getting a small pepperoni pizza for two and it was the perfect size with leftovers and not feeling completely disgusting. The sauce was incredible and crust quite flaky. Highly recommend going!

My biggest problem with the pizza is that it is too doughy. But I come to realize this issue varies day to day. It is less likely to occur with smaller pizzas. With bigger pizzas, I add extra tomato sauce (not an ideal solution).

Overall, pequod's is a good pan pizza. It's caramelized cheese crust is to die for which is properly a very accurate term because there is no way burnt cheese is good for you. However, the pizza does lack some texture balance with the dough. And, unfortunately I do find this distracting to my eating experience. Don't get me wrong! You should still go out of your way to have this pizza if you haven't had it. It's unique. Just don't expect it to be the best unless all you care about is the caramelized crust.

This is seriously the best pizza I've ever had in my life.  You want real Chicago deep dish?  Then forget Lou Malnati's. Forget Giordno's.  Come to Pequod's.  

They cook the pizzas in cast iron deep dish skillets.  It gets served to you in the dish with all amazingly delicious crispy edges.  The pie is so full of the toppings you select.  We had a pizza with sausage and you can tell the sausage is home made.  

This place is pretty big too.  You walk in and think the only tables are there on the main floor around the bar but the space goes back a ways and there's an upstairs.  It's a great space for sports viewing as there are TVs everywhere.  Pretty decent beer selection too.  

We had to wait about a half hour for a table which was fine.  They have a space next door where you can order a drink while you wait.  Just expect to have to wait and plan ahead.

Ah where to begin! Chicago is notorious for their deep dish pizza and besides Lou's, I would recommend staying away from the Big 3 (Gino's East & Giordano's) because of Pequods and Art of Pizza. Don't get me wrong, the Big 3 are good, but I prefer Pequods over them any day. I have been here many times and Pequod's is one of my favorites in Chicago, but I ordered delivery for this review.

Pequods is a official Blackhawks bar and it has a limited selection of beer on tap. It's two floors and the place is actually kind of old/grungy, but it really doesn't matter because you come here for the pizza anyways, right?

In my opinion, Pequods has the best and biggest toppings in Chicago. It would probably rank as the heaviest deep dish pizza in Chicago! Their tomato sauce and bottom crust isn't the best, but it does it's job. To be honest, the bottom layer of crust is quite dry. The tomato sauce is a little wet, but it is flavorful. Lou's, Giordano's, and Art of Pizza have better sauce. But the best part about their pizza is the caramelized cheese crust! It looks burnt, but trust me is it glorious! I highly recommend ordering extra cheese as it gets applied to the crust. Two slices will definitely fill you up and it's about 2,000 calories. But it is worth it!

Service is usually adequate and their appetizers are ok. I've had the Jalapeno poppers and cheese sticks, but they're average fried food. The salad was ok as well, but you should really save yourself for the pizza. Wait times can be very long at peak times so it's usually best to get on the preferred table list. Here are my rankings for deep dish pizza in Chicago: Art of Pizza, Pequods/Lou Malnati's, Giordano's, Gino's East, and Nancy's Pizza. Piece Pizza actually might be my favorite in Chicago and it's New Haven style.

pics.caption: A large pan pizza with pepperoni, green/red peppers, spinach, and extra cheese. A little messy, but worth every bite!

review.des:
In the beginning, there were Mount Vesuvius tomatoes that inspired the pizza napoletana (my favorite pizza). Later in 1900's, her younger sister, New York-style pizza was born (my second favorite). Many years later, their giant big-boned Chicago deep-dish brother was delivered. This pizza snob dude tried four deep-dish pizza big names in Chicago so far, and I hereby dub Pequod's  my favorite.

However, do you know what the best part is about Pequod's pies!! For me, it was those caramelized burnt ends!! People don't like their ''cornicione''. But I found myself eating them, non-stop. My criticism is they pour a lot of sauce into the pizza. So when you're working on it, the sauce will burst all over your face and most importantly your beard.

Thanks to some awesome Chicagoan friends, I was invited to a small event over here. We were about 20 people. Michelle, the organizer, pre-ordered lots of pizzas. To be safe, I ordered a small thin crust cheese pizza, because I'm a part time vegan. Michelle said it was the best among all pizzas ordered!! I really liked it. The cheese amount was a generous Midwestern portion by default. I would've loved more crunch on the base. But you know how it is. The flavors were there, 4.2989899 stars.

The waitresses were efficient but you can feel they were pressurized as it was so busy and crowded. The place is old and dim from inside. But who cares if you have a fancy photographer friend like Daniel to make photos look amazing!. Location by the far nicely crowded western side of Lincoln Park is so smart and full of life. I had much fun meeting with new yelp friends over here. Cool people. My buddy Alex A was a must to be present, as usual.

PS. my 26K marathon runner buddy from New York LOVES this place. Would definitely come back for those caramelized cornicione.

03/23/18 - Last night an unofficial Yelp event was held as a farewell party for our former Chicago CM Alex S at Peaquods Pizzeria @ 2207 N Clybourn Ave in Chicago.  In Alex's S. short stint as Chicago CM he has did a great job of bringing together some epic Yelp events.  I would like to take this opportunity to thank him and to wish him the best in whatever his future endeavors are.  It was a fitting tribute hosted by Michelle, Salena & Liang at Pequod's Pizzeria for Alex S.  I was honored to be one of the chosen to attend the farewell party.

As far a Peaquod's pizza I love the caramelized crust on the perimeter of the pizza, but I'm not especially fond of the thick soft doughy interior of the pizza.  Like many of the pizza restaurants they have both thin & the thick doughy pizza crust which I got to try both last night thanks to the thoughtfulness of the 3 ladies that took the time to canvas the 20 or so people in attendance to try and find out what their preferences were on pizzas.  I mentioned to Michelle that while I appreciated the thoughtfulness of doing that, it is very difficult to please everyone and suggested maybe a vegetarian options for those non meat eaters & a mix of meat & other toppings as it is hard to cater to everyone's individual choices.  Naturally I was surprised when both Michelle & Liang told me my pizza with sausage, mushrooms, black olives & garlic was sitting on the table as requested.  Thanks to the ladies for organizing this event for Alex S.  We all want to wish the Best for Alex S in his future whatever that may be

This is the first time I ate at the Clybourn location so it was kind of cool to see the restaurant which is a 2 story restaurant.  As I arrived I ran into Sarah S outside.  As we walked in we were told they had 2 groups upstairs in the 2nd floor dining area.  This is where we met our fellow Yelpers.  

When it came time to pay the girls were working out the bill when Ahmed A came up and snatched the bill out of their hands and paid the bill for the group.  Thank you Ahmad That was a very unexpected and generous thing to do.

I give 5 stars + for the cool Yelp people at the event, but only 4 stars for the pizza.  Very good pizza, but my favorite pizza is Lou Malnati's butter crust.

Came in for my mom's birthday on a very rainy and icky Saturday. I had made a table request online the day before, which I would recommend because it seems to be crowded at all times, including 2:30pm on a Saturday.

We came about 20 minutes earlier than our reservation and they were still able to seat us after only about 5 minutes of waiting. We grabbed drinks at the bar, I was pleasantly surprised to see they had Krombacher on tap.

We were seated on the main floor towards the back, but they do have an upstairs that gets more natural light and looks to be a little more spacious. The seating is close-quarters for sure, but nothing super uncomfortable. Frankly, it is a pizzeria that has a bar and is not fancy, pretentious or otherwise, no frills.

We kept it super simple and just ordered a large pepperoni pan pizza. We were advised it would take 45 minutes, but it came out in less than 30 minutes, so that was great!

The pizza itself was fantastic! As others have said, it is not exactly like other Chicago deep-dish/stuffed pizza. This has a caramelized crust that is crispy enough to add good texture, but not like other deep dish where you need a knife to cut through it. I liked the sauce a lot, it has a little sweetness to it. Really a fantastic blend of what seemed like good quality ingredients. Not skimpy on pepperoni, cheese or sauce, everything came together wonderfully and we had a lot to take home from a large between 3 people. It's filling but I actually would argue not as "stuffing" as traditional deep dish.

Our server was good, we didn't really need much, literally just ordered the pizza and that was about it.

Great spot for a unique pan pizza, nothing but good things to say about Pequod's, I'm a big fan.

Pequod's makes the best deep dish pizza. I left off the elusive 5th star for one reason, well actually two. ..extra sauce. ..extra cheese. Make sure you order both & load up on toppings. Pequod's isn't at it's best with simple one or two ingredient pies. These mandatory additions (which should be standard) will make all your deep dish pizza dreams come to fruition. Let me explain.

Pequod's doesn't serve the traditional Chicago deep dish pizza with a thick cheesy layer, instead there's a deliciously crisp bread-like crust with a caramelized cheese rim (see pics, it's not burnt despite the color). The extra sauce and cheese balances out the thick crust. All the standard toppings are offered and always fresh. No arugula, artichokes or pesto drizzles if that's what you're into. Just delicious satisfying pizza.

Be forewarned the cook time is 45mins to an hour, but well worth the wait. Some tips suggest placing your pizza order with the hostess as you wait for a table. This was not an option during my last three visits. I suggest ordering wings and sit tight until perfection arrives.

Was really impressed
We went here on a tip from a Uber driver
Solid 10 for the deep dish crust was perfect, sauce had a nice little bite with a hint of spice,  that went well with the meats we chose and a 10 inch was perfect for 3 people we'll be going back for sure

I will start this by saying I love their pizza. We order from Pequods almost once a week. It's our favorite pizza delivery in Chicago and has been for the past few years.

However, the last four deliveries have all had issues. A few weeks ago, they forgot to bring the delicious, amazing ranch we paid for. Sure, it's only ranch, but it complements the food so well :)

The next time, the toppings were wrong. We ended up calling and the manager reluctantly fired a new pizza and we waited another hour-ish for the correct pizza.

Last weekend, after waiting almost 2.5 hours, we found out the girl who took our order entered the wrong phone number. The driver came back and told us he was here an hour ago but couldn't get ahold of us since the wrong number was entered.

Tonight, they once again forgot the ranch we paid for.

I sent them an email outlining what has happened the past four times and received what most would consider a garbage response. The manager/owner/whoever sent incomplete sentences basically saying that they have a new delivery ordering system and they are working out the kinks. Sorry about that.

In the end, I would NOT recommend ordering delivery from them for some time. If you need some Pequods, dine in or pick it up. Their delivery system now is whack.

Finally, after trying 4 different pizza places in Chicago, this takes the cake for the best Chicago pizza I've had! I think this is what we envision when we say "Chicago deep dish pizza".

However, it did remind me of Pizza Hut's pan pizza since I think they use a pan pizza base/structure, but different crust and sauce of course. It made me appreciate pizza hut's pan pizza! Lol

We ordered sausage and pepperoni on our pizza and let me tell you, the sausage here is amazing! So definitely order sausage if you can.

pics.caption: Sausage and pepperoni deep dish pizza! Excellent! 4.5/5

review.des:
Ok so I eat here all the time! I LOVE THIS PLACE and I NEVER got around to review it.

So today I called to make a call ahead order and I was told they no longer do that. Mind you I am traveling an hour to eat here So I called back and asked if I ordered for a pick-up could I eat it there and his response was that He doesn't see a problem with it especially since they weren't  busy or there wasn't a wait. So I gave it a go

I am giving them a 2 star review because the food is amazing but today I experienced the worst management encounter in my life.

Upon arrival I told the hostess I was there for a pickup. She walked away to check on my order then when she came back I asked her if I could just eat there since there were MULTIPLE open tables and NO wait.

I was told that we couldn't eat our pickup pizza there even though we were going to order drinks and app and of course  tip the server.

The woman who spoke with me was very rude and after canceling the order she told me I was able to eat it there. UNBELIEVABLE!

Pictures are from my last visit. Obviously not today since we left.

Also I brought my cousin who is in from the Army FROM GERMANY to eat here and he was very upset that we couldn't eat here BUT we ended up going to a VERY well known establishment couple miles away for Pizza Pot Pie that he LOVED!

pics.caption: Love the food... management needs some work

review.des: I'm disappointed because of all the build up. My kids gave them one, two, and three stars--so the average is two. The deep dish crust was a bit dry, didn't have enough cheese, and edges were burnt. The thin crust pizza was okay. The zucchini was inedible. The onion rings were okay. I really don't understand why they got all these awards. The pizzas didn't have a lot of flavor.  Neither did the garlic bread. I just expected more from a place that was highly acclaimed. Too bad.

pics.caption: I can't even eat these.  Don't waste your money.

review.des:
This review is strictly for their delivery services. It has nothing to do w the quality of their pizza.

For the past month or so, I have ordered a pan pizza every weekend. I love it. I crave it and they are reasonably priced.

However... each time I have ordered it, they'd f*^%#} it up. Literally, every. Single. Time.

Two of the four weekends they forgot part of the order listed on the ticket attached to the box.

One time they made It with wrong ingredients so I had a pizza delivered and had to wait another 2 hours for the correct one to be delivered.

And the 4th one they delivered my pizza to the wrong address so we had to wait longer again.

All of these issues stemmed in the last month or so. We never had them before. We've emailed management and they respond as if they don't care with phrases like, "wish I knew what happened..." uhhhh I just told you? But okay.

As my favorite pizza place in Chicago, I may need to hunt for a new one. A more reliable one. This is to the point where I feel I am sacrificing what I really want (my order) for whatever they feel like giving me. And that's no way to order pizza on Friday night!

If you're ordering from them. Quadruple check your order on the phone and if they arrive without it.... be ready to wait another two hours for the (fingers crossed) correct order to show up!

We made a visit to Chicago for the marathon this weekend. My boyfriend, who is the runner, requested classic Chicago deep dish pizza for his post race meal. Our server another restaurant actually referred us to Pequod's. We took a short metro ride and a lovely walk through Depaul University to get to the restaurant. The wait was 1 to 2 hours but we were able to find a seat at the bar. The food was absolutely incredible and I am so glad that we were told about this spot. We ordered the bruschetta and a deep dish pizza with meatballs and canadian bacon. We weren't able to finish it all in one seating and happily took it home for a snack later.   When I make a return trip to Chicago I will definitely make this one of my meal stops.

Having only had Lou's when visiting Chicago in the past, I was looking for deep dish pizza at a location that was favored by the locals and was not just a large local chain. My sister suggested Pequod's having been there before and I'm glad we came here.

We were lucky to easily find the table as the 45 minute wait for the pizza is agonizing when you are starving! We ordered a medium deep dish pizza and customized one half while leaving the other as a cheese pizza. The pizza was amazing, the crust in particular was delicious. The servers were attentive even as the place got busier the later it got. Definitely, would recommend Pequod's to anyone looking to try deep dish pizza while in town.

Finally made it to Pequod's when an old friend was visiting from out of town, and just like everyone says, it is GOOD.

It did take the full 35 minutes or so for the pizza, but that's to be expected with any deep dish. They just have their standard sizings of cheese pizza, and you can add whatever toppings you want - so we got peppers and mushrooms.  The whole place smells amazing, and when the pizza got to the table we were all practically drooling over it. The cheese is so meltey and perfect when they serve the slices onto your plate, and they've got a solid proportion of sauce to cheese to crust.  The best part is probably the caramelized edges of the crust, but the whole pizza eating experience was all in all amazing.

If you like deep dish - go to Pequod's.

pics.caption: Large pan pizza with peppers and mushrooms!

review.des:
Although I'm not the biggest deep dish fan, this was definitely my favorite over Lou's and Giordano's.
Their pizza is lighter and has an awesome crispy crust.

It also feels much more traditional and less of a tourist trap than some of the other chains.

The only time we eat deep dish is when people come to visit from out of town. This will be our go-to spot from now on!!

What to get: pan pizza
Service: 5/5
Atmosphere: Casual, sports bar
Wait: 45 mins (Saturday 11:30AM for 1)

The Experience:
Another out-of-towner trying to get a taste of that legendary Chicago, deep-dish pizza. I should specify that this is a pan pizza, where it has a caramelized crust rather that a fulling-encasing thick crust. That extra crunch at the bottom of your pizza is what you're after.

Even when it just opens, you're going to have to wait. It gets crowded easily and even as a solo diner, I nabbed one of the few spots at the bar. The waiting is actually for the pizza to cook. A personal size takes about 45 mins. Just choose your toppings, have a drink, and wait.

The staff is attentive since they know you'll be waiting. The name of the game is waiting here. If you can do that, you're rewarded with a stellar pizza. A personal size is filling enough for 1 person. I even took some home to eat later, but it is similar to eating a pie. Best part is that crunch from the crust with the gooey cheese melting all over.

It's a wonderful must-try if you're in town.

Attention, attention!!

I don't care who you talk to or what they say, Pequod's Pizzeria is by far the absolute best pizza in Chicago.  I am not exaggerating. There's nothing else like it! I've ordered delivery and dined in at this fabulous locally owned establishment and I've never been disappointed. While the wait may be long depending on the day and time, it's totally worth it. Do yourself a favor and ignore the hoopla surrounding the larger pizza chains around the Windy City and eat pizza like a local!

I'm pretty basic when it comes to my pizza options... I tend to stick with a plain cheese pizza and I douse it with red chili flakes and dip it in ranch. This pizza is what I believe most people would describe as a pan (deep pan) pizza, however it's truly unique and unlike any other pan pizza I've had. Not only in Chicago, but anywhere! The crust is buttery and caramelized to perfection! The crunch is amazing and gives it the texture you need when it's topped with ooey gooey cheese and red sauce. So delicious and filling.

You're welcome! I can just picture the huge smile that will spread across your face as you devour your first Pequod's pizza... or your 50th (wink, wink)!

It was ok.
We had the classic. We dont get it.
Malnati's Classic is better and Giordano's most consistent.
Geno's is best little independent joint in town.

Tiny neighborhood pizza place with a LOT of hype. We were lucky to snag a seat at the bar while we waited for our table but that's where the good ended. We were seated at a high top next to the host stand and it just felt like we were in everyone's way. Everyone waiting for a table was just staring at us eat...not the most fun.

The pizza was tasty but not my favorite. We ordered the deep dish with pepperoni and sausage. The pepperoni had great flavor but the sausage was heavily flavored with fennel. I was't a fan. If I lived nearby, I would give it another try but I wouldn't go out of my way to go back.
My favorite deep dish in Chicago! Good beer selections and you can buy pitchers ! Good as take out/delivery but the best eaten in house. Nothing fancy about it -no frills just some good pizza !

Love Pequod's! The pizza is worth the wait. We love it so much we even had our daughter's first birthday party there. The waitress was sweet and patient, she did not get flustered or make us feel rushed even though, as always, the place was super busy.

Insanity. Pure insanity. This place is fantastic and the pizza was the best we have had on our trip. The cheesy burned cheese goodness on the edge was fantastic. Thankfully it was the Blackhawks official bar, it was empty and had no wait. LETS GO PREDATORS!!!!

Is there a TEN STAR button?!?!?!   Noel was freaking AMAZING and it is the best pizza I have ever had in my 37 years on this green earth!    The meatball app warmed me up enough for the wait and the House dressing was fire!   But I swear best cheese, best pepperoni, best crust and unreal amazing customer service.  No question no doubt I'll go back!

Love love love Pequod's! This has to be my favorite deep dish pizza place in Chicago. I'm not a local, I'm not a native. Just a foodie Yelper who loves Chicago style pizza!

I've had the typical places like Lou Malnati's and Giordano's, which are also good in their own rights. But when you pile your cheese high over the edge of the dough that it crisps up and makes each bite of the crust tantalizingly cheesey, how can you say no?

I'm a classic with the sausage, which here consists of giant blobs of pure deliciousness and the best kind of kick to your encasd meat. They pile the toppings on sky high so you don't have to worry about bring jipped of the $2+ per topping. Honestly, my most recent visit consists of sausage, pepperoni, and green peppers and I had more toppings in each bite than dough, which is not a bad thing.

Whenever I get meat toppings, I find that there's always enough sauce, but looking at the table next to me last night, who got all veg, I did notice it was a little drier than ours, so I can see why people ask for extra sauce.

Even with the hour long wait to get a table and 30-40 min for the pizza, I still love it here. I do say, plan ahead - cause waiting nearly 2 hrs will get to you. I come hungry, but not hangry, and grab a small appetizer to share to tide free table over. 4 people, a medium pizza with app combo was about $10 a person. Definitely worth the trip!

pics.caption: Medium pan with pep, sausage, and green peppers!
App combo. A little too much fried for, but the breading on each item was well made and delicious!

review.des:
I've had Pequod's a couple times before (dine-in and delivery) but decided to stop in today for their awesome lunch special deal before a movie. For $4.95 you get a personal sized cheese pizza and a fountain drink-- it's an amazing deal!

I added giardiniera and pepperoni (each topping was 80 cents) and a side salad ($2.50 extra). When it comes to Chicago pizza, I'm typically a diehard Lou's girl but I was really impressed by Pequod's-- especially for the price! The personal sized pizza had a lot more of the crunchy cheese on the crust that Pequod's is famous for compared to the larger pies. I would skip the side salad next time as it had not been spun properly and left a huge puddle of water in the bottom of my bowl.

That amazing lunch special does not include any refills on drinks. My server never offered me another one which I gladly would have paid for. I'm in the service industry so I definitely understand the woes of a lunch shift where everyone is spending $5. It certainly wouldn't deter me from returning.

Overall, this was by far my favorite Pequod's experience. I will go back next time I'm going to Regal Webster.

After a 2.5 hour wait...yes we hung out for that long, we were not disappointed. We had individual an pizzas; mine was sausage and mushroom and friend's was peppers, garlic, and pepperoni. The caramelized crust/cheese is what makes this Pequod's.

Hip joint with upstairs area. Loud when crowded! Definitely will bookmark and be back next time in Chicago!

I had seen Pequod's on the Food Network and it was also recommended by locals, so I had to give it a try while in town for the race on the previous day.  I came in during lunch, so I had the lunch special, which includes an individual stuffed cheese pizza and drink (no refills) for $4.95 + tax. An extra topping is 80 cents, so I got bell peppers.  The lunch special is available weekdays from 11:00 AM to 3:00 PM.  You definitely cannot beat that deal anywhere in town, especially for the quality of the pizza that you get.

The pizza itself is very good, just like everybody says!  It has a nice buttery crust that is nicely caramelized on the edges.  Despite all of the rave reviews, I think it is tied with Lou Malnati's for the best Chicago style stuffed pizza, which are both definitely better than Pizzeria Uno, Gino's East, and Giordanos.  However, Pequod's is definitely cheaper than all of the others, especially for the lunch special.  Pequod's stuffed pizza also has a higher crust to toppings ratio than the others, but that is OK with me...I know some prefer less crust and lots of cheese like Lou's prepares.

Since it is so good, you can expect a wait since the dining area is quite small, unless you sit at the bar, in which case there is no wait if there is available space.  It is also very dark inside, and also very noisy and crowded.  If you are claustrophobic, you will not enjoy the dining area. People were bumping into me while I was trying to eat.

If you are a fan of Chicago-style stuffed pizza, I highly suggest Pequod's.

pics.caption: Store front as of 10/9/2017.  I forgot to ask about the Whale Tale.
No guns allowed!  Also ranked #2 pizza in America by the Food Network.

review.des:
The outside of the building looks a little run down and there isn't a place inside to wait and there weren't a lot of parking options. We waited for about 20 minutes to be seated and there was a sign that said a pizza would take 60 minutes to make.

We were seated upstairs and decided to order drinks and apps while we waited for our pizzas to cook. The app combo comes with jalapeño poppers, breaded mushrooms, fried zucchini and mozzarella sticks.  It was pretty run of the mill as far as fried appetizers go. We also ordered cheesy garlic bread which I don't recommend (soggy bread, not much flavor.)

Our pizzas were ready in under 60 minutes. The deep dish with pepperoni, sausage and onions was AMAZING. Best deep dish pizza I've had hands down. The second pizza we ordered was thin crust with onions, pepperoni and ground beef and was pretty decent.

Side note: the bottle of wine we ordered was opened before it reached the table, which was kind of weird. And our glasses weren't dirty, but they were smudged and not the cleanest...

Overall, in the future we will definitely be ordering in from this place but likely won't dine in again.

Soooooo good!!! I think they have the best pan pizza (deep dish).

Ordered half fries, half wings, tossed salad, and a small pan (cheese, sausage, green peppers, mushrooms).

Everything was amazing.

The side crust is carmalized so it's basically a cheese crust. The bottom crust is more doughy so it's more of a thick toast than a regular pizza crust.

Dining there yesterday was just so uncomfortable. We got seated upstairs and our server (dressed in a minions costume) had a pretty bad day. She was visibly upset when orders went wrong and would announce it half way before reaching the guest. One group sat down and she went over and they asked her how is she doing and the server replied "well my tips have been crap all morning because orders have been messing up so that's how it's going." It was so uncomfortable hearing that and being only 3ft away from the table. In another instance we heard her telling a group she apologized for their incorrect order and said "it's not my fault, it's her fault. She messed up the order" pointing to the other server (dressed in a devil costume) and left the section. We looked at the serve in the devil costume and she was visibly upset and looked like she was on the verge of crying. We felt soo bad. Lastly, our server was speaking to who seems to be the manager and complaining about how orders have been messing up all morning. In this situation, this should be handled at the back of the house. NOT in front of guests.

Listen, I know we all have an off day but you deal with it privately and away from your guests. I work for one of the biggest restaurant groups in the city, and if this happened at any of our restaurants you would've been removed immediately. Don't make your guests feel uncomfortable, that's probably a part of the reason you weren't getting tips.

How have I never been here before!

.... it still strikes me to say this, but they're... *taking a momentary pause. not for drama. more because it still hasn't sunken in, yet* .... I think I like Pequod's more than Lou Malnati's.

I'm actually sad that I haven't been here sooner.

I'm actually resentful that nobody's told me sooner.

I'm actually pretty angry because I could have had much more Pequod's in my life, and what if my life had been over before I never even tried them.

And maybe I'm in denial, and just haven't had a good pizza fix lately, as if being Chicago-born doesn't entitle me to a bit of pizza-coinnoisseur-ness, and I've shamed other 90'kids TMNT lovers by having denied myself such ooey-gooey-goodnesss.

.... I think these are stages of grief.

BUT OH, HOW THIS PIZZA MAKES MY HEART SOAR!

to find out that they sometimes have a 3-hr wait, makes perfect sense. That it has an adjacent bar next door, which is the DEDICATED space for waiting for your table --- also makes perfect sense. No... it's not pretentious. Pequod's is just that serious. This is like the Disney World for pizza, where you look forward to it, and expect the wait (on top of 45 min cook-time wait) because standing in line earns your right to taste the Pequod glory.

OK ok I'm really over-embellishing.. it's just that Chicago is so rampant with pizza, that it remains difficult to be impressed.  But even their tomato soup was bomb dot com! ... and I sure love my tomato bisque from Panera, but DANG. it was slurptastic.

... Even the leftovers were just as amazing. It's nice because their crust is crispy all throughout, unlike other competitors that can rave about a butter crust, that you have to commit to a slice to get to that tasty finisher at the end.  Every bite has that buttery finish.

Idk. IF you haven't yet, you're missing out. I recommend a party only of up to 4 people so you don't have to wait, and to go at an off-time (like during the week, or before/after typical dinner service).  If you can eat 9 or later, I think that would be prime time to come during the week.

Wow. I just can't say enough great things, and I'm already salivating, waiting on an excuse to come back.

Where do I begin!? let's start off by saying that I've heard nothing but great things about this place.. yet have had two crappy experiences.

Two weeks ago, after boating we decided to order some pizza, everyone raved about pequods, so I decided to call in an order. After being on hold for 20 min, I finally got through and placed an order for 2 large pizzas. The girl said 2 hours for delivery.. WTF? Fair enough.. we shall wait, over 2 hours pass and nothing.. I call, on hold for 10 min, finally to have he girl say .. "Sorry, we canceled your order, we don't deliver to the harbor anymore" WHAT!!????? We've been waiting for 2 hours!? Why didn't someone call me or say that!? She apologized and hung up, mind you. I fought with them and my bank for a week because they STILL CHARGED ME!

Fast forward to last night. Again, we want pizza after boating. We see our boat neighbors had pequods and they said it was delivered .. WTF! I call in an order and they said "we don't deliver to the harbor." I say, my neighbors just got delivery! She puts me on hold then processed to take my order... Like REALLY! They delivery when they want!? Anywho... I place an order and her quoted TWO HOURS! We wait, we wait and finally our BURNED PIZZAS ARRIVE! 2 hours and $80 later, our pizza arrived, everyone was super excited and starved and we open the boxes to three burned pizzas. LIKE WOW. Had to eat around the burned crust. Super disappointing .. and I ordered HOT wings and got BBQ.

What a JOKE. Will never order again and will make sure to tell all of my dock neighbors to not bother with this establishment.

During my short trip to Chicago I had a tough decision deciding which deep dish pizza spot I would visit. I ultimately boiled down the choices to either Lou Malnati's or Pequod's and ended up picking Pequod's. Pequod's is not located in the touristy area of Chicago so I ended up having to catch an Uber here. Not wanting to wait a long time, my friend and I decided to stop by around opening time @ 11. We were quickly seated upstairs upon arrival. Our waitress was very friendly and was very attentive the whole time we were there.

I opted for the personal pan pizza with green peppers, sausage, olive, and mushrooms. Keep in mind that toppings are not free of charge so it can quickly add up. The pizza came out within 10 minutes piping hot. It's worth mentioning that their personal pizza's don't come in the skillet. The thing that stood out to me most about the pizza at Pequod's was definitely the crust and the tomato sauce. The tomato sauce tasted very fresh and the crush was not too overwhelming. The toppings I opted for were not overcooked and paired well with the pizza. At the end of my meal I was glad that I was able to try out a Chicago deep dish pizza and throughly enjoyed it.

Overall I had a positive experience from food to service at Pequod's. If I were to be 100% honest though I personally prefer NY pizza compared with the Chicago deep dish. The deep dish got a bit tiring for me near the end of my meal. If it's your first time in Chicago as a tourist, I would highly recommend trying out a deep dish pizza. I can't compare between Lou's or Pequod's but I'm sure neither one would disappoint as they both have very positive reviews on Yelp.

pics.caption: Personal pan with green peppers, mushrooms, olives and sausage

review.des: 5 stars for the pizza. 3 stars for the service. We arrived in Chicago for a short three day vacation and wanted some good Chicago style pizza. Upon recommendation, we gave these guys a try. We ordered a few standard appetizers which were pretty good with how basic they were. Then on to the main dish, the Chicago style pizza. Amazing. Absolutely amazing. We kept it simple with pepperoni, sausage, peppers and onions; and we were not disappointed. From the large chunks of toppings to the buttery crunchy crust. Words can't describe the awesomeness of this pizza. I highly recommend the pizza here. Trust me, you will not be sorry.

From the outside it looks small but when you go in boy is it spacious!! Folks had been telling me for years about the pie at Peaquods but being brand loyal to other Chicago pizzerias I paid them no mine. The unique thing about Pequods in my mine is the carmelized crust on the deep dish. The sauce has a nice balance as far as zestiness. Ate some deep dish, ate some pieces of thin crust. Enjoyed my Coca Cola! Refills were done promptly. Had a reservation with a tremendous group of people and we all enjoyed ourselves.I think it's neat how Pequods has a good reputation but it isn't of the old guard of Chicago deep dish places. It signals to the world that the torch has been passed to a new generation.

Pequod's salad was amazing, get the Caesar dressing as it comes on the side. Jalapeño Poppers were good, they messed up our order of the sauces but corrected it quickly. Mozzarella Sticks were very good.

We ordered two pizzas and, while they were good, I cannot say they were great. The caramelized crust was good but I would not say it made the pizzas. I am a big fan of Lou Malnati's and, in my opinion, I would choose a deep dish sausage from Lou's over this.

The big question is would I come again? Taking into account the wait, the pizza and the cost = No. For me Pequod's is one and done.

Food taste wise its delicious. My only complaints are how crammed the inside is, and felt a little nickle and dimed (got a big order of cheesy garlic bread that came with no marinara which seemed odd and got charged for the mini cups they brought us when we asked, weren't told we'd get charged for each one either) Food wise though the pizza is delicious. Split... or at least tried to split a small with a girlfriend and we didn't even close to finish it. Next time I'm back in Chicago this will definitely be back for the pizza, they know what they're doing in that kitchen.

Came here with some friends after the last day of Lollapalooza (Sunday night) a few weeks ago. We got in at 11:30 and Pequod's closes at midnight, so the owner requested us to order our deep dish to go. We were fine with that, given most of us (not me :D) had work the next morning, and so we ordered two pizzas among the six of us to take back home.

We waited at least half an hour for the pizza, which is understandable (not sure if this is the average wait time) because it's deep dish and needs to bake for awhile. A few minutes after we ordered, another party of 6 came in, sat at a table (we were sitting at the bar to wait), and ordered.

One of our pizzas came out around midnight, but not the other. We had to go up to the cashier and ask him if our other pizza was ready. He went back into the kitchen for another few minutes, to which we were terrified that they had forgotten to even start our pizza, but then came out with it.

As we were leaving, we saw food being served to the group that came in after us. I guess the owner was fine with that group eating in the restaurant rather than taking it to-go. We were fine with that too because we had our real lives to get back to in the morning, but I just thought it was odd, perhaps a little unprofessional.

Our deep dish pizza was cold by the time we got back to our apartment (a 30-minute drive from Pequod's), but it tasted fine warmed up in the microwave and we were HUNGRY so it was good. It's not the best deep dish pizza I've had -- Zachary's here in Berkeley (Oakland) is still better -- but from what I've heard, Pequod's is better than Giordano's in Chicago.

I'll probably come back in the future with enough time to spare before closing time.

Yikes, oh have the mighty fallen? My last visit was for the personal cheese deep dish and also a medium pepperoni.

It is my regret to inform all the pizza aficionados my taste buds have either evolved to dislike the pizza, or they have revamped their portions, skimping out on the cheese, sauce and toppings.

Most of the pizza was corn meal bread. It was absolutely disgusting, but the personal deal is 5 bucks or less.

I ate half the personal pizza but couldn't find a way to finish it unfortunately.

Restaurant didn't carry vinaigrette dressing for the small salad -- just oil and vinegar.

Maybe the Morton grove location is better now?

pics.caption: My personal cheese pizza. Just bread. Even worse for the medium pizza

review.des: Hands down best Chicago style pizza I've ever had!! I went for lunch and found that the personal pizza is the perfect size! I had nothing bad to say about this pie, it has enough sauce, cheese and whatever ingredient you choose to enjoy it completely and the burnt cheese as the crust gives the pizza an incredible crunchy taste! Besides the lunch special is perfectly priced and impossible to pass by. My experience at this place was so great that I did not mind the 45 minutes the pizza took to be made!

A m b i a n c e:
Dim lighting, indoor seating on 2 levels, TV's, like a chill sports bar without obnoxious drunk people. Be patient, there will be a wait, but it's worth it.

N o i s e  L e v e l:
Kinda loud, tables are close to one another, so it can be a good date night spot.

D r i n k s:
Beer, wine, cocktails, and soft drinks.

F o o d:
Always get the deep dish pizza, it's the only kind a true Chicagoan will eat proudly. The ingredients are delicious, the sauce is not sweet, a great balance of toppings/crust/cheese/sauce ratio. Ranch dressing is also amazing.

R e v i s i t:
Yes, duh!

Late and quick lunch at one of my all time favorite pizza places in the world...Glad to see the quality of the pies hasn't declined since the passing of the owner/founder, Burt Katz... Personal Deep Dish with sausage and mushroom... Every pizza can be a personal pizza! Service was fantastic sitting at the bar...

Pequod's is delicious! Hands-down one of the best Chicago Deep Dishes in town.

They are ALWAYS busy - especially on Cubs game days! I think they started delivery finally, so I will have to give it a try. I'm not a fan of waiting outside when it's cold for an hour+ for a table.

The lunch special is awesome.

Yumyumyumyum the crust and the dough are delicious. The service was attentive but be prepared to wait for your thick, luscious pizza to be cooked. I got cheese and tomatoes. My friend got pepperoni, green peppers. The medium was just right to stuff us with no other appetizer.

Burnt crust, no thanks. Not for me. I will say that I'm in the minority of my friends who loves this stuff.  The whole "Chicago style pizza" scene is totally lost on me. It's more like pasta than pizza. If you like  to eat your pizza with a fork and be full after one slice then have at it.  People rant and rave about this place, just not for me.

We went on a pizza tour.  So yummy!  Service was good!  Only issue was very inconsistent slices for our group.  Mine was literally two times as big as my husbands...but likely due to serving big group. Sausage pie was so good!

I was pretty disappointed by Pequod's as this was my first time ever getting REAL Chicago Deep Dish pizza in Chicago. My friend who's an IL native suggested we go to Pequod's over the other deep dish places because she preferred them over Giordano's or Lou Malnati's. We showed up on a Monday right when they opened at 11AM and were seated right away in an empty (and dark) dining area. We each got an individual pizza (7") which was a cheap $4.95 with the purchase of a soft drink for their lunch special. I asked the server for topping recommendations, who suggested sausage or pepperoni. So we each got one of those.

The pizza took 40 minutes to cook, even despite being one of the first few customers in the restaurant. Not sure if that's the usual length of time it takes to cook the pizza or if the wait gets worse the busier the place. When it came out, it was un-applaudingly small and served in the original deep dish pan. Had a very dark, borderline-burnt crust which I assumed was melted cheese held under the broiler. You could get four "slices" out of that one individual size.

The taste of the pizza itself: too saucy, not enough cheese, few chunks of sausage, and the crust was essentially like a plain dry-fluffy foccacia bread. You could say I was disappointed, as the only reference of deep dish I had previously was Uno's Chicago grill pizza which I have to say tastes better than this, though their tomato sauce is a little too sweet. Wouldn't say I was blown away by this one, and hope I can try a larger selection of REAL deep dish the next time I come back to IL.

Forget Giordano's and Lou Malnati's; come HERE for the actual best pan pizza in Chicago. Not quite deep dish, but the crust is thick enough for my liking. There's only one location in the city, but no matter where you live, it's worth the trek!

Yum! This has been my favorite pizza place in Chicago. We went on a Thursday evening around 7 and only waited about 10 minutes for a table. The Pequod's salad and garlic cheese bread as apps were great and came out quickly. The pizza took the expected 40 minutes and was cheesy, saucy, and crispy.

pics.caption: 1 piece of a small pie with sausage, pepperoni, and mushrooms. Yum!!!

review.des:
I'm from the area, and I have always thought deep-dish is gross. Pizza often makes me feel sick due to an excess of cheese and bread, so I only eat it if I know it will be worth it to feel terrible later.
This stuff was the s**t.
Not exactly deep dish like other places, but a deep pan pizza with a large amount of the toppings you ask for. I was surprised by how good it was and by the insane amount I ate of the spinach and onion I got - was also glad we got an appetizer as the wait is long (although they are very clear and up-front about it).
I used to tell tourists that they were the only ones who liked deep-dish and locals thought it was meh, but it turns out I'm a fool who was just going to the wrong place.
One star off because the A/C does not seem to be working there and it was crazy hot.
I'm visiting from Cali and asked the locals the best pizza in Chicago.. And this is it.

This deep dish pizza is really good but is heavy. Got the deep dish pizza with Italian beef. It was really good, my critic to the pizza though is the crust is heavy and with all the sauce and beef it just keeps adding on. But to make up for the crust is the upper crust of the pizza is amazing. They melt cheese on the top crust and it looks burnt but is not and is to die for.

I got mixed recommendations about Chicago's Deep dish pizza. Some of our friends recommended skipping it, others compared it to a heavy casserole. Our friend and host recommended that we try Pequod's Pizzeria. I'm glad that we did!

This Chicago style pizza is deep dish is made with a caramelized cheese crust. So the crust is cheesy-burnt, the bread is light and fluffy and you get a massive amount of sauce and toppings! The small sausage deep-dish easily fed 3 of us (me, K and a friend).

Other than that, the service was great. The setting is bar/pizzeria. There is more seating upstairs. If you reserve with priority seating requests, you cut your wait time in half!

I definitely recommend this style of deep dish!

I knew it would be hard to find a favorite pizza joint with a short trip to Chicago. And I know I still have many more to try. But after many recommendations for this place and trying a hand few pizza joints, this one. Pequod's. Is BESTEST (ok maybe it's tied with Bonci but these are completely different places that  also should both open up in Houston... please?).

I prefer cheesy pizza with a thick yet crispy crust and savory toppings. Toppings like Giardiniera. If you like mildly spicy, tangy type flavors, you better add this stuff because it's a pizza game changer. And just thinking of their lightly burnt caramalized crust makes me want to get back on a plane and Uber straight to pequod's. Great place to spend a Sunday watching football with fantastic pizza and beer.

pics.caption: Sorry. I got too excited and ate half the pizza before bothering with a picture.

review.des:
I ate here while in town and fhe food ans service was great!  Cant wait to
Come back!

You can't beat the $5 lunch deal at the best deep dish pizza spot in the city. While the tourists flock to Lou's and Giordanos, the true Chicagoans know that it's all about the crispy cheesy crust, the savory smooth sauce, and the toppings for days on what can only be described as "crust with the perfect amount of pillowy, bready goodness while still remaining crunchy."

Pequod's is the best. Get there as early as you can to avoid waiting for 3 hours. Call ahead to start your pizza order so you don't have to wait 45 mins once you sit down. And get a side of ranch to dunk your 'za. Trust me on this one.

It looks like a deep dish pizza in pictures, but if the crust is 90% of the thickness, is it a true deep dish? That is exactly what you get with the pan pizza - a thick bread with sauce and toppings on top.. pretty much the opposite of how Gio's and Lou's does it. The worst part was that the toppings were not even cooked (probably because they were sprinkled on top rather than being baked into the pizza). Our mushrooms and onion were basically raw and was pretty nasty to eat tbh. The crust was also badly blackened and had a bad rubbery texture.. we couldn't even eat it.

The Pequods salad is also extremely basic. It's just simple lettuce and onion topped with pepperoni and cheese in the shape of a whale. Not worth the $10.

Sitting in Hinsdale on a Sunday afternoon.
Wife: Oh I could go for some pizza!
Me: Mmmmm, Pequads!
Wife: Yes, but that's so far!
Two hours later (including drive and wait) we had the best pizza in front of us!! Thank you Pequads for existing. Now come to the Southwest suburbs so we can be even more friends.

Yelp
Comments/Thoughts/Opinions/Suggestions:
This is the local spot for pizza in the Windy City! I am a pizza lover so I had to try out this city favorite deep dish pizza.

Food: I thought the pizza was good. The bread was very thick and toppings were all fresh. I do however wish my pizza had more sauce, cheese, and if the crust was more crispy then I think it'd be perfect !

Drinks: Full bar , upstairs and downstairs. This is probably super convenient for when the Cubs play!

Ambiance: Very Chicago feel! I loved it. They have big screen TV's everywhere. They also played awesome music major throwback!

Price: Super Reasonable!!!!!

Location: Perfect, quaint little restaurant right on the outskirts of the city. Definitely a local pizza place.

Parking: Street parking. It's Chi-town  people!

Cool Features: Lots of Tv's. Upstairs and downstairs bar!

Service: Excellent , very helpful and attentive.
Two thumbs up for Pequod's Pizza. Cool little old brick building with a hip vibe. The service awesome.

This place came highly recommended by the staff at the front counter of my hotel, so we gave the a try for pizza, delivery. Well, it took an hour and a half and the crust was burned all the way around. Very disappointed because it was obviously burned and they still opted to deliver it. Try someplace, anyplace, else. Never again. Save yourself the aggravation, get your pizza elsewhere.

The best. This is my favorite deep dish pizza in Chicago and I've lived here 30 years. I've gotten into arguments with people about which is THE BEST (between this and Lou Malnatis) but in those debates Pequads is always part of the discussion. It speaks for itself as you'll always find a line out the door of people waiting to get a table. It's a short wait (and they have a seated indoor place next door you can wait in), but worthwhile one. Definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for good quality Chicago pizza.

Probably one of my favorite deep dish pizza places in Chicago.  It's hard to compare Pequod's to other deep dish joints, since this reminds me more of a pan pizza (which I guess is basically deep dish) but the crust is just different than the chains in Chicago.  The crust is fluffier, spongier, and more like bread than it's chain competitors.

I really like that it's not a chain, locally owned, and there is only one in the city.  On the other hand, this makes getting a table sometimes difficult.  Going on weekdays and off hours helps with this.  Toppings are good, they have other appetizer options, but pizza is the way to go here.  Always been cooked well and never burnt, no complaints.

Pizza- check, sauce- check, carmalized crust - check! This pizza and cornbread crust is to die for. Sometimes the crust can be a little too carmalized but sometimes you get that sweet perfect bite by the crust and its just heaven. One of my fav pizza joints in Chicago.
