pics.caption: Large pan pizza with sausage and giardiniera... soooooo good!

review.des: Awesome Chicago pizza.  We stopped at Girodano's, and while good, didn't quite hit the spot.  Pequod's certainly did!

If ya like Deep Dish this is the place...
I'm a NY Thin Crust guy but when in Rome right..there's lots of choices for deep in Chi-town and I have sampled a handful this is tops only because of the crust, the outer is a glazed burnt cheese wonder...little chewy but its thick crust so go and be hungry

If I ever crave deep dish, this is my go to spot. When I have out of town visitors, I recommend this place over anything else. The pizza is delicious, thick and I dare say JUICY (with cheese). The absolute best part is the crust. It's hard and chewy and delicious. It's so good a lactose intolerant person like me thinks it's worth the pain to come once I'm done. Typically I order sausage for my toppings, but I've also had giardiniera (yum) and green pepper mixed in. It's hard to go wrong.
One or two slices are filling, so this place is great for groups OR for someone that's extremely hungry. Speaking of groups, there is an upstairs space for seating if you have larger parties.
I've also tried their meatball sandwich, tasty, but I wouldn't make a trip out here for that.
The only con is that the wait times are so very long, so this isn't a spot I come to without planning for a wait. Keep in mind, you also have to wait a while for the pizza since it takes a while to make it (like all deep dish). I recommend doing priority seating online, which isn't really a reservation, but it does help with the wait sometimes.

AVOID DELIVERY at all costs...

Let me preface this review by saying that I love Pequod's pizza. It's one of my favorite (if not my favorite) pan pizzas of all time.  However, their delivery is horrendous.  I've ordered delivery about 6 times from Pequods. 3 of those times, there have been major issues with the delivery.

First of all, delivery takes a while. But they're up front about it. I can live with that. The issue comes in when there are problems with the order itself. Usually when someplace makes a mistake, they own up to it and fix the problem as quickly as possible. Pequods does neither of those things. Let me elaborate on this with respect to today/tonight.

From start to "resolution" was almost 5 hours. I placed the order at 4 and was told that the order would come in about 2 hours.  It came in a bit less time. Great!  Unfortunately, the salad I ordered was missing.  I called back and eventually got through to a manager who was fairly dismissive and gave me the choice of voiding the salad or having it delivered. I opted to have it delivered, to which she responded by saying that they were very busy and she wasn't sure when we'd get it.  Ok.  This was 6 pm. Fast forward to 8:45. Still no salad and no update.  So I called back and after waiting for about 10 minutes on hold, I finally got an update. The first salad wasn't made (we knew this otherwise, they would have just brought it).  The second was made but the delivery person forgot it on his way out.  This seemed a bit suspect to me, and of course no one will fess up as to whether the salad ever did exist, but what can you do.  In the end, I got through to another manager who offered comping the salad and a $25 gift card for the a future order. I told her that I wanted the entire bill comped given the trouble I'd had. She said that half the bill was the best she could, and I accepted. I told her that I'd never order from Pequods again, to which she responded ok, we're sorry to lose a customer. It seemed insincere.

Long story short, Pequods needs to improve their delivery significantly.  50% success is not acceptable and no one should feel like they've done something wrong when they haven't. The bill should have been comped.
The best pizza I've had, period! The pan pizza style is delicious. I cannot wait to go back :D
Lou Malnotti's who? You want great pizza, this is where to go! I did take out, so I don't have anything to say about the service or location, but ordering take away was super easy and such a delight!
Great place for a group! We had friends visiting from out of town and we shared two pizzas and two pitchers and everyone paid about $10!
My favorite pizza in Chicago. The cheese lined crust is what sets it apart. Homemade toppings make for an incredible slice.
Dear Pequod's, I love you. Sausage and giardiniera pizza every time. And they have ginger ale fountain soda. Magical place.

Voted best pizza so had to try and I agree....
This is a must go place ... gotta go back again soon
My favorite deep dish pizza in Chicago! They usually have a long wait, so either go early or plan to wait 1+ hours. Worth it though!

We enjoyed the pizza here.  The downfall is it is overly crowded, our table was right in the middle of the restaurant.  The staff was slow and obviously overwhelmed.  The food was good I would stick to carry out for this pizza place

Long wait, less than average burnt taste pizza, horrible slow staff. I was so excited to try but left in much disappointment.

It started as a 20 minute wait that actually was 1.5 hours. Bartender was more interested in getting the single guys number over serving drinks. Then to wait another 50 minutes for bad burnt pizza.

I won't be back.

Five star for sure!

This pizza is amazing.  I find some deep dish style pizzas to be a little much - I'm more of a thin crust guy, but this really hit all the marks for me.  Toppings were plentiful and nicely toasted, crust was absolutely incredible and there was a good overall balance between sauce, cheese, and crust.

I'd go out of my thin crust comfort zone for this any time.

Service was good as pizza places goes, no complaints there whatsoever.  Will definitely be back!

Delivery Review Only! I had a pretty bad experience with Pequod's recently. They delivered the wrong pizza (it was the delivery guy's fault, my name wasn't even on the receipt), I rang them up and they said they'd replace it with the right one. Great, right? The next delivery guy shows up and demanded a $3 delivery fee?!?!? I'm like, dude I already paid that fee for the first pizza and you guys messed it up. He wasn't having it so I told him to take the delivery fee from the other driver who messed up. At the very least, Pequod's could have handled this...

I don't know if it's because I was upset, but as I started in on the new pizza I realized it's pretty much just bread...you don't even really get the carmelized crust with delivery.

I think it's better at the restaurant because they serve it in the pans and the bread it warmer, but I will never order delivery again and I may take a long term pass on the restaurant due to the bothersome interaction.

Chicago has so many options for deep dish or pan pizza, but that caramelized cheese crust sets Pequod's apart from everywhere else. I usually like to save my crust for last to dip into whatever fallen toppings are on the plate, but that crust is just too good to wait. Eating at Pequod's means that you may wait for 45+ minutes for a table, but fresh in the restaurant is the best way to eat it. I've ordered it for pick and delivery and while it's good, it doesn't stand to the excellence of dining in.

Their sauce is so well seasoned, the crust is crispy and they have fun toppings to choose from (pineapple, variety of olives... what can I say, I'm easy to please) and it even tastes good reheated. Waiting to dine in or delivery can be a little tedious, but once you're eating that pizza it's easy to forgive and forget.

Pequod's is a vessel filled with crispy, cheesey, gooey, oily goodness and my mouth is Moby Dick and I'm gonna destroy and consume everyone and everything on board.

Stellar deep dish and different than the typical giordanos, Gino's, and Lou's. The crust here is different, and the sausage is made in house apparently. These differentiating factors make the pizza here unbelievably tasty and heavy! Great with a refreshing beer to wash it down. I also like starting with a salad, and their house salad is a great starter to the meal. Even super crowded on a Monday afternoon, so that tells you something about their delicious pizza.

I wasn't a big fan of the service though I have to admit. This is probably the only reason pequod's isn't a five star joint for me, but excellent pizza and vibes nonetheless!

Visited here for the first time with my daughter lastnight for a half order of bbq wings (I'd get a full order next time), medium thin crust sausage and pepperoni pizza, and a Miller Lite. It's a no frills place with great service. Although it was almost 11pm, the atmosphere was great for families and couples alike. The pizza was delicious! I'll definitely return if I'm in the area!

Awesome pizza. Worth the wait and you will wait. Even with a reservation.

Recommendation: bar seat. Great service and no wait! I mean, you still wait 45 min for your deep dish, but that's a given!

When in... Chicago, you must try a deep dish pizza. It is my first go at a Chicago style pizza & my friend picked the best place that offers generous portions of toppings, cheese & red sauce. We kept our pie simple with 2 toppings: mushroom & sausage. A good decision because the pie with 1 inch of all it's goodness was rich in flavor & filling after one slice. I can also taste the fresh ingredients, which makes this pizza a standout as well.

pics.caption: About an inch of saucey goodness!

review.des: I went to this place on a recommendation knowing how good deep dish pizza is in Chicago, we had to try it. It was a great experience, however, we tried the traditional deep dish pizza and some appetizers. The pizza was very good, but our wings came out cold and soggy. We sent them back and they apologized and gave us new ones. They didn't comp us, and the wings came out 20 minutes after we sent them back, so by the time we got them back, the pizza was coming out too so it was annoying. The food still tasted great, just disappointed on how it all went!

Whenever you're home in sweet old
Chicago, you gotta go 45 min out of whichever way you are coming from to get that goodness that is the caramelized crust that is Peaquods. I tell everyone about this place if they are visiting our fine city because it's that good.
I came with high expectations! The pizza was ok but was not mind-blowing. I tried their original and added ground beef & veggies.

This is the place where we take all of out of town guests, and every single person loves it and hasn't been disappointed. Great take out, and the pizza is unbelievable. Be prepared to wait, it's well worth it!

You've got to be kidding me.
Fucking seriously. LOL this "pizza" is a joke.
This place deserves negative one star.

I hate writing bad reviews because these establishments have real people working to make a living. But I am appalled by the number of fake positive reviews and inflated rating.
None of these people here who give good reviews of this place have probably ever had real good pizza.

I don't get the raving great reviews and horribly regret going here. Of all the good places to go eat, we went here and had to go out of our way to get here, in hopes the pizza would be delicious. It took us a 30 minute drive from downtown to come to this rickety area. That is usually a good sign but not for this place.

There was a very slim layer of cheese on the pizza. It was 90% bread, 9.99% sauce and maybe close to 1 % of actual cheese. It tasted more like a burnt garlic bread, minus the good flavor. I shouldve went to the grocery store and bought some Texas toast. Would've been worth it more than this atrocious round bread.

Please take a look at my pictures of the pie we received. It looks nothing like a pizza. And tastes nothing like one.

To make a long story short: the waitress was so dismissive and oblivious half the time. She forgot we needed to order ( you have one job) then tried to be abnormally fake, extra sweet to our toddler. So much so that even he said he didn't want to be there.
The atmosphere was more like a pub or bar. It reeked of stale liquor and was dark, and cramped. Such a joke. Not to mention THE 40 MINUTES IT TOOK TO MAKE IT.

40 minutes??? To burn some bread?? LOL. okay.

You want pizza???? Real nice, thick, cheesy, goey, delicious pizza??? Go to colorado and try the pizza at Old Chicago.
I guess the famous "chicago" pizza is only good by it's name, not by the actual location.

pics.caption: Pizza? Where is the cheese??!?!?! This is 5 inches of nothing but burnt, soggy bread.

review.des: Damn good pizza, I'll be coming here for life.

Not sure about all of the rough reviews, because Pequod's was amazing! We ended up here late on a Saturday night after the Patriots game ended from Tripoli's tavern. It was our first night in Chicago so we were looking for a deep dish fix and thankfully Pequod's had late night hours to accommodate us. Service was top notch from the moment we stepped in until we left. Our waitress was friendly and peppy and explained the menu, jumping us right to the page with the deep dish (she knew) and explaining how many servings/pieces each size of pizza was (whether you would have leftovers or not). She also indicated the 'wait time' as some are calling it or how long it takes them to make you an amazing pizza. Geez, people. We opted for the small pan pizza with pepperoni, jalapeño and Italian sausage and an order of cheese bread with homemade, I repeat HOMEMADE marinara. The marinara was amazing and the bread was also pretty great and came out quick after our order was taken. The wait for the pizza was probably less than what was quoted to us.  The pizza--came served hot, oh so delicious and flavorful. We loved the burnt, crisp crust, a different spin on deep dish. The Italian sausages were ginormous and it was stacked with pepperoni (worth that extra charge per topping). I was only sad that I couldn't finish my pizza in one sitting. And, prices were so reasonable-our bill was under $30. We also had Gino's on this trip, and while a classic staple of Chicago, it didn't compare to the food quality received at Pequod's. I would love to try them again next time I am in town.

It was okay. I'm a Chicago native and their restaurant was an average sports-related jock place with fairly good pizza. I wasn't super impressed the way some people are. But some people are also garbage. I must stress that I did not DISLIKE this place, but it also was not interesting or wildly unique. It brings the Southwest side -- where I grew up (by Midway) --to the Northside, which is why I posit that people up here love it and think it's amazing. Whereas it's just the same stuff I grew up with.

Looking for good deep dish? Pequods is the best hands down. The carmelized cheese crust is amazing. Its what I reccomend to all our out of town guests.  However, go during lunch and avoid the long wait for the dinner rush.

If you want Chicago style deep dish (not from a chain) GO TO PEQUOD'S!

We went to a Cubs game and wanted to grab some pizza after while we were in town. We happened to be with someone from Chicago who told us about Pequod's...as we were planning on going to a different place. So happy we changed our mind and went to Pequod's.

It was a Friday night so we knew we would have to wait...luckily our friend called ahead and put our names down for call ahead seating. We ended up only waiting about 10 minutes for our table of 4.

We got a large pan pizza...half pepperoni half italian beef and hot giardiniera. I don't normally like thick crusted pizza, but this pie was amazing. I also have never had giardiniera before - and that was life changing!

We had unfortunate car trouble that kept us from going back home to MKE, so we did an intensive search to find Chicago pizza on Christmas Day! We were happy to find that this very popular place was open so late at night. It was pretty late (maybe already 10pm), so we were only picking up, but inside it was surprisingly very busy! I think the staff were surprised too at how many people would be coming out on a cold Christmas night! We thoroughly enjoyed solid Chicago style pizza with their "carmelized" crust. Very filling on a cold Christmas night. Would definitely look to try again and consider braving the Wait to sit down.

I understand taste and preference is an individual experience, but I have had better pizza.  I prefer Due and that type of crust.

Don't get me wrong, the pizza was good, it's the management that is a problem.  My assistant booked a reservation for me and a few clients - one just in from Scotland that very day.  We arrived 20 minutes early.  We were told we would probably not be seated for more than an hour.  When we pressed that we had a reservation, we were told that we were put on a list, but the seating time is not guaranteed.  I assure you, this was not communicated when the "reservation" was made.  An hour later, we were still seated outside, waiting.  My assistant called and asked to speak to the manager (I didn't force her or anything, she was upset with the whole situation - I had also talked to the management myself).  The manager told her we were not there. She had to describe what we were wearing.  Now, the manager had already been outside, called our party's name and we replied accordingly.  He walked back inside.  So, he knew we were there, told my assistant we weren't and it was officially an issue.  Twenty minutes later, the manager came out, said he was sorry for the confusion, assigned blame to my assistant and we were seated.  Unless you have all day to wait or just don't mind, Pequod's has tasty pizza.   Personally, the management's ruined the experience and we won't be back.

Solid deep dish option. A little less thick than other varieties in the area but just as food. The charred crust is definitely the most note-worthy part of the pizza. The small is huge and sauce is delicious. The anchovies are good with salty goodness. The best part is they deliver pretty far. Pequod's is a great option for late night eats. But give yourself an hour and half for sure if delivery.

I was visiting from out of town and was so excited to try "deep dish pizza". Unfortunately I won't be back. My order was just okay. I wasn't moved. The order took a long time but that's good to know it's freshly made. The caramelized crust is unique  but the pizza was way too bready and more more on the dry side not enough sauce but I did like the thin crust pizza better. Customer service was really good and the place was cozy! Really appreciated the buss boy who brought out our pizza and cut it and put it on a plate for us.
Among the best.  You must like dough to enjoy the pizza because it is thick and crispy at the same time.  Not too much cheese which lightens it a bit.

Absolutely amazing Pan Pizza. This won't be considered a deep dish pizza, so Lou Malnati's and Giardanos are different types of pizzas. But this is by far the best pizza in town. The service was great. Prices are very reasonable. $5 for a personal pizza with a drink. It was definitely Filling. If your in the city, Pequod's is a must. You wont be disappointed

Family and I went on a Wednesday.   Busy busy busy
Good:   Pizza was good hot and had a nice flavor

Bad: was not able to preorder said it wouldn't.  Help w/ wait.   Once we got in we placed order.    Waited about 40 min.   To get sat.  Then pizza took about 35 min.    Ther was a major screw up.   As 3 tables sat after us and. Got pizzas around same time.
When we asked about the status of our order it came out

Side note :   Pizza was not good next day
Won't go again
This place was awesome! If you are looking for some great deep dish pizza, check them out!

I had high hopes for this place, but I was very disappointed. I'll start with the pros. I liked the ambiance, it's a kind of a hole in the wall place. We came at an odd time, linner, so we were seated immediately. I ordered a personal size pan pizza with an array of veggies. It really didn't have a lot of flavor and the crust didn't seem all the way done. I don't know maybe it was a bad experience, but it's not the most convenient place for us to go to so I honestly don't see us going back.

The atmosphere is very casual and local. You are welcomed with pretty friendly service. They are nice and patient. The pizza is less doughy and saucy compared to all the other deep dish pizzas. The sauce isn't as tangy. The sleeper here is the meatballs. They are some of the most tender meaty goodness that I have had. The sauce that they come with is rich in flavor and had a subtle smoky flavor to it.
I would definitely describe this pizza as Detroit pan over Chicago deep dish. Good pizza, but if you want true layered cheesy Chicago deep dish goodness go to Giordano's.

This is one of our favourite pizza joints in the city. But good lord! They got a guy working on the 2nd floor who smells worse than a rotting corpse. I'm so glad I ordered a pizza with garlic to help mask that stench when he walked by. Pretty sure I took 5 years off my life from inhaling. And our server never got me a refill.

Don't get me wrong, this is a great pizza joint and I'll continue to come back.
Best deep dish I've had thus far. CanNOT beat the lunch special! Would definitely recommend.
I used to think numero unos pizza was best till i had a pizza at pequads Amazing! and staff was great, when in town its a MUST!!!!!

Truly in love with their Chicago style pizza. The crunchy edges, delicious sauce (we get extra), great ingredients. The best dough. Our craving for it takes us there often!

Totally a no frills place that is always busy. We go for lunch a lot, on weekdays, to avoid the lines and crowds. Also the individual pan pizza lunch special on weekdays can't be beat.

Only suggestion to them would be to put more spinach on for the spin topping. After the bake, you don't see much at all.

pics.caption: Pepperoni & spinach, extra sauce and light cheese!
Pepperoni & spinach, extra sauce and light cheese!

review.des:
Not a fan of the atmosphere,  tv's, sports bar, sometimes too much dumb male meatheads.   But food is fantastic!!!!  Great pizza.  Try any!   Salads top notch.  
Not  a fan of high stool tables.  Recommend getting a booth.  
Sometimes super busy and slow service, but I have patience and its worth the wait.

No, it's not technically Chicago deep dish, it's pan pizza. But it's so much better! The caramelized crust is perfection. You honestly don't need more than 2 slices or you'll be down for the count.

There will always be a wait. It's just how it is!
Perfect crust on an amazing deep dish pan.so glad we picked this over the chains. Could not be better.

pics.caption: Perfect personal pan pepperoni jalapeno & sausage

review.des:
Decided to go visit the Pequod on North Clybourn Avenue after the movies. The host began to lead us to the upstairs section. I requested to be seated downstairs since my boyfriend couldn't walk up the steep, what appeared to be at least a 20 step staircase. The host refused and began to explain that they were only seating guests upstairs since they wanted to give the wait staff a final rush. 

The restaurant had PLENTY of open seating in the lower level. Upon requesting for the manager, the manager sternly said this is a regular procedure. 

After discussing several options with the manager on-duty. He finally agreed to let us sit at the bar, place an order and wait for his server downstairs to get off of her 20 minute break before moving to a table on the main level. 2 minutes after sitting at the bar, looking over the menu. Another handful of guests began to trickle into the restaurant. After another minute, he screamed "Busy (another hostess's name), take them to table 7." Three additional groups after us were immediately guided to seats on the lower level. WTF. 

Aren't restaurants in business to serve customers and maximize efficient table turns? Perhaps this place needs to reconsider their 'policies'. 

Here is my point. You had open seats with at least 12 tables open, why couldn't your patrons who clearly expressed the inability to walk up the flight of stairs not be accommodated. All this angst was uncalled for and has made this visit most likely my last visit.

I've ordered from them a few times, and I like the "caramelized crust" they are known for - but in general, I think the crust is too much bread.  It still all tastes good & you can tell they use good quality ingredients, but I'd only get it if my friends want this one in particular these days.

I was prepared for a wait, so when I called for delivery and was quoted an hour and a half, I was cool with that. 2 1/2 hours and multiple phone calls later, our pizza arrived.

And if the pizza was amazing, the wait would have been mostly forgiven. But it was not amazing. I'm sure the fact that it had been sloshing around in a warming bag in the delivery guy's car for an hour didn't help, but the pizza sucked. The bottom crust was super thick, super flavorless, and a mysterious combo of crumbly and mushy. The sauce and the sausage were good, but the rest of the toppings were generic, boring, and in the case of the garlic, still super raw.

If you have to eat here, I'd recommend eating in the restaurant, but I've had significantly better pizza at a number of other Chicago places, so I'd give this one a miss.

Oh the caramelized crust!!!...Honestly my favorite pizza ever, anywhere. It differs from the traditional deep dish pizzas found elsewhere in the city. More along the lines of pan style that must be attacked by knife and fork.

Having been to the Pequod's in Morton Grove originally. I fell in love. So when it was time to visit my family for the holidays. This was my first stop immediately leaving the airport. I've been craving it for over a year since my move to San Diego. And it did not disappoint.

We got my go-to deep dish with pepperoni, sausage and jalapeno. The cheese gets crispy and caramelized along the edge providing that crunch to go with the soft dough and buttery pie-like bottom crust. The toppings are plentiful and savory.
Super long wait, but the deep dish is great. Probably my favorite in Chicago to be honest.
Thought is place was ok compared to other deep dish. I prefer Giodarno's. Our pizza was a bit burnt. Other ppl really like this place though. Leftovers actually tasted better the next day.

No restaurant is more overrated in the city than Pequod's. Growing up down the street, knowing people that have worked there, and even dating a die-hard fan, I just don't get it. Thick, heavy, BURNT and dry are all of the textures and qualities I get from Pequod's. Long waits, loud angry suburban patrons and rude waiters trudge through the hype to an expensive, and unpleasant dining experience. Last time I made the mistake of visiting we tried some wings, which, alike the pizza, were dry and disappointing. The had the added bonus of having a generic taste to them as well.

For me, even the chains like Uno and Lous beat Pequod's, but Exchequer will always have my heart.
Here. For. It.  Best deep dish in the city.  No question.  Don't believe me, don't go (more for me and mine).
10/10 Will return. Grew up eating Pequods in MG with the lovely lady in all the photos hung on the walls. Viva la Foof. Love you CKB.

Good pizza, good prices, good service. I'm not wild about the burnt crust, but I know good deep dish when I have it, and this is good. There's definitely better deep dish out there, but Pequod's fulfills my constant deep dish craving.

I've only had the deep dish here twice but, both times walked away very satisfied! Ingredients were plentiful (sausage, mushroom, spinach) and although the crust is quite thick, I did enjoy the "burnt" cheese edges.

This pie is probably not for everyone but, judging by the daily packed house and people waiting in line, they are doing something right.

Kids got the thin pizza as well and that was very good too. Service was average but, overall no complaints. Seating was a challenge, especially if you have any large people in your group but, manageable.

Overall, a good place to get a little different spin on Chicago deep dish pie!!

Pequod's chooses to focus on crust over cheese. This deep dish pizza has a biscuit like buttery crust that is covered with a thinner layer of sauce and cheese than competing deep dish stores. Their signature caramelized crust is actually a layer of cheese on the outside side edge and is fantastic, albeit a little burnt. But no complaints from me, huge fan of burnt cheese. Wait can be long, but there is a nice bar next door that you can grab a drink while waiting. Still a thin crust pizza fan at heart but enjoyed the change of style for the evening.

This was crazy. 4 hours for delivery and couldn't get a response other than traffic, meanwhile there's 3 different ways to get where I was. When I tried calling, I could get to speak with someone. Noticed there's a trend from other comments on here about delivery service.

While visiting from the east coast and being disappointed by the other well known deep dish (Lou M...), this was just as disappointing. Maybe because it took forever, it was soggy and not crispy, but either way, so doughy. While flavorful, it wasn't worth it IMO...

Usually, the wait is quite long to be seated. I recommend coming during the weekdays because we were seated right away. Reservations are not allowed but you can call ahead. They inform you ahead of time that pizza takes 40 minutes to be served, which was pretty accurate. My friend and I ordered a small pan pizza with pepperoni, jalapeños, and extra cheese. The small comes with 4 total slices which was plenty for both of us to share. My friend wanted the extra cheese which was a good call because it made the pizza taste that much better. The pepperoni was well seasoned and crispy around the edges just how I like it. The caramelized crust can be a hit or miss. Half of the pizza was caramelized perfectly but the other half was pretty burnt making it hard to eat. It's a great place to try if you want to try other pizza besides Giordano's and Lou's.

Ok, so after what must have been a year of planning, procrastinating and failing to get into this place for dinner, a group of us finally braved the wait, the 50-minute pizza prep time and went in.

The good - the pan pizza (we got pepperoni with pepperoncini) was REALLY EXCELLENT. Long after my stomach was overfull with the pizza my taste buds were still craving for yet another slice. Seems like a sure way to pick up some serious weight...

The less good - the service is somewhat rough. There seemed definitely to be a feeling of "we're so good and so popular that we'll do what we want, treat you how we want to and if you don't like it there are a 100 people waiting behind you". Yes, yes, you're good and popular and all, but service is still supposed to matter. This is the only reason for my not giving 5 stars. I hope they pay more attention to that.

Still a great experience.

The best deep dish pizza in Chicago hands down. Their burnt cheese crust is amazing. Be prepared for a wait almost any time you go in. It's very popular since they only have one location near downtown.

Here is how I would compare it to the competition. Pequod's is the best overall. Giordano's has the best quality cheese. And Lou Malnati's has the best sausage pizza. Chicago Oven Grinders is another unique beast of its own that's definitely worth trying. Avoid Gino's East if you can.

Delicious deep dish pizza that's worth the 45 minute bake time. The sauce is tangy, delicious, and not too salty, and the crust is perfectly thick but crispy. I make sure to go to Pequod's every time I visit Chicago because I always crave a half sausage, half spinach pizza.

Unfortunately, the second time we went, our pizza came out a little lukewarm, and the cheese wasn't hot enough to be oozing out and stretchy. Nonetheless, the flavors were as consistent as the first time we visited, and we left satisfied.

So, I had an appetite for pizza and decided to visit Pequod's. Words can't convey how delectable my food tasted. The waitress was extremely professional, friendly, and energetic. She exuded a contagious energy that brightened my day. The drinks, on the other hand, were weak and nothing to brag about. Overall, i'd highly recommend. 5 stars for food and 3 stars for the drinks.

pics.caption: small deep dish and regular pan pizza

review.des: Order the deep dish To Go and the pizza was 95% all crust-very little cheese and sauce. It was good but due to the overwhelming amount of crust I would have to say this is my least favorite Chicago deep dish pizza. My first experience was dine in and we loved it so not sure if dine in vs pickup is the difference.  Are they skimping on the cheese and the sauce totally or only pickup?  The whole group was disappointed and especially me for suggesting.
I always love the pizza here. It's the way the cheese caramelizes to that cast iron pan. I think they should come up with a pizza that as all edges like one of those brownie pans. I'm a genius!

One Star delivery service

My buddy and I had one of the most terrible pizza deliveries ever last night. Pizza came 20 min late after a 1.5 hr original estimate, so nearly two hours wait which we were both totally prepared for to get an excellent pizza.

When the pie finally did arrive, the bottom of the box was completely soggy as if it had been resting in a puddle for an hour and the delivery driver offered some free cheese bread as a consolation. In most cases we probably wouldn't even have eaten it, but we were starving and out $45 so we are it. It was disgustingly soggy as you can imagine.

We'll never order delivery here again and I don't recommend any one else does either. Damn shame because the place can put out a damn good pizza (or at least they used to)

I'm not a huge fan of deep dish/Chicago-style pizza; I'll never deny that much.

That said, when in Chicago . . . yeah.
It's a Chicago thing.

And if you're in Chicago, it's downright blasphemous to NOT stop in for pizza at Pequod's. PERIOD.

I'd rather come here than take my chances at Lou Malnati's any day of the week. Damn skippy.

Try the giardiniera. Be sure, too, to try simply onion and garlic together. (Really good stuff!) I always just get half and half -- half giardiniera and half onion/garlic.

Why bother with garlic bread and Buffalo wings, for fuck's sake? This is a PIZZA joint, and you're here to eat (deep dish, Chicago-style) PIZZA.

A salad? Maybe -- to start.
A cold beer? Absolutely -- that's almost a given.
But all this other food on the menu? Meh.

P.S.: Both locations are loud and crowded, but, hey, that's a GOOD sign.

P.P.S.: The website sucks -- looks like they paid a college kid to put it together on GoDaddy.

P.P.S.: You're not going for romantic seclusion, nor to look at a website, crappy or not. The food's damn good, and THAT'S what you go to Pequod's for.

I had bad stomachache and diarrhea after eating there. Pizza was ok, not impressive, BBQ wings were terrible, covered with sticky sauce and very salty. The wings are probably the reason I had diarrhea, because my husband didn't have it and he's fine.

Edit: The restaurant reached me back and apologized to me with good attitude

Best pizza in Chicago hands down!!
If I could give more then 5 stars I would - it's that good.

Whenever I'm craving a good pizza, this is my go to spot.

From the in house special sauce to the  caramelized crust and the crisp yet airy dough, this pizzas got it all.

Personal favorite toppings - giardiniera + basil

Make sure you eat it there as the crust has a 15 min tasty life otherwise gets soggy and need to put back in the oven.

This place gets crowded on thursdays and weekends.

Also the Lincoln park location is much better then the Morton grove location.

I wish they opened one up in the western burbs, but until then, I'll be coming to the city often.

First bite is yummy, 1 slice is good, but no more after that.

Got a medium with 3 toppings and a pitcher of blue moon.
Couldn't finish the medium pizza among 3 people.

I will start by saying I was overly hyped for this pizza so maybe that's why I put it at 3.5 stars. We got there and there were told it was a 45 minute wait for pizza once you ordered it. Cool, thats what I expected. We were meeting a friend who lives in Chicago (we were in town from Houston) We were put on a wait and given a pager to notify us when a table was ready. After 20 minutes we went back to find out how much longer because if it was going to be 20-30+ more we were going to go next door and have some drinks to pass time. They told us 10 minutes. Finally at 20 minutes we asked again and they already had us marked off even though our pager never went off and we had moved from outside, to inside the door because it was windy. They were able to get us seated promptly.  We ordered drinks. I ordered a gin martini, and yes I know its a pizza place so i wont complain that it wasn't great, thats on me. The beers I had to follow were cold. The salad we ordered was fresh and the dressing was really great. The appetizer combo was good (fried zucchini was my favorite) Then...our pizza. The cheese crust beautiful thing I had been waiting for since I saw it on tv some time ago. The gentleman that brought it out was courteous and asked if he could serve the first slice and we accepted. The pizza looked great. It just didn't taste as great as I thought it would. I have had other Chicago pizzas, and although this one wasn't bad...it wasn't my favorite.  I felt like there could be a little less breading, with more sauce and toppings. The cheese crust was good but not as flavorful as I was expecting either. I dont think my review should keep anyone away, because I was overall happy with the visit. I just hope people realize this pizza needs a deep dish to fit all that crust in it.

Sorry but pequod's lost their recipe when the millenials took over in the kitchen. I remember it being way better. Thin crust was actually thin and the sauce was really good. Nothing to brag about. I went there the other day with a friend and took a lot of shots for it not being the awesome pizza everyone rants and raves over. And how about some air conditioning when its Florida weather. Dont just open up the front door. I know people are drunk but it's still hot asf!

Walked in super excited to end my Chicago trip on a bang with Pequods as my last stop so I was SUPER bummed out when I walked in with my 3 friends and all our bags and the HOST who could've been the owner glared at me, looked at the Yankees hat I was wearing, signaled with his body that we were clearly in a Chicago bar, and moodily showed us to our seats.

??? I was so thrown off by the lack of hospitality. I get city pride and I'm all about that as well.

Other Than that, 4.95  is a great lunch deal. Pizza was good. Our waitress was nice. But I wouldn't come here again.

This was my first time eating deep dish pizza and o boy was I impressed. I came on a Saturday afternoon and there was no wait. When I thought about deep dish pizza, I thought that it would be a thin crust surrounding the pan filled with sauce and cheese. However, there is more crust than I had imagined and it is so light and fluffy, which is something I had never experienced when eating pizza. There was just the right amount of sauce, cheese, and they didn't overdo it with the toppings. It wasn't that oily either, which is unlike the pizza I have had in New York. I loved it especially the cheese that crisped up on the side of the cast iron pan. My friend and I got a large pizza with sausage and pepperoncini on one side and pineapple and Canadian bacon on the other (don't judge my friend really likes pineapple on pizza). If you like spice, definitely get pepperoncini. We could not finish the large even though we wanted to and would get a medium next time. This is a must try if you are like me and have never been to Chicago before!

pics.caption: Large pizza with sausage and pepperoncini on one side and pineapple and Canadian bacon on the other

review.des: BEST PAN PIZZA IN CHICAGO. Worth the wait! Sit down, order a beer, and wait for the magic that is about to become your best pizza experience in Chicago.

My favorite Chicago pizza joint by far. I skip out on the flashy tourist joints like Lou Malnati's every time I come back to the city, and head straight here instead. The numerous positive reviews are accurate, very homey down-to-earth midwestern vibes. The caramelized pan crust is phenomenal, I appreciate it when places focus as much of their effort on the crust as they do for the toppings.  Simple, and great quality. Service was efficient and very nice.

I'd have to say, on our trip to Chicago, I was most looking forward to Pequod's but it did not deliver as hoped.  The environment was great and what you want from a local deep dish place.  The staff was great and the some of the other items we ordered (hot wings, cheesesticks, garlic cheese bread) were all good but the pizza fell short.  It was dry (lack of sauce and over cooked crust) and just not that amazing.  Went to Lou M's later in the trip and it wasn't even close, shockingly.  Lou's dominated.
One of the best pizza places in Chicago by far. The carmelized crust is so tasty and the sauce is great. I love going there and even ordering it to go.
Never a bad experience. It's a little tight inside but the pizza is so worth it. Everything about the crust is amazing!

I had guests over on a Sunday night and had called the night before to place the order. On Sunday morning, I called to remove a pizza as some guests were not going to be able to stop by. The pizza was supposed to come at 7pm, it did not come until 8. By that time the crust was extremely soggy and the pizza was lukewarm.

When the driver handled me the receipt, it still listed all three pizzas (and the price for 3) despite the fact that he only had the two. He assured me that they were working on the refund for the pizza I asked them to remove. A few days later the charge posted and didn't reflect the refund so I called to ask. The manager assured me the refund should post by Friday and told me to wait. I checked today and no refund had posted.

I called again today and the manager informed me that no one on their end had worked on a refund nor put any notes about a refund in the system. He first incorrectly told me that ordered 4 pizzas and received 3, which was not the case. After needing to walk him through it, he finally initiated what I hope to be an actual refund. This should not have taken this many calls and due diligence on my end to remedy their mistake. Extremely unprofessional, don't waste your time here. Get Lou's instead.
Service, wait and taste of pizza has all changed for the worse. There is better out there. This place used to be awesome. What a shame!
Not really impressed. We were seated upstairs. It was really hot. I mean no A/C hot. Service was good but pizza was just ok.

We went to Pequod's after a bodybuilding competition, which means that it's time to pig out and see how fast you can go from ripped to fat again. That would probably sound cooler if I was the actual bodybuilder, but it was actually my friend so instead it was time to pig out and see how fast I could go from fat to fatter.

The servers were über-friendly and the pizza arrived in stages but looked great. We ordered pizzas with peppers and sausage, mushrooms and ham and even a basic pepperoni thin crust pizza  for the annoying, picky guy (me). I inhaled my entire pizza and thankfully, the servers were gracious with the coke refills to keep my momentum going.

The other kids at the table ordered and devoured the bruschetta in record time and everyone seemed to love their pizza.

I'm from New York and not a fan of deep dish Chicago style which is why I ordered a thin crust pie. It also explains my pizza snobbery and why I'd be unwilling to grant five stars to anything that didn't knock my socks off. But again, this is good pizza. Great atmosphere. Lots of TVs and friendly folks.

Next time I'm in town, as my favorite bodybuilder would say: I'll be back.
Amazing pizza, made to order, the service was awesome. The food was too delicious. Cheese melted running down is one satisfactory factor of eating pizza.
The pizza was great, especially the crust which was super crispy. I loved the environment and will come back soon.

Sometimes, this place is easily 5/5 and some of the best deep dish in the city. Other times...well...not so much. I've had experiences here where the crust was so perfect and crispy, and the pizza was perfect. I've also had the reverse where the pizza seemed almost soggy. I will keep coming back chasing that 5/5 experience though.

I love the pizza here. It's unlike your typical deep dish pizzas in this city. Caramelized crust and fresh veggies are on point!

This was until I dined in . . . Within 5 minutes of sitting down I felt like I was working in the kitchen and making the pizzas myself. Soooo hot in there! On top of that, I had to sit in this heat for over an hour waiting on my pizza. And I wasn't the only one. My poor server was SWEATING to the point where I thought her perspiration was going to drop on my pizza when it finally came. She was cute though

In all, love the pizza but can this place invest in some AC? Judging by how busy it is, I know they can afford it. I'll come back in the winter when I need to warm up.

Yes.....a Chicago institution. Real pizza, not tomato soup on a cracker. Thick and juicy, the crust is heaven.

Try it, you'll like it
Service was great! I recommend ordering an appetizer because the pizza will take some time but is definitely worth the wait! Really loved the atmosphere here!
Visiting from out of town, Pequod's was recommended to us. This pizza was one of my favorite meals ever! The only thing I didn't like, was that I was too full to eat a second slice.
Great pizza, great garlic cheese bread, great drinks, but there's a tiny sink in the upstairs bathroom which is super weird....great other than that!!!!

Honestly, I could write forever about this pizza ... but why bother. Let me state categorically that I HATE Chicago pizza.

Having said that, my Chicago-style pepperoni, sausage and hot pepper pizza was without question one of the best pizzas I have had in my life. Absolutely insane!!!!!

Forget ALL the other Chicago big names for pizza .... I have had them all and there is not even anything remotely close.

I really could write in great detail, but it would not be enough. See my photos ....

pics.caption: Perfect slice ... the cheese is not burned ... this is how to make a pizza!  Kudos to the chef.
Pepperoni, sausage and hot peppers .... whatever you order ... do NOT forget the sausage.

review.des:
Thank you so much for Friday Night...
this place is a class act & excellent pizza..
we had some nypd guys with us.. Although
they were like a fish out of water with
Real Pizza, they still give great reviews..
Once again
Thank you....

If you don't already know this place, you're obviously not from chicago.  It's an institution unlike any other here. While it's not my favorite Chicago pizza, the pan is super tasty. Burnt cheese + crispy bottom + bready crust = satisfaction. Don't be alarmed by the apparent size of the restaurant - it has 2 floors and seats a lot more than you realize.

Scale 1-10 of how good their pizza is... I would say 7. It's nothing life changing but it is worth the wait. I would say top 5 favorite pizza places in the city. I wouldn't consider their pizza traditional deep dish but it is a solid pan pizza. The wait staff was great! Overall great experience.

This place is a classic and among the best in Chicago.  Forget the big names in the deep dish game, this spot is it and it's legit.   There's always a wait but it's worth it and Drinking Bird Bar is a good place to hang while waiting.  The inside of pequads pays homage to Chicago sports and Blackhawks.
Their pan pizza is a perfect blend of ingredients baked to gooey, cheesy and flavorful perfection.  Crust is crispy and buttery.  See what the hype is about!

Of course I had to stop by a deep dish pizza joint when in Chicago! We came around 10pm on a Fri night and waited around 20min. Our server told us that it would take around 45 min for the pizza to cook but ours came out in about 30min. We got a small 10" pizza with Italian beef, onion, and spinach. This was the perfect size for two people because it gave each of us two huge pieces that really made us so full!! I mean, unbuckle your belt full..
I loved the crispy crust and red sauce. The cheese was super gooey that when we took our first bite, it was all stringy! All in all, it was a great deep dish pizza. It didn't blow my mind but it left me feeling satisfied!
The lunch special is amazing! $4.95 for a personal pizza. You can add a salad for only $2.50 more and it comes with a drink. Pizza is really delish!!

One of the trademarks of Chicago cuisine is its deep dish pizza. While the origins are unclear, deep dish has been a critical defining element of Chicago food for decades, and every time I visit Chicago, I am compelled to go to at least one deep dish pizzeria.

Having tried Giordano's and Lou Malnati's in the past, I decided to give Pequod's a try. Located in Lincoln Park, it was rather out of the way of everything else I wanted to do (namely sightseeing in the Loop, and shopping in Chinatown), but I wanted to try it at least once.

At the time of writing this review, the base price for a large deep dish is around $18 with no toppings, and then about $2.50 for each additional topping. When it comes to pizza, I like to have many toppings, so I got pepperoni, sausage, Canadian bacon, tomatoes, mushrooms, onions, and green peppers. I shared the pizza with 3 other people.

I felt that for my appetite, I should have shared the pizza with 4 others instead of 3. The pizza is very thick and filled with toppings. I only managed to eat a single slice - though I did have one piece of garlic cheese bread before that (fairly standard as far as that flavor went). The pizza was perfect deep dish - the crust was crunchy, the cheese was layered and thick, and the toppings all blended together nicely.

One of the downsides of deep dish, I feel, is that it's not nearly as good when delivered, because of how thick the pizza is. The pizza gets soggy quickly, and towards the end of the meal I already started to feel the cheese start to be more solid and not as tasty. The trade off is that deep dish, when eaten fresh, is incredibly rich and full of flavors.

There are different schools of thought as to whether or not deep dish is "real pizza" - some say that pizzas are meant to be more flat and meant to be a nice balance of 50% crust and 50% toppings, whereas others would say pizza is pizza as long as the ingredients are there. Regardless of the case, I do feel deep dish is an incredibly unique way to experience pizza, and it is honestly my preferred way of eating pizza. Pequod's ranks easily as the best deep dish I've had yet, and may be one of the best pizzas I've ever had.

Once again, the magic of yelp has led me to glory. This place is excellent. Unlike the super deep dish (Also delicious) at other local places, this pan style is equally tasty but less filling (therefore more pizza gets ingested).

Maybe the highlight, is that its more of a local gem and not massively crowded like the big deep dish venues. I would recommend!

This wasn't my first visit to Pequod's, I came back because I had a craving. We walked in, talked to the host, who told us it was an hour and a half wait and then once you order your pizza after you sit down, another 40 minutes. We walked past her and immediately 2 seats opened up at the bar, we sat down and ordered right away. Pro tip - always look for bar seats! The pizza was a little disappointing this time around. We got a medium deep dish, half cheese half sausage. The sauce was more tomato-y than I remember, and the pizza seemed a little underdone. Maybe it was just an off night. The pequods salad was good though, with the homemade Italian and homemade ranch dressings.

Number "1" in my book you can taste each flavor, pan pizza w/carmelize cheese, what a treat, little slow on service but not bad. This dive bar is worth it!
It's her first time 9/22/17 yum

The service was great. Cheesy garlic bread was good but probably would not order it again. The cheese pan pizza was also good but more bready/ less cheese than other Chicago pizza spots. It's hard to compare pequods to a traditional deep dish pizza since it's pan here.. but I think I do prefer a more cheesy dip dish style. The best part was definitely the caramelized crust!

As many others have said, it's the skillet style cooking! The cheese carmelizes, I don't know if they have it, but they should just do a no crust pizza of just cheese and fillings, gracious it's delicious! But the crust is really special too. Do yourself a favor, don't settle for mediocre pizza, life is too short!

I don't see what the appeal is for Pequod's but maybe because I had it delivered the first--and only--time I've tried it. It was so over-rated! The crust was not even that great. This is a pizza that's definitely the opposite of the deep-dish. The deep dish is basically a cheese pie, while this is a whole lot of bread with very little sauce and cheese. If that's your thing, go for it! I personally like more sauce in my pizzas. And for those people that compare a deep dish pizza to Pequod's, tell them that they're not even the same thing!

They caramelize the crust on their deep dish pizza.

That is all you need to know.

My favorite pizza in Chicago. The pan pizza is heaven. And no the crust isn't burnt, haters. It's caramelized and it's deliciously chewy.

If you come here on the weekend or in the evening, expect a bit of a wait. And the pizza themselves take pretty long to cook too. But they did have the great idea to open up a cocktail/beer place next door called Whale Tail, so you can booze up a bit while you wait for your table.

The only downside is sometimes the pizza can be hit or miss. There's days where it is bland, which I know is crazy to say after proclaiming it to be my favorite pizza spot. But when they hit the mark, it's the best the city has to offer. A good tip is to bring some home and eat it the next day for leftovers after pooping in the oven a bit (no microwave nonsense). It's even better the day after.

The staff is also really nice. From the friendly waitresses' to the older gentlemen (with the great head of hair) who is always working the host stand.

The Pequod's restaurant is known for their deep dish pizza with caramelized burnt crust. They typically have a long wait and the pizza takes about 40 minutes to cook once you put in the order. You should put in your pizza order right away because of the long wait.  I suggest you get the deep dish pizza with sausage. The pizza has large chunks of sausage with a hint of spice. You will leave feeling full.

Ordered from here on a Saturday night and took about an hour 1/2 for the food to be delivered. We decided to go wild and ordered mozzarella sticks, onion rings, spinach thin crust pizza, pepperoni and sausage pan pizza, carrot cake and red velvet cake.

* Mozzarella Sticks - cheesy goodness and the marinara sauce that came with it has extra tasty. Not sure if they put cheese or something else in sauce, but it was delicious. (5 stars)
* Onion Rings - crispy and crunchy. They come with BBQ sauce which made them even better (4 stars).
* Spinach Thin Crust Pizza - the sauce was bland city. I wouldn't get this again. (1 star)
* Pepperoni and Sausage Pan Pizza - so meaty, great amount of sauce and nice crispy crust. They give you nice chunks of sausage, which have a sweet taste to them. I recommend ordering this pizza with these toppings. (4.5 stars)
* Carrot Cake - was good, but the slice was super small for the $5.95 price they charged (3.5 stars)
* Red Velvet Cake - my friend said it had a pizza taste to it (this was said after he brushed his teeth) and was the worst red velvet he ever had (1 star).

All and all if you going to order/dine at Pequod's I recommend sticking to the appetizers and pan pizza.

Overrated. I was excited for this pizza, even had it on "my list". Pan pizza was more like focaccia than pizza. It's wasn't terrible, just not up to the hype. Service = stoned 20-somethings in pj or yoga pants just making an extra buck. they don't care, so neither do I.
Best deep dish in the city!  If you go to Gino's, Lou's or Giodano's...sorry boutcha, but you're a tourist ;)

Pequod's Pizza, one of the most famous destinations for deep dish or as they call it, pan pizza in the city most famous for it is a destination worthy of a dedicated visit.. A dive bar atmosphere pervades, but it manages not to feel seedy or gross. The inside is deceptively massive with multiple floors and rooms, so even though it gets packed, the wait time is only occasionally prolonged. The longer wait is for the pizza to actually be cooked, but we end up only waiting maybe 20 minutes even though we're told it will be 40.  There's even beer available from some of the local craft breweries and not just the big domestics as you'd expect at a dive. The deep dish is succulent and doughy. Each slice requires diving in and indulging in a monstrous bite. I love a good pepperoni and this pan pizza has a good pepperoni.

I have been a fan of Pequod's since the mid 1990's.  I've dined at their Morton Grove, IL location as well.  Great pan pizza...perhaps the best if your seeking a non-traditional stuffed or deep dish crust.  The fluffy, caramelized pan pizza crust gives this pizza an additional feature which practically has you licking your plate.  Excellent ingredients, well prepared pizza, plenty of appetizer options makes for an enjoyable pizza dining experience.

Now this is what I came to Chicago for...some DELICIOUS deep dish pizza!! It's a telling sign when multiple people I know in Chicago tell me that Pequod's is their favorite pizza joint. We came here for lunch and there was still about a 30-45 minute wait. I like how Pequod's isn't a chain (compared to Lou's) and it has a much more homey vibe to it. It's a great pizza pub. It's not located in the downtown area, but it's a definite must if you're visiting Chicago. The trek out is worth it.

My buddy and I split a small pizza. They don't have pre-set pizzas on the menu; they really encourage customization. We settled on the cheese only with sausage, pepperoni, mushroom and onion. Talk about out-of-this-world pizza!!! I'm a huge fan of deep-dish and to get an authentic taste of Chicago deep-dish pizza was amazing. Everything, from the crust to the toppings, was delicious. I love how the crust is caramelized and I loved the thickness of the pan pizza. Not to mention, the sausages were huge!! Let's just say that each bite was magical.

The wait once you're seated can be a while because they make each pizza to order. It might be a good idea for them to take your order while you're waiting to be seated in order to speed up the process. In any case, the wait is definitely worth it and it's probably one of the best deep dish pizzas I've had. I can't wait to go back when I'm in town!

pics.caption: Cheese only with sausage, pepperoni, mushroom and onion

review.des:
I love a good crust so I was super excited to try deep dish in Chicago.

Pequod's is away from the center of Chicago but it was still packed. Luckily, we had made "reservations" (not real reservations, just cuts your wait time down). We were still seated right away, but were told the pizza would take 45 minutes. Bummer.

We started with an order of wings which were nothing special.

There's a few sizes you can choose from and you can pay for additional toppings. I chose spinach and fresh garlic. 45 minutes later our pizzas came out piping hot in a cast iron skillet allowing for a crispy, thick crust.

Pequod's had more of a sports bar feel, which I did not expect.

Overall a solid spot for deep dish.

Generally, I'm a pretty calm individual. Unless it comes to pizza. I will literally fight anyone who bad mouths Chicago style pizza. (Why are there so many people who hate on the deep dish?! It's a lot of people I have to fight!) So when I got the opportunity to visit Chicago, and got the opportunity to try authentic deep dish, I was in a pizza-induced haze for the weeks leading up to the trip.

My boyfriend's brother lives in Chicago, and recommended Pequod's as a place the locals eat at. Now, I don't know how accurate that statement is, especially since I'm not a local, but it was crowded nonetheless! Very crowded. As a party of 4, it took a little while to get seated, but not long at all to be a bother. (I've had longer waits at an Olive Garden.)

We ordered two pizzas, with a multitude of toppings, and waited. Both my boyfriend's brother and the waitress warned that it was going to be a while, so I got a salad also. It was delicious, and helped pass the time while I waited for the magnificence that is Chicago deep dish. And when it came, delivered piping hot to the table, I swear I almost fainted.

I wish I got pictures, because it was literally one of the most beautiful things I've ever seen in my life. Much like one of the wonders of the world, it'll take your breath away. Don't even talk to me about my first bite. It's just a void in my memory because as soon as I put a bite in my mouth, I ascended to a different plane of existence. When I came back down, I can remember the bubbly, gooey cheese, and the flavorful robust sauce, and the crunchy, caramelized crust. My mouth is watering just thinking about it now...

Oh, how I wish I could go back! The pizza was so good! The service was fantastic, too. And the price, for the literal pounds of food you're getting, is very worth it. And the interior is very cozy and very homey. One of my favorite parts of Chicago, for sure!

Love love LOVE!!!!! this pizza. If you consider yourself a Chicagoan like I do, you must have checked out this place at least once!
The only issue is that it is very small and crammed, so I would say it isn't 100% family friendly.
I'd still come back because it is some great finger licking good pizza. You never know you might find out if their pizza is for you.
Best deep dish in the city. Less doughy than others. The crust is basically burnt cheese. The wait can be long but it's worth it!

Overrated in my opinion.  If you like a lot of baked bread this is definitely the place for you.  Not sure how this place got so hot but it's not worth the wait and there are so many good pizza options that you shouldn't let yourself get caught up in the hype.  Saving grace is the burnt crust, I actually like that.
This pizza was actually really good ... the burnt crust was great and loved the atmosphere ...

DO NOT order delivery. The first time, after waiting for three hours and receiving no pizza, I called to check on it and they said they had lost my order and that they could reorder and deliver in two hours. The second time, after waiting for two hours, the order showed up completely wrong - the ticket itself was correct, but the pizza was not at all what I ordered. I called and without missing a beat (this must happen all the time) they said they could either remake the pizza and deliver in two hours (seriously??) or give me a credit, but I couldn't have my money back. I honestly love this place and have been going for years, but the last time I ever eat there will be for free when I use that credit.

Two stars because I found a hair in my salad. The pizza was good; first time having deep dish in Chicago and I was pleased. We ordered the medium size to share between 3 people and there was leftovers. We had half pepperoni and half pepperoni and meatball. The crust was nice and crispy and there was an ample amount of toppings. Definitely a fun place with friends or chill date.

Came here tonight with some friends, I've had Chicago deep dish and was expecting that in my head, however, it was different than the other deep dish I've experienced since it was "pan" pizza. I personally enjoyed this better than the typical deep dish. We got pepperoni and meatball, it was delicious. We had a Pequod's salad and French fries to start, the fries were seasoned with a really good flavor. The dressing on the salad was amazing. The pizza does take 40 minutes to cook but was worth the wait, will go back.

It's not Chicago without pizza! I always thought Chicago was known for their deep dish pizza, but based of off every Lyft drivers I had, pan pizza is the new hype!

Pequod is located outside of downtown Chicago, so I made it a mission to try it during my short stay! The pizza price would be based off of number of toppings.

As suggested by our waitress, we got a medium for a party of three. We were worried that 8 slices were three was not enough, but after eating, we were glad we listened.

As shown in my pictures, the pizza has a lot of breading. A lot of reviews complained stating it's not deep dish, which is true. The menu clearly says pan- hence all the breading.

My only complaint is that it does take 25-30 minutes to make each pizza, so be prepared to wait!

pics.caption: Slice of Italian sausage pan pizza
Medium pan pizza - half Italian sausage and half mushroom

review.des: This resturants is really packed all the time and the wait is long but the food is worth the wait. I got a pepperoni deep dish and it is one of the best deep dishes in chicago. Highly recommend.

Oh hell yeah!  Do pequod's followed by a movie at the Webster theaters, you can't beat that evening.  The pizza is a true "Chicago experience."  The service is not so great but that only adds to the experience :)!  Seriously good pizza though.
Both locations have awesome, caremelized cheese edge deep dish pizza.

So many people hype this place up.  I've never been happy with the pizza here.  After four experiences and four disappointments- I'm finished with this place.  Consistently inconsistent.   So many excellent deep dish places in town, this is not one.

As a long-time Chicagoan I can say that Pequod's is my favorite/the best deep dish in the city.  The toppings always seem very high quality to me and the browned cheese on the crust is amazing.  On other deep dish pizzas I never even eat the crust because it's just boring bread; not so with Pequod's.  Like any deep dish place the wait for pick-up or delivery is always pretty long.  If you're trying to order this on a football Sunday, let alone on Super Bowl Sunday, get your order in early or plan on a 2-3 hour wait.  Happy eating!

Something to try while in Chicago, but don't expect quality service. Pizza is ok, just not my favorite. It's a pan style pizza with a little extra. Be sure to eat the crust, it's the best part. Food runners were on point, but servers and hostess could use some training especially for a place like this.

Waited on hold for 30 minutes.... finally got through to the operator and they told me that they would not deliver to my address because I was 1 block outside the delivery radius. I told them I would walk to the block that they do deliver to (1 away from my current location) and they said that would not deliver. This **was** my favorite Chicago pizza joint but now I will not see myself going here ever again.

Thanks for the memories

We made a reservation. We called and confirmed 15 minutes before we arrived. We paid for a taxi to get to the restaurant. We arrived, and were informed that our reservation had been canceled without being notified, and that there was nothing that they would do. No apology, no attempt to accommodate, just too bad for for us. Quite a way to treat customers. There are lots of good deep dish places in Chicago. Avoid this one.

I recently had my first experience at Pequod's.  I've lived in Chicago for years, and I work in the area, but the lines are always so long that we usually opt for something else.

It was FRIGID on New Year's day, and I was in the area, so decided to finally satisfy my smoldering desire for the Pequod's cheesy crust I'd heard so much about it.

And it was pretty good.  

My carryout experience was a hot mess.  I walked in and got my ticket, and was told to wait for my pizza.  Several other people came in, got their food, and left...and I was still waiting.  The waitresses were in some sort of an argument with the guy who was supposed to be picking up pizzas, and I spent my 15 minutes of waiting time listen to them complain about how much he sucked at his job and how he was screwing them over with his laziness/incompetence (I'm paraphrasing, because their language probably isn't appropriate for Yelp).  It was sort of funny, and the guy did seem like a mess, but it really wasn't professional.  Turns out he lost my ticket, so after all that, I had to start the process over again.  Whatever...it was a holiday...stuff happens.

I got the pizza home, and it was good, but I'm not sure it was worth the hype.  The crust is legit tasty, but I found the pizza itself to be really bready.  Almost like a focaccia.  I'd probably go back, but I wouldn't wait in line or go out of my way.

I was picked up by my Lyft driver, Antoinette, heading to Gino's East but when I asked her where the best pizza in town is, she drove me to Pequod's. It was close to 9pm and a line out the door so you know it's probably good! Fortunately for me, there was a seat at the bar. They had a great beer and drink selection, which is good because you may have a couple before your pizza comes out. It took about 45 min for my pizza to be served, and it was totally worth the wait! Absolutely the best Chicago style pizza I've ever had , hands down! Cannot wait to come back.

This place is much better than Giordano's, but doesn't beat Lou Malnati's. However, the crust at Pequod's is very unique. I'd come here just to try the crust. It's very chewy and has a slightly sweet flavor.

Wow 5 Stars without a doubt for Pequods delicious deep dish pizza! Known as the newest favorite pizza and deep dish in Chicago. Many locals and especially tourists are more familiar with the popular pizza Chicago brand names such as Lou Malnatis, Giordanos and Uno but there is a new favorite in town in Pequods. Loaded with toppings, surrounded by a crispy and cheesy yet light and airy crust, Pequods delivers a unique approach to the ever traditional deep dish in Chicago.

Located in Lincoln Park, Pequods is a tiny restaurant pumping out a lot of ZA! With a tremendous following, Pequods is a favorite to a lot of people in Chicago. I have never tried the thin crust but a lot of people swear by it.. I enjoy a crispy thin crust but when I'm going here there is no doubt I am getting the loaded pepperoni deep dish. It is an incredible pizza and will leave you in a serious food coma.

I don't understand this as a number one Chicago pizza. For me it falls flat. The caramelized crust isn't enough to keep me coming back. The pizza is more bread like than anything else. It's as if they substitute out a pizza dough for a loaf of bread. The ratio of dough to sauce to cheese just doesn't do it for me. There is way better pizza in Chicago for me pequod's doesn't even make my top 5

Best deep dish in the city by far. I've been here at least 25 times and always bring people visiting from out of town. We always order pepperoni, onion and extra cheese. Regardless of your choice of toppings, I recommend ordering extra cheese!

Be prepared to wait for this Chicago classic. I came around 5:30 pm and ended up not getting a pizza until 8pm! Plan accordingly guys! I think you can take the food to go as well but we dined in so it took a bit longer.

We ordered a large pizza (for 3 girls) with a variety of toppings and extra cheese. We also got a cheesy garlic bread appetizer.

The appetizer was ok. It's just bread with a lot of cheese. I was starving so I thought it tasted good but it was pretty generic. They were also super skimpy with the marinara sauce.

Our pizza was super cheesy. I don't know why we got extra cheese! Deep regrets. It has enough cheese. The toppings add up so choose wisely. Our pizza ended up being ~$45 total (from a base price of $18). Each slice weighed like 5 lbs. That's a lot of food. The vegetables are really fresh and the premium meats very good. You can't go wrong with your favorites.

Service is good, albeit slow because of its popularity. The space is cramped and dark but I think that is the genera design of these pizza places. I will probably not go back because I don't like this kind of food plus the wait was no fun. But when in Chicago - you must eat deep dish and Pequods is a great place to go get some.

Can we talk about lunch specials?  So many times a lunch special does not feel special, but Pequod's does!  Monday - Friday you can get in on a smoking deal!  $4.95 for their personal pizza and a fountain drink is ridiculous (in the best way possible).  Now be aware that is just for a cheese pizza but you can start piling on the toppings for $0.80 each to customize that pie.  I put Giardinera on mine and was repping like a true Chicagoan.  I opted for a lemonade as my soft drink and since it was a weekday off I did choose to them buy myself a beer because pizza and beer, hell ya!   Had some 2 Brothers on draft and was loving my local lunch.  The pie was more a a deep dish style and the cheese had some nice caramelization around all of the edges. Do not be fooled it is not burnt!  Perfect sized meal for lunch but they do make things to order so it will not be a quick meal if you have somewhere to go.

Simply the best crust, deep dish sauce,  and pie in the country.   Great atmosphere and the service is really good.    

Love this place, anytime

Very bready and the gave us the wrong delivery order.  Instead of getting a combo type pizza we ended up with an all veg pizza.  If you're visiting Chi and looking forward to Deep dish, try the typical options first and make this place a 2nd meal or choice to compare with.
Just wanted to confirm - went back a second time and this place is still hot garbage all around - the staff, the wait, the food. Never again will I waste my time or money here.

Read the great reviews and had to try the pan pizza.   Didn't realize it was over an inch of crust with thin layer of sauce and cheese.    I don't mind carbs but didn't want almost all bread.   45 mins wait for pan pizza to cook - it takes 30 mins to bake a loaf of bread.
Been my favorites since my folks took me to the Morton Grove original and told me stories of the infamous Burt.  Stuff is still so good, just remember when dining in its so hot out the gates.
The pizza was so amazing, we had the deep dish. Our waiter was nice and attentive. I am happy I got to try one of the best deep dish pizza places in Chicago.

Best deep-dish pizzeria in Chicago!

Okok so I am still a deep-dish newbie as my only previous experience has been Lou Malnati's. But I really dig the way Pequod's prepares its pizza. There is a reasonable layer of cheese on the bottom with plenty of tomato sauce on top and a crispy crust. If you like mounds of oozing cheese, maybe Lou Malnati's is for you. But I prefer the cheese to be a component in my deep dish (because otherwise, I might as well have a lasagna, right?) The two of us split a medium with garlic, onion, and basil on top. We only managed to finish half, however, but that might be because we had an early dinner and had Purple Pig for lunch... But that just means more leftovers for the next day!

pics.caption: Medium pizza with onion, garlic, and basil

review.des: Just being down the road from where I work I stopped here for there lunch special.  4.95 for a personal pizza and a soda.  How can you go wrong? I topped mine with sausage, black olives, and green olives. You pay .80 cents for each additional topping. This personal pizza hit the spot for lunch. The pizza had just the right amount of sauce and was done perfectly. When I arrived there was no wait and I just sat at the bar. The service was attentive as he always kept my drink fresh. For under 10 bucks this is certainly a go to place for lunch but make sure you arrive with an empty stomach cause it's filling.

pics.caption: Lunch special. Personal Chicago style pizza.

review.des: This is by far my favorite Chicago style pizza in the city. I don't know why I have never written a review before because it has been my favorite for many years. The crust is the best. The atmosphere is super relaxed and chill because it's basically a bar that serves amazing pizza. They have the bar area downstairs and then a dining room upstairs. They have pretty good appetizers, my friends and family have said the beer is good although I don't drink it. The service has always been good. I've not had one bad experience I've been there a million times. The only thing I can say that is not ideal is that during peak hours the wait is crazy long but that is just a testament to how good it is. So it's on you to plan accordingly. :)

I LOVE THIS DEEP DISH PIZZA. I've lived in Chicago for a bit now and tried a lot of different deep dishes and this is the best. I am also newly vegan and got it without cheese with all the veggies. It was delicious. Def recommend this place to anyone who wants good pizza!

Great pan pizza; arguably the best, depending on what you like. There is a lot of bread, but the cheesy crust is awesome! Be prepared to wait well over an hour if dining at the restaurant, and order way ahead of time if ordering take-out or delivery.

Pizza is good, but not wait 40 + minutes with no AC and request-only drink refills. So glad we didn't have to suffer a wait time to get a table like I've read about. We picked this place after a lot of research for our weekend in Chicago and probably came in with expectations that were probably a little too high.
I am not a big fan of deep dish pizza.  But this one is pretty delicious.  Get it with fresh garlic, it will make your mouth stinky, but it will make your taste buds dance!

My friend recommended this place over all the other deep dish places so had to try it. I've only had Lou Malnati's and I wasn't a fan so figured I'd give it another shot. We had a 90 min wait so stopped over at the Drinkingbird next door for a couple drinks (pretty good) and finally got seated and ordered a large pan pizza with pepperoni, sausage, mushrooms and peppers and a full order of wings.

The wings were okay and looked like they came from a food deprived chicken. The pizza is massive and has this nice charred crust but I've come to the realization that I'm just not a deep dish fan. The toppings were fantastic but the pizza just lacks the amount of cheese and sauce that I like. It feels like you are eating a salad of toppings with some crust on the side. My friends liked it but I think I'll stick to New York style pizza myself.
Best deep-dish on the Northside IMO. Thin crust is actually amazing as well (a local secret). If you're an out of towner. deep dish takes 45 mins..come early.

Be warned on the weekends they don't take orders ahead of time. Pizza takes 75 minutes not 50, we ordered a medium. It's so hot inside because they've constructed the airflow by adding temporary tables. Don't get mad at the waitresses they are doing the best they can.
