I called before to make a reservation, hostess said no it's not necessary for two people, I'll put you on the priority list. Got there, your on priority list, it will be 20 minutes, was 40 minutes. Just order delivery, carry out line a hot mess.

Ordered a personal pan sausage deep dish for takeout on Saturday around 4pm. Was told that it would take around 45mins.

We came straight after sharing a personal deep dish from Lou Malnati's so we can compare the two side by side. The one from Paquod's is much larger for pretty much the same price, but the crust is more soggy. The sauce tastes like it's from a canned one but overall it's not bad. Definitely less cheesy than Lou Malnati's.

That being said, to each their own and I would suggest trying all!

This is the epitome of a Chicago deep dish. The wait was a bit long (around 45 minutes for me), but it was worth every minute. The caramelized crust and the thickness of the breading underneath all the sauce and cheese was perfect. i loved how thick the pizza was and how everything just came together. I got mushrooms and sausage on my pizza and it was just amazing. I do have to note that it's best if you come in a party of 3-5 so that you can share the whole deep dish!
We were told Pequod's has the best pizza in Chicago. We were not disappointed. The pizza is so delicious and the service was friendly.
Pizza was freakin awesome! Long wait to sit and then to get it cooked but well worth it! Stop by if you're in the Chi!

When there's over an hour wait for a place, you know it's good. I ended up ordering to-go because it was already pretty late on a Friday night and there isn't a huge abundance of seating in the restaurant. Long wait aside, this is some quality pan pizza and after trying Lou Manalti's as well, I can say Pequod's is definitely the superior pizza.

Ordered the large (14 inch) pan pizza, with pepperoni, mushroom, olive, and sausage. All the ingredients were fresh. Pizza wasn't too oily. Mozzarella was stringy. And sauce had good tart zing. On my second slice, I realized they do use a lot of crust on the bottom, but when you're eating it you don't really notice.  The caramelized crust is crack. Single-handedly the best pizza crust I've ever had.

Bottom line: great quality deep-dish pizza.

Simply one of the best pizza places in Chicago their pizza is different from any other pizza have eaten the staff is always nice food is always good and I always bring my friends Fromvout of town to try

Disappointed.  Flew into Chicago and 1st stop was Pequod's Pizzeria.  We were seated right away on Tuesday for lunch.  However we had to wait 5-10 minutes for waiter to come take our food and drink order.  We ordered the pan cheese pizza and a thin crust pizza with pineapple, mushroom and onions, a salad and french fries.   Salad and French fries came out first.  French fries were good however there was a dead fly in our salad.  We lost our appetite for salad.  So we just told them to take it away.  Pan pizza can out and it was underwhelming.  Tasted a bit dry.  However the thin crust pizza was laden with cheese and toppings.  It was very good.  I would recommend the thin crust over the pan pizza.  We had to wait another 10 minutes to get a waiter to give us the check and another 10 minutes for them to come back to process the payment. I heard a lot of great things about this place but next time I think I'll just order to go.  Service was slow and they didn't seem apologetic about finding a dead fly in our salad.  Disappointed in service and food.

This was our first deep dish pizza, which was recommended by a lot of people. We absolutely loved this place. It was so delicious.

I highly recommend.

Came here because it was highly recommended, and I had tried all the other deep dish chains. Our wait was 1.5 hours on a Friday evening. Be prepared to wait if you dine here!

The best part of the pizza was the thick and caramelized crust. The rest of the pizza was pretty good, especially the sausage we selected as a topping. However, it wasn't as cheesy as I would've liked it. The crust also tasted and looked quite burnt.

Solid place to get deep dish pizza, but I still prefer Giordano's, Gino's, and Lou Malnati's.

This place has got to be the best pizza in Chicago. I have been devouring their pizza since the 90s and it has consistently been great. If you havent checked them out , I would recommend you put them on the top of your list. They are a Chicago must try!

Disclaimer: I'm a native New Yorker. So I'm temporarily expanding my definition of pizza to include the Italian Pot Pies that Chicago inexplicably calls pizza.

Is Pequod's the best pizza in Chicago? I mean, it's better than Unos and Giordano's and Malnati's.

But is it the best pizza in Chicago?

The first time I went I braved the wait and got the small with sausage. I like the classics. I thought it lacked some serious umami and it gave it a kind of bready flavor. On the other hand, I was a fan of the carmelization and could see the potential in it.

Still, the hype persisted, so a few years later I gave it another try.

I liked it a lot more the second time around. I got it with the sausage and the fresh garlic,  which has become my go-to for deep dish. The garlic provides the punch that was missing the first time, and it was a much better experience.

So it Pequod's the best pizza in the city?

My favorite pizza (in Chicago) remains Coalfire, which isn't deep dish and therefore is an actual pizza. And, well, please refer to my disclaimer at the top.

I'm probably in the minority here, but my favorite deep dish remains My Pi in Bucktown. There is an additional punch of flavor it gives you that Pequod's hasn't quite been able to match. I love Pequod's crust game,  but everything else falls just a little short by comparison.

Despite that, unlike the Au Cheval burger debacle that I will vociferously go to war over, I wouldn't object to anybody saying Pequod's is the best...deep dish...pizza.

After reading the reviews for a few different pizza places, my boyfriend and I decided to check out Pequod's while in town last night.

We got there around 5:15 on a Thursday and were seated right away on the second floor where it is much calmer and quieter. When we left an hour and a half later, the place was packed and the downstairs was very noisy. So yes, get there early if you don't want to wait!

We ordered two appetizers to hold us over while the pizza was cooking: jalapeño poppers for him ($7) and half order of hot wings for me ($5). My wings were very good- spicy and plenty of meat on them. Plus they give the option of ranch or blue cheese which was nice and also novel for me because at many upstate ny places it's blue cheese or nothin' and I'm not a fan. I'm not sure how long the pizza took but it didn't seem long at all because it came out very soon after we finished with the appetizers... perfect timing!

We got a 10" deep dish pizza with pepperoni and black olives (~$15). My boyfriend wasn't sure about getting the small pizza to split for fear of not having enough, but it was plenty! We actually each could only eat about one and a half slices- and there were four all together. The pie itself was very tasty. Crunchy and chewy crust, lots of toppings, tangy sauce and I actually really liked the toasty burnt cheese ring around the crust which is their specialty.

I realized that deep dish is not my favorite--- I'm a thin crust girl at heart! But I'm glad I gave it a shot and I don't think there's a better place than Pequod's to do it.

pics.caption: Slice of a 10" pan pizza with pepperoni and black olives (~$15).

review.des: Great place to enjoy a great pizza. Hole in the wall but well worth the 45 minute wait for pizza

Place is packed and I know this is a lot of peoples favorite pizza, but the deep dish just doesn't do it for me; Too bready and spongy instead of sauce, cheese, and toppings. And it isn't just the pizza. I phoned in my order for carry-out. When I arrived, it to me 30 just to get to the front of the carry-out line just so I could check in, get my pizza, pay for it, and walk out. Come on man. Set up a separate entrance or something.

Delicious!  We had a table of 11. We had reservations at 5 and were seated immediately.  Our waitress advised us to put our pizza order in right away as they take 40 minutes or more. We had two deep dish, one spinach and mushroom and another with sausage, peppers and pepperoni.  We also had a flat pizza half cheese and half pepperoni.  My nephew is on a special gluten free diet and the manager took the time to discuss options and they settled on sausage that they would cook especially for him.

Service was excellent!  We have had many deep dish pizzas in Chicago and think this is the best we've had.  I highly recommended this place!

Finally I was able to visit this place, I am not from chicago, Being a pizza lover always asked people of the best places for pizza and pequod's was always on everybodys top 5 list.

The place was crowded, we got our table in 40 minutes and then our pizza in another 50 minutes.

For deep dish the options are less and you can add as many toppings as you want with extra $$ per toppings.

The crust was very crispy and that was the best part of the pizza than the taste. Overall the experiance was nice and would like to come again.

Ehh not the best, I'm a local and love deep dish pizza once in a while...okay maybe three times a year because that stuff is heavy! But I wasn't a fan of the burnt crust that makes this place so popular. Which is fine because you will either love it or hate it. It's just not my cup of tea.

The service was great though, they did forget a topping but were nice enough to deduct the cost of the topping and then some for the inconvenience.

No matter what they tell you when you call in to make a reservation just know that these guys DO NOT take reservations! The lack of professionalism, and being packed in like a sardine, is not worth the wait for this pizza. Go to Lou's instead!

I see it advertised on Chicago's Best and everyone says how great it is.  I was at an Air bnb and decided to order.  I'm sorry but it was just ok... the sauce was bland.  Maybe it's me?
I will try them again.  The delivery was fast.

First of all don't be fooled by the pictures the topping is only two or three small slices of meet or whatever you ask for .
   
I had one of the worst experiences ever with one of the managers when I told them what's wrong with my pizza she said in order to fix it it'll take about 45 minuets just like what it took us to wait for it when we had to wait an hour to be seated and another 45 minuets to get the pizza. Or she will take care of it and since we waited enough we agreed that they'll take care of it, unfortunately when it was time to get the check we found that she took care of the topping that it was missing only which was the protein topped and no way I'll have a pizza with only cheese. After a long argument about what they mean by we'll take care of it they agreed to take of another topping I paid just to be done and leave it was absolutely not professional from her. Trust me It's an overrated place if I didn't have this experience to be fair I'll give them 3 stars
Delicious pizza! Went there with my boyfriend and we ordered a medium. We couldn't finish it because it's a pizza that really fills you up. I will definitely come back along with friends.

Favorite deep dish in Chicago. This one is known for its crust so it's not quite as heavy/greasy as some of the other big name deep dish joints. Always expect to wait at least 1 hour, but the buzzer works at the neighboring bars so you can grab a drink while you wait.

I'm not huge on pizza but went there with hang out with friends.  I must admit it was pretty good.  For someone who prefers thin style, that's a huge complement.  I can see why  so many people rave about this place.
Totally worth the wait, great pizza always the freshest ingredients.  One of the best in the city,!

**This rating is based on Chicago pizza joints. Pequod's would score a higher rating when compared with pizza in Austin, TX for example.

I feel that most every Chicagoan has their favorite when it comes to pizza. For me, growing up, it was Giordano's. While Gio's is still a classic, a few years ago my favorite switched to Lou Malnati's which I only tolerated as a kid funny enough (not all locations are created equal, the Lincoln Park location is one of the best). I've heard rumblings over the past few years that Pequod's was not to be missed. My brother had heard the same and we finally tried them out.

The atmosphere has a pretty standard sports bar/pizza place vibe that works. A Euro Cup match was being played while we ate which was nice. Now for the pizzas. First, I would say don't even mess with their thin crust. We tried a slice just to test it out and to me, it was on level with microwavable pizza in terms of flavor and texture. Their pan pizza is definitely an upgrade. We got a large with sausage, mushrooms, and fresh basil. As a whole, I'd say it was good, but no new craving has been created and now I feel the need to go to get my Lou Malnati's on before heading out of town.

I will say that their sausage and burnt crust were the two clear highlights and the bottom of their crust was crispy throughout. They were not cheap with toppings either as they piled them on. Also, there was a guy there who I'm guessing is either the owner or the GM and he was really really nice and you could tell he had genuine care for his patrons. They do a solid pan pizza here that is worth checking out.

P.S. Always always always avoid ordering a personal pizza at any Chicago deep dish place. It's no where near as good as any medium and above sized pie.

If you like a loud, bustling place where you don't mind long wait times, plastic drinking glasses, and difficult-to-find parking, you might like it here. But if you're hungry you might be hangry by the time you get your pie.

Don't get me wrong, the pizza is terrific, but with all the wonderful pizza places in Chicago I won't go out of my way to go here.

By boyfriend, on the other hand, loves this place. He likes the bustle, loves the pizza, and doesn't mind driving around for 15 minutes to find parking and then another 30 minutes or more to get seated and then another 30 minutes  for pizza.

I don't get deep dish pizza. We waited over 2 hours on a Saturday to get some pizza from Pequod's. The space is cozy, but has 2 floors. Our waitress was friendly enough, and our appetizer of jalapeno poppers came out quickly enough, but we had to wait another 45 minutes for our pizza. (a wait we already knew about).

The pizza itself was a deep pool of tomato sauce, cheese, and toppings. Basically impossible to eat with your hands, which led me to use a fork and knife. It was pretty tasty, but not really much of a pizza. And honestly, I prefer the chain deep dish pizza, Uno's, because the crust is much more buttery. It was good, but definitely not worth waiting close to 3 hours.

the BEST deep dish in the city. all the big name chains that tourists go for cannot compare to the delicious, inexpensive menu at pequod's. when you have friends or family visiting and they want to go for AUTHENTIC chicago deep dish, this is where you should be taking them!

We called for priority seating here on a Saturday night (they don't take reservations), and still had quite the wait, but it was worth it! The food was fantastic. We ordered jalapeño poppers, which were great and only took about 10 minutes to get to our table. The pizza took longer, about 45 minutes after our already two hour long wait. But the pizza was fantastic. It's not quite true Chicago deep dish- the crust is pretty thick- but we still loved it.

I'm holding back on 5 stars because service was a little chaotic. Our waitress was nowhere to be seen most of the time, and it took a while to get our waters.
Delicious pizza, cant wait to go back!  Their crust is so unique!  Really a fun place for the family.

I've gotta say that I definitely like Pequod's better than Lou's!! I've been to Chicago twice now and have tried both places during both visits. Pequod's definitely takes the cake on this! ...or should I say pizza? Hehehe. They do a pan pizza, so I guess it's not the traditional deep dish in a sense but it's still my favorite in Chicago! And they give generous portions of pepperoni! Every bite literally had at least 3 slices of pepperoni in it. It takes about 40 min for their pizzas once you place the order so we called ahead and just did take out! The middle ended up being a tad bit soggy but it was still all good to me. It's more of a bar vibe in there so it's a great place for big groups. Definitely a must visit when coming to Chicago!

The service was terrible at a peak time- it took so long to place our order that by the time we left we'd been there over two hours.  We came with a family of 8, ordered two pizzas.  One was under cooked and the other was perfection.  For the cost and wait, I expect near perfection and better service.

UPDATE: shortly after posting we got outreach, which is meaningful and show they care.  I'd try again, but perhaps purposely come at a less busy time.

Favorite burnt style crust in Chicagoland area. Way different than what you're used to. The individual pizzas are the way to go. Whenever i go bigger the pizza seem more dry and lacks sauce. So if you go big ask for a xtra sauce so you won't be disappointed with a hockey puck arriving to your table.

AWESOME deep dish pizza!! Much better than both Lou Malnati's and Giordano's. I don't know why it's taken me so long to try this place out! I suppose the other two aforementioned pizzerias are more famous to non-native individuals roaming about Chicago for some deep dish delight (such as myself) because they are established chains and have quite a few locations on the map. However, Pequod's blows either of those other two out of the water!

My friend and I were seated in the adjacent Whale's Tale in order to be served faster, but we were assured that the pizza we would be getting was produced by Pequod's. Additionally they told us that we would only be able to order the appetizers available at Whale's Tale as well, and not from Pequod's, which wasn't an issue for us as we didn't get any appetizers. I'm not sure exactly how the relationship between the two establishments functions, but it worked out to our benefit as we were seated immediately, were able to place our orders as quickly as possible, and were served the pizza in only 25 or so minutes. I believe that the maître d' said they actually served the pizza at Whale's Tale even more quickly than if we had placed our order seated in Pequod's, which I also don't understand.

Small 10" Pan Pizza w/ pepperoni, sausage, mushroom, and green pepper -  My friend and I initially wanted to overload the pizza with all the toppings, but the waitress serving us mentioned that having too many could cause the pizza to undercook, and so we only got got these four toppings, which I am super glad we did now in retrospect. I LOVE the "carmelized" crust on their deep dish, which is essentially just some slightly burnt cheese. It adds a nice crunchiness to the crust and actually doesn't have too much of that acrid flavor associated with burnt cheese - it does have a small amount of it, but just the right amount. The bread was so soft and fluffy - I was surprised how much bread there actually was in each bite. Initially I thought there was too much, but as I kept on eating I began to enjoy the fact that there was so much of it. It really helped to hold each bite together, and there was so much flavor in the toppings, sauce, and cheese, that I didn't feel like the bread was excessively drowning out and diluting the flavor of any of the other components in the pizza. Again awesome AWESOME deep dish.

Overall an amazing deep dish experience. As a Californian, I've always heard about the wonders of deep dish pizza in Chicago, and up until now I've always been slightly disappointed. Pequod's is amazing and has definitely set the bar for me for deep dish pizza! If you've never tried deep dish before in Chicago, I would definitely DEFINITELY recommend passing over Lou Malnati's or Giordano's and trying this place out instead, especially if you only have time to try one place. Unmistakably the best deep dish in Chicago that I've tried so far!

Well, this was a pretty solid pizza.

Arrived at 6:45p on Sunday night. There was a hawks game on.  The wait was approximately an hour. We ended up finding a bar seat.  

The wait for pizza was advertised at 50 minutes but ours arrived after about 35 minutes.  In the meantime we ordered a Peqoud Salad (half size), which was more than enough for 2. Also ordered a tasty 3 floyds beer. Only 4 tap selections, but at least a couple were craft.

The pizza was excellent. It had melted cheese on the side edge that was a little burnt and tasty. We also got meatballs and spinach on it. Both great options.
On a hot summer day the upstairs area can be a bit humid but the pizza was amazing and well worth the wait.

Recommended to me by numerous people before my trip to Chicago, and most definitely praised by locals while I was here, I was on a mission to get to Pequod's. Seriously, this girl in an UberPool we were with was talking about the usual big dogs of deep dish since we said we were from out of town, but the moment I brought up Pequod's, she yelped (haha) like there were ants down her pants.

It was a group of 5 of us, so we got the large (14") pie with pepperoni and sausage. We each had a couple of drinks so one slice was definitely enough, and two would bring you over the top. I had two :)

While I still prefer the classic New York slice, I can definitely get behind the deep dish from here. The crunchiness of the crust is what sealed the deal, balancing out the gooeyness of the cheese, and the tasty (and not too salty) pepperoni and sausage. It truly tasted like they used some top notch ingredients and put a lot of love into their pies.

To sum it up, there's no beating their meat! Might be fine in the back alley, though...

pics.caption: A slice of a large pepperoni and sausage deep dish pie

review.des:
This is my favorite deep dish in a city known for deep dish pizzas. Great crust, quality toppings, but what puts it over the top is the crisped up cheese on the crust---so good.

They own a bar next door if you want to get a drink while waiting for your table

AMAZING. Seriously, if you are in Chicago and do not go here you are missing out. Me and my friend went here (world series weekend) on Saturday. We went on the website and requested a table for 2 at 4:30 p.m. about a week prior. When we got there we were immediately seated. I highly suggest you do that, the website claims it cuts the wait time in half. I know this place is always crowded so I was super happy when we were seated right away. We probably picked an early enough time. The place was pretty packed.

When we were seated we ordered our pizza immediately (since the wait for a pizza can be up to 2 hours - ours was 2.5 hours). We also ordered fries and mozzarella sticks as apps, good choice because we were STARVING and smelling pizza and seeing people eat around you was not helping the wait. Oh boy I just wanted my pizza lol.

We were told to order extra sauce, and thank the lord we listened to that kind gentleman because when our pizza came out it was AMAZING. We got a medium, extra sauce and pepperoni. I seriously am craving this pizza as I'm typing this it is that good.

Any and every time I am in Chicago I will go to pequods. Seriously, it is that good and 100X better than the other chain pizza places (Giordanos and Lou Malnatis) I've tried them all and Pequods is by far the best.

EVERYONE GO TO PEQUODS!

Ok so I've heard through word of mouth and reading online this one of the go-to places for deep dish in Chicago. Granted we ordered delivery I would give this place another try in store. The woman taking our order was not great had to repeat everything several times and she just didn't have a lot of common sense so ordering was a bit of a headache. When it got here (restaurant is less than 3 miles from hotel) it was barely hot and sorely lacking sauce. The salad was good and the toppings on the pizza were good. Overall don't do delivery!

The pizza was good, but definitely not my favorite deep dish.  I had a personal sized pizza with spinach, tomato, and mushrooms.  The portion size was good and the lunch special price is great.  I'm not really a fan of their sauce, though.
Favorite deep dish pizza. I'm not a huge deep dish fan but if I had to choose it would be pequods. Show up early or show up after the rush. The pizza takes a while so be prepared to wait.

Trust in the crust, not in the service.

Pequod's is considered by many (the vivacious LeAnn P among them) to serve one of Chicago's best pizzas, and after a visit this past weekend I can believe the hype.

It takes either a very special pie or a very special lady to get me to eat deep dish (as I much prefer thin crust); in this case it was a little bit of both.  Fortunately we came early enough in the evening before great masses crowded the place, so getting a table was no problemo.

Knowing that their Chicago-style was legendary (3,000 reviews on Yelp, god damn!), we hastily asked for a 10" pan with pepperoni, sausage, and green peppers.  Pequod's is famous for their burnt cheese crust, which comes out black and delicious (much like Drake).

Thirty minutes seems like an eternity when you're craving the 'za, but eventually it arrived and we dug in with little hesitation.  Great sauce, plentiful toppings, and a blackened cheesy pan crust had me singing their praises.  It was incredible, folks.  I'd say my expectations were high and even they got surpassed.  I still feel weird eating pizza with a knife and fork, but when it's as good as Pequod's I could honestly care less.

Bread = 4.5
Circuses = 2.5

The 'za was as good as the service was bad.  But in what way?

Our server Alex greeted us, got in our pizza order and brought us drinks, after which she pretty much vanished.  When our deep dish finally arrived, a different girl brought it out and sliced it for us, who later also brought us more refreshments......so where did Alex go?  Maybe she quit.  Perhaps a family emergency?  Noooooope!  Turns out, she was just chillin' at the bar, hobnobbing with some locals while enjoying a glass of wine and a slice.  Apparently, her shift had ended.  Areyouf*ckingkiddingme?

I had no words.  None to describe how flabbergasted I was that our original waitress totally bailed on us without warning.  A quick "hey, I'm closing out, (new waitress) will be taking over for me", would have sufficed but we didn't even get that much.  When the check came, I wanted to confirm that Alex wouldn't get diddly squat tip-wise for abandoning her customers, but as the server was listed as "CZ01" (whatever the sh*t THAT means), I've really no way of knowing.

The men's bathroom had a ton of graffiti in it, but not the cool kind like at Emporium Barcade where it's intentional in an edgy sort of way.  Here, it was a normal, clean-ish bathroom that a bunch of people straight up vandalized. lol

It's not that I wouldn't want to return here-- because the pan pie is really, REALLY good --but since everybody and their grandma claims that they're "Chicago's best pizza" I feel obligated to try them all before making a 2nd lap around town.

Get here early to avoid the swarm of people, and pray that your server doesn't randomly disappear.

pics.caption: A 10" pan pizza (chicago-style) with pepperoni, sausage, and green pepper. Good stuff man, good stuff.

review.des:
My sister & I came here Monday afternoon and we made it in time for the lunch special. We tried Lou Manalti's the other night, but we weren't amazed. On the other hand, Pequod's took our breath away.

The Chicago Lunch Special is Monday - Friday 11 AM to 3 PM. You get a 7" cheese pan pizza and soda (no refills) for $4.95. If you want to add any other toppings, there is a charge per topping. For two lunch specials (w/ toppings), the bill came out to be around $12.

One thing that I hate about Chicago deep dish pizza is the wait, but Pequod's was worth it. The crust was buttery and flakey. The sauce was amazing and it was cheesy (but not too cheesy). I highly recommend going here as the flavor is outstanding.

pics.caption: Horrible lighting in there, but the pizza was amazing!

review.des:
Pequod's was my first crack at authentic Chicago style pizza in Chicago. In fact, it was the very first stop we made upon arrival into the Windy City and it certainly did not disappoint.

Their specialty is the "caramelized crust" edge on their pan style pizzas. The cheese was oozing out onto the side of crust and it was full of cheesy goodness. This is how they differentiate themselves from the competition and they execute it very well. We got a large sausage and pepperoni deep dish which was essentially a meat lovers pizza. Each bite was bursting of flavor and left us completely stuffed at the end. The only issue I had was that it was too crusty for my liking. I prefer a traditional deep dish that's not as doughy but that's just a matter of preference. The ingredients here were fresh, they don't used canned tomatoes which is splendid.

As with all authentic Chicago style pizzas, the waiting time will be long since they have to bake the crust to a nice golden brown.  Getting the buffalo wings as appetizers in the meantime is a solid move. They were delicious and it certainly made the wait for the pizza more bearable by chowing down some delicious wings. They have a good selection of craft beers too which is nice. As a few people in our group were San Diegans, we had to go with a pitcher of our beloved Ballast Point Sculpin.

Service was friendly and efficient as well. We were there until past closing at 2am and they did not rush to kick us out. They provided prompt and courteous service even though we were literally the last customers of the night.

Overall, Pequod's definitely earns their reputation as being one of the finest deep dish pizzerias in Chicago. Although I prefer Lou Manati's, I am not at all surprised that many people have Pequod's ranked as the king of Chicago deep dish.

pics.caption: Deep dish w/ pepperoni and sausage
Deep dish w/ pepperoni and sausage

review.des:
Pequod's has really gotten down how to get the perfectly crispy crust. If you love a crispy crust then you will love Pequod's.

The taste is great and is a good location for deep dish pizza.

The only thing I will add is that they could be a bit more generous with the toppings. I could count the pieces of ham that received on a pizza on 1 hand. Most other pizza locations overload the pizza with toppings.

The crust was amazing!!!! If you want a savory pizza go with the Hawaiian pizza! If you are feeling bold do a split between that and maybe pepperoni and mushroom a large (14' works perfect for 3 people)! The wait was worth it!

This is my go-to for Chicago style pizza.  Everyone has their favorite, but IMHO, Pequods is the hand's down champ.  The caramelized crust is just everything.  My go to here is sausage, garlic and spinach.  Add some mushrooms if I'm going HAM.

The hype is definitely real. So this is how Chicagoan does pan pizza. Buttery flakey crust with nice and zesty tomato sauce. The caramelized crust is also really good. Here, you  
build your own pan pizza, base comes with just cheese and sauce so add additional as you wish. Weekdays lunch special is probably the best deal. For $4.95, you get your own personal pan cheese pizza then add whatever toppings. Weekday lunch service is pretty quiet so if you're a tourist then I would recommend coming during this time.

If you are looking for the DEEP dish style Chicago is famous for, you are in the right place. One of the best in the city at what they do, Pequod's is on most locals lost of top pie. Tourists, however, are missing out.

Be prepared to wait, but so worth it!

I have been to Chicago before but had never sampled the pizza from Pequod's, instead I usually opt for either Lou Malnati's or Giordano's which this place currently sits behind on Yelp. First impression I think it is fairly ranked depending on what you prefer.  
PROS:
- The sauce is really good and nice an peppery.
- That ring on the outside is not burnt crust it's actually burnt cheese and they do that on purpose and it's amazing.

CONS:
- Not much cheese in the cheese layer below the sauce which surprised me

All in all it wasn't my favorite, just because I prefer a cheesier pie - but still very good.
Probably rank it as a tie for second with Giordanos but for different reasons.

Went here as it was recommended to me as the best place for deep dish by "locals" separating it from the infamous tourist deep dish spot downtown. Pizza was nothing memorable, but my four day stay in the hospital sure was. Best tasting, most expensive salmenella ive ever had. Not insinuating, just putting it out there as a warning. Can safely say I have not been back since (it's been 3 years, still paying off hospital bills). Enjoy!

Ordered takeout on a Sunday and was told it would take 50 minutes. When I arrived, it took them 10 minutes to figure out and tell me that they had forgotten to make my pizza. Given that it is deep dish, it would be another 50 minute wait to get my pizza. They told me they would comp. the pizza (I still had to pay the tax which was weird) and deliver it free of charge. However, when it arrived, they charged me a $2.75 delivery fee. On top of it all, the pizza was way too doughy compared to other times I've had pequods and it seemed like they skimped on the toppings. Only giving them above 1 star because the carmalized crust is good, but not good enough that I'll be coming back after this poor service

No parking, or worried about a ticket... Didnt have a reservation so we were crowded and squeezed into the bar, then served too much dough and not enough anything else. People may like deep dish, but they can keep it, if Pequod's is what they are describing. I will take thin crust over this anytime.

Very tasty pizza but for that price i would like to see more cheese. It's mostly bread and sauce. I believe their sauce and the way the cook it well done is the key. Maybe next time I go I will order extra cheese if they allow it. Therefore beware cheese lovers there is a paper thin layer of cheese on this pizza and the only way they can get away with this is because of how they caramelize the little cheese that is on there which amplifies the flavor.

Also be prepared to for a possible long wait during busy hours, the restaurant is not very big.

Now THIS is the deep dish pizza that we had heard so much about when planning our trip to Chicago. Be ready to wait a long time (over an hour after being seated), but an attentive waitress kept our sodas refilled and we had great conversation while waiting. And, the pizza was worth the wait. This truly felt like a neighborhood spot where you come for the good food and friendly service.

pics.caption: Personal pizza with tomatoes, spinach and garlic. Wow!

review.des: Worst customer service. Pizzas great but management is lacking basic customer service. Long story short, I don't care how good the pizza is after my experience with management. I know my experience is a daily occurrence & the owners should be aware they're losing customers & profit due to their inability to hire employees who have common sense.

I went here on a trip based on the recommendation of a Chicago native. The pizza was incredible -- especially the burnt cheese edges. If you're in the area, it's well worth it. Very casual, noisy sports bar vibe and be prepared to wait around 40min after you order. I enjoyed it, though I'd probably do take out if I went again.

Very disappointed, I had been here quite a few years back and thought it was ok. After the reading the hype, thought I would give it another try.

It's still just ok, doesn't live up to the hype.

PS: I forgot to mention this is the perfect pizza for those lactose intolerant because there is almost no cheese on this pizza.
Fantastic.   Came here with the family.  Travelled from Houston and were told to visit Pequod's.   Holy Cow.  Get the deep dish pizza.   Delicious and filling.   Enjoy.

Don't get it, not sure what all the fuss is about. Somewhat average pizza, maybe its' popularity is because of its' past reputation.

Tried a large tomato cheese pizza and also a pepperoni and vegetable pizza. Both were the same, lots of dough, some tomato sauce and some cheese. Not sure what all the raving is about since the dough is not very tasty. Actually the best part of the dough were the ends that touch the pan which were burnt with cheese. However overall, it was a very bready pizza. Along with that we had the Caesar salad which again was average at best.

For dessert we had a brownie again average at best, it was very cakey and dry.  

Being a tourist, I was very disappointed, as I expected much more. In fact I've tried a deep dish from the Uno's chain and found it to be superior.

I guess I've been there, and done that, but not worth a return visit.  Sorry to lambaste a Chicago institution but I honestly was expecting a lot more.

If you ask me deep dish or thin crust I choose thin crust every day. But as far as deep dish in Chicago Pequods really does it right. Everyone I bring here from out of town falls in love. The crust is delicious here - definitely unique to pequods. Best time to come is when they open so you get seated right away. Order some apps - but stay hungry. I've only ever been able to eat 1 generous slice of deep dish. But it's been well worth it. Leftovers ain't too bad either!

Everyone knows this is basically the best pizza ever. Just ask the insanely long line out the door every night. It's thick, hot, the veggies are fresh, it's not too saucey, and it's absolutely worth the wait. Perfection. The kind of spot you will insist upon to out of towners so they can experience joy for once in their lives.

Came here on a pizza tour; this was my second time here.  

Ambiance: Large and crowded place.

Pizza: We had the sausage pepperoni and it was quite yummy although quite heavy (maybe because we had been at two other pizza places before that). So i suggest you come with an apettie because the slices are quite large.

Staff: We didn't have much contact with the staff so cannot comment.

Everyone raves about this place and I suggest you try it at least once.
The pizza here is amazing. The portions are huge. We had the deep dish pizza. Everything is pretty quick. We had it before seeing a movie across the street.

Been here several times now and the quality is just not consistent.

It's a fine balance between burning the outer cheese too much and keeping it just at the right crispness - and they fail often.

Sauce also hit or miss. Today it was too sweet.

Sausage was great though. One of the most consistent things here.

Crust - fluffier and thicker than Lou's buttercrust and overall tasty.

Just be sure to ask for the outer cheese to not be burned to the point it's all black.

Tasty crispy caramelized cheese isn't totally black, it's a dark brown.
We went to Lou Malnatis first but this place is definitely the real deal original!! If you really want Chicago deep dish! Go here!!
Another Chicago staple.. I have been a customer for more than 25 years..., the crusted cheese sided pizza is like no other.. casual, friendly, family chi town must!!!!
Classic Chicago deep-dish pizza. Surprisingly inexpensive for how filling it is. Bring your A-game appetite.

This is the spot for deep dish that Chicagoans love, and honestly its OKAY. It's not amazing or going out of your way for, but it's not bad either. I would rather take a tourist to this spot than any of those over the top block-of-baked-cheese spots.
Best pizza in the city. Have loved this place for years. Great lunch special.be prepared to wait for weekend dinners. Delicious.

Place is much bigger than I thought.  We were seated on the 2nd floor. Needless to say even our big group of 23 people were quickly seated even though the place was so busy on a Thursday night.  It was my first time but we came here due to one person in our group saying it's the best deep dish pizza ever.  Well it was very good but it's not the best :). We ordered 5 large pan pizzas from regular cheese to sausage garlic to pepperoni garlic.  I'm so full as I ate 4 pieces.  The waitress was nice.  Don't know about the prices since I didn't pay.  My only complaint was the place was loud and we had to yell to talk and hear each other even though we were sitting so close to each other.  I would definitely come back if I'm in the area.

Forget Giordano's or Lou's, Pequod's definitely has the best deep dish in town. Whenever we have friends coming in from out of town wanting some deep dish we always take them here.

Main reason we don't come here more often for our pizza cravings is because the wait is usually 1-2 hours on any night of the weekend.  

The staff is friendly and the food is great. Definitely order some appetizers since you'll have to wait about 30-45min for the pizza. I'd recommend the breaded mushrooms and bruschetta.

pics.caption: Pan pizza with giardiniera, mushrooms and ground beef

review.des:
Best deep dish in my opinion. I'm usually a thin crust type of gal but after my experience with Pequod's. Would have to say it's my top deep dish.

Been here a few times whenever my friends or family visit I would take them to Pequod's and they absolutely loved it. Some even order some to go on their flight back to California. It has all the right flavors. Perfect crust. Not too hard or soft. Just about right. The last few times I was at Pequod's. I order the vegetarian, can't go wrong with just pepperoni, and also the meat lover dish. Also order a side of fries and garlic bread as well.

Just to warn you if you decide to come here get ready to wait. There's always a wait here that's how good it is or if you prefer not to wait. Order to go. Or come on an off time. There were days I've came here around noon during a weekday and longest I waited was 15 mins but weekends your average wait time would be 2hrs.

There's only street parking so it's hard to find if you're driving but I always uber here.

Great pizza! To me, the ratios of dough, sauce and toppings is just right . It takes awhile to get your pizza but they let you know that before you sit down. I recommend coming early instead of during the dinner rush as your wait will be way longer !

We were on the search for the best pizza in Chicago, and tonight I'm convinced we've found it. My sister is ignoring the fact she is lactose intolerant just to consume the deep dished goodness. The vibe is casual and in no way pretentious, the service was fantastic, and best of all, the food did not disappoint. Pequod's offers every comfort you would hope to find in a hometown booth.

We just spent $35 dollars on disappointment. We ordered a large pizza with sausage and mushroom on Memorial Day for delivery. At first, I thought somehow my fiancé had just gotten sauce on the box, himself, and the table. I open the box to find most of the pizza was sauce and dough. We each ate a slice, and then decided the rest wasn't worth eating. We were both hungry and pausing between bites. This really didn't taste anything like the pizza we had at Pequod's before. The following weekend we had a frozen pizza from Costco that was a million times better. What we learned from our $35 dollars of disappointment: do not order delivery from Pequod's. Did I mention we waited close to two hours for this pizza?
Waited 3 hours to sit down. Then waited another hour to get a pizza inside. And the Pizza was mediocre. Worst experience in chicago.

Pequods was recommended to us by numerous people, giving it the title of "Best Pizza in Chicago". We were anxious to try the amazing caramelized cheese crust everyone was raving about. We arrived at Pequods on a Friday at 5 pm, thinking we would beat the dinner crowd. Upon arrival, we were told the wait time would be 20-45 minutes. After a little more than an hour, we were finally seated. We placed our order, and our waitress informed us that the pizza would take about 75 minutes. I wish they would have told us that earlier, but we decided to wait it out since we already made it this far. They weren't lying when they said 75 minutes.

When the pizza finally arrived, we devoured it in less than 10 minutes. Was it amazing? Yes! Would I wait 3 hours again? Probably not. Next time, we're gonna try to avoid the weekend dinner crowd. Waiting 3 hours for a pizza is kind of ridiculous. Plus, they have a great lunch deal.

Now back to the pizza. The bottom of the crust was buttery and golden, with just the right amount of crunch. The caramelized cheese crust was just how I imagined it would be. It had a nice chew to it. The ratio of bread to cheese and toppings was perfect. Not too heavy like most deep dish pizzas. I'm officially giving Pequods my vote for best pizza in Chicago.

Four stars for wait time. But I guess good things come to those who wait.
First time here and coming to Chicago. Definitely heard great things about this place. I'm not a fan of deep dish, so I ordered the thin crust. Let's find out! Go Dodgers!!

Hate to be harsh, but I found it totally meh ...

Went for lunch today around 12:45PM, and it was a 40-minute wait. Sadly, I don't think it was worth it. Ordered the large cheese pan pizza, and here's how I would describe it: was mainly a crust, with a doughy "filling", and then a very thin layer of tomato sauce on top. It comes out kinda burnt too. Where was the cheese? Not sure that this is true deep dish pizza.

And while I realize it was a cold day, it was so cold inside the restaurant that we - and everyone else dining - were wearing our coats while eating. (We ate downstairs so hopefully it's different/better upstairs.)

On the plus side, our waitress was friendly and attentive, you get free refills on your soda, and the cheesy garlic bread and mozzarella sticks (ordered as appetizers) were fine.

Alas, after all the hype, I don't feel the need to come back, as there have got to be better pizza options in this great food city of ours ...

So maybe it was because we ordered take out but i honestly was not impressed. The pizza lacked flavor to me it was a regular cheese and pepperoni but i was hoping for a little more especially since everyone talk about it. I will be trying it again for sure and hopefully ill be able to update this review. But till then...it was just okay.

Good food but bad service.

Was told it would take 45-60 min to get seated, ended up taking a little over 90.

We even ordered our pizza 30 min before we were finally seated and we still had to wait an extra half hour before our food finally arrived.

Bar tenders had their heads in the clouds and everyone else that worked there couldn't care less about disappointed customers.

Stick to delivery if you can.

Always great, and always worth the wait.

Pequod's is, in my book, serves the best pizza in the city of Chicago. If you plan on coming though, know that during peak hours will could easily have an hour or more wait until you get seated, and then another 40 minutes to an hour before you get your pizza (not because they are slow, but because the deep-ish dish pizzas they serve take a long time to make).

The bar has a good selection of beer, and the service is always friendly.

On my most recent visit, about 2 weeks ago, we learned that the owners of Pequod's had opened a bar next door called Whale Tale. The great thing about that place is is that when you put your name in for a seat at Pequod's, your buzzer will work next door at Whale Tale. The people over there know that you are most likely there waiting for a table, and so the service is appropriately fast.

Back to Pequod's though. Sure, ambiance-wise, it's a Blackhawks bar, but the pizza is the star of the show. Their pizza is, like I said before, deep-ish dish. I usually describe it as like a halfway deep dish. Pizzas are made in cast iron skillets and there is a layer of cheese baked in underneath and around the crust giving it a perfect, crunchy, parmesan seasoning all the way around. To me that is the best part. Pizza topping selections are plentiful, and they are not shy about loading them up onto the pizza.

I've never had a bad experience here, but there was only one time that I was here that I didn't have to wait less than an hour for a table (I think it was the middle of the afternoon for some reason).

I can not recommend this pizza enough. You should also note that they do have priority seating that you can access and set up from home before you venture out and take your chances with the wait time. That is definitely worth looking into.

I've had just about every Chicago deep dish (I was born and raised in Chicago, so it's pretty hard not to try them all)

I have to say, this was probably my favorite of them all.

I loved the caramelized cheese on the edge of the crust, good flavor on the sausage, fresh toppings and plenty of cheese.

The service was good, and although the place was extremely busy, we really didn't have to wait long for a table.  (had time for a beer at the bar)]

Definitely a recommend, and in my opinion it's among the best in Chicago.

pics.caption: Caramelized cheese crust, doesn't get any better in my book

review.des: Best. Chicago. Pizza. If you're trying to decide between Pequod's, Lou Malnati's, Gino's, Giordano's, wherever else - you gotta do Pequod's hands down.

In the last couple of years that I've come here, I've learned that the servers are snobby, rude people, but the pizza had always been great, so I've put up with their attitudes. But then yesterday I had this crappy pizza that did not seem the same pizza I've learned to love and be proud of. Whenever my relatives would come to Chicago, I'd put up with the long wait times cuz it was worth it all the way. Did something change with the recipes or ingredients? We ordered two large ones and before the cheese used to overpower and melt into the breading of the pan pizza, now it just looked like some toppings on a piece of bread if that makes sense. Anyway, I was disappointed. :L

I'm trying to give them the benefit of the doubt. I had them on my bucket pizza list to try before I moved away from Chicago. So we ordered their pizza (despite having to do by phone because that is the only way they could take our order). The pizza took forever to get there (even by deep dish standards), and I realize that deep dish doesn't travel well (and I'm not a huge deep dish fan as it is, but again, had heard great things). In any case, I was not a fan of the pizza at all once we did get it and opened it up. If you are going to try them, definitely go in person, and hopefully it is much better than what I experienced.

This is a constant debate between friends who love it and friends who don't think it's great. I personally am a fan. It does have a lot of crush which might turn some people away, but that's what I like. I got spinach deep dish and would highly recommend.

I wanted to kick off my first trip to Chitown right with a deep dish pizza. I was originally going to go to Lou Malnati's but my well-traveled friends steered me to Pequod's which is apparently where the real Chicagans go.

My group of 4 waited an hour to be seated at 8pm on a Thursday. It took close to another hour before we actually got our deep dish pie.

Caesar salad (9) - Pretty basic. It was pricey considering the salad came with nothing but what tasted like packaged croutons and one lone cherry tomato.

Large w/ italian beef, mushrooms, onions (30) - Chicago is know for its italian beef sandwich so I figured may as well hit 2 birds with 1 stone and get it on my pie. The pizza came piping hot and the cheese were perfectly gooey. Pequod's is known for the burnt cheese that coats the edge of the pie and that was probably my favorite part. I'm usually not big on crust and unfortunately Pequod's wasn't an exception. I like my crust to be crispier but theirs is on the doughy, airy side.

Was it delicious? Hell yes.
Would I wait 2 hours again? Doubtful.
Should you go if it's your first deep dish experience in Chicago? Definitely.

Large w/ italian beef, mushrooms, onions

review.des: Best pizza in Chicago. It's worth the wait, sometimes they'll let you call ahead and place your order. Skip the other Chicago pizza joints you hear people talk about, this is the spot to go and where locals go!

Visited Pequod's last week. My brother, nephew, and myself came out from California. I must say, you folks in Chicago don't know how good you have it there. You cannot get pizza half this good in California unless you make it yourself. We got 2 medium pizzas, sausage and pepperoni and sausage and onion. We are 3 big eaters and still had 2 pieces left over. The carmalized crust lived up to the hype, wasn't doughy at all, sauce was fantastic, and the sausage pieces were golf ball size. I loved the fennel taste and garlic. Servers were good and kept the water and beers coming as needed. I really enjoyed the old town feeling there as well. A dinner like that in CA would cost $100+, it was only $65 there. CA really sucks, at everything!!! I'm moving.

It is with great disappointment that I write a poor review for Pequod's. I just recently visited with great enthusiasm to eat Chicago Deep Dish at this location, but I left very saddened and dissatisfied with my experience.

My main complaint is in regards to the timeliness and service. I had just arrived home from a long road trip and was excited to eat at a former favorite Chicago establishment.

I visited on a Sunday evening around 7pm. When I arrived, I was greeted and told there would be a half hour wait, which I was ok with, expected, and accepted the pager to await to be seated. About 20 minutes had passed and I noticed a couple of parties that came in after me we're being seated before me. I waited a few more minutes and then approached the hostess to see where I was in line as I was concerned that I may have been overlooked. The hostess was quick to notice that she could not find my pager number on the list, despite having a pager number assigned. She apologized and said she would have me seated next. I was quickly assigned a table and as the other host was directing me to it, she explained that my pager had been called as indicated by the circle marking on the device, but didn't understand why it didn't go off to alert me that my table was ready. Again, the hostess apologized and said it was good that I mentioned something otherwise I could have continued to wait unknowingly as they proceeded to go through the waitlist disregarding my assigned pager number.

My server came and took my drink and pizza order shortly after. I ordered a Small Deep Dish pizza and having been here before and aware of the signage regarding cooking and wait times for a deep dish, the wait began. There were a couple of parties across from me who just received their pizzas when I ordered, they ate and left as I waited. I also noted that I was watching the end of the 4th quarter of an NBA Playoff Game and started to watch the following playoff game close to Half Time.

Basically I waited quite a while as the tables across from me had new parties seated and waiting whose pizza orders, one of which was a Large Deep Dish came out and was served at the same time as my Small Deep Dish was served. I expressed my concern to my server regarding the wait time, who seemed somewhat agitated that the wait time was an issue to me, explaining the cooking time can take up to 50 minutes. I could have mentioned, that was the only time I was checked on since I had placed my order and I explained that I was not arguing or complaining, just voicing my concerns regarding the obvious situation regarding the timeliness. My server said she would have a manager come by though I did not ask. I was already feeling miserable about the whole experience that honestly I just wanted to pay and leave. (Of note, I noticed the servers were using hand held pads for ordering and charging which I am sure could easily time stamp the events as they were placed.)

A manager came over and apologized saying that he understood the situation, explained that it was busy, and  it just happened that all the pizza orders came out at the same time. I was offered 25% off my bill, which I honestly did not care to account for as a new server came by to check on me and who I asked to have my pizza boxed, that I just wanted to close out and pay.

As a Chicagoan who has lived here for some time and has had positive memories of this place before, I will no longer return nor recommend this place to residents or visitors alike. Is it a pizza to experience? Possibly, but it is definitely not worth the wait and with so many options for a good Chicago Deep Dish, there are a number of better pizza places in this great city.

I understand this review may not be significant to anyone that could go through the thousands of positive reviews, but for anyone that does happen to read through this, I hope you have a better experience if you decide to eat here.
Not much else to say other than the food here is awesome.   The parking is a little off, but the food definitely made up for this.  My wife and I will be back sooner rather than later.

I'll start by saying: I'm not a fan of deep dish.  However, if I was in the rare mood for a bit, I'd say Pequods is amazing. Solid crust and good hearty sauce. Much is left to be desired on the restaurant venue appeal, didn't look pristine or clean, but I chalked it up to being a "dive pizza joint."  Plus, you're not eating pizza off the tables. :)

Since discovering Lou Malnati's last year, I've decided that I like Chicago deep dish more than I thought I did. On our way to the airport, we were limited on time and therefore came here upon a friend's recommendation. I liked the feel of this spot. A bar/pizza joint. The service was excellent. Everyone was so friendly and nice to newbies like us.

I liked their caesar salad. It was nice to munch on it while we waited for our pizza that takes about 20 minutes to make. So in comparing the two, I think I like Lou's better for a few reasons. Pequod's crust was too burnt/crunchy for me. There wasn't enough cheese. I like Lou's because of the perfect chunky tomato sauce to cheese ratio, as well as it not feeling insanely heavy by being too heavily breaded. But I do like this spot's vibe and their beer selection.

Do you like caramelized cheese rings? If so you are going to LOVE Pequod's! Wouldn't call it deep dish but hey, neither do they so we good. Think, Pizza Hut pan pizza with fresher ingredients and a magic ring of caramelized cheese around the crust.

Came here with my friend for lunch to try another Chicago-style pizza place, since I had tried Lou Malnati's during my visit to Chicago last year. We were seated immediately upon entering. The interior is not huge; the restaurant is deep but not very wide. The atmosphere was very pub/bar like, which I did not expect.

Service was friendly and our waitress was great. She said it would be about a 45-minute wait for deep dish pizza, so we tried to place our order quickly. I think the actual wait time ended up being just a little over thirty minutes though.

I also ordered one slice of thin crust just to try, and added one of the "premium toppings" of Italian beef (apparently also very Chicago) to it. It was a big slice and not bad, but I prefer my thin crust even crunchier (think New York-style pizza, and yes, I realize that I shouldn't be expecting that while in Chicago).

All of the deep dishes start off with just cheese and you customize your pie from that point after picking a size. Each additional topping costs extra, and the cost of each topping depends on the diameter of your pizza. You can also order half-toppings (I think it means it is only put on half of your pizza) and premium toppings.

The deep dish was decent, but not particularly memorable in my opinion. I enjoyed the "caramelized edges" mentioned on the menu, but instead of the crunchy crust I was expecting, it was actually just darkened cheese which they must sprinkle along the pan's edge. I think I prefer a crunchier crust overall, which is why I usually get thin crust during the rare occasions that I eat pizza at all.

I'm glad I tried Pequod's and their food is not bad, but I think Lou Malnati's better suits my tastes (just a personal opinion).

pics.caption: Deep dish mushroom, garlic, and basil.

review.des:
Yuk!
Service: 1/5
The waitress really didn't know the menu, as small as it is. We didn't order jalapeños (which I love, but not on pizza) which ended up on both pizzas. And she charged us twice for one of the pizzas. I'm not into causing a scene so I didn't mention that or the jalapeños.

Atmosphere: 5/5
Multiple TVs playing sports 24/7, what's not to like?
Rathskeller like lighting, fun.

Pizza: 1.5/5 (we ordered deep dish and thin crust).
Sauce: bitter, tasted like it was cooked and not laddled on fresh.
Cheese/toppings: Small gobs of mazzorella on the top, did not cover whole pizza! Light on the meat.

Crust: too much flower, cracker like consistency (too much flower, acidic bite), and no char!!! Unforgivable.

Seriously, Pizza Hut is better.

Pretty good deep dish pizza. A 40 minute wait which is standard for Chicago deep dish. The crust was good but not life changing. Good local Lincoln Park pizza joint. The fried zucchini was really ok and service was slow to normal.

Wow! What a terrific pizza rest, the personal size pizza is wonderful, the chicken wing were crispy and delicious, the service was fat, polite and friendly! We were lucky we didn't have to wait ! We will definitely go there again and again!

4 stars for the very accommodating and very good service...but is it worth the Michelin hype? I didn't think so (3.5 stars for the pizza). The pizza crust is good, but when you order sausage in your pizza, you expect more than a few measly bits of sausage on your pizza. Seriously. My first slice was huge but had two tiny pieces of sausage. Good on the veggies, though. The next slice, which was smaller, did not fare much better. Alas, Pequod's, you will never replace my love of Lou Malnatti's with its stick of butter in the crust and wheel of sausage. Just to be clear, I didn't expect a wheel of sausage...just an adequate amount of sausage to reflect the medium pie we ordered. *sigh* Next time I'm in town, I will go back to my favorite, or even Giordano's which is a solid second in terms of pizza. This is clearly at least a third or a fourth. I really wanted to like you!!!

The caramelized crust on their own pizza is to die for. I know this place technically isn't deep dish, but if you're looking for some Chicago-esque pizza in the city, I try to take visitors from out of town here instead of Giordano's or lou malnatis.
This is one of the best deep dish pizza places in Chicago. I usually get the sausage green pepper and black olive and it never disappoints. But whatever you get is good.

My most favorite thick pizza in the city. That crust is delicious and pizza is just amazing and worth the wait.

Skip the typical bar food appetizers, they really aren't that great. But the pizza makes up for it. Just plan to wait for the pie.

This is my favorite pizza in the city! The staff is INSANE about checking and double checking ID's here, which is so weird for a pizza restaurant. I've seen the waitresses drinking beer on the job too! I usually order and take home because I know the service is so poor, but god their pizza is so amazing

I've been eating Pequod's for years and love it! While I wish they put a little more sauce on their pizza, the overall quality and flavor is top notch! Make sure to swing by and check them out if you're in the area.
The only "deep dish" pizza I like. That carmely cheese... oh man...

First time in Chicago and I did some research on the best deep dish pizza prior to arriving. Pequod's was first on my list. I just HAD to go. The building was so old and had such a cool vibe. They took us up these old metal stairs to the upper floor. Loved the atmosphere! We were given shabby menus that you know thousands have seen and ordered the pan pizza which they were known for. We were told it would be a 40 min wait (they also had a sign as we came in that notified customers of the wait time). We ordered their bruschetta as we waited. It was phenomenal! The pizza seemed to come quicker than we expected. IT. WAS. AMAZING! It will haunt me in a good way. Staff was great. Heard about the Whale Tale. Can only imagine how crazy this place gets during the prime season. Will most definitely be back!!!
Our fav pizza in chicago- worth the wait for the atmosphere and classic flavor. We had drinks at the whales tail next door, had deep dish. Delicious!

pizza is decent. I like the amount of toppings and I like the burnt style crust. But they lose stars for their service. their delivery service has horrendous and took 2 hours to get and they didn't even apologize.

I got their garlic pepperoni and liked it. Good, but not amazing. I get Lou's cravings more often. Don't really crave peaquods much.

I'm from Chicagoland suburbs, I've had every type of pizza from paisans, giordanos, Lou malnatis, home run inn, and etc. Plus to top it I've had pizza from all around the us; Connecticut which actually won an award for best pizza in America, multiple places in New York, and so on. Pequod's is hands down the beat pizza I've ever had. Even my friend whom swore against deep dish pizza saying it was gross says Pequod's is the best he's ever had as well!

Not a big pizza person but the pizza here is unlike anything I've ever had. The caramelized cheese makes the pizza and it is supported by great crust and sauce. Don't be afraid to order randomly off the menu the quality of food shows through all their dishes. Service is always great and thorough even when they are extremely busy. Always worth the wait.

Definitely do their "priority seating" thing online. Even with that, it took an hour and a half to get a table (we were quoted 30-1 hour) and then you have to wait an hour while your pizza cooks...

Other than that everything about this place is amazing. The interior is cute and reminds you of any of the other Chicago pizza joints, and the waitress, while overwhelmed, was still friendly. The sausage pizza was absolutely AMAZING!!!!! I have been a die hard fan of Gino's (despite being told it's a tourist pizza, not the real deal) but I may have to change my allegiance...I had been told this was where true Chicagoans go for their deep dish, and now I totally get why. The pizza was easily some of the best I've ever had.

Overall, come on an off night, cuz they aren't exactly the best with managing reservations. But no matter what the wait or price or whatever, the pizza is worth it.

Overall a good pizza but the hype was high and the pizza was just good.  The crust was overdone and while there were PLENTY of toppings the taste was just good.  Nothing wrong.  The brochette had a nice tomato based topping on garlic bread but was not worth the almost $8.  Calling ahead helped greatly with the wait and the service was good.
Added a pic

Stuff me like the bread and beer processing machine I was meant to be. I've been sauced many times at this fine establishment not only from the vast beer selection but by the never ending flow of well spiced tomato gravy.

This is real Chicago style pizza. It's the freshest pizza that I have eaten with traditional ingredients and their own special sauce. We were recommended to come here based on our hotel. We wish they had one of these places back home. It's so good. Highly recommend visiting if you happen to be in town. If you're a local, you're one of the luckiest person in town.

The pizza and chicken wings here are both top tier. Every time I have gone I have had to wait to be seated, which is a sign of how good they are. Because their popularity outweighs their capacity, I suggest trying to get before the dinner rush.

I've ordered delivery from Peaquods a couple of times in the past and had I never been to the actual restaurant, this might be a 5 star review.

I feel like the longer I live in Chicago, the more I hate deep dish, but of all the deep dish places, this is one of my more preferred...It's saucy, there's a hell of a lot of toppings (so you don't feel ripped off paying $30+ for a damn pizza), and though heavy - you don't feel as terrible as you do after eating Giordanos, per say.

My visit to the actual Peaquods though (and I've been twice), was kind of disappointing. The actual pizza parlor is a little reminiscent of a dive bar (similar to the feel of Pizano's on State/Gold Coast). My complaint though has to do with the waitstaff. It really seemed like they were doing the minimum. "Can i take your order?" "here's your food" "Here's your bill." It just took away from the deep dish pizza experience.

That all being said, I still recommend Peaquod's to all my out of town friends (vs. some of the other well known deep dish chains in Chicago).

Amazing deep dish pizza. Really long waits, but sitting at the bar (first come first serve, wait for a spot) always gets  the job done! There's a small one upstairs too! Haven't had to wait for one of those spots yet.

Bathrooms too close to the dining tables and someone destroyed the bathroom when I was there just made for a very unpleasant experience.. pizza was fluffy but very dry tasteless bland crust. Ended up going here with the pizza your downtown. Next time I would pass. Too crowded, too hot, and smells like feces because of the stalls by the tables #yuck

Yeah, decided to try and give them another shot today. Figured I'd try carryout this time. Went to see a movie across the street, then afterward walked in, and placed my order, pre-paid and all. They said an hour to an hour and 15 it would be ready. Came back after running misc errands at about an hour and 20 minutes later. Nope...needed 10-15 more in the oven. Took 30.

There's just no drive for service here. It's a shame that the food is an easy 5-star rating but the general attitude towards the customer is a 1-2.

Do better. Im kind of done with this place. Lou's has exceptionally better service and if Pequods is #1A for pizza Lou's is #1B. Im fine with that.

PS: Funny side note: They have the 2014 Zagat survey of their restaurant posted on the wall inside near the carryout pickup...Service is rated a full 8 points lower than food. As if they're proud of it.
Best fuckin pizza I ever had in my life but I have yet to visit NYC just for the record.... Don't sleep on em
Best in town. If someone comes to visit it's the first place we go. If you think Lous is where you take someone from out of town, I feel bad for that person.

Visiting from San Diego I tried three places while in San Diego. Connies, Luminatis and this place.

This place wins hands down.

Ordered the deep dish with sausage jalapeño and onion. Shared a pizza with a friend for $30.

Totally worth it!

pics.caption: Perfectly balanced.. jalapeño, sausage and onion.
Decadent jalapeño, sausage and onion deep dish!

review.des: I first heard of Pequod's on the Food Network. When I saw it, I immediately knew my first stop in Chicago. The wait wasn't as long as I expected and was seated within 20 minutes. I ordered fries for an appetizer and they came out quickly. The fries were really good and had some kind of seasoning on them to make them stand out. The pizza took awhile to come out and I expected that since it is made to order and deep dish pizza. The pizza was good  as advertised. The only downfall for my time at Pequod's was the wait to get cashed out.
Not a huge fan of deep dish, however Pequod's hits the spot - way less cheese, more toppings & sauce. & the caramelized crust...! Give them a try!

It's fine. The pizza is good. I didn't know honk that the caramelized crust was much different than other pizza places. It's a good place to get a place to eat, if you are in the area. There was nothing wrong with the service or food. I ate lunch there, it was a nice setting. Not sure what goes on at night- it seems to be attached to a club? One thing to keep in mind that, like all good pizza joints, expect about an hour wait to get your pizza.

Delicious.  Great crust.  Amazing flavor.  Crust is out of this world.  Deep dish pizza is flavorful and is the best deep dish pizza in chicago.  the bread, crust, cheese is out of the park.  this caramelized crust is great. the cheese is fabulous.  Awesome Pizza!

During my short weekend trip to Chicago, I had the pleasure of trying 3 of (from my research) the top deep dish pizza joints in the city. Pequod's is ranked #2 for me.

I highly recommend going to their website and making a reservation right away. They will text you a day before to confirm your ressie and you're set. When we walked in on a Saturday night at 7pm it was PACKKKED. The party of 2 ahead of us was given a 2.5 hour wait time. We were a party of 7 and we were seated right away. MAKE A RESERVATION.

Loud, large dive bar feel.

+ bruschetta - Skip it. It's bland and not good at all here.

+ ravioli pesto and marinara - Both were tasty, but nothing to brag about. If you're craving ravioli and want to order one, I'd say go with the pesto.

+ PIZZAAAAAA

CRUST - their "caramelized crust" is their specialty and what separates them from the rest. It's basically burnt layers of cheese -- ok that doesn't sound too appetizing but trust me, it's so crunchy and SO good.

TOPPINGS - You can choose your own toppings (from basic and premium lists). They say  not to pile too much on.

-- Sausage and pepperoni - per our waiter's recommendation. Basic, but SO SOLID. I think would've been better with mushrooms and bell peppers.

-- Bell peppers, mushrooms, and Italian beef - also per our waiter's recommendation. It was good, but the beef didn't really go well with the pizza overall. I wish we would've gotten more veggies and tried the meatballs instead.

I think if we weren't starving and did more research on which toppings to choose, we would've enjoyed our pizza way more. Nonetheless, Pequod's is still a MUST on your hit-list for Chicago eateries and we're glad we got to enjoy it with little hassle/wait.

pics.caption: Mushrooms bell peppers be Italian beef
Mushrooms bell peppers n Italian beef

review.des: Love this place a billion times!!!! Great pizzas!!! Velvet gorgeous voice waiter sang happy birthday. He made mr laugh so hard forget comedy clubs come here!!!!!!!awesome

My favorite.
Crust is unreal. Tend to overeat and say I'll never eat pizza again, but I eventually find myself coming back to Pequods.
This is my favorite deep dish place in Chicago. The ingredients are fresh and delicious! You have to have the sausage, yum!
Big portions and delicious. We ordered a medium pizza and were so full! I had leftovers for days. I'd definitely come back here. Such a chill setting.

Yum! Long wait!

Went at 12:45pm on a Sunday. It was packed, but we got a table for two within about 20 minutes. Our pizzas came about 45 mins after ordering (which was quicker than the expected 50-60 minutes).

Got two deep dish personal pan pizzas, one pepperoni and one with pepperoni and veggies.

The crust wasn't too massive (which is why I don't like Giordano's), but I didn't think it had much flavor either. The toppings were nicely cooked and there was a good ratio of sauce and cheese.

Nice atmosphere, the front windows open, good selection of drinks and apps to keep you satisfied while waiting on the pizza. There must have been group seating upstairs, but the downstairs has a bar and two and four tops.

Next time I'm going to pop over to the new nail place just across the street to get a quick mani while waiting!

pics.caption: Pepperoni personal deep dish and another with pep, green olives, green pepper & onion.

review.des:
Very DISAPPOINTED! Had to toss it in the trash. It was NOT deep dish more like bread with marinara, cheese and meatball slices. How whack is that?!? It was a thin layer of cheese on top of thick bread. I don't understand why it takes 45 minutes to make bread dip dish.

I'm only giving the two stars for the friendliness of Makayla (Filipino girl) she was very friendly. People like that who are friendly make the establishment wonderful.

Parking is so hard to find but there is street. Like I said before good luck.

pics.caption: I didn't know deep dish is all Bread. 3/23/2016 personal meatball dough deep dish

review.des: Came here on a Saturday around 7:30pm and there was a two hour wait for a party of 2. Luckily the bar is open seating so my friend and I managed to find a seat in about 20minutes. We shared a small pan pizza with pepperoni and mushroom and it was delicious! They are generous with their toppings, which helps balance the thicker crust. I also really enjoyed their tomato sauce, which is surprising because I'm usually not a fan of super saucy pizzas, but the flavor was phenomenal.  I've been in Chicago a few years now and have been to all the major places. Pequod's pizza isn't what comes to mind when I think of "deep dish" due to the fact that it's not stuffed. Instead it's a thicker caramelized bread crust that's balanced with a generous portion of good quality ingredients. Regardless, it's a Chicago must! I really enjoyed the pizza and would definitely recommend it!

Best pizza in the city according to me. Love the sausage. Love the buttery crust. Deep dish is amazing l, but thin is quite good too. Definitely takes a bit to get a table sometimes, but it's worth the wait and they have good beer.

Excellent deep dish pizza in a dive-y setting. We had a small and it was plenty for the two of us with leftovers to take home. Loved the carmelized crust. We shared the half sized house salad and that was also plenty. It was about 5 miles away from downtown so nice to get out of the downtown area for a bit on our long weekend visit. This place is legit.

pics.caption: Genuine Chicago deep dish pizza. Excellent. Very filling. One piece was enough for me.

review.des:
Chicago. Day 7. Pizza.

Deep dish crust - 5/5
Toppings (pepperoni + sausage) - 3/5
Toppings (italian beef + ground beef) - 4/5

Overall, best deep dish I've had. "As good as it gets."

The reason I came back was bc the pizza is done right !! So so good  

Good timing: did a 9pm delivery for the identical pizza & it was delivered to my house tonight at 10pm, but it was very skimpy on the toppings including the cheese. I also had only 7 pieces of green peppers and the onions were a great portion. That cost 1 star in my book. Was kinda bummed.

The second observation for tonight's meal was the $6 cheesecake that was smaller than small and very much not the value I'm used too at this restaurant. When I say small, I'm talking like
"is this a bad joke or something?"

I went to take a picture of it but my boyfriend had already eaten most of it. My comparison for this is that the $8 cheesecakes at the cheesecake factory are litterally 4x the size and gourmet to the heavens...
