Seating is very limited and about 20 minutes after we were seated, a huge line of people formed at the hostess stand (they began quoting wait times of 1 to 2 hours)! It takes a while to bake a fresh pizza so don't come here if you are in a hurry.

I probably should've taken away 2 stars for their awful instant iced tea. Skip it. So gross. I always lose major respect for restaurants that care too little to fresh brew their own iced tea. It's not that difficult to do! At least the beer list has Lagunitas, a must-have with pizza.

I made the mistake of letting my husband order the pizza and opted for a medium with extra pepperoni. Let me tell you, Pequod's understands the concept of "extra." This pie was loaded with spicy pepperoni and it was good, but I had to pick off pepperoni to give him because there was so much. I really liked this pizza (didn't love it, but it's good). The crust is very light and fluffy and tastes like beer. It reminded me of a classic pan pizza crust, but the carmelization was amazing! I could eat that part all day long. The sauce was very spicy which I also liked. This isn't a fancy place but the pizza is great. It was worth the walk.

pics.caption: Their iced tea is instant and gross. Go with soda, water or beer instead.

review.des:
We visited Pequod's for the first time on Friday, September 2nd.  We arrived at about 8:15PM.  
As a visitor, it appears that there are three main competitors that are popular with both locals and tourists.  Pequod's, Lou Malnati's and Gino's East.  

Well, Pequod's was our favorite of the two that we tried (The other one was Lou Malnati's).
We absolutely loved the crust and the way they browned the cheese that was melted over the crust.  We found the pizza and toppings to taste delicious and we were pleased with the amount of sauce and cheese used.  

I would DEFINITELY RETURN and eat here again,.  Why three stars?  I have one suggestion.
I wish you would be able to "order ahead" once you put your name in and then by the time you get your table, there was less of a wait.

I know, that would probably cut into profits for ordering other things like appetizers and drinks; however, during busy times, would that really be a problem?  It seems like there is always someone waiting anyway.

Secondly, and due to no fault of the restaurant, there was a group of really, really drunk party of five slurring generalized insults the entire time.  They were rude, throwing food around, saying discriminatory things that several tables could hear and just were a terrible group of people to be sitting around.  

Should we have said anything? I'm not sure whether we should or not.  The server who very clearly heard them should have been the one to take care of the issue (I personally believe)

So, overall -- our favorite pizza -- and we would return.

Not a huge deep dish fan but when visiting Chicago, I figure you have to at least have it once.

I've done Uno and Lou Malnatis but wanted to give Pequods a shot- it did not disappoint. Really enjoyed the crust versus the overly buttery kind you typical get. Also found it to be a little less doughy overall.

Would definitely recommend adding this to your Chicago pizza tour.

I came here on a recommendation from a friend who lived in Chicago.  I got on the "preferred seating" list for 7 p.m. and we got here early.  Upon arrival we were told that it would be a wait of 45 minutes to an hour.....even though we got on their "preferred seating" list for 7.  What kind of restaurant makes you wait an extra hour even though you have a reservation?

I guess business here is so good you can lie and give customers the shaft and not have to worry about it.

I waited to review Pequod's until I had many others under my belt (85+ at this point). I remember loving it about two years ago when I first had it; before I knew anything about the hype. You can argue who has the best deep dish in Chicago, but I want to put a spin on this. If you look at the menu, they call this "pan" pizza and I'm glad they do, because I'd consider them the best pan pizza in Chicago, not deep dish. What I'm trying to say is pan pizza is known to be over-compensated on the dough. This is a very doughy pizza. I consider deep dish more balanced with more cheese and toppings and less dough. To each their own. I really like the airiness of the crust. It has a well-cooked bottom crunch, yet a chewy center. The sauce is more savory and is a true sauce, not chunk tomatoes. I hate to say it, but the sausage tasted a little dry and gritty. This is more than likely due to it being cooked on top of the pizza. There was a decent amount of cheese. It was enough, but wouldn't have complained if there was more. Of course I have to mention the caramelized cheese crust. This is the best bite of the pizza and what they are famous for. Don't be alarmed, it does not taste burnt at all! I also got a thin crust pizza. It's nice that they do a braided outer crust. The toppings were abundant and the it was far more cheesy than the pan pizza. I really liked the thin crust. I think everyone should at least get Pequods once to say they did and it may be your new favorite pan pizza. If you like lots of dough, this will be your place.

Having lived in Chicago for over a decade, leaving and then coming back again, I can now safely say that the beat deep dish is from Pequods. It's tough to get in on a weekend night, but weekday evenings are no problem.

What is there to state accept this is the best pizza in the city. They take pizza to another level for taste and the restaurant experience is not bad either. They did a remodel some years ago at the Clybourn location to add more seating and to update the look. The crust and the pizza sauce is just magnificent. This place is definitely worth the trip if you are not close to this location. They also have a location in Morton Grove.

bon appétit!

I call Lou Malnati's Pizzeria my favorite Chicago pizza chain, but Pequod's may very well be my favorite Chicago pie! The Carmel crust is to die for and is like no other. Very cozy joint in a nice neighborhood. Parking is difficult but worth it. If ever in Chicago and looking for a true Chicago gem this is it!

Took a long time to come out and the refills were slow.
But the pizza was very good.  We ordered a deep dish with olives, onion and mushrooms.

I really like the pizza here. I've only had the deep dish. Also have had salad and apps there which were fine but nothing special. My boyfriend has gotten a pasta dish and thought it was good but nothing to write home about. The pizza has a caramelized crust which I've heard some people think is too much of a burnt flavor, which I can understand. It's up to your personal preference whether you will love the pizza or not. The service is just ok, and I've ordered it for delivery which was not a good experience. They messed up on my delivery time and tried to deliver it when I wasn't there, so came back about an hour later after completing more deliveries. I had to microwave the pizza once it arrived and the fries we got were soggy. I would go back for the pizza, but would not do delivery again.

Oh, deep dish. Tried 'em all, including now the locally-recommended Pequod's. Cheesier than others, bottom crust a bit thicker, and it sticks together better than most -- but it's also pricier than most, and with it comes a wait time longer than most. Maybe I just don't like deep dish that much.

Thin pizza was below par. At least the employees were all super nice?
Three times, three pizzas delicious and warm from the oven. You can't claim yourself a visitor to Chicago until you have brought your stomach here! The best deep dish in Chicago!

We ordered a pizza an hour before close, paid for it upfront, walked up 20 minutes before close to pick it up which is when we were told to come get it and all the employees looked at us, and ducked behind the bar. We waited outside knocking to get our pizza that was paid for, never got it, and out $30.

Deep Dish pizza is good. If you're visiting Chicago I would try one of the more popular joints just to avoid the long wait and hit this place when you have more time to try different pizza places.

Waited about two hours for a table. The customer diversity was made up of a lot of families and a lot of kids. It was a bit of a mad house but the staff handled everything well.

I have always heard people talking about pequods so when I came to eat here with a bunch of friends I was so hyped. We even brought some friends that were visiting from Florida. The place was packed so I thought it was a good sign. We ordered the sausage with pepperoni, pepperoni sausage with jalapeño, and canadian bacon with pineapple. After we ate I felt so bad for bringing my out of town friends. It was so meh. It wasn't bad but it also wasn't good. Good thing Florida pizza is trash so pequods was ok to them. The atmosphere is fun but it gets so packed that sometimes it's hard to get a hold of your server. But when u do they are nice and helpful.

While the pizza is amazing, the customer service is less than stellar (at least for delivery).  I've frequented Pequods for many years, several times a month.  I finally decided to get it delivered.  I noticed that I was less than a block from the cusp of their delivery zone and almost didn't call until I saw that they would be willing to make "reasonable accommodations."   I was told that it was way too far north (even though they deliver for several more miles south) (about 2.5 miles).  In fact, they tried arguing with me as to where I actually lived, stating that it was far too many miles north of a particular street (that I actually live south of!)
Am I bitter?  Sure.  But when they offer "reasonable accommodations," and then argue about the location of my address.... hmm.  no pizza is worth that treatment.

I have definitely had better service from here before and I was k with the crappy service, til I got home to eat our carry out pizza. We got there at 4:30 pm, at this time we were advised there was a 45 minute wait, so we went to the "waiting tank". Now its 5:45pm and we still have not been seated, I went to ask how long did we still have to wait for a table, the hostess gave me attitude as if "how dare I asked such question" and said we still had 7 people ahead of us.  Couldn't wait for that, had 7pm tickets for the movies and its almost 6pm, I still had another hour for a table and 30 minutes for the pizza... lol. I just placed an order for a carry out to have ready when we left the movie theater.. 20 minutes later, once I finished my drink, went to the same girl and asked to change the time for pick up, wanted to assure my pizza wasn't just sitting there over cooking if it was done earlier than expected. She told me it was impossible to change the time, she said " the kitchen is extremely backed up, most likely it won't be ready by 9 regardless".
We get there at 9:30, which was the time I asked them to change the pick up time to, didn't check the pizza, was too excited to eat it since I had been craving it for months.
when I get home, its an over cooked and cold pizza that I found. I couldn't even finish one slice. Hostess should try to pay more attention to requests, it would make the 3 hour wait more bearable.

We are from out of town and went here based on Yelp reviews. We went on a Monday night at 8pm, so we were seated immediately. Take note that even after you order, it's a 45-50 minute wait for the pizza. We ordered the small deep dish pepperoni for the two of us. My husband ate both of his and was full-- I could only eat one. It was really good but the underneath was a bit dry. The caramelized crust was delicious.

Hands down the best deep dish pizza in Chicago! I've ordered delivery from there no less than 25 times in the past couple years and it's consistently exceptional pizza!

As a heads up, there's often a wait if you go in person. I'd recommend putting your name in and then heading to grab a drink at the bar next door.

Keep it up Pequod's!
Omg my favorite deep dish place in Chicago. It's where I bring all of the out of towners for "real Chicago pizza". It's also a great date place, right across the street from the movie theater.

Pequod's is my favorite pizza in Chicago and that is saying a lot because Chicago has terrific pizza.  To give you an example of how great it is, I never order an all veggie pizza because I usually don't feel satisfied unless there is a meat topping.  This is the only place where I will order one because their thin crust pizza is puffy and delicious, they have they perfect amount of cheese and their seasoning is so good.  Of course their thick crust pizza is wonderful too.  You can't miss with anything you order.

First off: I think deep dish pizza is sort of like a very large hot pocket at best and a tomato soup in a soggy bread bowl at worst. SO, I'm a little biased because I'm not the biggest fan of deep dish.

That being said, I thought that the amount of food was fantastic. The portion size is fairly good, though it's not exactly "cheap eats" for 2. My boyfriend was disappointed in what he got for the cost, but he also couldn't stop comparing it to regular pizza in NY.

Pequod's felt different to me than Giordano's, and I appreciated the decor and the zombie Moby Dick theme, so for that alone, I think this place is solid.

I'm a huge fan of sauce, so I actually loved that there was a lot of it, and that's my favorite part about deep dish. The pan style pizza here is served in the pan, and the service was good. The crust is nice and burnt, just the way we all like it. It's not a ton of cheese but still plenty for you to feel like you're going to have a heart attack. I think it would've been awesome for a late night snack but unfortunately, we had too many meals planned to take any home or go back. I look forward to trying this place again next time around.
Don't care for the wait or the attitude. Pizza is meh. Honestly, the alternatives you have before you when you are rejected by them and often much better.

We shared a wonderful deep dish pizza that we customized with pepperoni, sausage and green papers. It was delicious! Be aware that you will wait 40 minutes from the point of ordering before your pizza is served! The place is multi-level and buzzing with people. Fun, casual environment!
Great pizza, friendly service and laid back vibes in the cutest neighborhood. This is a must!

Wouldn't know how the pizza is because the person taking delivery orders was so rude I decided not to go ahead with the order. Seems like they don't need my business, so I'll take it elsewhere.

Update: my husband did order the pizza one night and the crust came completely burned and the pizza just wasn't good (although I liked their pepperoni). I can't believe this place is to popular
Best pizza in Chicago. The wait is rough - always...but worth it. Grab your pager and go next door for a cocktail while you wait!

Absolutely my favorite pizza in the city. A unique take on deep dish with a delicious crispy cheese crust.

Would recommend the pepperoni banana pepper toppings - so good.

Long waits if you go in person pretty often but ordering takeout works great.

Pequod's isn't the best pizza in Chicago, it's the best pizza on the planet!  The caramelized crust is to die for!  After living here for 20+ years, this is my go to place to amaze out-of-towners on our best local pizza.  Pro tip:  the personal pan pizza lunch special gets you maximum caramelized crust for minimal wait time.  Enjoy!

Pequod's is the only deep dish pizza that I recommend to friends and family visiting Chicago.  Other pizzerias tend to have a spongey crust that gets soggy towards the end of the meal, but Pequod's caramelized crust holds up to the weight of the ingredients on top much better.

Quick tip:  Instead of sharing a medium pizza between two people, get two personalized pizzas for more caramelized crust.

Pizza was just ok.  Service was not good.  Slow and no attention to detail.  Then my wife told me the woman's restroom was dirty.  We had 3 places our friends told us to go for pizza, next time we will try one of the others.

My favorite 'deep dish' in town. FYI- it takes 45 minutes to prepare from time of order. The caramelized cheese crust is delicious.  Not too heavy. The sauce is super yummy too. Staff was friendly. Will definitely be back & will shoot to bring visitors here instead of the more familiar choices.
If you don't get the caramelized crust you're not doing it right. And the sauce... ooooooh the sauce... I love this place
No double about it, Pequad's has the best pizza in Chicago! Hands down!
Amazing pizza! Best deep dish pizza in Chicago!

Very mediocre. We were definitely disappointed based on all the stellar reviews of the deep dish pizzas. Our pizza crust tasted okay but nothing great. The dough was a little dry and bland. The wait here is also insane and definitely not worth it.

I probably won't go back as it is not worth the wait for the mediocre deep dish. Personally,  I think Lou Malnati's is better. Maybe it was an off night?

I came here once before but just got a salad. It was good, really big portion but again, nothing i would order again.
One of the best deep dish pizza in Chicago hands down!the pizza is always good the long wait is the only major downside to pequods.

Deep Dish! I literally came from New York to try this pizza! My girlfriend is a Pizza lover, so after asking around and doing some research we landed in Pequads! The cast-iron plate makes a big difference, and as my pallet continues to evolve you can taste the different seasoning! Worth the travel!  Check out my instagram for places to visit and eat @expensive_appetite

After a few recommendations from locals, we decided to visit and taste for ourselves. We arrived and waited for about 10 minutes before we even got asked about what we would like for drinks. In discussions with the server, she advised that the deep dish takes about 40min to bake. So, we opted to get slices instead as we had a plane to catch. Well, 40 minutes later 2 of us got slices that were warm, not hot, warm. Our friend ended up getting a personal thin crust which is not what he ordered. The pizza was not good for any of us. We were absolutely disappointed with the service and quality of food. Maybe on a return trip, we'll try again and get better service and food.

I'm giving it a 3 out of 5 but only because I put salt on the thin crust with anchovies and olives, which seems nearly impossible. Otherwise I'd give the pizza a solid 2.5 and contest reviews suggesting items even in the top 5 of Chicago pizza. I'm not sure how they got on this list but I cry foul...not even in the top 20. The service was decent and the beer was cold.

Sweet sauce, amazing crust and perfect amount of gooey cheese. The pepperoni was crispy and the pizza wasn't greasy!
Totally worth the drive out.
Worth the hype!!!

This pizza is great for both locals and out of towners looking to dig in to some Chicago style deep dish pizza!

This is one of the best pizza spots in Chicago!

I went here once. It was a long wait and we had to wait in this little coffee like shop a store down. They must be partnered together. We ordered an appetizer because we knew deep dish would take a while to cook. The food overall was really good and the vibe was chill but the wait was a little long.

not sure if I like it compared to lou malnati's!
service was ok, wait was crazy, crust was a little too greasy for my taste, and atmosphere was extremely crowded

Pequod's. Pequod's. Let me count the ways I love you.

1. That caramelized crust: It makes my taste buds water just remember that deliciousness.
2. That sauce: not too overpowering but spread evenly across.
3. The pepperoni and sausage: delicious flavors that compliment the cheese and the sauce perfectly.
4. The mozzarella sticks: the best I've ever had. The cheese and the breading and  the marinara - they've perfected the formula.
5. The Pequod's Salad: a delicious salad with meat and cheese and pepperoncini.

I've heard about Pequod's ever since I moved to Chicago in 2010. But I never went ... until last week. And now I've been twice in the less than a week. Because the pizza is amazing. The service is great. Everything is amazing.

I've ordered the pan pizza twice with friends and it's amazing. The caramelized cheese with a sturdy, yet flaky crust makes an amazing vehicle for the cheese and sauce and toppings. Every bite is a little taste of heaven.

I love pizza of all types but this is incredible. It's officially made it's way into the number 2 spot in my list of favorite pizzas, which had been occupied by Lou Malnati's deep dish pizza for over a decade. But now it goes 1) Chicago Pizza and Oven Grinder's pizza pot pies, 2) Pequod's pan pizza, and 3) Lou Malnati's deep dish.

One of the best pizza places in Chicago! Great, dive-bar kinda feel to it. Usually very crowded on weekends, so come early or expect to wait. They let you order pizza while you're waiting, which definitely helps. Beer options could be a bit better, but other than that this place is legit.

Unless you go by yourself like I usually do so you can sit at the bar or unless you go at an odd hour, expect to wait at least an hour.

That being said, the wait is totally worth it if you're looking for Chicago Style deep dish pizza. Pequod's does it better than anyone else and it isn't even close.

I used to be a huge Lou's fan and still go there as I don't live near Pequod's, but when I have the time & am itching for the best deep dish around, I make the hour train ride to eat the best.

What makes Pequod's the best is their perfected crust. Slightly burnt which gives it a crunch without being overly doughy. Their sauce has some zest and is not pure tomato. The zesty sauce gives the pizza some kick. Sauces that are pure tomato are garbage in my opinion. All their ingredients are extremely high quality. Great beer selection as well.

If you're itching for deep dish that is head & shoulders above Lou's, look no further than this gem only true Chicagoans know about. Simply the best.

You clearly need to make a big decision regarding deep dish pizza, so I'll make this brief and hopefully useful: Pequods makes a solid deep dish. They're "famous" for their carmelized crust, which is really just burnt cheese around the edges. You will wait a very long time to eat it (45 mins from the time you order, that's not counting waiting for your table). You will be tempted to order a salad, because waiting 45 mins to put food in your mouth seems unbearable. The salad will be the saddest excuse for a salad you've seen, a complete waste of stomach space, but you'll be somewhat happy to not be starving anymore. Your pizza will finally arrive almost an hour later, and you will inevitably think it's the best pizza known to man, mainly because your stomach is half-full of sad romaine. But this! This is hot & cheesy and bready. Your rational brain may kick in and remind you: this is merely cheese & sauce on a thick piece of dough -- don't get so excited. Ok, ok, the edges are crispy, and that part is incredible, you wish you could eat a whole pizza made of the edges. You will then wonder: did I just order this monstrous pizza just to eat its edges? Perhaps. Perhaps you did. But that's what people do in Chicago, so there must be something to it.

If that didn't help you make your decision, I'll just add: this pizza may not change your life, but it will fill your belly, and sometimes that's good enough. You'll also experience an authentic, bustling, pizza parlor vibe that doesn't feel touristy (except for all the people who are clearly tourists). The beer selection is pretty basic. The servers are all in a hurry, but remain nice enough. And those salads - please don't.

There are lots of places in Chicago and beyond that make a tasty deep dish. Little Star Pizza in CA is still my favorite of them all, and they aren't in Chicago. The end.

pics.caption: Deep dish with "carmelized" crust (aka burnt cheese)

review.des: Just had my first Pequod's pizza. It was delivered to my hotel with no plate or utensils; I guess I should have asked. It was haphazardly cut, which made it even more difficult to eat. The ingredients are fresh; the sauce is a bit too sweet for me; and, overall, not a lot of flavor compared to other choices I could have made tonight. I suppose there might be others who would have enjoyed this, but not exactly what I was hoping for tonight.
Seriously tasty pies! Nice people too. Gets busy early so don't wait!

I used to hate Pequod's because I grew up on Giordano's. Well, Pequod's is in fact delicious. The cheesy and buttery crust is just so yum. It totally grew on me. We usually get sausage, which is always a good hearty choice.
One of my Favorite Deep Dish Pizzas in Chicago.. they do it right Love the well done crust

It took over two hours to eat!  Okay so we had to wait for about twenty minutes, they took our name gave us a buzzer and we went next door to have a drink. We ordered only to have our meal given to the wrong table.  They remade our pizza but burnt it we ordered some appetizers while we waited for pizza three.  The staff was nice but we had to ask them what was happening.

I don't get deep dish, or 'stuffed', pizza. And I LOVE pizza. It has all the components that I love - it's carb-y, and cheesy, and messy, and goopy - but the whole thing just never is as satisfying as I'd like it to be.

Pequod's gets great reviews, and maybe this is where mine should end: I am not a fan of deep dish. But THAT said, it's claim to fame are charred cheesy edges. These are nice, and different, and give a deep flavour to the edges of each slice.

Based on a recommendation posted to Serious Eats, we got a basic pie with extra sauce, extra cheese. The sauce at Pequod's is great: zesty but not overpowering.

But...yeah. I just didn't enjoy it. It was too "bread"-y, and one-note (gosh, I sound insufferable). Not helping was the caesar salad we got in a bid to offset the pizza; it was just leaves with a gloomy dressing and hard croutons. I think we were both envisioning something a little more, well...special, somehow.

Super friendly attentive staff, though! So there's (definitely) that.

Yelp note: EXTRA SAUCE PLZ (this I stand by!)

I thought I didn't like deep dish pizza. Then I ate a pedquods. I apologize for now for my immature dislike of something so damn good.

Best pizza in Chicago. Absolutely loved it and could unfortunately eat many many more. So delicious.  Pizza was available late as well which is great after a fun night in Chicago.

A must try!

One word, Amazing! I'm not gonna try to compare it to other pizza joints in Chicago, but this one isn't only about the Pizza, but the ambiance, the service, and the food. Pequod's is more of a locals place to go, so you don't see many tourists. When we go there for dinner on a Saturday, there was a wait of 35 mins. Which from my understanding is a very short wait time for a Saturday night. Once we got our table, we were seating upstairs. It almost felt like a "Speakeasy Pizza" joint. This place isn't a "tourist pizzeria". It's authentic Chicagoan, packed with Chicagoans. It's very loud[in a good way], people just entertaining their guests, having a good time, chatting, laughing, and enjoying some great pizza.
It's one of my top 2 for pizza in a city that has more choices than any other. Only downside is it's so busy that you need to order early - that pretty much tells you how good it is!

This pizza has so much tomato sauce. Not good if you don't like that. Also not too many ingredients to chose from as toppings. Not too busy tho on a Wednesday afternoon if you absolutely want to try it. Also the new paying thru iPad systems that suggest a huge tip are very annoying. I would like the default to be no tip and for me to add tip if I enjoyed the service.

It may have been better a few years back but it's still arguably the best pizza on earth and easily Chicago best deep dish. I've regularly had all the spots to hit and Pequads is clear numero Uno! I hit it everytime I'm in Chicago
My second favorite deep dish spot in Chicago, right behind Art of Pizza. But if a buddy comes into town wanting deep dish, go here for the beer and atmosphere over Art of Pizza.
Very good service and food we split the appetizer platter and had a personal pan pizza. Not your typical deep dish ver good crust a bit thinner pizza game changer you must try if you love pie!
Amazing pizza!! A must have when visiting Chicago. Great selection of appetizers and beer.
Favorite deep dish / pan place in the city.
Best deep dish in Chicagoland! Worth the wait to have it done right. Plenty of ingredients, great texture to the dough and just the right amount of cheese.. What a pie!!!!!!

After seeing the restaurant on the travel channel and we were going to be in the Windy City, we needed to stop in and try. It was a Sunday evening and my wife called to see what the wait would be in an hour. They told her no wait. When we arrived, the place was packed and the wait time was 30-60 minutes for 2. This isn't necessarily their fault. You can't predict rushes of customers. Maybe a better way to say it would be there shouldn't be a wait but we can't guarantee anything. This was only the beginning of our wait.

It was suggested that we can also sit at the bar, which is full service. We went upstairs and found 2 seats at the bar. The 2 bartenders were very nice and attentive. They had about 8 beers on tap, all light and hoppy so we stuck with water. We ordered a small Caesar salad to share and 2 individual pan pizzas. About 20 minutes later, the salad arrived. After waiting that long for a salad, it should have arrived in a bowl that had just been woven by master craftsmen. It didn't. It was a small salad, enough for 2 to share if your not very hungry. The dressing was very good. Nice taste of Parmesan.

We waited just under an hour for our 2 personal pizzas. There is no excuse for that kind of wait without letting the customers know so they can chose whether they want to stay or not. We weren't given that option and we had walked for an hour to get here.

The redeeming things were the staff and the pizza. I ordered a personal pan with sausage, pepperoni and garlic. It was delicious. Probably the best pan pizza I have had. We at at Lou Malnati's last time and, in my opinion, this was far superior a pizza. The caramelized crust was awesome. The sausage, our bartender told us, was made just for the restaurant and had a fantastic flavor and consistency. The sauce was a little sweeter than I usually like but with the crust and toppings, it was perfect.

If not for the wait, I would go back again. Maybe try at another time. Pizza gets a 5 star rating. Wait time for pizza gets 1 star. Averages out to 3 stars.

Bruh. Why does this place exist and can I have one for Christmas? Best pizza in the city, hands down. I don't even like deep dish pizza and I will eat an entire pan pizza by myself and not share. The burnt, crispy crust is the business. The sauce and toppings are fresh and tasty. My go to for pizza.

Having heard so many praises for Pequod's, I was super excited when I found out we were going to get a delivery of their pizzas for a party on a Friday night.

We ordered the pizza on the Wednesday to be delivered on Friday at 7:30pm, the order was confirmed and my friend's credit card was charged. My friend called the next day to amend the order, still confirming the order to be delivered for Friday at 7:30pm. My friend called again on Friday afternoon to confirm the order to be delivered for the previously agreed time, and it was once again confirmed.

Friday comes around and we made a little appetizer to be enjoyed while waiting for the pizzas.

7:30pm comes around and no pizza.
7:45pm, no pizza.
8:00pm, still no pizza.

We call Pequod's to see how much longer until we were to expect our pizzas. The person on the phone said the ordered was placed, but the kitchen staff didn't want to make the order, so they tossed it out. He said they were going to make it now though. He apologised and gave us a $30 credit to be used on our next order.

The pizzas finally came at 9:30pm, 2 hours after the thrice confirmed time and didn't look very good and was super doughy, so I didn't quite like it. I guess the kitchen staff really didn't want to make this order.

I'm extremely disappointed with this encounter with Pequod's. What is management doing to the kitchen staff to make them choose to ignore an order simply because they did not want go make it? Or was it just an excuse for them forgetting to put in our order all together?

Please fix how you operate your business!
Overrated. Way too doughy. The ratio of sauce to bread is way too little. Lou malanatis all day

I consider this the best deep-dish in Chicago, but ironically the menu says that they serve "pan pizza." From what I can tell, the main difference is that the crust is slightly less thick/tall, but Pequod's makes up for it with an unprecedented crispy and flavorful crust, which is rewarding given that so many deep-dish crusts are just soggy barriers for the delicious fillings. This place just barely beats Lou Malnati's for best Chicago deep-dish.

Read about 4 other top Chicago restaurants on Cat the Critic: catthecritic.wordpress.c…
With all deep dish options in Chicago, this one by far takes the pie. The buttery crust supports the cheese to sauce ratio and the no-chain vibe makes it feel much less touristy.

Before you go, know that CARAMELIZED CRUST means the BOTTOM OF YOUR PIZZA WILL BE BLACK. This is not my preference, and had I known before perhaps I wouldn't have gone. But I still give this place 3 stars because the atmosphere was fun, drinks were great, and I had a great time with my friends. The blackness on the pizza is from the fact they put cheese under the crust as well as on top of it, and so the cheese directly touching the pan tends to get really cooked. Personally, I just couldn't get it out of my head that I was potentially eating carcinogens by eating burned crust... but this is certainly not the restaurant's fault! It's just how they do things.
From the pizza places that I've tried, this is one of  the best pan (deep dish) local pizza store in the city. I am pretty sure there are many such places...
Service was poor. One pizza came out cold and watery. Piss poor beer. They took the pan with the cold pizza, and put it in their oven a bit longe. There was a half eaten slice of pizza in the pan.

I could talk about the pizza but it would be a bit of a broken record at this point. I wanted to write a review for the hosts at Pequods.

Shout out to the hosts/hostesses at this place for seemingly always being able to keep their cool and get people seated. I get anxiety just thinking about how hard it must be to manage those wait times/tables etc. Good for you guys - keep killing it.
Awesome food Greta service very enjoyable will be back!
Pizza is super tasty. Make sure to get it well done and extra cheese.  Again place is always packed so call ahead of time if you are on a schedule.

First time in Chicago and Pequod's was the first deep dish pizza place I tried. Now when they say "deep dish", they really mean it. This pizza was super thick, heavy on the cheese, and delicious. Not to mention, one slice was all I needed to fill me up. My group of 5 got a large (8 slices) and we had plenty to go around. I'll definitely be coming back!

This pizza was awesome... Loved the crust! I had cheese and my brother had sausage and we were both very happy. Service could have been a little better especially since it wasn't busy but the food was great:)

pics.caption: My little brother enjoying his cheese and sausage deep dish.

review.des: Pretty darn good but  not earth shattering.  We showed up around 5:00 pm before the rush.  Parking was available and pizza came out pretty fast.  I think our server forgot about us as we sat there for about 20 minutes waiting for the check.  I'd try it again though.

I know this place has rave reviews, but honestly, I just don't see it.

Pros-

Delicious and generous toppings (I got the deep dish sausage and peppers)
Fast delivery

Cons-

While the sauce and toppings were amazing, the pizza was a thin layer of cheese followed by 90% bread. And it wasn't the soft "gooey" kind you'd find on a typical pizza. It was super dry and flaky. Very disappointing.

I'm glad I was able to say I tried it. But just not worth the hype in my book.

My favorite deep dish pizza in Chicago. Eating at the restaurant takes a lot of patience as the wait times are usually very long. I ate there the first few times but got tired of it, figured that it would be more convenient to just carry out and enjoy the pizza at home. The spinach and jalapeno combination of deep dish is my favorite.

This was so far out of our way, but I was told by a friend to go.  This hidden gem was worth the trek.  

This is a hole in the wall, locals only bar with great pizza.  This is not a tourist stop and shouldn't be.  We were able to get a cold beer and a personal pizza for lunch.  The pizzas were everything I hoped a Chicago pizza should be.  

Our service was outstanding.  I was a little concerned when we walked in, but the entire staff did a great job.  They were very friendly.

It's not that it's terrible, it's good, but not anything special. I took the L and walked pretty far out of my way to try it as I heard so many good things. Disappointed to feel I've had the same tasting pizza at the chain pizza places on the west coast. I guess I had to give it a try when I came for a visit to Chicago.

Doooooowngrade for delivery - they don't use third parties so you have to call. Understandably it's busy but I got through. Placed an order at 5:30pm. Hour and a half she says. We live 10 minutes away but with my bronchitis and the rain storm figured delivery was the way to go.

Got the pizza at 8:30 (double the estimate). Noticed on the receipt the order wasn't put in until 6pm. Received it medium warm and the onion rings were cold - and they forgot the ranch .... straight to garbage and they are my favorite onion rings in Chicago. At least they got the pizza toppings right...?

I know you're popular and busy, Pequod's. But at this point you should have a system in place for deliveries. Get it together, P.

This is as legit as it gets to chill with some buddies or significant other in a very casual environment.  

The thing to get is there pan pizza and a couple of beers, end of story.  No particular ingredients, anything tastes great!  

If you are looking for a good pizza place to visit at night, look no further!  

Super chill staff.  You will feel right at home.
Hands down, best pizza in Chicago. If anyone tells you differently, they're lying. Thin crust or pan, both are amazing. The Chicago chain pizza restaurants can't even compare.

Ordered delivery on a Friday. Never making the mistake of ordering here again and will take every opportunity to dissuade others. Wrote a much longer review but deleted, because why spend the time?

Terrible pizza (yet always seem to order once a year thinking it'll get better). Rude and unprofessional customer service. Waited over two hours for delivery (was quoted 1:30 when ordered, again when I called to get an eta after 1:30, and can be seen clearly on my receipt). The manager(?) was incredibly rude and called me a liar about the quoted time ("I doubt you were told 1:30 - we train our girls to say 1:30-2 hours). Looks like some retraining is required starting with you sir. Life is too short to deal with people like this.

Point is...Many pizza joints that are much better and treat their customers with respect. Why bother with this bready, bland and sad pizza from an establishment that apparently doesn't value their customers? Easy decision and easy to remedy this situation before insulting a paying customer as well as your female employees.
This was my first experience with Chicago style pizza. Holy cow - worth the wait! (Because if you wanna eat there- there'll probably be one!!) bonus - great left overs!!

THE BEST OF THE BEST! Do not waste your time going to Lou Malnati's or Giordano's. Pequod's is where it's at!

I'm from South Jersey and am all about crispy, thin crust pizza. However, I actually debated my deep devoutness and commitment to thin crust pizza after taking just one bite of my personal deep dish mushroom pizza from Pequod's.

I would be satisfied eating the crust alone, that's how delicious it really is. The crust is made from basically cheese that crisps and caramelizes while cooking. The inside of the pizza is not as dense as I would have expected from a deep dish pizza. It was creamy, light, and I didn't feel gross after chowing.

I could write so much more about how unreal their pizza is, but I would prefer that my mouth stop watering.

Fantastic pizza! We love how the cheese was well done on the edges and the crust was perfection. We got there around 1:30 in the afternoon and got into a booth right away. By the time we left there was a long line of people standing along with a few sitting outside. Our waitress was friendly and attentive and we really enjoyed the chill vibe there. Definitely a place to put on your list if you are visiting Chicago.

pics.caption: Yum! Look at the delicious caramelized crust.

review.des:
Pick up is the way to go, as the pizza is still piping hot and fresh when you get home.

I could eat that carmelized crust all by itself. Hands down, Pequod's has the best crust and pizza. Their proportions are perfect, as I find other places' dough/crust to be too heavy. Their sausage is amazing...really a stand out sausage. I usually get a sausage and pepperoni combo and another with green pepper and onion. While I can eat a lot, pizza is usually filling, but for Pequod's, I make sure I eat at least 4 pan slices since I love it so much. Diminishing utility with the more I consume doesn't really exist here at Pequod's.

On another trip, tried the Italian beef and giardiniera. This was on point and they did it right, though sausage remains my preference.

To note, I actually prefer NY thin slices but Pequod's pan pizza is that phenomenal.

Pequod's has the deep dish pizza that I was looking for! We had a late lunch after walking to Pequod's from the Lincoln Park Zoo. It was 30+ minutes for our pizza to arrive, and the wait was worth it!

We had the pan pizza with spinach, mushroom, and 1/2 order of sausage (for the husband). You pay for each topping, so we didn't go overboard. Bottom crust was thicker than at Lou's Malnati's which was what I was looking for. The caramelized crust was good and there was a generous amount of toppings. You get full quickly after one piece, but we had to finish it all as we were flying back home that evening. I noticed that the pizza was a bit saltier which was probably due to the cheese.

The restaurant was larger than I expected with two levels and there was a private section in the back of the second level.

Guess this is a good place for birthdays since we saw several large parties eating here.

pics.caption: Pan pizza with mushroom, spinach, and 1/2 sausage

review.des:
This is as good as it gets.

It'll be busy, but my group of three saw an opening at the bar and went for it.  The bartender was quick to serve us, and always checked in on us.  It was an early afternoon, so we just wanted pizza.  

Every bite is fantastic, and I savored for the crust at the end.  Seriously, one of the best pizzas I've ever had.

It's very filling.  The 14-inch pizza was too big for the three of us, and this includes two with huge appetites.

I used to love this place in college. I went back tonight and had an awful experience. The hostess with the brown hair, glasses, and winged eyeliner was rude and a smart ass. If I call and make a reservation and you call it a reservation on the phone w/o any further information about said reservation, I'm going to assume I'll be seated within half an hour. An hour later we were seated. Reservation was at 7:30 and we didn't eat until 9:30. The pizza was soggy. I could tell it was soggy coming out but the guy who gave me a slice insisted it wasn't. The pizza was okay but the service was horrible. JUST DO CARRY OUT!

Best pizza I've ever eaten in my entire life! Not even exaggerating... they also have a pretty decent beer selection which makes this place a 5 star review. This is a MUST if you are visiting Chicago!

Requires a 24 hour advance reservation.
At 5:00pm we were told 4 1/2 hour wait unless you call 24 hours in advance for "priority" seating, and then it is an hour wait.    This is my second time trying to eat Pequod's in a week. Will have to wait another year before we came back to town.
The service is nice and the food was fast... the taste was rich... the sauce was a bit much...made it a bit runny...
Very good pan pizza, crust with the cheese is awesome generous in the cheese I really liked the sausage and the veggie as well.
Best deep dish in the city! It of course takes about 45 minutes to cook the pizza once you're there, but then it's worth it. Fun neighborhood joint with amazing pizza.

Deep dish pizza is as good as it gets. Pequod's is known for their caramelized crust and the staff is super-friendly. If you want to dine in, I suggest placing a "dine in" order at least a few hours before you go. If you say you'll be there at 7pm, when you get there at 7pm, your food is ready to be served. I don't know if they offer the same service on weekends but definitely call to ask.

IT'S SO GOOD! The crust, man, it's the absolute best. I get the veggie or some variation of a veggie pizza and it's just so good. The service has always been decent. They a little bourgeois  (bougie) though, maybe it's just me. The hostess's for the most part be stale as hell, I tip my 20% boo, boo.  It's alright, I don't if they still doing it, but between 11 AM-3PM M-F they have deals.
Fun environment & solid food. One of those "this is Chicago" places. Good spot to bring people from out of town (cheese in the shape of a whale!)

Had lunch there last week....servers and bartender, a lady, were
very unfriendly and indifferent.

First pizza came out Luke warm, sent it back to re heat.

Place isn't horrible, but certainly, imho, not worth a return visit.

Dont get the personal pepperoni pizza. It's very impersonal. Very much lacking in cheese and flavor. Deep dish more like fake dish.

Good service though.

Amazing deep dish. Get the pepperoni, caramelized crust is to die for. The long wait is worth it and the service is generally fast. Put in your deep dish order right away because it does take about 40 minutes. Awesome place to gather with buddies.

I had one opportunity to try deep dish pizza. there were several places I could have chose from, but I picked here. I had to wait 30 minutes to be seated, and then another 40 minutes for my pizza. Waiting for your food here is like a quest. Its not easy, and there are times you want to quit. But patience is rewarded with their damn good pizzas. I ordered a medium with pepperoni and sausage. It was just enough for two hungry people, and we were definitely full afterwards.
Service is not good, but its not bad either. Our waitress attended to us within a reasonable time, considering it was a full house.

The crust gets alot of attention here, but I think the best part is the combination of everything. The main player in this pizza is the bread. Usually a hunk of bread that thick would be dry and disappointing. Here, the pizza is fluffy and moist. The toppings burst with flavor. I still dont know whether I like the pepperoni or the sausage more. The cheese was just enough to be gooey but not overwhelming. They could have added a little more sauce, but I think I preferred it on the less saucy side. the caramel crust was cooked just right, but its not mind blowing as some people make it. Overall, it was an excellent meal. Not too salty, not too greasy, and not too saucy (which gives me heartburn). considering this pizza was neither of these things is quite an accomplishment.

So I have to admit, the waiting for a table and the. The pizza definitely tainted my opinion of this place. I came to Chicago for a conference and had a bit of a reunion with old coworkers, one of which lives in Chicago. She picked this place for us to all have dinner on Sunday of memorial day weekend. The place was packed and there were a lot of us. You can't make a reservation and we ended up waiting close to 2 hours to be seated. We ordered salads and the appetizer sampler to tide us over for when we finally sat down and the had to wait another hour for our pizzas. (For those keeping track, we had to wait 3 hours to eat.)

The crust is as amazing as you've heard. Crunchy, caramelized, crispy. The sauce has a bit of a kick to it, which I didn't love. There could have been a little more cheese. Overall, it was good pizza but I was underwhelmed. That could have been from waiting 3 hours to eat, or it could be that I just like pizza the way they make it at home in NYC. Either way,  you have got to try deep dish when in Chicago. I would recommend this place but don't come with a large group. You will wait forever.

Unsure what the hype was about this place. The decor was old smelled kinda raunchy inside? They seated us upstairs in this booth, was about to fall apart. The fan above the table looked like it had not been dusted in years, swallow as the blinds on the window we were sitting by.
The waitress was rude and obnoxious, one of them trying to be funny and cute - but she was neither. We ordered drinks (watered down alcohol) got some apps they were good but the smaller had like 3 of each thing, huge plate but minimal food.
Then we ordered pizza - the most foul pizza I've ever eaten. The sauce tasted watered down - zero flavor and the pizza dough was not good - I asked if the pizza is always this burnt, she replied no they must've left it in to long - sorry were busy??? Really ?
Then the bill came and was way over priced !

Over all if you want something in the upside - the food runner was the most pleasant person in the place and was the only one who was apologetic !

Save your time go someplace else who will appreciate you spending about $200.00.

This was the first time I had proper pan pizza -- and I loved it! Usually I'm a thin crust type of girl and of course once in a while I  crave my Lou and my Gino's, but pan pizza was never that appealing to me. BF's craving led us to this place, and I immediately loved the ambiance. We were seated upstairs and our order was taken fairly quickly.
We started with the combo appetizer and I immediate fell in love with the mozzarella sticks and mushroom poppers. They were hot, crispy and tasted fresh.
For the pizza, it took them about 30-40mins to get it to us. We had sausage and pepperoni with 1/2 mushroom and 1/2 peppers. They did not skimp on the toppings. I really liked the bread to cheese to topping proportion for the most part, and with just a drop of cholula, I loved my bites. We had 2 leftover pieces from a medium pizza, and when eating it the next day, I could taste the bread way more than anything else and that's when the proportion seemed off.
Other than that, I definitely enjoyed my time there.

This is the pizzeria you go to in Chicago if you don't want to feel like a tourist. Lou Malnati's and Giordano's may be more famous, but I couldn't care less. Pequod's serves the best pizza in Chicago! Their secret is layering the edge of the pan with cheese so that it's baked into the crust, giving it an amazingly delicious flavor that's highly addicting. The pizzas are made to order and you can pick and choose whatever toppings you want. Because of this, it could take 20-40 minutes to get your pizza, but that's totally fine because you can kill time with pitchers of beer or whatever sporting event is on at the time.

Pequods does not have gluten free pizza which I need since I'm a celiac, but my husband wanted to try their pizza so I went with him. He got a deep dish pizza, wine and a salad. There was a 45 minute wait, so I went to grab a gluten free pizza down the street. His pizza arrived at the bar, so I sat down and was eating my pizza as well. The manager came over and told me I couldn't eat my pizza. He also said he needed to ask us to leave. I totally understand there is rules about outside food, so I put the pizza box in my oversized purse, and stopped eating. I thought since the pizza wasn't out that it would be ok. We continued to sit at the bar while my husband (a paying customer) was enjoying his food. The bartender who was very nice came over and asked if my husband needed his food boxed implying we need to go. My husband said he was not finished, and asked if we had to leave. The manager came back over, and aggressively told us he had said we need to leave. I offered to the manager to wait outside with my purse (which had the pizza box in it) while my husband finished. The manager was not having it. I could understand if we were not complying or making a scene, but the manager was totally out of line. My husband barely drank his wine, and had not yet touched his salad. He said he wasn't going to pay for the food if he can't even eat it. The manager said we still had to pay, but couldn't finish. My husband said he wouldn't pay if he can't eat, so the manager took his glass, forks, etc. and threw it all on top of the pizza and told us to leave. This was a terrible example of customer service! I will never go back. This guy seriously had a personal problem, and very unhappy in his own life. I can't believe someone would treat customers like that! Not only did he lose our sale, but we would have came back because my husband actually liked the pizza.

I came to Chicago for one thing. DEEP DISH PIZZA.

Lunch special. $4.99 Monday-Friday. 11am-3pm. The special includes cheese pizza with a soda.  If this was available back in Los Angeles, you would find me here everyday.

I added sausage, pepperoni and mushroom. It does take awhile for it to be cooked roughly 30-45 minutes. Totally worth it. The pizza is a bit bready but I totaled love it. Especially the burnt crisp. Ugh i'm salviating as I write this and wish I could eat it right now.
Definitely a personal size is perfect for a person and I eat quite a LOT. I was totally stuffed after eating this.

This spot is the spot. I tried the other competitors and this one ended up being my favorite. I came here twice before leaving Chicago.

Now i'm sad that I can't eat this pizza anymore.

Best pizza in Chicago by far! Im not a fan of crust on any of my food but when I'm eating this pizza its my favorite part. I dined at the one in Morton Grove for my boyfriends 21st birthday & tonight this one. I personally like the Chicago location better but both have just as great pizza & service.

Decent, but not crazy good for my taste. With so many options of deep dish pizza, I think this one was way too salty and lacked the depth of the tomato taste that I like due to the excessive salty cheese.
Awesome deep dish. I love getting extra sauce and extra cheese, I learned that from my friend Eric. He is skinny, but he knows how to order some good deep dish pizza.

This is some of the best deep dish pizza I've ever had in Chicago. It's busy for a reason. Make reservations, it's worth it. Lots of choice. Deep dish, I recommend over thin crust but they were both good. Good appetizers and plenty of choice with the beer selection.
Child friendly, they even had creations and drawings for the kids, remember it more like your local bar than a restaurant. Very nice staff.
Enjoy

There was so much hype about Pequod's Pizzeria that my husband, a friend, and I finally checked it out. It was extraordinarily busy, but we were seated quite quickly. The service was also prompt despite the norm of having to wait 45 minutes for a stuffed pizza at any establishment. Our server kept appetizers and drinks coming while we waited. The pizza was good. Was it as good as my favorite Chicago stuffed pizza? No, it wasn't quite that good in my opinion. Nevertheless, Pequod's offers a very solid Chicago style pie that everyone should check out at least once.
Delicious pizza!!  Think you have to dine in vs takeout heard it's not nearly as good. Past two times they did burn bottom of my pizza but still one of my favorite deep dish Chicago pizzas.

Came so highly recommended to us as the best deep dish in Chicago. Nope, not even close. We had olive and mushroom, the toppings weren't even cooked. The sauce was bland and the salad was hohum. We got seated quick and the service was good but the star of the show wasn't really a star.
I'll stick to Giordano's, if I feel like something different Lou Malnati's. The crust was too hard and I didn't care for the sauce.

I'm so torn about Pequod's. I know a lot of people love it, even close friends of mine, but I find it really basic. I've tried it on a few occasions--twice for takeout, and recently I stopped in to eat at the restaurant. It's definitely bready and more of a pan pizza than a deep dish, at least to me. I find that with takeout just getting it with plain cheese wasn't enjoyable. It just congeals and also loses its crispy texture underneath. I think the toppings are what offset the breadiness of the crust. That being said, the caramelized crust is really delicious, even as leftovers.

My husband and I stopped in a few weeks ago on a Saturday night around 4pm. It was already pretty busy but it was only a 20 minute wait for a table, and they told us pizzas were taking 50 minutes. We got a table upstairs that was in the corner, which was nice. Our waitress was nice but I have to say the service was extremely disappointing. It took forever just to get a drink and our appetizer came out and was the wrong thing. A few tables around us also received wrong orders. We shared the house salad with ranch, and the dressing was really tasty. The wings, once we got the correct ones, were pretty crispy and had a nice BBQ sauce.

Our pizza ended up taking almost an hour and a half to get to us and by this point we were starving even after apps. It was very cheesy and had good flavor. I like their sauce, it's not too sweet or too tangy. We did half with sausage and onion and half with cheese. I definitely prefer the side with toppings-- it offsets how thick the crust is. Eventually our area started to get really crowded and there was a big group of drunk people that snuck past the host and were trying to order pizza without waiting. The waitstaff just kind of let it happen, which was frustrating because it caused us to have to wait a really long time to get our check and leave.

Overall I think the pizza is good, and I don't mind eating it, but I don't find it special. I also think that other Chicago "deep dish" varieties like Lou's are much better and have a much more enjoyable ambiance at their locations. Dining in at Pequod's was crowded, slow, hot, and just not worth it.
SOOO Good. Really really good if you like pizza in the form of pizza bread style.. hope that makes sense. So yummy in my tummy!

Really good pizza. I've had the classics like Lou Malnati's and Giordano's and Uno's but this is great in a different way. The wait (almost an hour) was not fun which is why I took off one star but the service was excellent and the pizza is superb. The sauce is a little sweet which might not be to everyone's tastes but I was really enjoying it. The crust was unique too. It looks kind of burnt but it's actually just carmalized and it has a splendid taste. I'd definitely recommend this place. Good job, Pequod's!

I am not a deep dish pizza person - I grew up on thin crust in our very Italian household - but I must stay this is very good pizza.  Not only that, the ambiance it very fun.  It's always a great place for us to visit during our Christmas Week-end on the city!

My favorite deep dish place in Chicago!!! I love that they are open until 2:00 AM, which means I can satisfy my late night cravings. You can do RESERVATIONS (priority seating) online! Convenient, and if for whatever reason the time or day is already reserved, the manager will e-mail you telling you a different time or day he can do.

We had a group of 14 on a Saturday and they were jam packed! We were seated on the second floor because of our bigger group. They gave us 5 high raise circle tables because they didn't have the shorter rectangle ones. That was the only weird part because some people had to deal with "indents" where they were sitting. Like you can just imagine connecting 5 small circle tables in a row and how some people would get stuck in the part where two tables meet.

BUT I DIDN'T CARE, because the most important part was seeing my friends. I'm just letting you know in case you plan on bringing a big group on a busy day.

[They do allow you to split 14 credit cards, it's a hassle but we didn't have cash]

I also can't comment on the service, but because they were busy, you can't expect the constant service. They seemed to have plenty of workers, but still couldn't keep up with the crowd demands, The waiters were flying all over the place and I struggled to find my waiter maybe 2-3 times and kept going to other waiters. But none of them were rude about helping me even though we weren't their table.

A funny thing I noticed is that they waiters have a habit of dropping plates (used) or glasses on the ground! I think there were 3 major spills during the 3 hours we were there.

pics.caption: their Mozzarella sticks are the best!

review.des:
This was my second time visiting Chicago and I've had the opportunity to try about 10 different deep dish pizza restaurants. All have been very very good. Tuff to even put them in order; but Pequods has become my favorite.

Amazing sauce, sausage, peppers and cheese.

I also like the way they bake theirs a little bit more than most places, therefore the crust is crunchy.

The wait time could be up to an hour, just like all the other popular pizza places, depending on what time/day you go.

Nice local crowd creates a great ambiance as well.

pics.caption: Small sausage & pepperoni. Perfect  for two.
Deep Dish sausage & pepperoni. My fav pizza in Chicago.

review.des: If you want cheese on cardboard then this is the place to come to. I think many of the good reviews come from the fact that it is open late and we all know that after alcohol just about anything is good. The crust was super dry and was covered with a thin layer of cheese. The waitress seemed quite disinterested in customer service. I would recommend any of the other local chains over this place.

Pizza is one of the best you'll have. Definitely 5 stars.

Downfall: the wait is excruciating (especially when you're hungry). Also, up stairs can get a little hot since they don't have A/C. The seating is definitely tight.

This place is super popular so as long as you have the right expectations on waiting times, you'll enjoy it!

Possibly the best pizza I have ever had. What i liked most was that it wasnt overly cheesy like some other Chicago establishments. Be warned that portions are huge - my gf and i couldnt finish a small pizza.

Goodness gracious this place is magical.
My favorite Chicago pizza spot by far. I take everyone visiting the city here and have yet to find an unimpressed customer that I've brought in.
If you're planning on lunch, you should be able to get a table pretty quick. Towards the late afternoon/dinner time, I'd recommend making a reservation. LONG wait times, so be prepared otherwise!

Some of the greatest pizza in Chicago, and you can trust me since I know pizza. The crust is a game changer, cheese is real nice and gooey. Wait times can be long, but bearable. I'd suggest a seat at the bar for best service.
This place is fine but I don't know why anyone raves about it. There is better pizza in Chicago.

Every time I visit Chicago, I go out of my way to make it to Pequod's. The crust is buttery, flaky and perfectly crisp. According to them, the crust is caramelized. The cheese, sauce and toppings make this some of the best pizza I've ever had.

On my most recent visit, I came at lunchtime and got the 7 inch personal pizza with sausage and black olives. The lunch special comes with a fountain drink for $4.95. I added the toppings so my total was under $7.50. It was delicious and cheap!

A few things to note:

*It takes awhile to get your pizza (at least 30 minutes but could be 45 minutes if they are busy), so if you are in a hurry, probably not your best bet.
*They have great craft beer choices to go with your pizza.
*It can get really busy so lunch or a weeknight be a good option.
*You MUST go here :)

Make sure to check out this amazing pizza place if you live or are in Chicago!

pics.caption: Lunch size 7 inch personal pizza with black olives and sausage

review.des: This is my first time visiting Chicago (lifelong Californian) and I was blown away by the deep dish pizza here. I didn't know pizza could be this good! Great service, great experience. Pequod's will be my go-to pizza place for the rest of my assignment here.

This place is great.   Best pizza in Chicago.  Now the wait is unbelievable   I called the day prior and asked if I could make reservations.   Well they don't do reservations but you can call ahead.  So I called ahead at 4pm for a table at 7pm and a when we got there they said there would be a 90 min wait.   So please order ahead and the best thing to do is take out.   It's very good.   I have tried a variety of pizzas in Chicago and this one is the best.

The pizza is phenomenal, but only if you dine in. Otherwise it turns out like the picture below. And unfortunately this has happened via delivery multiple times. Perhaps a message can be relayed to the delivery drivers - quality trumps speed.

First time at pequods we went on Saturday night with a reservation and when we arrived my reservation didn't mean anything at all! So we went somewhere else because there was a 2 hour wait time and they couldn't accommodate us even with a reservation. "They said it moves your wait time up to an hour!"

We returned the next day Sunday for lunch and there was no wait time luckily!!

We had the individual pizza with mushrooms and half sausage.  It was yummy the think pan crust was crunchy and sauce was in between not too sweet or tart. Surprisingly I was expecting a lot a lot of cheese like giordianos pizza but not at all for a change!

I liked it and will try it again on an empty stomach. And lastly there's a second floor yay I thought they only had one floor more seating hooray!!
This place is a Chicago gem! It's the absolute best. Such a laid back vibe and amazing pizza to go along with it.
Easily one of the best pizza places in Chicago! Always a long line since the food is so good!

Yeh ..... I don't get it.  These are so many great reviews on this place. We tried what would be proclaimed to be the best pizza in the universe and it felt very short. The crust was mediocre at best the cheese had no flavor and the marinara sauce very bland. I was with a party of five... We ate it but we didn't feel like it was that great. Sorry!

I hate to give this place a one star , specially because I love the pizza here . But every time I come here i could never sit in a booth ! I get it it's always busy but today is a Monday ... maybe 5 tables were being used I requested a booth that was available and I was told no ! So I don't understand why not if there's was no wait behind me ? They just wanted to sit me in a tiny table in the middle mind you I just had knee surgery that does not allow me to sit in high chairs . But when I requested a booth I could t even explain that to the girl because  she didn't even let me finish telling her why I was requesting a booth . Sadly I had to just walk out because I couldn't get a booth and I couldn't sit in a highchair .

They're making pizza the right way here. I'm not a huge fan of the traditional Chicago deep dish style- but Peaquod's really nails it.

The pizza pub atmosphere is great for a few draft beers and a couple slices. They make the pizza in such a way that the crust and end of the pizza is carmelized giving a crunchy bite of cheese. It's simply good, and unique from the other deep dish spots in the area.

Can't miss this one!
Ordered a delivery and it was an'effort' to get GrubHub, etc. to pick up even though PP lists them as a service. That said the two pizzas were terrific.
Excellent! great deep dish pizza amazing thin crust. The staff is always friendly and the ambiance is great. By far the best pizza in the city!!!!

After asking everyone we encountered for a pizza recommendation we ended up here.... apparently this is where the locals go! The restaurant has 2 floors and nothing out of this world in terms of appearance. Staff was very nice, we ordered their deep dish Supreme. The pizza was good but if I was to go again I would stick to just plain cheese or pepperoni as I think the combination of the sauce and toppings was overwhelming but tasty nonetheless. The garlic cheese bread is highly recommended. I have a good overall experience and would recommend.

I'm torn. Pequod's is a great pizza, however my latest experience has me thinking I won't be ordering there anytime soon. We called in a delivery order at 5:30pm and did not get our pizza until 9:15pm. I couldn't believe it. When I called to check on the status at 8pm, the kitchen had not even gotten the order. The woman on the phone intimated that there was nothing she could do, and snidely asked if I wanted to talk to the manager. I spoke with him and he assured me he'd put the order in and have it sent out first thing. That took another 1:15 hours (I live 0.8mi from the restaurant). It's really unfortunate because it's good pizza, but just buyer-beware on deliveries... you may wait a long time. Pizza isn't worth a ~4 hour wait.

I had the pan pepperoni.

The pizza breaks down like this: 90% cardboard flavored crust, 4% mediocre sauce, 5% ashes of what was formerly cheese 1% razor thin pepperoni.

This how a pizza would be made if the only consideration was maximizing the profit, as the cheapest ingredients dominate way beyond what is palatable; then handed off to an incompetent cook staff to burn any flavor right out of the pie.

Will not be returning.
Best deep dish pizza in the city! Generally always a wait when you dine in, so plan accordingly. However their pizza is worth the wait.
This place is ridiculous. DO NOT GO HERE. We put a reservation in and they said we s STILL have to wait for over an hour. Plus the PIZZA is terrible.

Pequod's has really gone downhill in recent years. The wait times are the usual for deep dish pizza (~40-60 mins) but then you often wait longer because of the hype. However, the last time I went my pizza wasn't cooked in the middle (cold, still-raw dough), even after all that time. I feel like a few years ago (like 2012-14ish) the crust was less bread-y, and had more flavor. The last couple times I've gone, I've been disappointed in both the food and the service. The servers are unsmiling and rushed. It was my go-to place to take visiting tourists, but now I'll take them up to Burt's instead.
Pequod's is one of the best pizza places in the city. It's a small, friendly environment with good food and drinks. It gets crowded at dinner time so come a bit early to avoid long wait times!

An embarrassing example of Chicago deep dish pizza. Check out the picture I posted that shows large hunk of bread with a tiny layer of cheese on top. A lot of the pictures look great with that burnt crust and all. But what you are not seeing is that there is almost no cheese on this "pizza". I was sorely disappointed after checking out the pics, seeing their high rating, I was expecting much more. Hopefully you read this in time so you can save your hard earned money for a more substantial pizza.  What they serve here is disgraceful.

I finally went and now know what the fuss is about.
GREAT pizza and good service. Be prepared to wait.
I have ordered from here for delivery too.  The place and environment are worth it though.

Being from NJ/NY area we are big on pizza in general. I have a couple spots in Jersey that make a good deep dish. So, we tried Giordanos because it's the "best", along with pizza uno too. Giordanos sucked, I can get better pizza at 7/11.

So, we get to Pequod's I order a personal pie and it was incredible, half onions and half sausage. It was a solid 8.5-9 . Crust was perfect, some deep dish places or pizza in general get a flaky crust and I can't stand it. Their pizza sauce had an interesting twist to it, not sure if it had wine/brandy/sherry in it. But man what a delicious twist.

Great job and we didn't wait too long either

pics.caption: Half onion and sausage, personal pie!!!

review.des: Hands down the best pan / deep dish pizza in Chicago. The fresh locally sourced veggies, the pizza crust, the sauce are all top notch!!!!!!

Not impress at all... Came in on a Wednesday night before the rush and the pizza was just basically bready. Major lack of sauce and cheese!! Our pizza wasn't even cut symmetrically, let alone it was even barely cut we have to use the pizza scooper to get a finer cut before putting it on to the plate. Been yearning to try this place out but left pretty disappointed. We got a sausage and pepperoni pizza and those two ingredients were point on. But the sauce and cheese was a different story. All of the tomato sauce fell onto the crust of the pizza and I like pizza crust and all but our pizza crust was burnt! So I wasn't even able to enjoy it as much. The thickness of the bread was major carb overload. Not enough cheese and sauce to balance it out at all. If anything, I say get thin crust so you won't be as disappointed as I am. But I never had thin crust so I'm not sure if it's any better.

This was our final deep dish pizza experience before we left Chicago, and it did not disappoint, the crust was nice and crispy and the pizza had a nice velvety texture, plus the sauce was quite tasty. We didn't have to wait for a table which was nice

Diner in once before and thought it wasn't up to snuff relative to the other deep dish offerings in the area.  Got delivery tonight and it was nonsense.  It was like a focaccia bread with absolutely minimal toppings.  Multiple slices had (barely) 1 of the 2 toppings we ordered.  This was an embarrassment.  Complete joke.  Never again.  Only plus was fast delivery.  Try Chicago's Pizza or Art of Pizza nearby.

The food is great, the rattlesnake of a host leaves a bit to be desired.  But the wait staff is friendly and Noelle was very attentive even though she was the only server there.  Wings are good.  Sausage and Pepperoni Large pie was delicious.

Great pizza- questionable service.  Spent over 80 dollars and they switched servers on us mid meal- no word on it, just new server- who checked on us pre food and to package up leftovers- which they then threw away.  Disappointing because the food really was very tasty- and would have made a good lunch.  Oh well- next time we will be a little less easygoing and will have better service to go along with our delicious food.

Their bartender(?)/manager behind the bar warmly greeted us as we walked in.

Deep dish pizza isn't my thing, so not going to rate based on that. On the other hand, my friend had a thin slice pizza and she said she's had better, "it was ok".

I LOVED my tomato bisque/soup paired with bread and butter. I ordered plain wings as well with ranch on side-- chicken is chicken.

My only qualm is the hipsters loitering by the bar. I'm not sure if they were workers on the clock (pretty slow evening; 12a) or they're just hanging out. Regardless, they took away from our server's potential attentiveness. They were loud, obnoxious, and kept talking to our waitress, while we were trying to get her attention for the check. If they were off the clock employees, I don't care how slow the place is, they need to take it down a notch and stop impeding on the server's job. It's like, you want to tip a server, but why would you tip someone who's just bringing you your food, and not checking up on you on a timely manner or to see if we're waiting on you to take the check because your back is towards us blabbering with your friends/coworkers. Shit, if im tipping you for satisfying bare minimum, leave the food at the bar and I'll pick it up myself. Regardless, because I know how entitled most millennials/this generation is, I'm forced to tip, for social courtesy.

In a city filled with pizza joints, I don't see the HUGE appeal of Pequod's. Is their pizza good, sure, there are lots of good pizzas out there. Just don't see anything that sets them apart. Having said that, I'd go back if others insist. Service was fine, pricing in line with other similar pizza places.

Definitely 3.5-4 stars. We waited over 1 hour to be seated, even though we were supposedly on a priority seating list. The restaurant itself was really neat- two stories but still very cozy. We waited over an hour for our deep dish pizza to come (our waitress thought they might have forgotten about it). It was good, but if this is the best deep dish pizza gets, I guess I'm just not a fan. The beers on tap were excellent and overall I enjoyed the experience.
I'm a thin crust fan but Pequods is my favorite deeper dish. The wait is long but the pizza is worth it.

The deep dish pizza is a must-try and a cannot miss. Enjoy delicious toppings, quality ingredients and friendly service. Be warned - bathrooms are a little rough, but they also have a late night bar so that would explain it.

Hands down, best deep dish pizza in the city. I have tried several places throughout the city and there's a reason there's always a wait for this place despite the number of tables it has. Plus the prices can't be beat. You'll pay more at any of the big 4 pizza places (Gino's, Giordano's, Lou's, Uno). If you want just one slice, head to Art of Pizza. You're welcome in advance.

If I could give zero stars I would. Awful delivery experience. After waiting 2 hours for the pizza, it was wrong. When I called I was told they would send out another pizza but that I'd have to wait another 2 hours despite this being a restaurant mistake! I asked to speak to the manager and was rudely placed on hold for 10+ minutes. The manager lied to me saying she would get out the corrected pizza to me in an hour .... it has been another 2 hours and still NO pizza!!! To say they're lack in customer service, lack in management, and overall rudeness leaves a lot to be desired!!! I would expect at the very least for the restaurant to offer me a gift card for my inconvenience! I would highly recommend getting your pizza elsewhere!
The best deep dish pizza in Chicago. Hands down. Small(ish) so come early or plan on a short wait.
Wonderful pan pizza with a delightful golden ring of cheese baked around the crust. Not "deep dish" in the classical Chicago sense, but damn good pizza!

We're a pizza hut household however when we want a fancier pizza option we typically go to Bricks, Stella Barra or Pequod's. Pequod's pan pizza is un-matched and so delicious. It's perfect for movie nights and has a relaxed, casual atmosphere I appreciate. I just wish they had more locations and weren't always so busy!
