Really great pizza and they give you huge portions. I especially like the crunch texture of the crust. The wait time is a little long for their signature pan pizza, approximately 45 minutes, but it's worth it!

The staff is super friendly and accommodating. In fact, when we had some left over and wanted to go watch a movie across the street, they let us keep our pizza in their fridge till we were done with the movie.

This is definitely a place I'd go to again if I'm in town. Fully recommended!

pics.caption: Pan pizza with sausage, Canadian bacon, Italian meat, spinach, and peppers

review.des: Heard of this place from coworkers, and I was interested in the carmelized cheese lining the crust. SO good - the pan pizzas take ~ 40min to come out, but the wait was clearly communicated and there are a lot of appetizers to choose from while you wait. The deep dish slices were surprisingly light and easy to eat. The sauce was really fresh, too. Wonderful experience!

I'm not a Chicagoan.  I don't mind Deep Dish, I love cheese.  But to me, it's more of a casserole type of pizza.  I have tried about 5 different places deep dish here in the city and this one is far and above the best.  The pepperoni is so crispy and there's the yummy slightly crispy cheese parts around the edge.  And the crust isn't super sweet like all the other deep dish places!  That's a big one for me.  
I would never wait the 2 hrs for my pizza again.  1 hr outside and then 1 hr at our table.  It was Saturday around 8 so our bad for the timing, but, it is way better to eat there than delivery.  Doesn't hold up well with delivery.  At least up to Lakeview area.  
Anyhow, it's delicious.  Highly recommend for ppl that want deep dish but aren't huge deep dish fans.  In my opinion :)

Tried it based on a recommendation, but not impressed.
Even placing the order was a hassle...no online option, and the girl who took my call seemed like I was interrupting her at work.
Got a 10" pan (deep dish).
The ingredients were not evenly dispersed, one piece (it comes cut into 4) had all pepperoni, another almost all sausage.  Couldn't see/taste the Fresh Garlic that was supposed to be added, but maybe it's all on a piece I've not had yet.
The crust was OK, but not impressive.

Can't recommend it.

This is hands down my favorite pizza restaurant in the city. I am so addicted to their handtoss, caramelized crust pizza. The wait to get a seating is something I'm not a fan of but that's the price I have to pay for getting the best pizza in the city.

I've had Chicago Deep Dish Pizza before.
My friend, a Chicago transplant for 10 years, stated this was a secret favorite of the neighborhood.  It is a bit crowded and loud, but that's a good thing, that means the food is good.
We were told that it would be a 40-50 minute wait.  We ended up waiting less than 20 minutes.  The pizza takes a while, 40-50 minutes and it actually did take that long.  Bring conversation with you.
We ended up getting the Large deep dish with: wait for it... Sausage + Spinach + Garlic!!!
It was delicious.
OVERALL IMPRESSION:
I'd say the pizza is about par compared to other deep dishes I've had. But, it's surely better than the average pizza. I would go back.

A place to drink socialize and eat
Pizza is no worthy of the title chicago deep dish
Medicinal taste
Slapped together with conflicting mix of flavors
Crust was crunchy but lacked the taste of Lou Malanattis

Not worth the wait or $$

Pequod's is the best of the best when it comes to Chicago style pizza! The toppings always taste super fresh. I only had to knock off a star because sometimes the hostesses and wait staff can seem really disinterested. But it's definitely nothing that would ever stop me from eating in or ordering delivery.

Have gone many times for dinner, but that lunch special is amazing! $4.95 for a personal size cheese pan pizza (toppings extra) and soda.  It's definitely the best pan pizza in the city (I don't consider it deep dish, like Lou's or Giordano's)

I'm not a fan of deep dish or red sauce but this place is fantastic. Crust is totally unique - crispy and flavorful outside but perfect soft dough inside. Delicious home made pizza sauce seasoned to perfection with excellent consistency. Peppers were full strips of vegtable and we had half Italian beef and half meatball- flavorful! Can't wait to come back - friendly/welcoming staff and clean establishment.

Pequod's is easily the best pan pizza in Chicago. The edge of the crust looks like burnt lace and tastes crispy, caramelized, and perfect, yet the crust itself is soft and pillowy.  They add a really nice amount of cheese and sauce and are not stingy with toppings.  The sauce has great flavor and a bit of spice!  The pizza is just so dang good - it's tasty, amazing, rich, and perfect.  There's also an awesome lunch special - you can get an individual pan pizza for 5! (Toppings are extra) If I am craving deep dish (though this is more pan than deep dish), this is absolutely where I want to go - if I can handle the two hour wait that usually accompanies dinner here.  

I give four stars instead of five because the service is generally poor and slow.  I'm not complaining that the food takes too long to come - it's deep dish, of course it's gonna take an hour (and on busy nights, more than that).  It's that our servers aren't the most attentive and forget things that we ask for.  It happens every time I go.

pics.caption: Look at that beautiful crust and gooey cheese.  Perfect.

review.des:
I just cruised right in this piece with a friend of mine, and sat down.

Our waitress was off the chain, and we definitely dug that.

The pizza was so good that I wanted to like marinate in it all day.
never wasted time this place is run like a zoo better places in the city to spend are money at

I came here after doing a little shopping in the area, and was pleasantly surprised. I have heard a lot of good things about this place, and the pizza exceeded all my expectations. Very highly recommended, I wish there was a Pequods near me!

This place came recommended by a lot of locals so to avoid naming another restaurant we went to Pequods instead of the other.

It is in up town Lincoln Park area so a bit out of the city. I've never been one for pizza but have only recently taken a liking to thin crust (actually my coworkers believe I love pizza now).

I had to get ready for this mentally as it was not a pizza at all. It was tasty. I don't understand the hype of deep dish but that's just me.

Keep in mind wait time for your actual pizza is about 45min so you'll need a light appetizer.
Very busy. Tvs available to watch sports games.

Went here because we wanted a late dinner after visiting the Art Institute one evening. My spouse has tried most of the other famous Chicago-style pizza places in the area. The pizza was delicious--good crust, though the cheese and sausage toppings were not well distributed. We enjoyed the meal, but spouse says it's not his favorite in the area. We called ahead and they said 30 min wait, but we were seated immediately.

Burnt awesomeness!

That burnt looking edge on your deep dish pizza slice? don't cut that off and throw it away. Pequod's secret to an intensely flavored crust is that the pizza masters apply a thin layer of cheese along the sides of the pan. While the resulting flavor is just decent, the texture is ahh-mazing! This caramelization gives a great contrast to the very thick and dense pie.

By the time we arrived at Pequod's (after hitting THREE other pizza joints) I was quite full. So, I opted for the spinach version while the bf had the sausage/pepperoni pie. Being that the crust is pretty hefty, some might feel that you need more sauce or more cheese to balance it out, but it was perfect for me since I LOVE carbs. ;-)

Located in the Lincoln Park neighborhood, it's a locals hangout but you'll spy the occasional tourists (us!) Definitely worth the train or car ride from tourist central Michigan ave.

Go to Pequod's -- crispy cheese crust or bust.

pics.caption: A slice of the spinach pie -- note the caramelized crust!

review.des: Unbelievable chicago pie! Asanty, I feel sorry for you. The fact that you would even consider Domino's as actual pizza. Your comments should be stricken from the records.
Great pizza!  Love the crust, sauce and everything in between!  Delicious!  Great vibe and fun place to hang out in a group or your significant other :-)
So good.... I recommend this pizza to new comers to town;) call in your order the place is so popular it's grown past the holding capacity. Local fav!!! Get some pizza after the movie!

On a recent visit to Chicago we were directed to Pequod's by a local rather than to more popular spots. We were not disappointed, the pizza was delicious and they have a great selection of beer as well.

4.5 stars, would need to visit more to see if it's 5 stars. Happy that they accept reservations. Really loud (we were seated upstairs). But the pizza, my goodness.

sausage and pepperoni deep-dish ($19 for medium 12") - 4.5 stars. Caramelized cheese crust was f-ing incredible. It looks burnt, but without any of that bitter burnt taste. I approved of the toppings-to-bread ratio (I don't want foccaccio, yo!). Sausage, pepperoni, cheese, sauce, everything was on point. The crust and base had the crisp & softness of a pan pizza.

I know in my heart of hearts that I will be back. That is a promise!

pics.caption: My first slice of Pequod's did not disappoint xD
Medium 12" sausage & pepperoni pan ($19). Dat caramelized cheese crust!

review.des:
UPDATE: This place got featured on food network as one of AMERICA'S TOP FIVE PIZZA JOINTS! SO IF YOUR EVER IN THE AREA MAKE SURE TO TRY THIS PLACE OUT!!!

So everyone knows that Chicago is known for their deep dish pizzas and there is a plethora of pizza joints running amok in Chitown. There's Lou Malnati's, Gino's East, Giordianios, and the list just goes on and on. Everybody has their opinion of what is the best and their favorite. The best pizza joints compete and some really might be better than each other by honestly the difference of what constitutes "better" is literally by a thin thread. That's why I was on the hunt for a deep dish pizza that was truly unique and I found it at Pequod's!

Their service was horrible and the way hostess and managers run the business just lacked class and professionalism. You can tell they were flabergasted with the crowd of lines waiting to get this pizza. We decided to To GO our pizza and just eat it inside the hotel. No worries! The cheese was still gooey when we opened it.

This pizza is truly unique and is baked in a black pan. The inside rim of the pan is sprinkled with mozzarella cheese and that is what makes their infamous caramelized crust. It might not be for everyone because my friend wasn't such a fan. She thought it just tasted burnt. (btw she doesnt really like food that much so her opinion is not valid). I, however, LOVED THE CRUST. It was chewy, salty, and flavorful. I liked the crust so much that when I was too full from my pizza, I took the crust off the other slices and just munched away on the crust.

So our waitress was a real sweetie, but overall we waited about 45 minutes to get in around 6pm (earlier than peak according to Google), then when we ordered, we were told it was going to be about an hour for a deep dish pizza. It's understandable I suppose, but the folks across from us sat down much later than us and their deep dish came about ten minutes earlier than ours. When ours arrived it was definitely not the temperature we'd assumed it would be (we both had fun picking up the pan with our bare hands) and we really questioned what all the hype over this place is about once we'd had a slice. I'm not an expert, but I did have my first deep dish just 4 days before coming to this place and enjoyed it much more.

At Pequod's, the crust is flavorless and takes up about 75% of the height of the dish. We were expecting much more sauce and much more cheese. And much more flavor. Overall the only thing not disappointing about this place was the sausage and the whale shaped mozzarella cheese they'd grated on the salad.

I dislike most of the pizza in Chicago. I never seek it out and rarely enjoy it. The style is so, so hard to get right and most places aren't consistent at all. It makes pizza reviews rather ephemeral. Pequod's is my favorite of them all.

Best deep dish in Chicago. Period.
Good, relaxed atmosphere. Great beer selection. Probably only do once every 6 months as an incredibly calorific experience.

I've had so many deep dish pizzas in Chicago, and Pequod's does it the best. If you love a heavy focus on toppings, a crunchy crust, and less sauce, their pizza wins for sure! While getting a table for dinner on the weekend means waiting 2+ hours, we have found that carry out is the best option since the hole-in-the-wall, crowded atmosphere of the restaurant isn't for us. I prefer this deep dish pizza over the often-favored Giordanos because the crust is much tastier (and not soggy in the middle) and the pizza isn't just all sauce.
The best deep dish in Chicago!  Love the slices of cheese as the crust.  Hands down, best Chicago deep dish!
Great pizza with a great environment too! It seems to always be busy but the wait is never as long as they say!

Over 3,000 reviews and over 1000 pictures - is this a tourist attraction or has this place been getting reviews since the beginning of yelp? As someone who has not tried chicago deep dish ever before, I was kind of disappointed. Was going to put 2 stars but since the description for "Meh, I've experienced better" doesn't apply to me since I've never had deep dish, decided to give it an "A-OK" rating. Don't get me wrong - i LOVE pizza, and I LOVE crust, but if all deep dish pizza is like the ones at Pequod's, then I may just be a thin crust fan. First of all, the caramelized crust just tasted like crispy crackers, and the crust in its entirety tasted like flavored croutons - super crunchy and not the stretchy, flavorful soft crust that I was expecting. Biting into a pizza I usually expect a chewy and yeasty texture to crust, but here the crust was more like...toast.
The toppings were good, they were pretty generous on the meat, and the cheese was wonderfully stringy and generous. Environment is amazing for watching sports (we came on the day that the Cubs won! haha this place is better for late night) and drinking beer, but if all deep dish has disappointing crust like this then maybe I'm just not a fan of deep dish pizza in general :(
Will try other deep dish places to compare!

I grew up on pizza from the south side but I can't lie this place was very good. The thin pizza was alright but the pan pizza was delicious. I prefer my pizza well done and it came out just right. Wings were also a hit I really can't complain about this place besides the parking and wait to sit down.

pics.caption: Small pan pizza with Italian beef and giardiniera

review.des: Literally the best Pepperoni Pizza money can buy. An institution! They never let me down at lunch or dinner or party size. Its always been good.

Overrated at its best. Location is not good, ambiance sucks and the pizza is very lackluster. Mind you I ordered a personal pan cheese only so maybe the toppings is what makes it. My pizza was pretty much burnt I wouldn't call it buttery definitely crispy and the cheese and sauce were nothing special. I would not venture here for another taste at all. Glad I went though to check out what they hype was about. Try for yourself!

My fiance and went here last night. We are foodies and try a new place every weekend. The places we try range from 5 star to total dives.

The pizza is amazing. The pizza is totally cheesy and the crust is the best you can get. We also tried a Pequod salad. The toppings were plentiful and the house made Italian dressing is the best I've had. This place will not disappoint.

Ive read some of the other reviews- you dont go to Pequod's for a 5 star atmosphere. You go for the food. If you want a 5 star atmosphere you choose a steak house, etc. This place is perfection and we are thrilled we chose Pequod's for our date night. We went to Distilled for drinks beforehand and also enjoyed ourselves

I love Pequods. But I have a few reasons for not giving 5 stars, even though I want to. I am a vegan so I was DELIGHTED to find that I could eat their deep dish pizza. The crust is one of my favorites and the sauce is so flavorful that it makes me salivate like crazy. That is all I can comment on since I usually just get a completely plain pizza, no cheese. I could add veggies I suppose. The price is okay, deep dish is usually more $$. I wish they offered vegan cheese! Also, be prepared to wait a good 40 minutes or more. It is worth it. OH and there are two levels, it is quite a cosy place.

Came here for dinner alone (lol) after a TON of people recommended it to me while being in Chicago. Arguably there is a bit of a competition between this + a couple of the other more popular pizza joints, but I decided to go with what I was hearing majority of people recommending.

Ambiance is very "local." Nothing exquisite or decorated or curated or charming, but felt very Chicago. Don't really know how to describe that. It was packed - came around 8pm on a weekday, but luckily was seated pretty quickly since I was just 1. Most there were in families/bigger groups.

I ordered the personal size deep dish cheese pizza. It was absolutely DELICIOUS. Caramelized butter crust (that is thick and chewy, but not overly so like some other deep dish pizza joints) and a solid amount of cheese (again... not too much cheese).

Overall, loved my experience here and would definitely recommend. I easily scarfed down the personal size pizza for myself (but I also am a pretty big eater - probably would have been good to split this with 1 other person, or save 1 slice of pizza for the next day. But it was just too good!)

Pretty affordable as well.

Would highly recommend to someone wanting an authentic Chicago experience that doesn't feel too "done up." Great tasting pizza doesn't hurt either ;)

I currently live in NY but I'm not a thin crust die hard-- I actually prefer deep dish. More sauce, more cheese, even more bread, what's not to like?? But I was somewhat disappointed with Pequod's, which was recommended by multiple Chicago-resident friends. The fact is, I didn't think it was a great deep dish pizza, let alone a destination deep dish pizza.

We ordered a cheesy garlic bread as an appetizer which I wholeheartedly preferred to the pizza. It was warm, melty, and garlicky, and suuuper cheesy. The pizza we ordered (which I also think is ridiculous that each topping is about an additional $2.00) was impressive in its presentation, but not as flavorful, and more bread than anything else, although the edges were crispy with crisp almost-burnt cheese. I thought it would be saucier and have a sort of doughy inner that kind of melded with the tomato sauce, with a crisp bottom, but I was sadly disappointed.

The pizza does take a while to come out. Highly recommend getting an appetizer or two to hold you over. And definitely throw out your expectations of getting a nutritious, healthy meal if you're coming here. I felt my arteries clog just sitting in the place with all the scent and grease this place accumulated over the years.

Want the city's best deep dish? Don't waste your time with the stuffed pizza "chains". This place is in a league of its own. Only downfall is that seating can be sparse on the weekends or during dinner rush hours. Great people run this place.
This place is always packed... but for a reason! Delicious pizza and they serve alcohol. Just give extra time to wait for a seat especially on a weekend. But once you are seated food comes quick :)

It's okay. The place is consistently packed with people coming & going and the pizza IS good, but it lacks when you compare it to some of the other pizza places on the south side (Nick & Vitos, Milano's, Russo's, Fox's, Beggar's, Giordano's). Because of this, I feel it is overpriced for what it is. I didn't like the northside yuppie crowd so much, but the service was pretty good despite it being constantly busy which was surprising! Kuddos to the servers for putting up with all that madness! In conclusion it's not a bad place, but it's also not someplace I would go out of my way for.
Tasty pizza. Unusual crust makes it worth a look.

I daresay that Pequod's Pizzeria, which is located in the vicinity of Wrigley Field (Chicago's baseball stadium), rivals even Lou Malnati's Pizzeria itself for best Chicago-style deep dish pizza!  I absolutely LOVED my deep dish pan pizza from Pequod's - it was perfectly tender in the middle and crispy on the outside, just as I like my pizza.  

The restaurant itself is big and we didn't need reservations at 7pm on a Wednesday night in mid-October.  We were initially seated at a high-top table but requested to be seated at a booth and they were quite accommodating, which I appreciated.  The service was good overall but the food was even better.  I highly recommend the 7" personal pan pizza - I got cheese only and it was perfect!

First time at Pequod's last night, and I was very impressed. I don't usually toy with deep dish, but the crust was delicious, and the service was good.

I will eat again.

First of all, this is not real Chicago-style deep dish pizza. Everyone needs to stop comparing it to Lou's or Giordano's.

Given the hype surrounding this place, I decided to bring my friend from out of town to Pequod's to show her how amazing Chicago deep dish is. It was my first time at Pequod's as well and we were both equally underwhelmed. I wish I would have taken her to a Giordano's instead.

We came in midday on a Saturday and were seated quickly. We started with a small order of buffalo wings, which did not particularly stand out, and then ordered a pizza for us to share. I was impressed with the topping options (including an italian beef option) but we stuck with pepperoni and peppers. Once it arrived, the pizza was soupy and we were disappointed to see it was mostly breading. Perhaps it would have benefited from a few more minutes in the oven, but overall there was just too much sauce.

Bottom line: definitely overrated and closer to being a Detroit style pizza.

very nice pan/deep dish pizza.  their sauce and caramelized crust makes it unique.  definitely a must try.  stay away from their thin... its a 2/10... nice beef... lot of other menu items just standard.

Two or so hours wait and our pizza was cold in the middle. Crust is just crumbly and soggy. Makes no sense at all that our less toppings pizza was cold and our every single topping on the menu pizza was warm. If you are okay with waiting for two hour for the pizza then go ahead but there could be better options out there.
Ordered deep dish, waited, waited. Received undercooked and burnt crust on edges and then to boot the waitress says "it's our special crust it's not burnt"

I'm not from Chicago and I haven't tried the other popular pizza joints, but I am from San Francisco and we do have some pretty darn good deep dish. Actually, it's so good that my favorite deep dish by far is still Little Star in SF, but Pequad's is definitely the runner up on my list. It was definitely memorable, my favorite parts being the burnt edges, but it's not as addicting as I was expecting.

JONASAPPROVED!

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago! It's truly everything you assume it would be. Be aware of a long wait ahead- usually about 1.5 hours. Also the pizza usually takes 40-45 minutes to make as well. Great option is to sit at the bar and eat there for quicker pizza eating. :)

I've grown up eating deep dish, but this was my first time at Pequod's and it was great! I expected a very long wait, but we went on a Sunday around 4:30/5 and were told the wait would be about 45 minutes. They have some seating outside while you wait, or you could go next door and get a free soft drink with your buzzer. I had just gotten my drink when the buzzer went off- our wait was only 20 minutes, which was a pleasant surprise. Being deep dish, there was also a wait after you order but the server said ordering just cheese may make the wait shorter. We got some salad and waited less than a half hour for pizza. The sauce was really good, and the crust wasn't as filling as other deep dish spots I've had. Overall, worth it to check out!
Pequods....... Love love love your pizza!.The best in the city. Whats up with the service. Our pizza was cold, our bartender she didn't even care. Still love you!

I was drawn to Pequod's because of its $4.95 lunch special. The lunch special is a personal one-topping deep dish pizza and a drink of your choice. What a deal. The pizza is enough for 2 people, and the drink comes with free refills. I ordered the deep dish with giardiniera peppers, and this was the perfect combination of mozzarella cheese baked into the pizza "crust" shell. The peppers and sauce are on top of the pizza, and there was a good ratio of peppers to sauce. The sauce is well-seasoned, and not overly sweet or spicy.

Pequod's is located in a line of businesses on a busy street. There is street parking nearby. The establishment itself is dimly lit, which gives it a bar-like feel. There is a full service bar and flat screen TVs showing sports games above the bar. The space itself is small, but I would recommend it for a meeting with friends as many people were doing or just a solo lunch. The service is fast and friendly, and your pizza arrives in 20 minutes with no wait.

pics.caption: Personal Deep Dish pizza with giardiniera peppers

review.des:
Really, a forty minute wait to sit down for pizza?  Must be some really good pizza.

And the eight of us waited outside, in the cold winter.  Argh.  Everyone insisted on waiting.  Fine.  We are all already there.

Lemme tell you something.  This place is a grower, not a shower.  We walked through a lot, to get seated on the top floor, at the very back.  Took us bears and pandas maybe ten or fifteen minutes to get through it all.

The waitress?  Got our complicated order just right.  She totally earned that $60 tip.

How was the pizza, you ask?  Some of our group came from New York.  They were inspired to start a business based on the pizza they had here. Idk how feasible it would be to order from here and then deliver it to Manhattan or Brooklyn, and have it piping hot.

I'm still in the group that says "Its just pizza, and no, if you think it's better than sex...you're not doing IT right."

A suggestion for better business and flow:

Give a menu to people waiting outside.  Especially during winter. You can even have them/us order and pay while outside.  We will do it.  Why?  Because we are already hungry.  And you'll have faster table turnover, so you can seat even more people in a night.

And it gives us a reason not to leave before we even get to enter.

pics.caption: Glory hole? Hahaha.  Surely, it's gone by now.

review.des:
It was super busy when we came in for our reservation on Sunday. We still had to wait a little which was no big deal. For an appetizer we had the cheese bread and a salad, both were decent. Our table ordered three personal deep dish pizza's which took over an hour before we were served and each one was missing a topping. In fact, the table of four that was seated after us got their pizza's first. I'm guessing our server put our order in late and even wrong.

Despite all that, the pizza's were full of fresh toppings and the crust is amazing! The sauce just soaked into the bread, but it wasn't soggy. And it was even better the next day, you don't even need to heat it up. I would definitely come back for another pie. Hopefully I won't have to wait so long to get my pizza next time.

pics.caption: Personal deep dish with tomatoes, onions, and green peppers.

review.des: One of my favorite place for deep dish pizza. The crust is to die for. The line to dine in is usually long but worth the wait.

This was one of the worst customer service experiences I've ever had. I arrived with my party at 6:30 pm, and was told it would be an hour and a half wait to be seated.

At 8:15 pm, we were told by the host that people who called ahead got to skip the line past people who were waiting in person outside the restaurant. I honestly don't understand this logic.

After we saw a party of 4 walk in and get seated at a 6 person table before us, we left.

I'm sure the food is great, but I can't say, I never found out. The service is just awful though. And with as much competition there is in Chicago for pizza, you would think the customer service would be better.

EAT HERE!

The appetizers are hit or miss but lets face it you come here for the deep dish pizza with caramelized crust. I am more of the stuffed pizza fan but Pequod's is a front runner on the deep dish pizza side of Chicago pizza places! If someone offers to take me here I except without hesitation and have introduced several people to their pizza. Its worth it so go!!

...be careful if seated upstairs, the stairway is a bit steep!

Pizza is amazing but customer service leaves much to be desired. I ordered a pizza to be delivered at a certain time to a certain bar at a specific time, to ensure that someone was there to recieve it. They delivered the pizza 40 minutes early when no one was from our party was even at the bar. I called their location once I learned of this early delivery and told them that it was unacceptable as no one was there to recieve it and was asked to be delivered around a certain time for a reason, which I was told was you ok when I asked before ordering the pizza. When I called the location to report the descrepency of delivery and asked to talk to a manager I was first transferred to someone who was not a manager then hung up on when I requested a manager again. When I called i.immediately back and asked for a manager the manager gave me an attitude about their discrepancy and was told that another pizza would be delivered at the original requested time to compemsate , to which as of now 3 hours later it still has not been delivered and their customer service leaves much to be desired. Therefore I am giving them 1 star purely on their customer service and inability to maintain their worrd.

Man I've been DIEIN' to try this place. As a self proclaimed yet extremely humble pizza snob, I'm always on the hunt for the next best slice.  Pequod's on the weekend is a nightmare- SUPER crowded and long wait times (we left our first visit there after being told we'd have to wait 2 hours for a table).  We gave it another go this past Sunday afternoon and were seated right away, which was awesome.  The waitress was nice, the Pequod salad was good (homemade Italian and Ranch were on point).  We ordered the pan style pizza with half pepperoni, half sausage.  Wait time was typical.  Finally got to try the infamous blackened cheese crust! Was the pizza good? Yah! Was it something I'd rave about, wait 2 hours for in a super crowded restaurant for, or drive back to try? Probably not. Honestly I was missing the crunchy, buttery crust a deep dish usually has, and the blackened crust just left me wanting something I wasn't gonna get.  It's good pizza, it was a great dining experience and I'm glad we tried it out, but I'd say we're a one and done here.  :)

Best deep dish I've had during my visit in Chicago! I def prefer it over Giordano's. The crust is crispy on the rim and bottom which makes a big difference for me. You have the option of toppings and size. The personal pizza was more than enough to fill my appetite! The bartender was super friendly, the vibe and atmosphere was chill and enjoyable. Def felt the Chicago spirit here. Sit at the bar for the ultimate experience!
Delicious deep dish pizza. Always packed. The crust was crunchy and delicious and so was the rest of the pizza. Would recommend this place over other deep dish places.

I have eaten a lot of pizza in my days.  (My doctor would probably say way too much.)  But the thick crust pepperoni pizza at Pequod's is my absolute favorite.  Period.  The caramelized sauce and crust are done to perfection everytime.
One of the top five Chicago pizza joints. Love this place!

Even though I'm a thin crust girl all the way, I figured I should still know about deep dish if I was going to live in Chicago.  We finally tried Pequod's last month.  It gets pretty crowded so we went on a random weekday for an early dinner.  We were seated upstairs (it was a little difficult for me to climb the narrow staircase since I was 40 weeks pregnant) in a table for two in the middle of the room since all of the booths were taken by larger parties. This was better than sitting downstairs at a high top table.  Even though it was busy, it wasn't crowded yet, but it still took a while for the server to come greet us and again more time for her to take our orders, get the check, etc.

We started with an order of the Caesar Salad (I forgot if it was the half or full order) then split a small 10" deep dish with sausage.  The crust was caramelized and crispy and held the sauce, cheese, and toppings well.  I was only able to eat one quarter while Hubby ate two and we took the remaining slice to go.  Pretty good for deep dish.  I would be interested to return and try their thin crust or even the lunch special 7" personal pan cheese pizza and a soda for $4.95.

The best deal in Chicago: come during lunch during the weekdays for a personal deep dish pizza and a drink for $5. Pequod's is consistently ranked as one of the best deep dish places in Chicago and I have to say it is my absolute favorite.

Usually not a fan of Chicago style pizza, but Pequod's pan pizza is oh so good.  As others have stated, its the crust that makes this stuff so crack-like good.  If, you know, you're into crack and all.  The crust is flakey and buttery on the bottom, but the prize is the burnt cheese crust on the edges.  Seriously, you need to monitor your fellow diners to make sure they're not stealing the burnt cheese crust edges of pieces that do not belong to them.  I know from experience.

Ok, ok...its not all about the crust, 'bout the crust....   In addition, Pequod's is generous with the toppings and their sauce is good, too.  

I've only had the pan pizza, and only delivery, so I can't comment on the other food items or dining in.  And the delivery can take up to 2 hrs on a Friday evening.  And yes, it was worth every darn minute of the wait.  Like crack, you gotta wait for your fix!

This stuff is flame! Don't sleep on this joint, you tourist will regret it! Mouth watering pizza and a really smooth atmosphere will make wish you were born in such a city. This place is where real headz come and chill and enjoy a slice or two. Don't come to Chicago and not come to this place! Located in the center of yuppie ville, no need to worry about the neighborhood, just watch out for their delivery guys!
The pizza here is pretty good.  Not sure about all the hype, but I liked it a lot.   Takes a crazy long time, so plan accordingly.

The service was nice... pizza took about 20 mins... the wait is worth it though probably one of the best pizzas in Chicago if not the best I've ever had... I'll have to come back for the $4.95 lunch special personal pan pizza and a drink

Now just a disclaimer that I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza. I'm much more of a thin crust person, but even I like this pizza. I guess it's kind of more a pan pizza than true deep dish but I don't care, it's deep dish enough for me. They cook it to have this crispy halo of cheese around the crust which is amazing!! I've found that Giordanos has too much cheese and not enough tomato sauce, and I don't like the buttery crust of Lous so this is my perfect deep dish pie. Perfect ratios of all the pizza elements with a cheesy halo, what more could you ask for? It's a bit of a wait and it's just street parking but it's worth it.

I came here based on word of mouth, having heard about it for so long.  If I was just judging the pizza,  I would give it another star, as it was very good.  The service, not so much.

We came in on a weekday afternoon and there were about 4 other tables being served.  We waited about 15 minutes before anyone came over, and then after ordering drinks, about another 15 minutes before they arrived.  This was draft beer, by the way, and the bartender was about... 7 feet away from our table.  This is a very small place, so it really starts to feel purposeful when you are being ignored for that long.

We would have liked to order more beer but we never got the chance to.  We placed our food order and the waitress left, at which point I'm assuming she was abducted or went into a coma in the back of the restaurant.  After about 30 minutes of staring into empty beer glasses, our pizza came.  We asked the bus boy to send our waitress back and he nodded, but she never appeared.

The pizza was really good, super crispy, melty, and I really like the personal pizza size.  The sauce was also very flavorful.  Two thumbs way up!

When we were done eating though, we had to ask the hostess for the check, as the waitress had never come back, and at that point I would have even just wanted a glass of water to wash my meal down with... so I'm not sure if I'll go back.  I'll probably try delivery instead!
The best pizza in the city! Every time my family comes in from out of town, this is a must try. No one does deep dish like Pequod's

Be aware that like most deep dish places out takes a while for your pizza to be made, but luckily here the appetizers are pretty good. The cheese garlic bread was just okay, but the jalapeno peppers, mushrooms, and mozzarella sticks were on point. Pizza uses a lighter crust than other deep dish places which I think is a plus.
Loved this deep dish pizza. Takes a while. Comes out on cast iron skillet, but flavor of crust, sauce, and toppings are legit.

Pequods - this is what Chicago natives will tell you when they ask if you ever had a good Deep dish, I mean really deep dish pizza before.

Having lived and worked in many different cities before I have had pizzas, normal and the exceptionally thin crusted ones as well. But not the deep dish pizza where you need to navigate through this deep dish pizza with a knife and a fork. Yes this is deep dish, not possible to do it with your bare hands, well yes you can but it will be a mess!

The deep dish pizza is good but it makes you bloated after a second piece. Apart from Pequods there is also Giordano's in Central Chicago near to the Willis Tower. Nice but you have to wait for your order, about 20-25 minutes for the deep dish pizza to arrive.

Try it! It's an experience.
Bomb pizza, great beer.  Staff was awesome, so was the dessert.  What more do you need?

SO OVERRATED.

First of all, the fact that everyone raves about this place as the best pizza place in Chicago is pure bs. This was my first trip to Chicago and I've been hearing that this place and Lou Mal something are supposed to be the best. Boy was I SO DISAPPOINTED! I should've known when I arrived at this tiny hole in the wall looking bar scene that the fact that this place has more than 3 thousand reviews is a little suspicious and most likely due to some incentive given for checking in or writing a good review.

Anyways, on to the pizza. So my husband  and I were super excited to try some really good authentic Chicago pan pizza. We ordered the cheese with mushrooms onions and olives. Visually, the pizza looked kind of dull and grayish all over, which I do not know why since all the veggies are supposed to make it look colorful.

TASTE: SO BLAND and BARELY ANY CHEESE !!!!! I felt like I was eating a fat piece of bread with veggies on it. The bread to cheese ratio is so off. I hate pizza that does not have enough cheese that's the fun part ! Eating the gooey cheese with a good amount of sauce and a nice balanced crust. But anyways, this is what killed it for me. Pizza Hut has more flavor than this place sadly to say.

CRUST: The ONLY good part was the outer burnt edges of the pan pizza. The pan dough that the pizza is baked on however, was so bland and nothing special.

COST: What also was annoying is the fact that they charge $2 which so much for each topping and they have no options to choose from, only cheese and you pick whatever toppings you want. They already charge $16 for a medium which is way overpriced anyways. For such a tiny hole in the wall they charge so much. The place definitely does not reflect the quality or taste of the pizza.

Overall Review: DO NOT get fooled by the massive amount of reviews. That's the only reason I picked this place as our first Chicago pizza experience over Lou Malnatis or any other famous ones. DONT WASTE YOUR MONEY here ! I honestly am so baffled at how in the heck this place is famous. SO DISAPPOINTED.

I fly out from Los Angeles and come straight here. Best pie I've ever found in Chicago. There's lots of infamous spots, but this is the one. Not just this location, but any one of the Pequods you'll have the best pie; period love is an understatement. Best of the best is close.

My friend said that this was his favorite Chicago deep dish. Having been disappointed by both Giordano's and Lou Malnati's, I was eager to try this place.

Our waitress noted that the pizza takes 40 minutes to bake, so we opted to order an appetizer. We got the sampler that came with mozzerella sticks, mushrooms, poppers, and zucchini... all of which were fried and of a similar quality that you would get at Denny's. Luckily we didn't have to spend that much time eating the appetizer because 25 minutes later, our pizza arrived! Wait, I thought it took 40 minutes, but whatever we dug in. We got a pretty standard sausage, mushroom, peppers and basil, They really piled on the toppings and the sausage chunks were huge and looked home made.

The first bite was delicious until I got to the uncooked dough, a nice layer right beneath the cheese and right above the rest of the cooked crust that was still mushy and raw. Well it was in the center of the pizza so maybe it was just that part. 2nd bite, uncooked. 3rd bite, uncooked. 4th bite, uncooked. It was at this point that we asked our waitress to return the pizza to the oven to cook more and she was kind to oblige. 5 minutes later (for a total of 30 minutes oven time), our pizza came back piping hot. But that layer of uncooked dough was still there.

Yes, the caramelized crust (read: burnt cheese) is delicious, but the sauce and the rest of the pizza are nothing to write home about. Sorry Chicago, but for me, Cali deep dish still reigns supreme.

Ordered their Pan pizza.  Crust was dense and had zero taste and was dry like aged bread.  Overall, totally subpar experience.  Ordered as a delivery, and it came 25 mins late.  No apologies offered, and person at store hung up on me when I asked if it would close to 30 mins late.

Pass.

Let me preface this review by saying that I'm not a super big fan of pizza, no matter it's shape or form, but I can appreciate a good deal when I see it. My wife and I wanted to experience the Chicago Deep Dish pizza and found this place to be well loved by the Yelp community. First of all, if you are relying on public transportation, be willing to go on a mini hike across the LePaul campus to get to this little gem. We came here on a weekday, just barely making it to the lunch specials, which was a personal 7" cheese pizza for less than $5. That is freaking amazing! Of course, we splurged a little bit more, added numerous toppings, and got a small side salad for $2 and a local, honey infused root beer. Alright, I wasn't a big fan of the salad or the root beer, but it wasn't that bad either. You can see from the menu that Pequod makes each pizza individually, with a minimum wait of 30 minutes to accommodate for the toppings. I initially thought we'd be safe from that wait time since the restaurant was fairly empty (which is unusual, based on the reviews), but I guess the wait time is unique to a deep dish pizza. MY biggest disappointment, aside from the pizza being salty, was that it was served on a regular plate, instead of a deep dish. Ok, so 7" pizza may not have needed it, but it would have given an unique illusion of a deep dish pizza. We eagerly scarfed down the pizza and found it to be perfect sufficient for the two of us. Unfortunately, I got incredibly nauseous a few hours after lunch, so I had to dock a point for that.

Food: 3 stars
Price: 4 stars
Ambiance: 3 stars
Service: 3.5 stars.

I think this is actually a long-running Punk'd type thing, where they must be filming people waiting forever and then pretending to like the worst pizza I've ever had (worse than Papa Johns).  
Yeah the crust gets caramelized into whatever is stuck on the bottom of your oven.  You can eat that with no wait, just grab a spatula and get at your oven!!
I do not get the hype.  Giordano's for life.

Extremely underwhelming. Never been here before, so I came here with an open mind. The pizza was lukewarm, the crust was very thick, which led to thin amount of toppings. The sauce tasted like it was out of a far. The cheese and maranta were great. This was on a Monday night. I really don't recommend waiting for an hour and a half.

Personally, I don't love deep dish pizza, pizza in general is never my go to but Pequod's is a great compromise for me and my boyfriend who loves deep dish pizza!

I've been here a few times and the pizza is great if you prefer more dough over cheese. They're usually pretty busy so i definitely recommend preparing to wait an hour or so on the weekends.

Also really appreciated them delivering to me when I lived on Adams St (which was one block south of their delivery area). I called on a Saturday night and asked, they had extra drivers that night, we had pizza delivered to us an hour later!
Their pan pizza is good. I wouldn't get thin crust as it's not the same and here are better options, but their pan pizza is bueno.

I'm not a native Chicagoan, but to me this is the best pizza in Chicago. I'm not a fan of deep dish so Pequod's pan pizza is my go-to. Whenever friends or family come to visit we love having an excuse to get Pequod's. The dough has a great bite and the edges get caramelized to crunchy cheesy perfection.  I'm pretty sure it's understood in our house that stealing the amazing cheesy bit of crust from someone's slice is unforgivable. We always get their sausage as a topping. I think they make it themselves and it has so much fennel. Yum! Also - the salad! They cut the cheese into little whales. Love it.

The only advice I would give on this place is that the pizza is so much better if you go have it in the restaurant vs. delivery.

Really casual atmosphere, plenty of room inside, but expect a wait due to this places popularity.

Service was great and the prices were reasonable. Came here as part of a bachelor party weekend, and 9 dudes definitely grubbed down. They're thick deep dished pizzas. 4 large pizzas were more than enough for us all, not to mention we also got wings.

I'll be honest, I'm not a huge deep dish pizza fan, but won't hold that against the specialty of this place! Be sure to make reservations for a large party!

THAT CARMELIZED CRUST THO.

If you love Chicago and love pizza do yourself a favor and get here. The toppings are delicious and plentiful, the beer menu is great, the service is good and the ambience, is, well, just ok. Not a deal breaker.

It's definitely worth ordering a large and taking the rest home with you.

Wow! Pequods! Finally!! After a very long time of anticipating Pequod's pizza and taking our out of town guests, I would say Pequods should not be rated as a deep dish pizza because it is not a deep dish pizza. It's like compare apples to oranges.  The pizza is delicious and one of the best pan pizzas, had a little resemblance to Pizza Hut's pan date I say, but it does.  My favorite Chicago deep dish is still definitely Lou Manalti's and Giordianno's!

Will I go to Pequods again?? Of course!!! It was a great pizza. If we were to just talk about pizza's, Pequods is in my top 3. Yum!

Oh my goodness. This is my favorite deep dish pizza place of all time. You can't go wrong with any type of pizza here.  I always get extra sauce on my pizzas here which makes them ten times better. You HAVE to go here if you are in Chicago and love pizza.

Maybe we just ordered the wrong thing - we didn't have enough time for deep dish so we got the thin crust. I've never in my life had a piece of pizza I didn't think was worth finishing - even elementary school pizza. I subscribe to the pizza/sex mentality - even when it's bad, it's still pretty good. Not the case with this pizza - it was not worth finishing and I didn't even try.

For the people who give this place a bad review due to "burnt crust" are idiots. That is caramelized parmesan cheese baked into the dough as it cooks. Due a little homework if your visiting or ask about it at the time you get the pizza.  So if your looking for a great deep dish pizza then this place is top 3 in Chicago   Suggest getting the sausage. All the sausage is specially made with their recipe from a local meet place in Chicago. It will take some time to get the food so be patient. Staff is great and efficient. Keep in mind it's hard to just walk in during the dinner time or weekend evening and get a seat. It can take 2 hours if you don't have a reservation. The pizza is top notch. I cannot speak to the rest of the menu, but who goes here and orders anything else anyway.
It's one of the three top pizzas for sure. You're doing this for a chicago tradition. Not for the taste Giordanos is my go-to

I didn't enjoy the food here. Too much grease. I felt ill that evening through the next day and normally my stomach agrees with everything.

My friends love it. I didn't. Nice management and maybe I'm just an odd bird.

I don't like deep dish pizza.  Sorry.  I said it.  But THIS deep dish pizza... I love.

So delicious!   Best deep dish I've had, and I've tried all the classics (Giordano's, Lou Malnati's, Gino's East, Pizzeria Uno).  

I don't know what it is, but it didn't feel overly heavy to me.. The crust was delicious, and the filling was gooey yumminess.  The four of us split a large (way too big for us), and we split the pizza in half.  Half was Italian Beef + Giardiniera, and the other was Spinach, fresh garlic, and mushrooms.  Both sides were amazing.  

Thinking about it makes me hungry, and I wish I could have some now. :(  Come to Dallas, Pequod's!!!
If you get it delivered, make sure it is uncut and you reheat in the oven for a few minutes. Arrives soggy a lot or the time.

The pizza was amazing, as always. The service this time? Not so much. Our server was so incredibly rude with her snarky comments. My friend asked her a question about a beverage and the waitress asked my friend if she just got out of a shelter lol ...... On top of that, I asked if I could order a pizza to-go at the very beginning of our visit, knowing that the pizzas take a while to cook, and she laughed and replied with "Remind me to do that later, I won't remember". I assumed she would come back at least once while we ate so I can do so, but she never came back to check up on us. She came back at the very end with our checks. I then reminded her about the to-go pizza and she sighed and explained that it would've been easier to just give me the check she had ready for me. After giving her a confused look,  she then reassured me she can add it on. I asked her to order the same pizza I previously ordered and she said "oh it's so cute how you think I remember what pizza you got" (as she's holding my check that clearly says the pizza I had just ordered).
How does this lady still have a job?! So rude!! Wish I got her name. Hope the owner reads these reviews.. I was at table 22 from ~2-4 o clock on Thursday December 28th. I wouldn't be surprised if most of these terrible service reviews are about her.
The best deep dish in Chicago, hands down. Took my cousin from New York, he is now flipped!
The pan pizza had an excellent buttery crust that complemented the loads of toppings well!

I was in Chicago for a business trip and wanted to try some Chicago style pizza.  Our Uber driver told us Pequod's was the place and he was right.  I love good pizza and this may have actually been the best Pizza I have ever had.  If you are in Chicago and have the time (45 min wait for us) it is worth it!

Pan pizza like you dreamed of. Lots of toppings. Mine had peppers onions meatballs and sausage. Started with a Caesar salad. Followed it with the crispy crust deep dish. Be ready to wait an hour but worth the wait. Trust me when I tell you there's very little that believe is worth a long wait. I'm an instant gratification kind of guy. This was worth it. Parking is on street and a challenge. Find a way to get there.

pics.caption: This is the prize for waiting an hour.

review.des: Best deep dish in Chicago that I have eaten at!!

BEST PIZZA IVE EVER HAD!!!!!!!

Hands down best pizza I have everrrrrrrr had!!!!!!!

Pizza: The crust was amazing like non other, every bite had a crunch to it, and best part was even though it was deep dish I did not feel like I was eathing something that was really heavy.

Atmosphere: Place is huge, two floors of pizza heaven, I suggest you call ahead if time and make reservations.

Service: All of the staff was friendly EXCEPT for the girl taking our order, from the second I sat down she was giving my group an attitude, it was obvious she did not want to be there. After asking for her opinion on a few items and getting such a salty response all I wanted was to have her leave our table and stop ruining the happy vibe we had that night. Its a shame because there are a lot of people who would love to have a job these days....If the owners are reading my review put the server with the attitude in check....server number AZ010 on my receipt

We decided to go with Pequods for deep dish after several recommendations from my local friends. The other options as many of you looking for pizza in Chicago May know are Lous, Giordannos and other small pizza joints. Let me start with the wait time, we arrived on Saturday around 6:45pm at which point we were told that the wait time would be anywhere between 2 to 2 and a half hours but before receiving a pager we had to come back to check in an hour before our estimated time of seating. 2 hours and later and we finally receive a pager and we get seated around 9:40pm. That's almost 3 hours of wait time just to be seated. After being seated we have to wait another hour just to get the pizza. Anyone who knows the place might say that because it was a Saturday the wait was expected and that's my fault for making the conscientious decision to stay and wait, however I stayed due to the high reviews. Here is where the pizza does not merit the wait. The pizza crust had a good taste but it was very hard to chew. The taste of the entire pizza was underwhelming despite having pepperoni, meatballs, onions, mushrooms and green peppers. Hope this helps anyone deciding to try this place. In my opinion it's overrated.

I'm going to say something blasphemous here and say this is the best Chicago pizza out there. I definitely take folks from out of town here more often than their more famous counterparts. Can't go wrong at Pequod's, especially before catching a movie or heading over to B&N to browse some books.

The deep dish crust is spongy. It is like eating toasted English muffin with toppings on top. Their thin crust is more decent. Ultimately, I don't recommend it nor would I serve it for my guests. Lou Malnatis is still #1 for me.

pics.caption: Spongy crust. Like English muffin or sour dough.

review.des:
Came here in the middle of December for what my Chicago friends said is very good deep dish.

Actually their exact words were "this is where Chicagoans go"

Was not expecting this at all. Pizza was very good but it is not deep dish....I know shocking right?

It's a stuffed pie not deep dish, and yes there is a difference. Nevertheless it's still a really interesting take on a classic, one that I wasn't aware of til that fateful winter night.

Go, be happy and enjoy "stuffing" your face.

My mom is in town visiting from Texas. She saw this place on the Travel Network and wanted to give it a try. I'm not a huge deep dish fan but that's what my mom wanted so we got it. I prefer/love Lou Malnati's. This pizza taste like they got a loaf of bread put some toppings over it and stuck it in the oven. The cheese was overdone around the sides (my mom said that's there "thing" which was weird to me but I digress). We ordered delivery and it took about 2 hours to get here, which isn't terrible given how long it takes to make deep dish pizza. The woman who took our order seemed rushed and unpleasant. The sausage was good, therefore maybe I'll go back and try thin crust one day. I told my mom that as a Chicagoan I would be ashamed if someone from out of town tried this and thought this was what deep dish is about.

Great pizza! My husband and I love this place but only get it once in a while because we try to stay relatively healthy. So when we do order we are really looking forward to it. I've had them deliver to my home before, but this time I'm being told I'm outside of the delivery zone. When I  checked their website I found that  I am well within the zone. I call back to clarify and am immediately met with an attitude (I guess I was annoying them. Idk. This was a different person). When I asked what exactly their boundaries were the person hung up 9 on me. I call back again because now I'm upset and want to talk to a manager. I'm immediately put in hold and a manager answers. I inform her that her staff is hanging up on people and that's when she again starts saying that I'm outside of the zone. So I inform at this point I'm no longer interested in their product and was simply asking a question to her staff. That's when I get a full explanation about a glitch in the system that is making things difficult for them. If that full explanation had been given the first time, instead of me getting shut down for asking questions, I might go back. But they've lost my business for good. Staff seemed to really care less about turning away business.

When I am craving pizza and happen to be in the city, I always head to Pequods! Located on the corner of Webster and Clybourn in LP, it is the perfect spot for Chicago style pizza.

My favorite thing to order is the pan pizza with extra sauce and tomatoes. The sauce is on the sweeter side, which I love! The appetizers are pretty good as well. The chicken wings and fried mushrooms are my favorite though.

Every time I've been there, the service is great. Friendly and fast!  I think Chicago wins with all the pizza choices, but Pequods is by far on top of the list!

The food was not good, our pizza was wrong and it had hair in it. The server saw the hair and continued to serve the pizza. They sat 5 of us at a 2 seat table, then tried to put one of our pizzas on a chair because there wasn't enough space in the table.  The manager trued to make it better but he just gave us an over cooked pepperoni pizza and threw undercooked sausage on it, there was barely any sauce on the pizza. My family was visiting from out of town and we went there because I heard great things. The pizza sucks. Little Caesar's is better than this place.

What's the all the hype about Pequod's? It's not even deep dish - it's a pan pizza. Seriously, check the menu.

It's a pan pizza than a traditional Chicago deep dish so there is a lot of dough - kind of like focaccia bread. There are two things going for their pizza - the burnt cheese/crust and the tomato sauce. Yes, burnt food can lead to cancer but it tastes so good. Why can't things like cheese and butter be good for you? The pizza is generously drenched in the tomato sauce but I didn't mind because it was thick, robust, and zesty. I would eat a bowl of pasta topped with the sauce since it was that good. If DePaul students weren't spoiled enough, the Lincoln Park location is open until 2am on the weekends vs. the 10pm hour at the Morton Grove location.

Pequod's - not quite a true Chicago deep dish pizza but still good.
The best pizza in the city! The service was lackluster on our second visit but the pizza is fantastic

Me and my BF decided to get carry out from this place as a Saturday night treat. I called to order and was told it would be an hour and 15minute wait for a carry out pizza. I was a little shocked but said it was fine since neither of us were starving. We arrived to pick it up at exactly the 1 hour 15mins mark and were treated by hoards of people crowding the entrance and spilling out onto the street. Once inside, it made sense. It was a Saturday night and this place is a little on the smaller side, so lots of people were waiting to be seated. I over heard the hostess saying it was a 1.5-2hour wait for a table, wow.

We ended up waiting in a slow-moving line to pick up our pizza. It was a little annoying how long it took to simply pick up a carry out pizza. And, we were lucky out order was actually ready when we got there. Some people had to wait even longer after paying for their order to be ready. Also, this place isn't super expensive, which I like. I'm pretty sure a medium pan pizza is only $16. The only outrageous thing is that each extra topping adds like $2.50, which adds up quickly. We paid $23 for a medium pepperoni and sausage pizza.

Once we finally got the pizza, it was good! I really really love the crust on this pizza. It's the best pan pizza crust I've ever had--nice and dark, but not burnt, and super crispy. I also loved the quality of the ingredients: nice, huge chunks of tasty Italian sausage and literally the entire pizza was covered in pepperoni which was awesome. The sauce was also good. My only complaint is that I felt the pizza was super skimpy on cheese at some points I was like, does this pizza even have cheese on it!? But seriously, this pizza is damn good.

Overall, I'd avoid this place on the weekend unless you're willing to wait 1-2+hours for your meal! But definitely check it out on a week night, this pizza is
bomb!!

I came here, because I've always heard great things about this place. I would definitely direct friends from out of town to Giordano's or Lou Malnati's though. I don't know if my experience was out of the ordinary, but the service was not great as the waitress was not attentive & the deep dish was very dry and bland. It also took about an hour for our pizza to come out.

Got a large pan pizza, half pepperoni, half mushrooms and green peppers. It's appropriately filled up 4 people, and compared to the other major pizza spots around town it was actually a little bit cheaper(large pizza w/2 toppings $24.65). The first bites were actually pretty amazing; the cheese by then was still very gooey and, being a pan pizza, the crust was crisp but also incredibly fluffy. It's not like the buttercrust at Lou's where you have something of a more pot-pie consistency, this is straight up large pan pizza. Also, was a little skeptical about the caramelized cheese crust at first, but after trying it I'm a fan. Not as incredibly amazing as most people say it is(I mean, at that point you can't really even taste that it's cheese), but the texture is great and I think I'd prefer it to other deep dish pizzas in that regard(after all, you're still getting plenty of the thicky doughy goodness on the base of the pizza...no need to have more on the sides). The pepperoni were nothing special, and would opt for the sausage next time.

One dangerous downside...after initially amazing first few slices, once it cools down a little bit you actually realize how much of it is actually dough compared to filling. Whereas with say giordano's you really have a ton of sauce and toppings and the pizza dough is maybe 1/3 the width of the entire pizza, here it's the opposite; the dough actually accounts for like 75% of the height. Once it cools down this becomes very apparent, as you notice the thin layer of cheese and toppings compared to the dough. That said it's all super fluffy so it doesn't feel as if there is that ratio upon eating it, but it does take its toll after a while.

So final deep dish verdict? Actually a fan, and would say this hits the right price point too. Only major cons are that I didn't get the sausage(not their fault), and that there is a lot of (albeit very fluffy) dough which makes the ratio seem a bit off.

Pequods has been on my bucketlist for a while now and today I finally got to experience the deep dish and it did not disappoint! First off this restaurant has 2 floors, the bottom floor was really busy so we were asked if we would like to sit upstairs and so we did. There were TVs to keep us busy while we were waiting for the personal deep dish pizza. The lunch special of $4.95 a personal cheese pizza with a fountain drink is an absolute steal and I really enjoyed it. The crust is the best deep dish crust I have tasted to date, it is soft and it melts in your mouth. Everything about the deep dish is delicious from the cheese to the sauce to the crust. It is also very filling! I will definitely be coming back here.

Pizza and bruschetta were good. Waitress was nice. We were seated upstairs - sign on the entrance said they're open until 2am. No one told us the upstairs closed at 11pm so we were taking our time, completely unaware. When we realized we were the only ones left we asked the waitress and finished quickly to get out but overheard one of the workers - small guy with a puffy bob - talking to our waitress about how "these bitches are taking their time". Just make sure customers are aware of the different closing times. No need to be passive aggressive.

If you are in the mood for deep dish, Pequod's is hands down the best in Chicago. That burnt crust is one of a kind. However, you will need to work to get your pie with waits frequently over an hour. Love the pizza...hate the wait.
Crust is absolutely amazing. The actual pizza has too much sauce, and too little cheese. Overall, really good!

This place is legitimately one of my favorite places to get deep dish pizza. Their crust is light and buttery, but the burnt cheese crust that you save for last is the best part.

Also, their service is great. Everyone is nice and friendly; they do their part to make you feel at home.
Chicago city staple. Not the traditional deep dish but still amazing. Has been featured on many food channels.

This is the best of the best of the best... provided you order it fresh, at the restaurant.

I dislike bar atmospheres, which this place definitely has, but I more than tolerate the dark, the noise, the raucousness for the sheer sublimity of this perfect expression of Chicago Pizza. The platonic ideal, to wax philosophical. It's also more than worth the long wait/the long prep time if you call ahead (recommended). It's a chain, but *barely,* with just one other location--the original, in the suburbs. Nothing like the tourist-friendly polish of Giordano's/Lou's, with a freezer in the front for tourists to ship "authentic Chicago"!!!! pizza souvenirs to their buddy Joe in Montana.

Now, it's well-known that the mere fact of being geographically served within Chicago's city limits does not a true Chicago Pizza make. There are four or five valid choices, in order of my personal preference: Pequod's, Giordano's, Uno's, Lou Malnati's, Gino's. The final four in that list are pretty close in ranking, and reasonable people can quibble about the order. Pequod's is in the #1 slot by leaps and bounds.

Be prepared for a thick, doughy, bready crust which caramelizes to crisp perfection. It's not "burnt" and won't give you cancer. Just exquisitely cooked cheese and tomato sauce. The deepest pan of all deep-dish joints. Fresh ingredients (I usually order with double mushroom, broccoli, and garlic). And the most FILLING pizza you've ever had. Two or three slices are all most people can handle.

As I said at the start, this pizza is really best eaten fresh. Ordered as delivery or takeout and reheated at home still results in an excellent, exceptional pie... but a good chunk of the magic is lost and it becomes more in-line with the others.
Service was great, but our pizza was burnt and dry - couldn't taste the caramelized crust at all.

I've been to Pequod's a few times before and was excited to go with some friends who were in from out of town this weekend.

We arrived at 4:30pm on a Saturday and were a bit surprised to find there was already a 30 - 45 minute wait for a party of 5. (This was the point we should've just gone somewhere else.)

We were seated at 5pm and ordered our pizza and an appetizer around 5:15. No one mentioned a longer wait time on food that evening. The appetizer came out almost immediately and then our server all but disappeared.

Around 6:15 I was able to flag her down and ask if she knew the status of our pizza, expecting it to be up soon. She came back about five minutes later to tell us she wasn't sure what had happened but a manager would be coming. A manager then came with nothing to report, returning again to tell us that the ticket was lost, they didn't do it on purpose, and it would be out in ten minutes. He also vented to us about their three hour wait for a table. (Uh, maybe because you can't keep orders straight in your kitchen?) When a member of our group expressed his frustration, he said he'd "do something for us" on the bill.

Look, I've worked in the service industry. I get that people make mistakes. But the manager couldn't even be bothered to apologize!

Our food eventually came about 90 minutes after we ordered it, and the pizza was good, but it wasn't worth the inattentive service and long wait.

Aaaaaand then the bill came -- with no discount given despite the manager's promise to do something for us. We paid it all and just left because we were all ready to go home at that point.

It'll be a long time before I visit again.

Not the worst deep dish in Chicago, but just not in the same league as Malnatis, Gino's or Giordanos. Service was decent, but not really sure what the big fuss is about. Interior is very small and in dire need of remodeling.
Best deep dish pizza on the planet! Seriously. Takes a little while to cook, restaurant is usually packed, but it's worth it.

Really is as good as it gets. No specialty pizza needed. Classic cheese, sausage or pepperoni is enough to make anyone believe that the pan pizza is the perfect style pizza there is. And Pequod's sizzles. The cheese is puffy and stringy. When you bite in, you keep biting for a hot second. There's a lot of pizza there.

I'd eat it at least once a week if it was more conveniently located!!

I hosted my birthday here last night and requested a table for 10 a few days prior to the day at 7pm on a Saturday (a very busy time). I received a confirmation within 20 mins. I then wanted to increase the reservation by 2 and also received a quick confirmation.

Upon arriving with many people waiting, we were seated right on time. It made my birthday experience great and is much appreciated. I highly recommend this place and also utilizing the prioritized seating request. Lastly, the pizza and service was great as always! Thank you!

I'm a big fan of Lou Malnati's for deep dish and it's my go to place but I kept hearing great things about Pequois and wanted to give it a try. The wait on a Saturday was pretty long (we were quotes 2 hours but it ended up being 1 hour). There's a Barnes and Nobles across the street so you can pass the time there. The restaurant/bar is pretty small although there is an upstairs I didn't see. We got down to business and ordered a small sausage along with a Pequod salad. The salad was standard and the whale cheese was a cute touch. The deep dish was generous and delicious. That infamous caramelized crust lived up to the hype, the crust is lighter than Lou's, and the sauce is bright and flavorful. I was bummed the sausage wasn't an entire layer like at Lou's but that might be personal preference. Overall, really good deep dish that I think will win over devotees and first timers alike. A fun atmosphere that is a great place to grab a few drinks and eat some pizza.

If I were to come down from a mountaintop and found a religion, I would never be more certain of anything in my life than I am of the unassailable quality of this pizza. The crust is Dante's Paradiso in cheese and bread, and the sauce and toppings are the east, the sun. Truly cannot recommend higher to any lover of deep dish. Pequod's Pizza is truly the still point of a turning world. It reminds Chicago of what it should be, and indeed all that it COULD be, on a daily basis. Service was pretty good

Love the pizza and wings!!!  Service is okay. Wait for delivery is usually 1:45 minutes so I end up picking it up which isn't ideal because It's usually a mad house in there. If they could improve the delivery service I'd give five stars for sure.

This deep dish pizza is amazing, from the toppings to the caramelized crust. I recently came to the Pequod's on Clybourn on a trip to Chicago and felt at home in the restaurant. It smells great, and there's a great atmosphere. If you like eating pizza and watching sports, this is the restaurant for you.

My first experience with  Chicago deep dish turned out to be enjoyable. I shared a sausage onion pizza with a friend. The sauce was very good, the crust was deliciously crispy and the dough was what I expected - a bit soggy but I guess that's Chicago right? Still doesn't beat New York though!
hands down chicago's best. the sausage is amazing, the crust is killa! love, love, love.

We got pizza to-go, and it was fantastic.  There really isn't a place to stand and wait, so make sure that you are not 20 minutes early like I was.

Pizza was fantastic, and the staff was really on top if taking care of me the entire time I was there.  Offering me water while I wait, and checking on my pizza every couple of minutes.  I'm pretty sure that my pizza was in my hands less than a minute from leaving the oven.

Overall it was a fantastic experience.

Hipster atmosphere. Crowded most times we go. Decent crafts beers. Great deep dish pizza with primo ingredients. Could argue that this is the best pizza joint in Chicago.

Expect about a 45-60 minute wait once you order your pizza. I usually get a deep dish [pan pizza] w/ extra cheese, sausage and pepperoni. The ingredients are huge too. Not those little sausage balls at Pizza Hut. I don't order extra cheese at any other pizza spot but here i think it's necessary. Just don't think it's enough cheese on their pan pizzas. Pizzas come out great every time. The only downside is that once you wait an hour for your pizza by the time it gets there is still too hot to eat so you end up waiting longer to eat it.  Fml. But with great conversation and a few drinks you'll be eating in no time.

Really enjoy this spot. Would recommend a few more beer selections but that's just being picky. Definitely  a must go to  spot in Chicago.

Almost forgot to mention the cheese melted to edge of the cast iron cooking pan. Cheese gradually goes from cheesy to burnt. Sounds weird but it give the crust a nice carmelized taste. Loves it!!!

pics.caption: Xtra cheese sausage and pepperoni - yum

review.des: Best deep dish pizza I've had. The sauce and the crust were equally delicious. One of the toppings we ordered was with garlic and it was a lot of garlic! We ordered their buffalo and bbq wings and the bbq sauce was amazing!

Ordered pizza for the first time as we like the thinner crust vs the traditional deep dish here in Chgo. Prepared perfectly and tasty. Delivery timing was also great. I highly recommend. Trying Pizanno's soon as a comparison .

Hands down,  the best pan pizza in Chicago.  The pans are so old and seasoned from repeat use, the flavor is out of this world.

Order wait is like any pizza place, it takes a while, the place is a bit crmped but always busy because it rocks.

Who doesn't love Pequod's pizza?  Was in before a movie at Webster and enjoyed the classic pan pizza with burnt crust. Yum!!  Just head's up the service is (still?) touch and go. Are they all just spacy or just always really busy? I don't know...they are nice enough and the pizza is delicious.

BEST PIZZA PLACE HANDS DOWN. I have lived in Chicago my whole life, and this is the best!! Awesome atmosphere and when you call ahead they will put you first on the waiting list.

I'd recommend calling a few hours before you get there- don't just show up, the wait is usually over an hour!

So I really wanted to love Pequod's because my friend Susan RAVED about this place. Maybe it was the 1.5 mile walk from the El that deterred me, maybe it was the AWFUL first date going on at the table next to me, maybe my expectations were too high - but I just thought it was okay.

Don't get me wrong, it was certainly above chain pizza crap and I did enjoy it, but it didn't knock me off my rocker. I had a personal pizza with nearly everything on it, and I think maybe that was the problem. I didn't get the entire essence of Pequod's because my sister doesn't like deep dish and I was stuck with a baby pizza. Don't worry I shook my fist vigorously at her when she told me this AFTER we walked 1.5 miles in the snow uphill both ways (I'm only slightly exaggerating)  to eat at this place.

Either way, I'm willing to go back and try it again because I really want this place to be as groundbreaking as everyone says it is.

I've gotten Pequod's a couple of times now, and I don't think that I'll be doing so again.  

The first time I ordered pick-up while I was running errands, and was told it would be a 45-60 minute wait on the pizza.  That was fine, and when I showed up, my order was completely wrong.  I ordered a thin crust with peppers and mushrooms, and was given a deep-dish pizza with only mushrooms.  When I complained to the staff, I was told that it would take another 30+ minutes for them to get my correct order out to me (that time included being given "priority" so that my pizza would be out more quickly).  No attempt to make things right were offered as far as a discount off a future pizza or knocking the price down on the current one.

The second time I was in the area with relatives from out of town, and happened to be in the area, so we stopped by to put our name on the list.  We intentionally went before the dinner rush (about 5:30PM) because I know how crowded it can get.  We were told 45-60 minutes for a table, which was fine.  Fast forward to 7:30PM and we were still waiting for a table and were pretty hangry at that point.  I would have been fine if we showed up and they told us that there was a two hour wait.  We would have simply went somewhere else, but every time we asked about the status of our table, we were told that one was opening up and would be the next to get seated.  We finally had to suggest to the hostess that we be seated around a high-top table (which for 6 people is a tight squeeze), and I never felt that anyone even cared about the poor service that was provided.  

I really wanted to like this place, but it seems to me that they feel that they can treat customers however they want because if they lose one or two, they'll have more lining up sooner or later.
