Definitely better pizza and service (here at the bar) than the Morton Grove location, though that really is faint praise.

~Peter O.

I've heard that real Chicagoan's don't like deep dish. Whatever. This place was backed and decked to the walls with Blackhawks stuff.

The best part of the meal, but also kind of the gripe about it, was our pizza. We ordered a spinach and tomato pie, but they told us it was a mushroom pie? (It wasn't--just spinach only, no tomato). Not sure how this all got bungled up but at the end of it a $27 medium pie was more than enough for the three of us for dinner.

The pies take a while, especially since it was busy, but it is well worth the wait--just get a pitcher and put in an app order. When the crispy edged, gooey pizza finally arrived, we demolished it.

Holy cow. I finally tried Pequods pizza after living in Chicago almost my whole life. What took me so long. My 21 year old daughter and i had the day together today and she wanted to try it. It was amazing. The burnt cheese crust was something amazing and absolutely delicious. Perfectly cooked.
The restaurant is really cool inside. Ambiance is terrific. It looks small when you walk in but they have multiple seating areas. Parking is a challenge but well worth it. Service was a little slow as our server wasn't as attentive as you would like, but the food really made up for it. Prepare to wait to be seated at peak times. Go on off hours to get in and out faster. I can't wait to go back again...

Great deep dish! If you're an out of tower and want to experience Chicago's pizza, you have to come here. I was a little worried because I like crispy crust pizzas and a thick crust made me wonder how good it would be when its soggy, but boy was I wrong. It added an extra bready flavor to the pizza and Meade it extremely hearty.

::phone ringing::

Pequod's: Pequod's, can you please hold?
Me: Yes.

Pequod's: How can I help you?
Me: Can I get an order for pickup?

Pequod's: Is this John?
Me: Yes.

Pequod's: What would you like?
Me: Large pan pepperoni.

Pequod's: Is that all?
Me: Yes.

Pequod's: Ok, large pan pepperoni. 45 minutes.
Me: Thank you.

pics.caption: Large Pan- half pep n chz.

review.des: After hearing awesome things about Pequods we had to come try it. Overall I was a bit disappointed. The toppings were great, but I'm just not a fan of how they do their crust. I know that's what makes them unique, I just didn't enjoy it as much as a traditional deep dish crust.

I came here on 12/29/17 during lunch and it was freezing. Everyone had their jackets on because it literally felt like you were outside. When our pizza came out we couldn't even enjoy it because it got cold extremely fast. We also refused to eat more than a slice due to the cold. Don't eat in during the winter, there's no heat. The pizza was of course delicious as always, but sucks that it had to be ruined.

Hands down best deep dish in Chicago! Worth the 2 hour delivery. The pepperoni pizza is a must order when ever I have friends in from out of town. The burnt cheese crust sets it in a class of its own.

Wow, more like eating a casserole with bread underneath but very tasty, fresh and light and rich, somehow simultaneously. I was good for a slice and a half and called it quits before things got out of hand. Amazed that the place was jammed at 1pm Sunday. They sure have it going on.

We are from Miami and wanted to go to where the locals have deep dish pizza. Luckily one of our uber drivers suggested Pequods and let me tell you it was SPECTACULAR. People say it's more of a pan pizza, but to me it felt like a deep dish. Anyway way better then Giordano's which is where all the tourists go to. You can get decent deep dish pizza where the tourists tend to stay at but if you are willing to take a 15 mins uber drive from downtown to Pequods it will not disappoint!

The family was really excited to try Pequod's because we had heard so many incredibly good things.  Unfortunately they didn't live up to the hype.

First of all the place was packed.  We wanted to do take out anyway so we asked how to place that order.  There is someone standing by the phone who just does the take out orders.  We wanted a sausage and mushroom pizza (with cheese obviously)  We asked if the sausage was sliced or crumbled.  The order lady didn't know, she had to ask.  Fine.  It was crumbled.  Just what we wanted.  We ordered the pizza and was told it would be an hour and fifteen minutes.  No problem, we had other things to do.

Picked up our pizza and brought it home to enjoy.  Well almost.  The crust on the diameter was amazing.  I don't know how they get that caramelization  without burning the heck out of it and yet making it the best tasting crust ever!  The center portion of the crust was only just okay.  Also, not too excited about the fillings.  There really weren't much of any.  Don't know what happened but I didn't taste or see any cheese at all and the sausage and mushrooms were also a rare commodity though I did find a few pieces floating about.  I really wish that Pequod's had lived up to its reputation.  As my son said, about 20% of the pizza was great, unfortunately that left 80% below average.
My favorite Chicago style pizza joint. The crust makes this pizza stand out. Also had the wings which were good while waiting for the pizza.

I called around 3 pm to order a pizza for take-out at 6:30. I got there a little early, around 6:20, and paid for the pizza. At 6:30 they told me that they made a mistake the pizza would be ready  in 15 minutes. About ten minutes later they told me 12 minutes, and the pizza wasn't ready until 7pm. The pizza was good, but not worth the hassle and chaos-- the restaurant was extremely hectic and disorganized. Not worth it.

I take friends from out of town here when they want to try deep dish but I find the pizza here only slightly above average. I am admittedly more a fan of thin crust pizza so only eat deep dish on special occasions or when others want to try it and I think Pequods does it better than most in Chicago. Ambiance is ok, it's pretty tight inside. Service is usually enthusiastic and does a good job of handling the usual hustle and bustle.

I'm normally a thin-crust/NY-style pizza fan, but I'm down for deep dish pizza ANYTIME if it's from Pequod's. It was so good that I overate and had a stomach ache the rest of the afternoon.

Keep in mind that you end up waiting ~20-40 minutes or so for your pizza since it's a deep dish and needs to bake longer.  

There are a lot of pizza joints to choose from in Chicago, but  if you're trying to pick one, Pequod's should be at the top of that list.

I won't get into the debate of New York Pizza and Chicago-style Pizza, but I will say that Pequod's definitely exceeded my expectations. Everyone told me that this was better than Lou Malnati's, so I had to try it out when I was in town visiting some friends. Tables were very crowded, but we managed to come at just the right time.

The bar scene was great, and we were definitely stuffed after ordering our own specialty pizzas. The crust is great and the amount of cheese to sauce is just right. Gotta love that stuff. Just wish it didn't take so long for to come out. I know it's common place for deep dish to take longer, just had to say it.

One thing I love was the presence of Fat Tire. I know Fat Tire might be pretty commonplace in Chicago, but it's actually hard to come by in New York City. I definitely drank my share of Fat Tires while I was eating, which made the experience even better.

I'll definitely be back, next time I'm in the area. Might need one more visit to push me over the edge and declare deep dish pizza as the better alternative to NYC pizza.

this is the deep dish place--excellent without being a soggy gooey mess. Also, since it is so filling, the price per head is very good. Second to none for deep dish and a pretty decent thin pizza too, a good bargain.

Deep dish with mushrooms tomato basil and olives. It was very good, flavored and tasty. This is the 4th deep dish pizza restaurant I try and it ranks pretty good.
I just rate it 3/5 and not 4/5 for the usualy very long waiting line, even when we call for reservation.

Once you've gone Pequod, you'll never be able to go back to regular pizza. Seriously, I do not know how I am going to be able to order and eat pizza in Saint Louis again. I was in Chicago for business and meet up with two local Yelpers, Lupe d. and Damian P. for lunch. If it were not for their hospitality I would have never discovered Pequod's and true pizza.

Side note: Meeting up with a fellow Yelper is easier then someone on those Internet dating sites. Yelpers post "real and current" pictures.

Both Damian and I started out with a Pequot Salad (Half Size). What attracted me to this amazing salad, is that they use no Iceberg lettuce. I have a strong dislike for Iceberg and was thrilled that they use Romaine. They then garnish it a variety of fresh vegetable toppings, pepperoni, pepperoncini and cheese. If it were not for Lupe being a regular and alerting us to take note of the cheese. Damian and I both would missed the detail that the cheese is sliced in the shape of a whale. Another big bonus point is that they always serve the salad dressing on the side in a little cup.

Besides the conversation and meeting fellow Yelpers from another city, the piece of resistance was the pizza itself.  Being a man from Saint Louis, I am use to thin crust and not a fan of "deep dish pizza".  However, when I saw the description how they make their pan pizza on the menu, I was sold. Pizza prepared in cast iron pans that have been blackened by decades of seasoning, is a winner. Then being told that the overflowing cheese emerges from the oven as a halo of caramelized crust had me saying, "thank-you Jesus". My personalized 7" size pizza with pepperoni, Italian sausage and jalapeño blew me away. I will tell you, Pequod's does not skimp on toppings, the tomato sauce is rich and the mozzarella cheese melted perfectly.

The service was friendly. We had a main server who was there when we needed her and other team members assisted making sure our food was delivered to our table in a timely fashion.

I have found my pizza heaven, I just wish it were closer to home.

pics.caption: Personal Size Pan Pizza - Sausage, Pepperoni & Jalapeño.
How appropriate for a restaurant with Pequod in its name.

review.des:
Although my friend who suggested this place has never been here, she said this place is talked about by everyone so we made our reservation around noon for a party of 11 to dine at 7pm.  We had other friends joined us and called them about 3pm to change it from a party of 11 to 15 including kids.  So reservation is a must if you're with a large group.

When we arrived, the wait wasn't long at all, about 10mins before they escorted us upstairs to our seats.  The place was jammed packed so I'm glad they take reservations.  The waitress was very attentive as she took our orders before everyone arrived since the pizza does take a bit long to make.

We started out with a pitcher of beer, salad, and some breaded shrooms.  The breaded shrooms are must haves.  They were very flavorful.  The kids loved it as well.  It was all gone before the rest of our party arrived so we placed another order of them.  We ordered 2 large thin crust and a large pan pizza.  As everyone was arriving, we ordered another pan pizza and a couple more pitchers of beer.  For a party of 15, 4 pizza was more than enough.

The pizza was delicious.  Very flavorful and the crust was the best I'd ever had.  It was nice and crispy.  I have never had a caramelized crust pizza before and I must say, it was awesome. The price was fair and wasn't to pricey.  I would definitely recommend this place but do keep in mind, it's a long wait if you're there on weekend because we were there on a tuesday night and the line was super long already.  So glad we made reservations. It is also a kid friendly place.  One of the best pizza places I've been to.

pics.caption: Large Pan Pizza with mushrooms, bell peppers, onions, sausages, and more...
Thin Crust Pizza - Half Cheese and Half Vegetarian

review.des:
I guess I just don't get it. First off, I don't really care for "Chicago Deep Dish." But during a tour of the best rated pizza restaurants in Chicago we were sure to try both deep dish and thin crust at those places that offered both.

The crust at Pequod's reminds me of Jiffy Baking Mix biscuits you might have with some sausage gravy and hash browns. Of the deep dish places we went, this was by far the most disappointing.

The people here (customers and employees) were nice, but the pizza is not the best we had in Chicago, let alone on a level with NY, LA, SF, etc.

The worst customer service and delivery. We ordered at 5pm because we knew it would be busy on the weekend and after 2 hours called to check. They said they tried to deliver, but we were sitting home the entire time. They offered to redeliver the 2.5 hour old Pizza or make a new one that would take another hour to deliver. Never again.

This used to be one of my favorite pizza places in the city. Great for someone who just can't get on board with deep dish but wants something more than just thin crust. However we attempted to go here at 4pm on a Saturday and were told we would not be seated with our baby. In case you haven't been there before it's not fine dining. It's a pizza joint. We won't be ordering from here again.

When you go to a pizza place, you don't go there for health food. But that's what these trendies at Pequod's think they're doing. If you like raw vegetables on your pizza - this is the joint for you. But if you just want to caloricly, throw caution to the wind, occasionally, as most  people do when they go out for pizza, there are innumerable places nearby where you can get a real pizza and an enjoyable pizza experience. You can eat your salad at home, anytime.

Grew up in Morton Grove, a few minutes drive from the original. May be the best pizza in the US! This location has late hours, befitting it's location, and been here many times with my daughter. Always had good food and service.

I heard many good reviews about this place, and I actually drove twenty minutes across town to go there.

Unfortunately, I was very disappointed with the front desk/waitresses attitude. I felt unwelcomed. They gave me a buzzer, and told me to wait for an hour. While me and my friend stood up waiting in a clustered place, I go to ask about the wait, I get a rude reply back from one of them, "It's an hour wait" I know it's an hour wait, I just want to how longer I have to wait since I am sure it was more than twenty minutes standing for my turn.

At the end, I handed in the buzzer and just left.

Thanks for the welcoming! Keep up this low attitude, and you'll lose that good reputation in no time.

I can't say that I would pick Pequod's deep dish over Gino's East (tomato sauce so fresh) or Lou Malnati's (finely balanced elements), but it was still very good pizza and our server was highly competent with our big group. We also get the mixed appetizers and those were good too. Kind of an unremarkable experience but a fun exterior and a cool interior with plenty of seating.

Best pizza in the world! Pepperoni, sausage, meatball.. love them all. Delivery can take awhile and sometimes may make sense to order half baked and finish in your oven. (Honestly, it comes out perfect.) I'd avoid getting too many vegetable toppings on same pie, as the veggies are cut kinda big. Lunch special is the best deal on the planet. Been eating this for a decade and never disappointed.

pics.caption: Small pan half pepperoni half sausage

review.des:
A couple of servers at Alinea recommended this place, so I had high expectations.
There's barely any cheese. The crust is about 7/8 of the pizza, the sausage wasn't fully cooked and it's burnt to a crisp.
Possibly the worst pizza I've had in Chicago. I'd rather eat 10 pies from horrible Giordano's than one slice of this trash. Dominoes would be a massive improvement.
Wow.  How do I describe this place.  It's Chicago style pizza, but better!  They put cheese on the crust.  How can that go wrong?

Lives up to the hype and worth the wait. it's the best deep dish, bar none. I am not a huge fan of deep dish generally but this place won me over! Get enough for leftovers and pop right in the oven. You won't be disappointed, as it is just as good day 2.
A little crowded.  A little hot.  But great bar atmosphere, and great chicago style pizza.  Burnt cheesy crust is fantastic.

We were like a group of 8 - 10 and we had a like an hour long wait before we actually got in and started getting ordering drinks and food. Both the appetizers and pizza was good, drinks were fairly good too. The staff is friendly but very slow service. The crust is definitely burnt, to the point where we thought they burnt it too much. With the idea of deep-dish and adding some veggies with burnt crust, it kinda felt as though it was too runny/oily so most folks didn't really like the pizza, but on the other hand, I thought it was good, except tasting burnt parts on occasion.

Good pizza! We got a medium pan pizza. Very filling obviously with good flavors. Delivery took about an hour and 20 min but they told us that right away and asked if it was ok so I appreciated that.

It was good deep dish, the caramelized crust was pretty good. Little burnt but it was our first time getting this pizza so maybe that's how it always is?

We liked it. Might try and eat there next time I don't know if delivery did it justice but even the delivery guy was really nice so I can even say they have good service haha.

pics.caption: Medium pan pizza with spinach, garlic and sausage.

review.des: Okay, I am generally just not a fan of deep dish pizza but after checking out some reviews, it sounded like this needed to be a must do. It was pretty tasty! Great ratio of cheese/sauce/dough -- even for that doughy deep dish, haha. Going off hours (e.g. the bar on Saturday afternoon) may be your best bet to avoid the line.

Being a thin crust girl myself, I only do deep dish / pan when I have visitors in town wanting to do classic Chicago.  Pequods was one I had been wanting to try so I went on their website and was able to put my name in 24 hrs in advance (apparently this is suppose to allow you to jump the line). Showed up on time and it's a 2 hour wait- same that was quoted to the party behind us as well... Ordered a salad and a medium pan pizza- way too big for the three of us, took about half of it home.  The crust was good, the sauce could have used a little more flavor...

pics.caption: Medium pan with beef, onions, mushrooms

review.des: Not exactly the best deep dish pizza in town. However, the sauce was probably the best part of eating this extra doughy pie. Sorry but I would rather order some Domino's pizza.

We stopped in for pizza having been told this is one of the best in Chicago for deep dish and they weren't wrong. However, in trying it for the first time, I don't think my husband and I are a fan of the pizza style itself. The service was wonderful, pizza arrived quicker than what we were told to expect, and the environment was great. I just wasn't a fan of the sauce and my husband didn't like the crunch of the bottom crust. Great pizza, just not our preferred way to eat it. We'd probably go back, just to try the thin crust version!

I live in San Antonio and wanted some Chicago deep dish pizza! One morning hopped a plane and took the "L" toward downtown. I was told by a former resident of Chicago to try this place! Walked around 1130 just in time for the $4.99 lunch special. Which was a personal pizza and a drink! Long story short the pizza was amazing I recommend getting sausage on it! Pairs perfect with the local beers. Took one to go back to Texas. Got back home the same day and went to bed with a full belly! I'll be back for another day trip Chicago! Worth it!!!!!

First time having pizza in Chicago and my friend suggested here over all the places in downtown where i was staying. There was a wait for parties of 2+ but we were seated right away at a 2 top. Place isn't too big and is kind of dark like a pub. They said about an hour for the pizza so we ordered wings in the meantime. They were actually really good and I'm picky with wings. They were big and crispy and not too spicy or saucy. The pizza didn't really take an hour i don't think. Im not  huge sauce fan so I'm glad i tried this pizza rather than the 'traditional Chicago style deep dish' that has all the sauce on the top. It wasn't too heavy and doughy. Could've had a tad more cheese but the caramelized crust totally made up for it. The bill wasn't too bad for a medium pie, wings and two drinks, but we did only got one topping. Came to $40. Only thing that could've been better was the service. I mean our waitress was training someone and it  was busy so she was dealing with a lot. I just could've used a refill :)

This is my favorite deepdish in the city. Their caramelized crust is the bomb, and they have a killer lunch special during the week. They are a little pricier and the waits are longer at night, so that is the only reason for the four stars. Awesome pizza though, and great appetizers too.

Just received my delivery...absolutely yuck. Thin Crust Basil, Tomatoe & Garlic was undercooked, had no basil & too garlicky (& I looove garlic). Thin Crust Half Pepperoni & Half Sausage was a thick crust, burnt & all pepperoni & all sausage. Neither pizza had any taste. Appetizer Sampler was inedible. Will never ever eat Pequod's again.

In my opinion, this is the go-to deep dish pizza place in Chicago. The cheese baked into the crust is what sets it apart, giving the pizza an extra little something. And surprisingly it's light enough that you can get three slices and not feel stuffed. Or maybe that's just me.

pics.caption: A large pan pizza with half mushroom, half sausage

review.des: Wow, that is an excellent pizza. Believe the hype folks.  We ordered a meatball and gardinera pan and it was delicious.  No wait, on a Saturday afternoon.  Wife says we'll be back to try the thin crust too.

pics.caption: Beautiful hot gardinera and meatball pizza.

review.des:
Great pizza. The appetizers are horrible especially the bruschetta, but the pizza is to die for. I really liked the grungy vibes of this place, and all the
AC/DC & Led Zeppelin playing. We got a deep dish with pepperoni and that was the way to go. It was recommended that we don't load the pizza with too many toppings.  It was two of us and we both can eat a lot, and the small size pizza was plenty. If you love deep dish pizza, this is a must try.

A++. Warning: can get crowded. They handle it well, but there's only so much they can do. We waited 1.25 hours on a holiday weekend night to sit, and once we did, people were waiting 2 hours or more. So, come on an odd hour, or a non-busy night. Otherwise, do like we did: bring a good book, sit on a bench outside (or order a drink at the bar next door), and wait. It's worth it.

Thin crust pizza had fresh ingredients! The jalapeños and olives were so good. I like the flaky thin crust. Tastes almost like a thin croissant. The small was perfect for two people.
Pizza took a while but I guess you gotta wait for quality food. Iced tea tasted watered down but I didn't give them a chance to fix it so can't dock them too much for that. Manager was attentive and was there to get things done!

I've never had an issue with the wait, and it's right across from the Barnes and Noble I frequent and Wegster theater. I think the longest I've ever waited was fifteen minutes despite everyone always saying it's a long wait (lucky timing, mayhaps?).

I got the sampler platter once which was "meh", but what you're really there for is the pizza, I imagine.

I've had the pineapple and ham, the sausage and mushrooms (and I usually hate mushrooms) and a few other combinations and always have to force myself to stop eating so I don't puke from being so full.

The wait staff kind of leaves you alone unless you look like you need something (in a good way, I'm never glancing around for the waiter in desperation for a refill or something equally insane).

Personally I don't buy the "crisped" edge thing. It tastes burnt but hey, I eat the hell out of it. Everyone else likes that blackened crust (which they do on purpose, it's not a fluke or an excuse) thing but I could do without, personally.

But, I know I'm getting it when I order and I keep going back so I've gotta be a little bit of a hypocrite because Pequod's is one of my go-to's.

So Lou Malnati's is my spot for deep dish in the city but I was recently made aware that Pequod's was giving them a run for their money. On this latest adventure to Chicago I knew I had to give this spot a shot so as I landed at O'hare on a snowy Tuesday I placed an order for this pizza. I had a feeling the wait would be long and sure enough it was a 2 hour wait to get the pizza delivered. I made myself comfortable in the hotel and sure enough after the 2 hour wait, I received a ring to get the pizza. I had opted to go with the sausage, pepperoni, mushroom and jalapeno deal. The pizza itself was massive and of course as soon as I held the box it felt like a million pounds.

After a few bites into the pizza obviously the sauce was rich in flavor with the toppings adding tons of flavor making a great combination. They had the perfect sauce to topping ratio and man.... The CRUST be out of control. Yes the caramelized crust is really that good and worth the mention in itself. I was unable to finish the entire pizza but had to kill the crust of it all the way through. The sausage had a nice spice to it however my one item is that I like a bit more cheese to my pies... personal preference though. All this said leads to a solid deep dish pie but personally I still am partial to Lou's "sheet of sausage" and the way they pull their pies together. Still a solid joint and definitely worth a visit and my second favorite pizza joint in Chi Town.

My family and I visited weeks back and I'm just finding time to review. This pizza was iconic back in the day and I haven't visited in many years. Maybe it's unfair to compare to my memory but our last visit was mediocre at best. We ordered the cheesy garlic bread and it was warm, gooey and satisfying! We followed this with a pepperoni pan pizza which is their version in the deep dish pizza.  We all enjoyed it but feel eve crust was soggy and impossible to pick up and eat causing us to have to use fork and knife. This was fine for me and the hubby but the kids had a difficult time and made a mess. Service was a bit slow but it was a packed house.

Meh. I'm not sure why people like Pequod's that much. I have friends who rave about it, but it's just not what I'm looking for in a Chicago deep-dish pizza.

Pequod's has that sports bar feel that is great for grabbing a pitcher of beer and hanging out with friends. But if you're just going to eat pizza, the wait is ridiculously long and for pizza that's pretty bland if you compare with other Chicago favorites (regardless of how touristy or franchise they may be). When we first sat down, we were told a 30 min wait, which is totally reasonable. By the time we ordered, the wait got bumped up to 50 min, and this was around 2pm. They should really invest in more ovens or something, because even as a business, having people just sit for 50 min waiting for food means less turn around with your customers. Anyways, as we were waiting, we figured we might as well order some appetizers. We got a mixed platter with jalapeno poppers and fried mushrooms etc. They were over-fried.

The pizza itself, when it finally came, was ¾ crust and barely any sauce or cheese or toppings. When I eat Chicago deep-dish, I expect to get a decent crust topped with a thick layer of sauce and cheese. They also put the topping on top of the cheese, which threw me off a bit. It was good if it was supposed to be cheesy bread or something, but it was lackluster as a deep dish pizza. The atmosphere might be a bit more laid back and a customer base of more college students or Chicagoans, but I'd still take Lou Malnati's or Giordano's.  

I will give them this though, they have a pretty good lunch deal if you're not looking to share.
This is without a doubt the best pizza in Chicago! they do a great job handling how busy they always are too, expect to wait a little but, but 100% worth it
I came here on my off day for the lunch special. The staff was super friendly and attentive. The pizza was super delicious as always! My favorite thick pizza in the city by far.

My favorite pizza in Chicago! As a Chicagoan, born and raised, this place is the best in town! They only have 2 locations (one city and one burbs), making it even more desirable. The fact that they are exclusive to Chicago is what I love about this place!

The Chicago location is a bit cozy so try to keep your party under 4. Otherwise getting a table is going to be 1. Very Hard! Like... incredibly, super duper hard!   2. You'll get to know your friend really really well.  The seats are kind of tight too, so hang your winter coats at the hallway coat hangers.  It'll save up the space for the very cozy booth seat for 4.

Get the sausage pizza cause that's the best!  Their sausage is seasoned differently.  It's a little sweet, with a touch of anise.  And the crust of this pizza is the best!  The cheese is caramelized within the crust!  Unlike any other Chicago Pizza, the crust is thinner and chewier.  It's not too fluffy and not over dough-y.  The balance between crust, cheese, and filling is perfect!

It's an o.k. spot for pizza. It's not the best deep dish pizza in the city. but it's also not the worst. It's an alright spot. It's comfortable, casual, and affordable. I would go again and I would recommend it to friends too. It's a good place to drop in after seeing something at Steppenwolf theater, or after Spamilton at the Royal George Theatre like I did.

I really liked the deep dish here! The pizza was soft and moist but the crust was still nice and crisp! It was worth the wait! I think their pizza is a good size and can definitely serve up to 4 people. Definitely check this place out if you're in Chicago!

I've loved Pequod's ever since I was little and my mom would bring home a pizza after work from their suburban location.  Now that I live close to Lincoln Park I try to go here every once in a while.  I won't get into an argument about the best deep dish in Chicago but just know that no discussion is complete without someone mentioning Pequod's.

The place gets crowded so last time I was strategic and arrived just as the Hawks game was finishing.  This was perfect as everyone was leaving and tables were opening up left and right.  We opted to sit at the bar.  We were told the pizza would take like 40 minutes so we ordered mozzarella sticks.  The pizza came out about 20 minutes later so I was pretty bummed we ordered an app, which I wouldn't have done had I known the pizza would be out soon.  I guess that's a good upselling technique on their part but I didn't have enough room for delicious pizza.  Tell your rumbling tummy to shut up (or hold it over with beer) and wait for the pizza.  They also have a really good salad, if you're into that kind of thing.

This was a recommend by one of our friends that used to live in Chicago and I'm glad she told us about it as we wouldn't have otherwise checked it out.  Best deep dish we had in Chicago hands down!  The caramelized crust alone should win awards.  We came early so there weren't many people when we arrived but there was a line when we left so get there early.

I'd come back to Chicago just to have another pizza from here.

The pan pizza is a staple and the thin crust isn't too far behind.

The dining service has always been so-so (My party invested 3 hours one time due to waitstaff errors).

Overall a great place.

Listen here, you must understand that this is a super busy and popular pizza joint that cooks deep dish pizzas (longer cook time) and you should proceed with caution and patience. This place is in no way a fine dining establishment so if you are looking for a wine list, a cloth napkin, and a server to be kissing your hand and feet as you enter, then this is not the place for you. This is a fun, busy, crowded and loud sports bar.

The pan pizza is delicious, the apps are great, and there are a million TV's. It's so easy to see snotty and impatient customers around you not understanding why the pizza is taking so long? Or complaining about no wine list? Or that it's too loud, or too hot, or too crowded, or blah blah blah! Come on, take it as it is, have fun and enjoy the experience!

Pequods will always have a place in my heart! Also, GO BLACKHAWKS!
I really like the pizza have had it at the restaurant and take out. Good customer service good pizza. Couldn't ask for more.

The fam and I tried this fine pizza establishment while visiting in April. The pizza crust was thick and flavorful with a cheesy crunch. We (five of us) ordered a large and could not finish our pizza. They have a bunch of flat screen TV's on the walls so this would be a great place to have drinks, and food and enjoy a game.

Our waitress was friendly and quick and we enjoyed our meal here.

Pequods pizza was a bit disappointing, I'm already not a fan of deep dish pizza (New York Pizza all day e'ry day) but when in Rome...
Pequods supposedly has an amazing crust, I must disagree, my crust had a doughy consistency (like not completely cooked, but come on, you made me wait 40 minutes for it...) the toppings were stingy and I paid for a premium topping (meatball) and barely got any.  The pizza seemed under seasoned and just was pretty meh.  The meatball I must say was tasty, it wasn't tough and and a decent flavor on its own but not enough to carry the pizza
Service wasn't terrible but wasn't amazing either...

Hands down the best deep dish/ pan pizza in the city. Been here 4-5 times and every time I leave craving more pizza but so stuffed. Decent selection of local beers as well. Come here early or on a week night because there will almost always be a wait and if you call for delivery and phone is busy, they are open but will not take your order because they are so busy.

Would give this place  10 stars if I could.

Oh Pequod's, you frustrate me so much....

This is definitely my favorite deep dish pizza in chicago.  The sauce/cheese ratio is exactly what i'm looking for and the caramelized crust is incredible.  However, I have had a few experiences with bad service.  If you want to have the best experience here, get take out or sit at the bar.

My last pequod's experience was ordering delivery:  I was told the delivery would take an hour and a half, which is standard for pequod's since their pizza takes a while to make.  After 2 hours, i tried to call to check on my delivery, no answer.  After another half hour, I gave up on the expectation of getting my pizza at all.  The next day i emailed them to request a refund to my credit card, which was done a few days later.  But no response to my email, no apology,  or anything at all.

I am generally pretty patient: if I received a call the night of the delivery saying "hey, something happened with our driver, we have to cancel your order"  then i would have been disappointed, but understanding.  What bothers me is the lack of communication, and wasting of my time.  If you can't handle deliveries, don't offer delivery.

It's frickin' good pizza.  I thought nothing could beat Lou Malnati's but I was wrong.  A co-worker suggested I try this spot and the pizza didn't disappoint.  I ordered one with extra cheese, basil, and sausage.  That frickin' sausage was to die for.  And the burnt crust at the end was really good.  I'm sorry I wasn't able to take a pic of it since my phone died.  

We each at a slice and was so full we packed it and decided to give to a homeless person.  Was happy someone could make a meal out of it.

Came in a bit after midnight right after the Cubbies took game 1 of the NLCS - surprised that we did not have a wait. We were immediately seated and placed our order shortly thereafter. While it does take a bit of time to get your order out (I think anticipation makes the wait seem longer than it actually is) it was absolutely worth the wait!

Can't wait to get back to Chicago soon and this will definitely be a place I would head back to everytime for deep dish.

Yummy in my tummy!

I have been coming here for take out for about a year now and I love it!

I usually order the same thing every time which is the deep dish pepperoni pizza with extra sauce! The sauce they use is rich, seasoned right and just plain delicious, so that's why I say extra sauce!!!

The caramelized onion crust is what makes these pizza's perfect!

The most recent visit was unforgettable! I ordered a pizza for pick up and I arrived early. So, I told the hostess I will be waiting in my car and I will come back in 10 minutes. As I was waiting she knocks on my car window to deliver me my pizza! Now that is worth 5 stars!!

If you are looking for somewhere different for deep dish that isn't Lou or Gino east.. Come to the north side of Chicago and experience a different style of pizza with outstanding service.

They are getting 2 stars because I know how great their pizza can be...

Unfortunately, I didn't even have the chance to eat here the other night:

I made a reservation last week with a very friendly hostess over the phone - and all was great, and I was looking forward to taking my family that was visiting from out of town.

We showed up at 6pm on a Sunday (our reservation time). One of the FIVE... yes FIVE hostesses standing there told me it would be atleast another 45 minutes. They then went on to tell me that they don't take reservations. WHAT?!? They tried explaining that 'I was jumping the wait-list with my called-in reservation from the week before'. (which by the way, if this is a 'thing'- this arrangement was never brought to our attention over the phone and we thought we were making a NORMAL reservation)

That night, we ate at Giordanos and it was wonderful.

Pequod's has definitely lost me as a patron with their poor customer service, ridiculousness to reservations/no reservations, and for having 5 hostesses (go bus a table and help out your fellow servers!)

Different kind of pizza. Two locations. Both divey and downscale. Fun, good pizza.
Nothing bad here.

After a full day of drinking, walking, shopping, and doing touristy things, I was delirious by the time we arrived here for dinner so I can't accurately comment on anything prior to the food, but hey that's all that matters.

From what I -do- remember, ambiance was nice (I felt cozy, and cozy is always a good thing for me), service was very friendly. The only poopoo was that our appetizer was forgotten until after our pizza came, but it was comp'd so I can't say shat.

Will not beat a dead horse and rave about how DELICIOUSSS the pie was (burnt. crust. ohmygahd), except to say that pizza is forever ruined for me. Perhaps I'm biased because this is probably the only real pizza I've had, but for now I truly mean it. Would find any excuse to visit Chicago just so I can come back.

We tried two deep dish places, Pequod's and Giordano's. We were a little disappointed by Giordano's, but Pequod's more than made up for it. They are totally two different pizzas. Giordano's is a layered pizza like a lasagna. Pequod's is like a traditional pizza with a thick crust. We tried the pepperoni and it was delicious! The caramelized crust is amazing.

They also had an alcoholic root beer, which tasted exactly like root beer.

The atmosphere was chill and didn't feel touristy like Giordano's.

This is the Chicago deep dish to try.
I prefer Pequod's over Lou's. The one thing I will say is that eating it there out of the pan is much better than getting delivery or take out!

I'm not a big fan of deep dish, but I liked this spot! You can get individual sized pizza and they have lots of different toppings. Also loved the vibe of the place and they had lots of craft beer on draft to choose from! If you are having a hard time picking a deep dish Chicago style spot, this is the place to go!

pics.caption: Garlic and basil individual sized deep dish with beer.

review.des:
The wait to even get the pizza was very ridiculous. It took 2 hours for pick up. I expected a lot more from their pizza since the wait was so long, but unfortunately I was disappointed.
Maybe it's because I'm not a fan of really thick crusted pizza? So maybe I'm a little bias.
But this pizza was just way too doughey for me. The flavor of the pizza was also okay. I've read a lot of reviews saying we should add extra sauce and extra cheese, but that was probably the worst decision to be made. Too much sauce and cheese and not enough meat. The ingredients were definitely fresh though. I give them that.

This is one of the best pizza places I've been to! The food is amazing and the service is pretty fast for a deep dish pizza place. I ordered the cheese fries and an Italian beef pizza. The fries were delicious pizza was surprisingly super great. This place is so underrated.
The Italian beef and sausage sub was just incredible. The deep dish was great too - kids loved it, but I'm a thin crust guy. Great ingredients, service, and atmosphere. A must for a Chicago visit.

I went to Pequod's for the first time about a month ago. The pizza was not for me but people love it. The cheese to bread ratio is very uneven. There is so much bread and it is kind of dry. The one thing i did like was they make great homemade ranch. If you like a very "bready" pizza then this is the place for you.

Been coming here for years and despite the lack of parking and the long wait times, we keep coming back because the pizza is just that good!  This place is well run and employees are well trained by the manager who is a fixture here!  He runs a tight ship and leads by being a hands on perfectionist in an environment that could easily be chaotic and unmanageable!  Kudos to him.

1970's Chicago deep dish pizza in a 1980's atmosphere.    I remember places like this when I was a child growing up in Chicago.   Pequod's is one of the only deep dish pizza joints remaining that I consider to be authentic.

PROS:
1.   Possibly the very best example of classic Chicago deep dish pizza, evoking memories of my childhood 40 years ago.
2.   It's delicious!
3.   The menu is everything you'd expect.   It's almost as if a committee got together and spent a year coming up with the most prototypical pizza joint menu.    

CONS:
1.  Success hasn't ruined this place, but it sure is crowded.    If you are a bigger group and plan ahead, you can sometimes get your name in for a big table.    But if there is just two of you, expect a very long wait, and to get stuck in a claustrophobic table if you are unlucky.  
2.   The location is really only good if you live in the area, or are visiting nearby Webster Place.    Nothing convenient about Clybourn Avenue.   (The good pizza is worth it though!)

Visit this place during an off-peak time, and take a cheese-filled trip back to the Chicago of the Richard J. Daley era.    If you grew up here, you may find a bit of yourself in this place.

My party ordered a salad, cheese bread, large deep dish meat and small deep dish veggie. Also a pitcher of beer.

I loved the sauce and meat, as well as the cheesy bread we got. The dipping sauce that came with the cheese bread was almost drinkable it was so good.

However, the crust reminded me of Pizza Hut, thick and greasy. I had never had Chicago deep dish pizza but heard all the hype. Was not impressed.

Our appetizer cheese bread came out after our pizzas which was already an hour wait. I was sat in this corner under a neon light that felt at least 10 degrees warmer than the rest of the restaurant.

Also, our waitress never once offered to refill drinks nor get us a round of waters. The staff "uniforms" were confusing since everyone wears a different color shirt. It was tough to figure out who worked here.

Overall, I'd eat it for delivery, but probably not come back in.

Just what you ever dreamed of for deep dish pizza. I had this delivered during my first try and was a bit disappointed but decided it was worth another shot. Have been to the restaurant twice now and am obsessed. I have ordered pepperoni and pepperoni/mushroom and both were phenomenal. A small is definitely big enough for two. Definitely call before OR order an appetizer because the pizzas take a bit to bake.

Skip Lou's and Giordano's which is basically just a chain now and head to Pequods. You really won't be disappointed.

After hearing all of the hype about Peaqud's, I was in the area last weekend and decided to give it a try.  I ordered a pan pizza with sausage and mushrooms.  I do like the crust very much, however the sauce and toppings were a disappointment.  Also be aware that although the crust is very good when the pizza is fresh, it doesn't taste the same when reheated.

Had my daughter's first birthday party here the other week. We had 30 adults and 10 kids. Party was upstairs in the private room in back which has a number of booths. Reserving the space was easy, just did it online and also got an email from Sean. I had a ton of questions and he replied quickly.

We decided to order off the menu. We ordered baked mostaccioli with marinara sauce, pitches of soda and 12 pizzas. Ordered both the thin and the pan. All different kinds of toppings. Food came out when we requested it, service was great. Janet was the main server and she was so nice and attentive. Everyone loved the food and it was a good time. For the amount of food we ordered and the number of guests, the cost wasn't bad at all and food really did taste great. Thin was crispy, pan was nice and cheesy and had a nice caramelized crust!

It's nice that the room doesn't have an amount of time you can have it for. We set up at 11am, party started at 1230. Food was out like I requested at 1pm and the party was over around 3:30 and we got our stuff together and left by 4. The room has 2 tvs so the guys were able to watch games. I would have a party here again, too bad there wasn't more parking in the area, but it's the city!

pics.caption: Pan and think crust pizza. Crispy and tasty!

review.des: This is Chicago's BEST deep dish pizza. Period. I've lived here for 28 years and nothing comes close. Definitely worth the often very long wait.

Be. Prepared. To. Wait. (no matter the hour)
Good deep dish, not the greatest in Chicago.  Dough is a bit bland as is the sauce.  Make sure you add lots of yummy toppings to make the pizza worthwhile.  Would I eat here again? Yes.  Would I choose this pizza over another place? No.

Definitely an upgrade from Giordanos which I've been told no self-respecting Chicagoan would find himself or herself eating at (whoops for me).

It was still the 45 minute wait for food, but the pizza quality was definitely noticeably better. The staff and service were great and the happy hour seems like an awesome nice touch. I can't really comment on the pizza other than it was tasty and better than the last Chicago pizza joint I was at.

Space can be tight so coming at off hours can definitely help get you a table faster. You might also have to get creative with where you park (farther from the restaurant) iif you're an outta towner like me.
This is the best pizza around!  Beyond good!  Order the deep dish and you'll smile with every single bite!!!

Great place, great food, today unfortunately the service did not meet up to par. Waitress/server Never gave her name and just seemed to be in a rush. Our order was taken and she made sure we always had drinks but a bit friendlier would've worked too. When you get charged for a slice of cake for a birthday girl, you know this ain't the place to celebrate in the future.

Well.  This is my second time here.  First with the wife and now with the boys.  I love the deep dish.  What a relaxed place and good environment.  Pizza takes 50 min.  But if you relax and have good people to chat with, it's all good.

Excellent example of Chicago deep dish. Decent zucchini fries too. Great beer selection. Fun servers. If I have a complaint it is that it feels
Like it takes forever to get that pie you were dying for a half hour ago.

Overrated. Maybe it was because I got a to go order though.

Had to wait 30 mins at the store after their quoted pick up time.

They then forgot my appetizer combo and had to make it "fresh".
But when I got home everything was super soggy and luke warm.

Will try again but eat in store this time.
First time in Chicago and everyone told us to come here. Expected more from this place but a lot of people love it.

This is my first review of Pequod's after two visits. This place is way up there in the Chicago deep dish hierarchy, and it is well deserved!

First tip, this place gets really busy on the weekends. Time for a pizza can be 45-60 mins, even much later on in the evening. But it's worth it! The first time I went I got green pepper, sausage and pepperoni. It was delicious! The crust is really unique at Pequod's and the meat was SO good in this pizza. The second time I got just sausage, which I didn't like as well. I recommend getting multiple toppings, it just adds more flavor.

This is a must visit place in Chicago. The pizza is outstanding and the building itself has a lot of character. I will definitely be going back again and again.

Since moving out from Chicago, the two things I miss the most are Portillos and Pequods.

Nothing else compares to the crust and sausage you get here.
My personal favorite deep dish in Chicago.

The BEST deep dish Chi city has to offer.  

I had to go gluten-free due to some health issues and losing this pains me the most. Sometimes I think the fatigue, bloating, and atomic farts might be worth cheating for!
Mediocre  pie . Tonight has an hour wait, maybe 3 dozen people waiting outside and 13 (13!) Booths with No one  seated at them.  Room for about 65.... fail.

Pizza was marginal and service was average at best. Heard a lot of good things about this place from the locals,
but it definitely didn't live up to the hype. One and done for me.

Last week was my first time eating deep dish pizza. There were so many options of pizza in Chicago. After reading so many reviews on whether it was better to eat at the tourist chain restaurants or driving out to Pequod's, we decided to listen to the locals.  We went on a Monday night and even though they didn't seem too busy we still had to wait a while to be sat. Keep in mind your pizza will take an additional hour to make after you have put your order in. I was with a group of 5 and we ordered the mozzarella sticks and the garlic cheese bread. The mozzarella sticks were nothing specials but the garlic cheese bread was so good and got us even more excited about the pizza we ordered.  Our pizza definitely did not disappoint! We were so stuffed. We ordered two large pizzas and we were not able to finish one!
We did not get a chance to visit Giordanos or Lou malnati's, so I can't compare the pizza to theirs but we were definitely happy with our experience at Pequod's.
I did take a star off for service, our waiter was very snappy. Took too long checking in on us and bringing us our drinks.

Ok i read so many great things about this place, was gonna go to Berts but didnt want to travel the extra distance, considering he started Pequads I figured it would be close. Well this one going down in institutional longevity, which means they been around so long they sucked the locals into thinking they were good. Tasted like a flavorless piece of Italian bread with spaghetti sauce on it, and some burnt cheese on edge of crust. Disappointing. Lous kills you by miles.
The best pizza in Chicago. Worth the wait as the caramelized crust is to die for! We went at 11 AM Saturday morning and it was dead.
The crust has the consistency of a fluffy biscuit + caramelized, the tomato sauce is light and sweet (not salty) makes for an incredible deep dish pizza, not as cheesy and saucy as the others.

I guess I'll be generous and give this place 4 stars instead of 3.  I rate it at 3.5  The pizza came out relatively quickly, or at least it seemed like it.  I wasn't a huge fan of the crust, but the top outside edge where the cheese carmelized was pretty tasty.

I still love the deep dish pizza from home (Zachary's and Little Star in Berkeley) I always compare deep dish to them and they are still the best in my opinion.

I was in Chicago for a 5 day trip and wanted to try out some of the best rated and highly recommended pizza places.

I liked Lou Malnati's better than this place, but this was still a good option.

The service was good.

Sorry for the boring review...

I heard good things about this place. So we decided to order take out. We had 9 pickup orders, mostly personal pans and one was incorrect. I feel that you'd have to eat there for the full experience, but the lady through the phone order was quite short with me. The pizza was alright overall, but service was only satisfactory. Parking is abysmal in this area.
I don't like deep dish pizza but this is definitely the tastiest I've had and, oh man, that crust! But we had a rather unfriendly waitress when we went so I have to subtract a star

I stopped here for lunch with a friend. The pizza was good and the price was right. I also like that it's BYOB! I ordered the lunch special, they make it fresh so it takes a little while but it is hot and delicious. I will be stopping again, Check it out if your in the area.

Hate to be hard on a small business, but this is NOT Chicago-style deep dish pizza. The "deep dish" option was just a thicker crust. I mean this pizza was so bad I took the time to take a picture and warn my Chicago friends. Would I be mad if I bought this for $10? No. But I paid a lot more than $10. Save yourself the time and money and get a gas station za instead.

pics.caption: All bread and no topping... This "deep dish" was a lie

review.des: Great pizza good environment, awesome beer. The waitress was nice, also the wait is a bit long but well worth it.

Maybe it's the crust... Maybe it's the insides of pure gooey heaven
maybe it's that I can put whatever the fuck I want inside (haha) what am I describing here?!
A GOOD DAMN PIZZA
I love deepdish. I know Giordano's is supposed to be the best or even Lou mal- but I really never like their deepdish the way I love Pequod's. They are good until you come here. And than a little light in your head turns on. And you realized you were settling for less!

They have Chicago beer and Chicago pizza. And they keep this city girl happy :)

Dear Pequod's,

You are the sand to my beach, the peanut butter to my jelly, the wind beneath my wings. No but for real. Today was a great experience of many at this wondrous pizzeria.

Although we waited almost thirty unbearable minutes to get seated, it was all worth it. Emily, our server, made us laugh! And not like, AT her. WITH HER. She was timely, well informed, and helpful. Our nervous, yet very cool busboy, James, was fantastic! It was his first day on the job, but he even remembered my boyfriend's request for blue cheese when I had forgotten.

The appetizers came at just the right time and temperature. Our beers were brought cold and filled to the brim. The pizza was perfect! Caramelized crust, melty cheesy goodness, filled with the right amount of pepperoni and spinach. Just the way I like it!

Pequod's is hands down the best place to bring a newbie for some Chicago style pizza. The atmosphere is great for every kind of person. Not too sporty, not too hipster, and not too yuppie. I recommend to all!

I went here on a pizza tour a year ago and thought it was fantastic so I was really excited to come back. I felt really let down today. Waited an hour for a table.  Once we sat down and placed our order we knew it would be about another hour so we got their garlic cheesy bread,  it's worse than the frozen stuff from the grocery store. It was rock hard and was only made edible because of the sauce we got with it. When our pizza came it was obviously overdone. The bottom layer of crust was black.  Even if I peeled off the burnt parts it was still dry and lacked flavor. Just utterly disappointing after a 2 hour wait.

As a Chicagoan, I'm embarrassed to admit that I just had my very first Pequod's experience last weekend. I can't believe I've been missing out on this much goodness for this long!

Pequod's is a jam-packed pizza place, and for good reason! Their pizza is the ooey-gooeyist of all the Chicago style pizzas. Their famous carmelized crust is just as good as everyone says it will be, and their tomato sauce is hearty and flavorful!

If you come to this location in the City, be prepared to wait! They do not take reservations but do have a priority list, which cuts down the wait time. We came in on a Sunday evening and waited about 40 minutes for a table, and again about 45 minutes for the pizza to come out. While the atmosphere is definitely divey, and while the place is jam-packed, it's worth it to experience the greatest of the Chicago deep dish options.

Friendly greeting upon arrival, got there early enough that the wait time was only 15 minutes. Started with the cheese sticks, they were good and served their purpose, take the edge off while waiting for our pizza. Ordered a deep dish with sausage, onion and green pepper. It was very good, but it could have used more cheese. Overall it's a great pizza with a unique flavor.
Always good!   A must try!! The best Carmelized pizza crust!  And if you can order ahead pizzas take at least 45 minutes.. But so worth it

This pizza is delicious. Gooey, cheesy, perfect. The tomato sauce is sweet and bright, and the crust is buttery beyond belief. We added garlic, mushrooms, and spinach to the pizza, and split between four people (and still had leftovers!)

We ordered a salad as an app, and the cheese came shaped like a whale (in honor of the restaurant's namesake). So cute!!

It's seriously just a pan pizza. It's not amazing or anything special. I feel bad saying something bad about a restaurant. It's good pizza but I don't think it was worth the price... I like flavorful foods and unique food. I had to put salt on my pizza. If your ever thinking "man I want some decent pizza" this is the place for you! It's alright nothing spectacular or anything to rave about.
Not a huge deep dish fan, but if you like deep dish, this is the creme de la creme

Not much more to add besides I loved the pizza. Personal size is the right amount for one hungry person. Also, well priced for the quality you get. About $10 for a personal size with two toppings. The caramelized edges are the cherry on top of a fine pizza.

Hype. I really wanted to like it because people rave about it, but its just not good.
First of all. This is not deep dish pizza. Its pan pizza. So if you're expecting a pizza like Lou's or Giordano's, go there, because this is not the deep dish you know and love.
Pequod's pizza is more like a focaccia bread, very doughy, with a little bit of sauce and toppings and a hint of cheese. If you cut it in half it would probably make great sandwich bread.
What toppings there are, are very fresh and of good quality.
The best part of the pizza is the burnt cheese on the crust. Burnt cheese crust really shouldn't be the highlight of your deep dish pizza though.
The wait is usually long and even if you place your order ahead of time, you'll likely be waiting anyway. Its like they're doing you a favor serving you bread with some sauce on it.
Skip Pequod's and Burt's Place for that matter and go anywhere else for pizza.

This place used to be great but they have been overwhelmed and have not figured out how to deal with the volume.  I ordered a pizza at 5:30 on a Saturday night and was told it would be 1:20.  I showed up at 6:50 and waited for an hour, asking three times if there was an update on my order and getting no answer, before I got two pizzas that had obviously been sitting in the warmer for quite some time.  Very disappointing.

So Lou Malnati's was my favorite deep dish pizza place in Chicago.... I thought no other deep dish could compete.... I WAS WRONG.

Pequods.... wow.  I really don't know what else to say that hasn't already been said about their amazing pizza.  The sauce... the fresh toppings... that crust!!!

I will happily drive from the suburbs to carryout from here.  I suggest you all do the same !
Great thin crust pizza!!!! Definitely worth a visit!!!

I first saw of this place on man vs food and thought I have to try this place. I am glad I did!! This place can get packed but luckily my husband and I beat the lunch rush on a Saturday and got a table quickly. Our server told us their pizzas take about 45 minutes so we put our order in and started with mozzarella sticks. They were pretty average. Our pizza finally arrives and on my goodness, DELICIOUS! The pizza is definitely worth the wait. It is so thick and the dough has a sort of sweet flavor to it which is amazing. My only complaint is our server was beyond rude. We asked for clean plates after our appetizers and that really pissed her off. So much so I saw and heard her complaining about us to the bartender. She didn't ask how our food was during our meal but sure did perk up when it was time to drop the check. Other than her nasty attitude, the place is great. We will definitely be back our next trip to Chicago.

What a gem! I love the vibe in Pequods, the staff, & the food. Normally I am not a fan of their pizzas, but I do find that their pasta is AMAZING!! I love how this Chicago pizza place separates themselves from the others. It's definitely worth a stop!!

Good, fast service, except the pizza was not as good.

Extra greasy. The crust and cheese were tasteless, but the pepperoni was alright.
Two slices of good pizza are worth $10, but not this pizza

Use to always buy from here, it was one of our favorite places for pizza. Thank God it's not our only place we like to order from. Ordered our normal double pepperoni pizza, extra pizza sauce, extra cooked. Gave my name, exact address including my apartment number and then proceeded to wait for our pizza to be delivered. We waited and waited but our pizza never came. We finally fell asleep a little after 1:00 a.m. Woke up the next morning and had two missed calls from Peqoud's, one at 1:23am and another at 1:30am. I called in my order at 11:48pm. So I called Peqoud's again tonight to explain that we paid for our pizza but never even got a knock on the door, despite me giving them my apartment number(we have a door man to let them into the lobby by the way so no excuse for not coming to our apartment.) The nice lady who answered the phone explained the situation to the manager on duty tonight(Friday night on August 4, 2017) and informed me that the manager said they tried to call twice but I never picked up the phone so they are not responsible for us not receiving the product that we already paid for. I am a professional in the hospitality industry and I am appalled at the response by the management at Pequod's. You expect your customers to not only pay you for a product, but then do the extra work of chasing you down to make sure they receive it? I apologize Pequod's, but I was never taught that this was the way a hospitality establishment was to conduct itself while I was majoring in Hospitality and Tourism Management at Purdue University. Maybe that's why we always rank in the top of the nation for our School of Hospitality and Tourism Management because we choose to educate our future industry leaders on proper etiquette in this industry. I don't want to insult another school by attempting to guess where you source your managers from, but they'd never make it past the first interview if it were my business. So, as happy as I would like to be to continue ordering from you, I will not be doing so for I have little tolerance for bad customer service. That includes not ordering from you for my employees when they work late as I have done the last two months.
Great Pizza, use lots of napkins, as it can get messy. Burnt cheese crust is a nice touch

We had waited over an hour for seating our group of 7... they do not take resv, walk in only.  The pizza pies were incredible!! The only thing was they had recommended 3 pies for our party and we only finished 2.  Trust me ... we tried! It was very cheesy and tasty!!

Left feeling a little underwhelmed unfortunately.  I love both Giordano's and lou's for deep dish so I wanted to try the other deep dish place I kept hearing rave reviews about.  Firstly, our buzzer never went off for our table so once we finally realized that people who had come in after us were being seated, we politely approached the host who then seated us right away.  Not a big deal and not the workers' faults at all but not the best start.  Mozz sticks as an appetizer were good but the pizza was just slightly disappointing.  It was a little dry on the bottom and I kinda wish we had gotten extra cheese on it as the sauce to cheese ratio wasn't great.  I would come back, but I think I'll stick to some other deep dish staples.

The best.

As a south sider, to give that distinction to a north side joint, and for pan pizza is a big deal.  But it's the best in the City of Chicago.  You won't find anything close.  Lou Malnati's has a crust that can be compared, but it surely doesn't top Pequods, not by a long shot.  I literally go out of my way to stop in here, and we try to visit only once in a while to preserve the sense of novelty and make it a treat.

Move over Lou Malnati's and Giordano's! This is the best pizza in Chicago, hands down. Technically it is considered "pan pizza", not deep dish, but that makes it all the more delicious! Imagine the Noble Roman's pan pizza you loved as a child, pumped up on steroids. That is Pequod's.

I am really picky when it comes to cheese/sauce/crust ratio on my pizza and many places like Giordano's are very heavy on the cheese and don't put enough sauce on the pie. Pequod's has the perfect ratio with a perfect amount of sauce so you don't have to order extra.

The sausage is packed full of delicious, fennel(ly?) flavor, but the real show stopper here is the crust. It's deliciously chewy and caramelized around the edges. The only downside to eating here is that the wait is often incredibly long, but it's definitely worth it.

For my first ever visit to Chicago, I knew I had to try the deep dish pizza. As a NY native, I am a die hard fan of the thin crust. But when in Chicago...

I had heard about the magnificence of Pequod's pies and came ready to eat (and wait). To our surprise, there were many seats available on a Sunday afternoon around 12:30pm! We got seated immediately and put in our order for a sausage pepperoni medium pie (6 slices for 3 people was more than enough).

My first bite into the slice was the best. It was loaded with sauce & cheese and man, that deep bottom crust was so good. The only thing I wasn't blown away by was the caramelized outer crust that receives a lot of hype. I preferred eating the actual pie instead.

I was impressed by myself that I was able to polish off 1.5 slices. Be careful trying to finish two; you may feel sick for a while. Otherwise, worth the visit and the future stomach aches!

Delicious crust on the outside, undercooked crust and veggies on the inside. I'm torn because the outside of the deep dish was so good (on the well done side with cornmeal), but the inside was meh. The yummy sauce was the tie-breaker, which is why Pequod's gets 4 stars instead of 3. That, and of the 3 Chicago style deep dish places I tried in my 3 day Chicago visit (yes, you read that correctly... I felt like a fatty for many moons after this visit).

The service was kind of slow (it seemed like a busy night), but tvs with bad movies made up for it  :)

Got take out, so I can't speak for inside of the restaurant. I had a friend visiting and he was on a mission to try different kinds of deep dish pizza. This place did not disappoint. The crust was sort of odd, more like bread, so if that's not your thing I wouldn't recommend their deep dish. We kept it pretty simple with giardiniera and sausage in one, with pepperoni and basil in the other. Very tasty!

If Pizza Snobs were celebrities I would be the Olsen Twins + the Kardashians.

Pequod's is really, really good pizza.  I would also label it as a Chicago "must try" given its uniqueness.   For those new to Pequod's I think its important to point out:

1) Their thick pizza is Pan, it is not Deep Dish.  Do not let anyone else tell you otherwise.  It is more of a Sicilian style thick crust pan.  
2) The thin crust should be avoided.  It's not bad, it's just as good as others in the Chicago thin crust scene, and the crust is fairly thick and dull.  They don't apply the same burned cheese, mouth drooling, method that is used on the thick.
3) The burnt cheese crust on the thick crust is awesome, and it just gives you that killer pizza "I am going to devour you" reaction aesthetically too.  Anyone who's had John's NYC will understand.
4) Sausage and meat quality overall is fantastic.  Huge chunks, be prepared.

I love pizza!! I went to this place about twice the first time I was very happy because we were able to get seated right away and the food didn't take too long to come out. The second time I came to this place there were less people and for some reason our food took forever to come out and they tried charging us for water. I'm never a person to really point things out like this but I found it very distrubing that we didn't get the best service that night. But other than that the pizza was great.

If you're looking for authentic Chicago deep dish style pizza then look no more.
Being a guy with eyes bigger than his stomach I believed the medium wouldn't cut it, boy was I wrong! After eating two huge slices my stomach couldn't budge anymore. It was either throw up in the restroom to make room for more or just settle for a to go box. The vomiting choice would be a win/lose. You win more room in your stomach, yet you lose the delicious beauty that you just scarfed down. Looks like you're in a picks huh?

I ended up taking half to go. I stayed at the Hyatt Regency, and the weird thing is they didn't have a microwave in the room. So I was forced to keep it inside the mini fridge and eat cold pizza when my digestive system passed through all the cheese and bread from the two slices before.

One downfall is this cold pizza was not satisfying. There is just too much bread that it just hardens up and doesn't taste like a normal cold slice of pizza. Other than that, I was more than satisfied with this place and I'm sure you wonderful Yelpers will be too!
Good luck with delivery here. Waited over two hours and was lied to about the pizza being on its way. Will NEVER order from this place again.

Best deep dish in Chicago.
If anyone is ever in from out of town this is my go to "Chicago pizza".
The pizza does take 45 minutes at least to bake, so plan ahead. BUT you won't be disappointed with the delicious, cheesy, crispy, crust.

Just writing this review is making me hungry for Pequod's
Wait time is always really long whether you're picking up or waiting to be seated. The pizza seems pretty average to below-average to me, not sure what the hype is all about.

I thought it was quite good! Prepare to wait because it will be a while. From the moment we put our names in, to when we left it was about 2 1/2 hours. But that is to be expected from one of the best deep dish places in Chicago (so stop complaining, people). The only downside I thought was there was much more bread than cheese and toppings. But it was still tasty nevertheless! I highly recommend it.
Whoever answers the phone for late night delivery is a total butthole. Cool customer service guys.
Where the locals go and for good reason. The crust is bomb. Worth the wait, but if you go on an off day. We got seated right away!

Three and a forty-five minutes. That's how long it took. We arrived at 5:15p on a Saturday and was told it would be an hour and a half wait. Took 2 hours and three times asking to get a seat. Then after we sat, took and hour and a forty-five minutes before we got the pizza. By the time we got the food, we didn't even want to eat it. It was good pizza, but not good enough to wait almost 4 hours.
Hands down my favorite pizza place in Chicago! Good brews, amazing caramelized crust and a fun environment! This is my go-to rec for people looking for the best in Chicago style cuisine. Period.

Probably one of my favorite pizzerias in Chicago.  Came here on a later afternoon on Sunday and got seated quickly (table for 2).  Ordered a draft bud light and the garlic cheesy bread to start.  The cheesy bread was delicious and toasty with a little burnt cheese on top with an amazing marinara dipping sauce.
For the pizza (now we're talking) we ordered a small (shareable between 2) deep dish topped with mushrooms and sausage. It was delicious with the perfect amount of burnt crust on the edges (known for that buttery and cheesy crust).  I think next time I might just order the pizza with just extra mushrooms.

This place is full of millennials who are in the business of waiting tables not to service tables but who think they deserve a tip for whatever service they choose to give. We were told by a fat waitress who looked like she got to eat for free that slices would be ready in 15 minutes and whole pizzas took 45 minutes. So we ordered a slice and a sandwich.  A couple got seated next to us but after 20 minutes of no service decided to go to the restaurant across the street. Then the waitress decides to come by saying, "Oh, you changed your mind?" We had to question why the order was taking so long after 35 minutes. We constantly had to flag this woman down to get refills. Then she was quick to drop off the check and say its seems you are in a hurry here is your check.  Then a minute later is asking if we need change. Why can't wait staff get it in there heads that it is, I will be right back with your change NOT will you be needing change? When they ask that i say yes i will be and then give them a lower or no tip at all.  Oh and the food was overpriced, charging extra on top of the already overprice sandwich for cheese $1.35 a slice and .80 for sweet peppers on a meatball sandwich priced at $7.45. Food presentation wasn't bad but did not taste as good as it looked.
Simply the best Chicago style pizza; not even close. You will walk out here with a belly full of bliss, delight and complete satisfaction. Wing are great, too.
Real good pizza!!!! Went to the one in the north suburbs since the wait for the one in the city was to long.. worth the drive.

Maybe because I'm not a local and don't know what it means to have a Chicago pizza but this place was just okay for me. In one week I tried 3 pizza places and this was 3rd on my list.

Pizza was fine, but didn't live up to the hype.

Really disappointed with my experience today. Ordered ONE pizza for delivery at 12:45. After two calls to the restaurant, the pizza finally arrived at 3:30pm, cold and stale tasting. The saying "pizza is like sex, even when it's bad it's good" couldn't be less true here. All this wait for less than sub par pizza. Will not be ordering here again.

This isn't pizza, sorry Chicagoans.

But for the casserole that this is, there's none better. Incredibly flavorful, delicious, perfectly cooked pie with great ingredients.

This is my favorite pizza joint. I can't say anything bad about this place. Everything is sooo perfect!! I never eat sausage but this sausage pizza is soooooo amazing. Even if we waited 1hr for a table, and then another 1 1/2 hr for the food. It was all worth it. It used to be a 6 stars in my eyes, now it's only a 5. Hopefully they will go back to being a 6. :-)

I was in Chicago. I needed to get pizza - the real stuff. And I had just come off one of those:
"last night - late night ....had to order what I could, what was open.. last ditch effort unspeakable thin crusts that actually arrived to brick cold and bleh."

Thats a review to come later - Save the better for first.

I did take out and called ahead from the train - I had to do a quick stop and grab on our way to the airport or I couldn't squeeze it in. I walked like miles off the train for this pizza and I don't go far out of my way (which at the time it seems like I was walking forever) but it was WORTH IT, amazing and the people were rocking.

1) I don't need to even comment first on the pizza - because let it speak for itself. I liked the atmosphere. Cute, on the corner - walked in - we were greeted right away with smiles and "What can we help you with!" Awesome! They were so gracious and kind - basically knew it was me! We were thirsty and they got us cups to go, accommodated us for our road walking journey with a speedy check out. I was so grateful. I wanted to stay!

2) Pizza smelled so good in that box. Good price too although I just got myself a small thick crust cheese (basic) but it was piping hot and I couldn't wait to get my hands on it. Rich and saucy. I was in heaven. I couldn't eat it all and that says miles for an appetite like mine. I was fortunate enough to pass it off to someone in passing that probably needed it more than me and they got to share in Pequod's Yumminess too.

Thanks for your "drive by" hospitality, delicious pizza, affordable pricing, cool venue and lifesaver when I needed my Chicago Style Pizza. I will be back!

When you enter the store, there is a large sign that essentially says that reservations aren't really reservations, but bump you up to front of waitlist when you arrive (I'm paraphrasing).

Unfortunately, they don't do a good job of communicating this prior to getting there.  My party as well as three others (including a bachelor party that was forced to find other food) experienced this.    We received a text message the morning of the "reservation" asking us to confirm the time and amount of people, but nowhere in that message did it convey the variable nature of the time.

Normally, not a problem, but if you have a larger party on a tighter schedule (ie bachelor party, or family with small kids), then waiting until 9:30 for an 8:00 PM "reservation" is less than ideal.    

Would suggest management improve the pre-reservation communication, both on the website as well as the text messages.

In terms of the food, overall quality was decent.  

For apps, we ordered the pizza bread, assorted appetizer platter, and pequod salad.  Filled you up, but nothing to write home about in terms of taste.

We ordered a thin crust cheese for the kids.   As a native New Yorker, I found the crust a little soggy, and the cheese a little excessive.  Sauce was excellent though.  Kids liked it, so that's all that matters.

We also ordered a pan pizza with spinach/garlic as well as green pepper/onion.  It had a nice caramelized crust (highly addictive).  The dough was thick with a generous layer of sauce.  The veggies needed some extra salt, but overall taste was pretty good.  One medium slice was enough to fill me up, and I have a fairly big appetite.

In summary, the pizza was pretty good (order the pan pizza over anything else), but I wouldn't wait 90 minutes for it....
