Pizza so delicious, you can overlook their awful pick up process.

Seriously, it's that good.
This will be my shortest yelp review ever...BEST DEEP DISH IN CHICAGO - by a long shot.

There are certain milestones when it comes to becoming a "real Chicagoan" and not just a glossy-eyed transplant from Cleveland. For me, changing the alliance of deep dish establishments was one of them. I had heard about Pequod's from people at work, but I stuck to Pizzeria Due and Giordono's as my go-to places. Until I tried the glorious caramelized buttered crust of Pequod's that is...then it was game over! Is the wait horrible most time? Yes. Is it kind of a pricy option? Yeah. But is it worth it? Heck yes!  If you're dining in, the restaurant is small, poorly lit, has horrible parking, and no where to wait...but the bar next door is pretty chill. But Pequod's delivery range is pretty big so it's easy to skip the hassle, stay in sweatpants, and have it dropped off right at your doorstep. This is THE deep dish to get in Chicago, end of the debate.

My first visit to Pequod's was a pleasant one.  Very unique and delicious crust on the deep dish pizza.  The mushrooms were incredibly fresh and the sausage was wonderful.

My only complaint, i had a side salad and their Italian dressing left something to be desired.

Will be going back again!

pics.caption: Deep Dish pizza with sausage and mushrooms

review.des: It's the best deep dish the tourists don't know about it. I take all my visitors there.

I still can't figure out how to pronounce the name of the this place properly!! Even though about a dozen Chicagoans said it during my trip, I swear each one said it just a little different.

I wish Yelp had 1/2 stars, as I think Pequod's deserves 3.5.  I'm rounding down and not up, because the other Chicago-style pizza place I tried during my Chicago foodie crawl (Lou Malnati's) was a solid 4 stars, and I think edged out Pequod's.

After arriving into Chicago from Seattle at around 8pm on a Thursday night in mid-Sept, my foodie crawl weekend was just a subway ride and hotel refresh away!  My friend had already checked into our hotel earlier in the day and in short order, I was ready to get the party started too!  We had carefully crafted our itinerary knowing that we needed to hit up the late night places on Thursday night due to my late arrival.  After some small plates at Avec, our next stop was Pequod's and its late night hours (It was about 12:30am by the time we arrived).  

Due to our jam-packed weekend of eatin', my friend and I shared a personal deep-dish pepperoni pizza only.  With a glass of red wine each.  The pizza took a while to come out (each one is made to order), but we were in no hurry-- after all, we were on vacation!!  It gave me some time to look around the small restaurant, (dive-bar chic was the ambiance) which totally reminded me of my college days.

Once the pizza actually came out, it appeared to have a burnt crust.  We called over the waitress, who explained to us that it was the specialty of the house-- to put a layer of cheese along the outside of the crust, which burnt and caramelizes as it bakes.  Apparently some people would revolt if they stopped this practice!  For my friend and I, it was just a tad TOO burnt, so maybe we got one that didn't pass quality control... but I would say I wasn't a huge fan though the rest of the pizza was delicious.  For this reason L.M. was my favorite pizza place, though I can totally understand a late-night post-bar hankering for Pequod's-- in fact, in my early-to-mid 20s,  I could have seen myself being a fixture here!
If you don't like their deep-dish pizza then deep-dish just isn't your thing. Plan ahead before going, because the place gets packed.

I've come to conclude that I am not a fan of Chicago style deep dish pizzas. So my rating remains neutral with Pequod's only because it was better than Giordano's pizza, but still failed to really impress me. I can't seem to figure out if you are to order, at most, 2 toppings or as many as you want. Because whatever we ordered with all those toppings (photo provided), it was not physically possible to pick up a slice and eat it with 1 hand, let alone 2 hands! I'm a grab-a-slice-and-go type of gal, and I couldn't figure out how to eat this except with a fork and knife. Which is fine. I can be a lady when needed. ;) But, again, it's just too overwhelming for my taste buds. And while others around us were devouring a whole entire pizza, we, sadly, couldn't get past a few bites. Honestly, it just seems like I'm just eating of bunch of baked/roasted pizza toppings and not an actual slice of pizza. There doesn't seem to be a balance between the dough, cheese, and toppings. Sad to say, I guess Chicago style deep dish pizzas and I are not meant to be~~

Let me start of by saying pizza is not one of my favorite foods, but I do consider myself a pizza connoisseur. I back this up by saying that I grew up with a father that loved pizza. Loves pizza so much. We frequently traveled to new pizza places always trying what's new and highly rated. So, with that being said, I have a strong opinion of "good pizza" - I do believe there is bad pizza. Pequod's is the opposite of bad, it's one of the best. The ingredients are super fresh and I would go as far to say the best sausage I have ever had on a pizza. Besides, Burt's Pizza, who was the guy that opened Pequod's and then went to a smaller pizza location in the burbs until recently, when sadly he passed away. The pizza was delicious, yes it is doughy, if that isn't your style, you may not enjoy this. Mike, my boyfriend, wanted to make sure I mentioned how great the crust is, in his words "it's top-notch" (I don't eat crusts). My only complaint is the garlic bread. How can you have such delicious pizza and such below average garlic bread.  Will we be back, absolutely. Pequod's definitely hits the spot and fills your pizza craving.

pics.caption: Large Pan Pizza - Italian sausage, garlic & basil -- order of garlic bread

review.des: I can only speak for myself here, but if I'm given the opportunity to order a final meal on death row, it's gonna be from Pequod's. Their pizza is the gold standard for me (both the abundant pepperoni thin crust AND the caramelized pan pizza), and the salad is also an absolute treat. My favorite now, forever and always.

This place has been hit or miss for me. The quality can really vary every time. The first time i went I wasn't a fan. The last time, it was absolutely delicious. So if you go once and don't like it, give it another try! Also better to go on off-peak hours when they're less busy.

The thin crust pizza was so, so good. I'm still thinking about it and it was two weeks ago when I had it for the first time. I didn't know the background of this spot. We just saw it was close to the movie theater nearby and it had some good reviews. We ordered a thin crust with pepperoni and ground beef. Pizza heaven on a platter I tell ya! Let me just say I came away impressed. Crust is a nice golden thin crust and not fake thin or soggy. Cheese and meat were fresh and quality. From the outside by all appearances it's very much a neighborhood dive bar/dining spot that one may not guess has excellent thin crust pizza. But this spot had waaaay better thin crust than many bigger chains or touristy stops I've been to that tout good pizza. If you're a big pizza fan you definitely have to try this place. I haven't tried the deep dish so I can't speak for deep but the thin crust was all that.

LOVE LOVE LOVE!! One of my favorite pizza places in the city!! I can't believe that other chains get more recognition because Pequod's is definitely one of the best!! Aside from the phenomenal pizza, the hot wings are also delicious!

This location has a sports bar feel and a bit small for groups and all the business they get. We had soup, salad, and their pan pizza. I chose the chicken tortilla soup which had no tortilla whatsoever but had a nice spicy flavor. The salad and house Italian dressing were good. The pizza was really good, not doughy as other pan or deep dish, and the sausage was huge and tasty. I liked the crust but my friend didn't. Even though I didn't finish my portion I was so stuffed that I didn't have room for dessert. The two waitresses helping us we're very nice.

My experience was more like a 3.5 stars. We waited little over an hour on a Saturday night. Parking can be an issue. Their menu is small and simple which is not necessarily a bad thing. However, I was disappointed they didn't have their own specialty pizzas and that you cannot order any food before your seated on weekend evenings. So I would probably try it again on a weekday.

pics.caption: Small sausage, pepperoni, & mushrooms pan pizza.

review.des: You may want to rethink fat shaming in your restaurant. I was visiting a friend in Chicago recently and she brought me to Pequod's. Great pizza! But when I went to the bathroom there was a Bally's Fitness poster that said, "Yeah, maybe it does make your butt look big." Really? And in a Pizzeria? Also, there was nothing of the sort in the Men's restroom. Nice one Bally's! Nice on Pequod's!

I've had Chicago pizza from many places and I feel like a pizza snob (Very high standards for pizza) in a way. I am not originally from Chicago (Kentucky originally) but lived there for many years and moved away. My favorite place was Petes on Western near Grace. My girlfriend, who is originally from New Hampshire, has never been to Chicago or had authentic Chicago pizza. Well, we decided to make a 7 hour trip from Kentucky to Chicago just for pizza. Absolutely no regrets at all.

Service was great, food was fresh and hot, and staff was friendly and welcoming. I didn't expect anything else. Needless to say, we are fans of Pequod's and will be coming back. Next visit will be after we move. Such a great place and cannot express how happy we both will be moving back to Chicago. Thanks for a great night, Pequod's.

Hmmm... where do I start?

Basically if I ask you what your favorite deep dish pizza is and you give me a different answer other than PEQUODS, I'll either assume you've never tried Pequods and/or you're from out of town... or that you have bad taste.

Loads of cheese and sauce and they don't skimp out on toppings. THAT CARMELIZED CRUUUUUST. Their wait times are anywhere from an hour to more. But can you blame them?? It's deep dish pizza made by the Pizza Gods. I always bring my out of town guests to eat Pequods and I've never heard them say anything like "Hmmm, I've had better." or "It's just ok." Their eyes light up as they take that first bite and tell me things like "HOLY F*** THAT'S GOOD!" or "Don't talk to me for the next 30 minutes as I stuff my face with goodness." (Now that I think about it, I really hope they're all being sincere.)

I can't remember if I've ever had bad service there, but I think personally the pizza itself trumps and cancels out anything negative, so 5 stars!
Pequod's has amazing pizza. It might be the best in Chicago. Everyone should try this place at least once.
All i can say is that their pan pizza is great, but keep in mind that the bread will get absolutely soaked and soggy if you take it to go.

My favorite Chicago deep dish. Lou's is a close second, but something about the crust at Pequod's is just utterly delicious. I love the meaty meat toppings, abundance of both delicious cheese and sauce, and did I mention that crust‽ I don't have much else to say as I haven't eaten in the restaurant and I always make the same order, but had to share my love for Pequod's.

Came here on a weekend getaway and we were prepared for the long wait so that didn't bother us! We got the wings as an appetizer while waiting for the pizza and they were DELICIOUS I totally recommend them.

Since there are plenty reviews on here I will tell you ONE THING. Follow the advice of fellow yelpers and keep it simple when ordering... They pack the toppings on so no need to go crazy! My boyfriend didn't believe me when I told him yelp said to keep it to a couple toppings, he got a supreme style, and he wanted my plain pepperoni (but I didn't want to share)!

pics.caption: Half supreme, half pepperoni mushroom spinach. The simpler side was better!
Pepperoni, sausage, Canadian bacon... So delicious!!

review.des:
We are in such a huge hurry because we have to get our guest to the airport to catch a flight but we ate here before and frankly it is the BEST deep dish pizza in Chicago hands down!!!
The carmelized crust is so freaking delicious and somehow the bottom of the pizza stays really crispy too which is rare for a deep dish!
I say you should make every effort to visit this pizza place on your next possible opportunity!

pics.caption: Mushrooms were very light and fresh.  Does Not usually go hand in hand w fried food
Green Olive, pepperocini and pepperoni!  The crust is crazy amazing!

review.des: Chicago's best deep dish. Sausage and pepper medium was delicious. I recommend not getting the large as the caramelized crust on the large is slightly overdone

The pizza was great, very filling, and we were prepared for the wait based on tips here. Busy weekend night but we were given a booth & plenty of time - weren't rushed out the door. The only thing I found confusing is that the wait staff didn't have a set uniform - some were wearing black tshirts with the logo, others were wearing street clothes, and someone who seemed like a manager was wearing khakis. It made it seem like customers were rushing around, which I found confusing and distracting. The room got warm as the crowd grew.

I'm not much of a deep dish pizza guy. Like Jon Stewart once said, I see it as more tomato soup in a bread bowl than an actual slice of pizza, but when in Rome (er, Chicago), why not indulge as the locals do?

Pequod's was suggested by a friend who has awful tattoos, but a pretty solid taste in food and he didn't steer us wrong. A small deep dish was more than enough for two people and it was quite affordable as well (I believe it was somewhere in the neighborhood of $12). The best part were the burnt ends of the crust, and as someone who doesn't always end up eating the crust, this was a nice surprise at the end of the tomato saucy rainbow.

The place itself is a bit of a dive and the perfect setting for a quick bite before a Cubs game. If I lived in town, chances are this would be my go to spot when craving a Chicago style pie (or "a f**king casserole" as Mr. Stewart calls it).
It isn't technically Chicago style pizza, but it is my absolute favorite pizza in Chicago. Try the ground beef pizza, it's not the most traditional topping but on their pan style it really works.

Pequods is my favorite pizza place in Chicago so much so that I always bring out of town guest here first because you can easily get Lou Malnati's or Giordanos but noting compares to the caramelized crust and indulgence that is Pequods.

For people that are uninitiated to Chicago pizza, I always say that you must try a couple of places and compare it to other Pan/Deep Dish places. You will be unsatisfied if you compare Pequods to other pizza you've had because of the difference in the category. Also, be careful reading any reads on Yelp -- always see where they're from! Most people giving low reviews to Pequods are out of towners and have not had Pequods or any deep dish pizza place more than once. If you compare it on it's merit to other Pizza, you'll be disappointed because there is no proper comparison (apples to oranges, both are fruit, but quite different.)  

The one thing that Pequods has over it's closely competitor is the amazing crust. It's caramelized and burnt looking but it's toppings are no joke. Equipped with a fork and knife, it's a difficult proposition to eat more than a couple of slices. Generally, a large can feed a group of five or more!

My only advice is to actually request more sauce. On lazy days, the pizza may come out too dry and a dry pizza is no good. More sauce gives it more of a hearty tomato taste that really balances out the superior Pequods crust.  Otherwise, pick your favorite toppings (Note: pepperoncini is not pepperonis, don't learn the hard way).

Overall, the place is good for groups EXCEPT on any game day which will inflate your wait for both the pizza and a table. I wouldn't necessarily suggest bringing a family here either especially with younger kids or older adults because it has a very bar-y feel to the restaurant. Otherwise, it's a great place for friends (esp. those visiting from out of town to convert to Chicago pizza believers).
